fields.headline: Neil Hamilton loses libel appeal
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Hamilton-Al Fayed libel case
fields.trailText: Former Tory MP Neil Hamilton today lost his appeal against last year's cash for questions libel defeat.
fields.body:
Former Tory MP Neil Hamilton today lost his appeal against last year's cash for questions libel defeat.

The decision comes a year to the day after a vicious five-week high court contest against Harrods boss Mohamed Al Fayed which left the former Tatton MP with an estimated £2m legal bill.

Mr Hamilton, who was in the court of appeal today with his wife, Christine, wanted Lord Phillips, the Master of the Rolls, Lord Justice Sedley and Lady Justice Hale to set aside the verdict and enter judgment for him.

He had argued that the High Court's decision was invalid because Mr Fayed paid £10,000 for documents stolen from his dustbins.

He is now financially ruined, owing £150,000 on top of his previous expenses and facing imminent bankruptcy. He is unlikely to resume public life now the court has refused to restore his reputation.

Outside the court, Mr Hamilton described the verdict as "justice in wonderland." He said he did not understand how the original judgement could stand when he had proved that Mr Fayed was involved in paying £10,000 for stolen documents.

"This is a green light for burglars everywhere to break into lawyers' offices and sell any papers that they find that would help a party unfairly to win a lawsuit," he said.

Standing next to his wife, Mr Hamilton said he was now consulting his lawyers about taking his case to the European Court of Justice. "I have been fighting this case for six and a quarter years and I cannot believe that this is English justice.

"Outside this court it says High Court of Justice but I am thinking of going out to buy the letters "I" and "N" to add to that."

Mr Hamilton brought his libel action over claims made by Mr Fayed in a Dispatches documentary broadcast on Channel 4 in 1997. Mr Fayed said that the former MP had demanded and received thousands of pounds in cash, Harrods gift vouchers and hospitality at the Ritz hotel in Paris, in return for parliamentary services.

fields.headline: AEK warn Spurs over Enic
fields.trailText: Tottenham fans have been warned not to expect a significant investment in the team from their new owners - by the chairman of AEK Athens, the Greek club which Enic have already backed.
fields.body:
Tottenham fans have been warned not to expect a significant investment in the team from their new owners - by the chairman of AEK Athens, the Greek club which Enic have already backed.

AEK's chairman, Cornelius Sierhuis, today revealed his belief that "the investment of Enic in Tottenham does not bode well for their supporters".

"Their investments in football clubs have failed, with the exception of Vicenza thanks to an exceptionally clever manager, and all largely because of an inability or unwillingness to fund in accordance with their stakes," he told onefootball.com.

The warning came after Tottenham chairman Sir Alan Sugar agreed to sell just under 27 per cent of his 40 per cent stake in the club to leisure and media company Enic for £22m.

That has given them a total stake of 29.9 per cent, just below the threshold requiring a bid for all of the club's shares but enough to give the firm a controlling interest.

The deal was confirmed to the Stock Exchange this morning but will not be completed until February.

webTitle: Zeta Jones free to sue Hello!

fields.headline: Zeta Jones free to sue Hello!
fields.standfirst: Nov 23: Hello wins appeal
fields.trailText:
Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas are free to sue Hello! magazine for publishing unauthorised photos of their wedding after a landmark court ruling, reports Claire Cozens
Nov 23: Hello wins appeal
fields.body:
Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas are free to sue Hello! magazine for publishing unauthorised photos of their wedding after a landmark court ruling.

In what is being seen as a test case, the two appeal court judges said today that celebrities as well as members of the public should have rights to privacy.

Hello! magazine published "snatched" photographs of the couple at their New York wedding last month after the couple had signed an exclusive deal with rival publication OK!, said to be worth £1m.

The decision clears the way for OK! publishers Northern & Shell, Ms Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas to win millions of pounds in damages from Hello! magazine.

"This vindicates our decision to make an appeal for an injunction because we strongly believed the rights of Catherine Zeta Jones, Michael Douglas and Northern & Shell had been strongly infringed," said Maninder Gill, head of legal affairs at Northern & Shell and the couple's solicitor.

"We're looking forward to pursuing this matter to trial and are confident of being awarded massive damages," said Mr Gill.

Hello! magazine published photographs of the couple at their New York wedding last month after the couple had signed an exclusive deal with rival publication OK!, owned by Northern & Shell.

Initially the couple won an injunction at the High Court to prevent Hello! printing further copies of the magazine, after 15,750 copies had already been put on sale.

This was then overturned on 23 November by the Court of Appeal, which explained on Thursday that it had not felt an injunction could properly protect the couple's privacy.

Today, the appeal judges gave their reasons for the decision. They said they had decided "with misgivings" that an injunction should not be granted, but that this "should be compensated for by damages". Lord Justice Brooke said that if the couple and OK! magazine were to sue Hello! they would have the support of English law in protecting the right to personal privacy. If they succeeded, he said, "the bill which Hello! will have to pay is likely to be enormous".

"But this is a risk it decided to take, with its eyes open, after we discharged the injunction," added the judge.

He said the couple were likely to succeed with legal action on the grounds of confidentiality.

Lord Justice Sedley said there was "a powerfully arguable case" that they had a right of privacy.

He said the courts had reached a point "which it can be said with confidence that the law recognises and will appropriately protect a right of personal privacy".

"What a concept of privacy does, however, is accord recognition to the fact that the law has to protect not only those people whose trust has been abused, but those who simply find themselves subjected to an unwanted intrusion into their personal lives," he said.

webTitle: Police team taken off race murder inquiry

fields.headline: Police team taken off race murder inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: An entire murder squad has been pulled off an inquiry into the death of a London accountant following a review of the case which criticised the team for failing to treat the incident as a racist attack.
fields.body:
An entire murder squad has been pulled off an inquiry into the death of a London accountant following a review of the case which criticised the team for failing to treat the incident as a racist attack.

Sussex police admitted yesterday the hunt for the killers of Jimmy Abatan, 42, had been taken over by a new squad which had started with a much clearer focus.

The decision was welcomed by Worthing West's MP, Peter Bottomley, and members of the Abatan family who have long believed that Jimmy, who was known as Jay, died at the hands of racists.

The father of two was attacked on January 24, 1999, outside the Ocean Rooms nightclub in Brighton, where he had been celebrating an imminent promotion at PricewaterhouseCoopers with his brother, Michael.

As they left, they had a row with a group of white youths over a taxi. The brothers were kicked and punched.

Jay, of Eastbourne, East Sussex, suffered brain damage. He was pronounced dead after five days on a life support machine.

Two men were arrested within 24 hours of the attack and charged with manslaughter. However, the charges were dropped and they were later cleared of causing Michael Abatan actual bodily harm.

Sussex asked Essex police to conduct a review of the inquiry last July and a first draft of a report by Superintendent Steve Reynolds was handed to senior officers at the beginning of the month. Sussex refused to disclose the details, but it is understood Mr Reynolds made sweeping criticisms.

Although the original murder squad did not rule out the possibility of a racial attack, it was not pursued as a priority. "There were issues that needed to be addressed and so we took immediate action," said a force spokesman.

Detective Superintendent Ken Probert, who is in charge of the new inquiry, added: "We are treating Jay's murder as a racist killing and 36 detectives are working on this case, taking a fresh look at the original investigation and developing new lines of inquiry."

Sussex has asked the police complaints authority to review the first investigation to see whether there are any grounds for disciplining officers. It will be conducted by the deputy chief constable of Avon and Somerset, Ken Jones, under the supervision of the PCA.

Michael Abatan has asked Sussex to publish the findings of the review and wants Scotland Yard's racial and violent crimes task force to become involved.

He said: "It's positive that there is a new team investigating my brother's death, but two years is a long time. I hope this is not a PR exercise. I want to work with the police."

fields.headline: Tory apologises for racist joke
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The race row engulfing the Tories intensified last night after a shadow cabinet minister was forced to apologise for telling a joke that was both racist and sexist.
fields.body:
The race row engulfing the Tories intensified last night after a shadow cabinet minister was forced to apologise for telling a joke that was both racist and sexist.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary and an increasingly prominent frontbencher, was told to apologise by William Hague's office after the joke, told at a Christmas party, found its way into the Guardian's Diary column.

Conservative central office stressed that Mr Hague had not demanded the apology, but the fact it was pushed for hints at the Tories' sensitivity over allegations that they are willing to play the race card.

At the party, held on Monday night by his colleague, the shadow foreign secretary Francis Maude, Dr Fox asked fellow guests: "What do you call three dogs and a blackbird?" Receiving no response, he supplied the answer: "The Spice Girls."

Yesterday he issued a statement apologising for the joke, which he repeated at the party and uttered in the presence of journalists.

"In repeating a widely circulated joke, I very much regret if anyone was offended," the statement read. "I naturally apologise if any offence was caused."

Last night, Dr Fox was unavailable for comment, and an aide said he did not know if the apology amounted to an admission that the joke was sexist and racist.

The apology came just days after Dr Fox's leader, Mr Hague, sparked the current race storm when he claimed that Sir William Macpherson's description of the Metropolitan police as "institutionally racist" had led to a decline in morale among officers.

While the Tory leader rejected claims that he was playing the race card as "truly disgusting and disgraceful", his comments drew fierce criticism. Bill Morris, the transport union leader, likened Mr Hague's stance to Enoch Powell's "rivers of blood" speech in 1968, and dismay was expressed by Steven Norris, the Conservative party vice-chairman who has been outspoken in support of racial and sexual inclusivity.

Gurbux Singh, chair of the commission for racial equality, has warned Mr Hague against "throwing away" the good race relations built up in Britain, while the bishop of Southwark, Tom Butler, has turned on him for making political capital out of the Macpherson report.

webTitle: MPs to scrutinise student drop outs

fields.headline: MPs to scrutinise student drop outs
fields.trailText: MPs are to investigate the factors influencing student drop out rates in universities.
fields.body:
MPs are to investigate the factors influencing student drop out rates in universities.

The House of Commons education committee is considering three specific areas which influence drop out rates as part of its inquiry.

They will consider student experiences - for example, financial considerations, the amount of paid work undertaken by during term­time, and the nature of the curriculum and qualification structures.

They will also look at how the quality of teaching impacts on student retention. Questions will focus on the appropriate level of academic support for students, the quality of teaching, how the relationship between teaching and research affects student retention, and the factors which affect the recruitment of highly qualified teachers in higher education.

Finally the MPs will consider how higher education funding affects drop our rates.

Official figures released this year exposed a wide variation in the drop out rates for different universities - even for similar institutions.

The committee is organising public hearings as part of the inquiry in January.

For more information, contact Robert Rees, email: ReesR@parliament.uk

fields.headline: Cockneys, Tykes, and Brummies
fields.trailText: WHAT A TITI
fields.body:
WHAT A TITI

Pip pip! Allow me to introduce myself, old chap! I'm motion picture director Lord Guy Ritchie. Now, pull up a chaise longue and listen as I spin a little yarn. Tomorrow, I'm getting married to the "missus", as I like to call her, but - what a merry puddle - there's not much to keep one occupied between then and now. So I thought I'd fill the time by finding out the latest news from the streets of my native East End of London Town gord blimey guv'nor how is your father and no mistake. And, my goodness, local association football team West Ham have only gone and purchased Titi Camara from Liverpool... erm... innit?

Cor, lummee, love a duck, he is a spiffing player I can tell you. The news that Harold Redknapp has signed the 28-year-old forward for £1.5m on a three-and-a-half-year deal will really please salt-of-the-earth London families like myself, director father John, fashion model mother Amber and her new husband Sir Michael. "I've come to West Ham to play, play, play and score, score, score!" said Camara this afternoon. That turn of phrase... so delicious... I would be humbled if he cited my work as an influ... erm... I mean, kosher line, me old china, nice one!

And, do you know, I quite like this new chappie's attitude. Hark, he's having a right old go at his former manager Gerard Houllier: "If Houllier says today I am a mercenary or a traitor, that is wrong. It can't be said that I've never loved Liverpool because there were moments when I wasn't getting picked and I stayed. Yes, I had a dispute with the manager, but I wasn't the first, he had it with Rigo [Song] as well. I don't think [Houllier] ever respected me so I thought what is the point working with him?" This Houllier fellow sounds like he's totally overstepped the mark. Go on Titi, dust his jowls with your gloves, challenge him to name his weapon and stick ver actual boot in!

KEANE ON LEEDS

Last night, just as the Fiver was being deleted without being read from in-trays around the world, news broke that Leeds had signed Irish wonder kid Robbie Keane on loan from Internazionale until the end of the season, when a permanent £12m deal will be completed. Today, the former Wolves and Coventry striker explained why he chose the Yorkshire giants ahead of other suitors Liverpool, Chelsea, Newcastle, Sunderland, Aston Villa and West Ham. Luckily for us, this happened at a time more acceptable to the Fiver. So here you are.

"I have a lot of friends at Elland Road and I have heard from them what a fantastic spirit David O'Leary has created and I am convinced that they will be a major force in the game for the forseeable future," said Robbie, frantically stuffing his tail between his legs. "I want to have the best possible football career and I know that moving to Leeds will help me achieve this." My, my, doesn't he sound chuffed to be back?

But whether Charlton, who have first option on players Inter send out on loan, will be as happy about this is another matter. "We spoke to Robbie, as we are entitled to do under our agreement with Inter," chief executive Peter Varney (presumably no relation to Reg of On The Buses fame) told the London Evening Standard. "We have tried really hard to bring him to Charlton but he was adamant about where he wanted to go. Inter have a signed agreement with Leeds for his permanent transfer at a fixed fee, without which the loan deal would not have been accepted by them." Well, that sounds completely fair to us. There's been no cheeky circumvention of the rules there.

THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR

Dec 21: Click here

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We're still the best team in Scotland because we have the best players and we play the best football" - Fernando Ricksen refuses to let the small matter of a 12-point gap between Rangers and Celtic dampen his enthusiasm.

DANGLING A CARROTT

"Doug Ellis, you little tease!" exclaimed an excited Fiver while in bed this morning. And you would have done as well, if your umpteenth attempt to read The Chairman's Xmas Message on Aston Villa's website had ended - appropriately enough - in a "field error". But fortunately we were soon able to reflect on a happier image - namely Harry Harris and his Daily Mirror colleagues (telling us that Juan Pablo Angel's £10m transfer from River Plate to Villa was "imminent").

Unfortunately, the player himself seems much less certain than Happy Harry. Because during our daily flick through the South American papers (Suramérica, amamos a sus atractivas señoras!) we found Angel with his mind on other things. "In the early days of January, my first son is born, Geronimo, and that can complicate things a little," Villa's potential saviour admitted. "If I leave, it is because a team to me has aspirations to fight for important things." Not the Intertoto Cup, then?

But even though Angel's planned trip to England - to look for a new house and have a medical - has now been temporarily postponed, Villa fans shouldn't give up hope just yet. Angel also told Argentine daily newspaper Ole that he's done his homework on Birmingham and reckons he could "handle the language well enough". But an ability to do a passable impersonation of Jasper Carrott isn't enough in itself. "I am at River and I would find it very difficult to find a club superior to this in the world," Angel stated. "For that reason, I need this at the very minimum, that they make me and my family feel comfortable." Surely Deadly Doug will see to that, won't he?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Bradford have made an enquiry about Aberdeen's out-of-favour midfielder Eoin Jess.

Chelsea and Manchester United have joined West Ham in the race to sign Boca Juniors striker Martin Palermo, reports Teamtalk. Palermo's agent has confirmed that at least two English clubs are vying for the Argentine international's signature - but Teamtalk reckon that United are favourites, as Palermo "was rumoured to be in Manchester yesterday for talks".

Former Crystal Palace reject Valerien Ismael could be set for a return to the Premiership with Derby, according to reports.

Yugoslav international Predrag Mijatovic has no plans to move to Aston Villa despite recent rumours linking him with the club, his agent Zoran Vekic told Planet Football.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Rangers will hold a memorial service at Ibrox on January 2 to commemorate those who lost their lives in the disasters of 1902 and 1971.

Bradford goalkeeper Matt Clarke has handed in a transfer request after becoming "disillusioned" at the club's failure to offer him a new contract despite three months of wrangling. "I'm disappointed with the way I've been treated," said an angry Clarke. "I just hope Bradford will be fair by letting me go for a reasonable fee. It will serve both the club and myself."

The SFA have ordered the Scottish Cup first-round tie between Montrose and Arbroath to be replayed after Arbroath included two suspended players in their team.

Nottingham Forest have agreed a deal with American MSL chiefs to keep US international midfielder Ben Olsen on loan at the City Ground for the remainder of the season.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.50am)

"I saw Harry Gration, the bloke who does BBC Look North with Claire Frisby, in the Flying Pizza in Roundhay, Leeds on Tuesday lunchtime," writes Matthew Kay.

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.30am)

"He also does some football reports for Grandstand and Radio 5 sometimes. I think he has connections with rugby as well."

Dutch Football (1am)

"Anyway, he was there to meet his wife and their two sons. The boys had WWF wrestling figures but were otherwise quite well behaved."

Argentine Football (2.30am)

"Harry looked quite haggered and his face is much pastier in flesh."

International Football (4am)

"My colleague actually disagrees with this point. She thinks he looked a lot healthier. Don't take her word for it though."

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm, 12.30am)

"Would you like to know more?"

Spanish Football (8pm, 1am)

Yes, Matthew, we would.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 3.30am)

What would you get McCaff for Christmas, Jason Hayford? "ONdigital." You really hate him that much?

Australian Soccer League (11pm)

Rolf Harris passes to Barry Humphries, who splits the defence wide open with a pass to Mrs Mangel who... scores!

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 12midnight SS1)

Barry Hearn's Leyton Orient feature - so at least ten snooker references are guaranteed!

Masters Football (10pm)

At least ten Kevin Webster moustaches guaranteed!

Sky Sports 3: Classic World Cup Football (10pm)

Africans accused of being defensively naïve or your money back!

British Eurosport: Classic Big Cup Football (9am)

That reminds us. Victor Kiam. Now there's a businessman. Eat your heart out, Silvio Berlusconi.

German Football (10.15pm)

He liked the Remington so much, he bought the company.

fields.headline: Hamilton reeling from 'bizarre' libel defeat
fields.standfirst: Hamilton loses appeal
fields.trailText:
4.30pm update: Neil Hamilton said he was "utterly perplexed" after losing his appeal against last year's 'cash for questions' libel action.
Hamilton loses appeal
fields.body:
A shocked Neil Hamilton said he was "utterly perplexed" by the high court's decision to turn down his appeal against last year's 'cash for questions' libel action.

A bitter Mr Hamilton said outside the court: "This is the most bizarre and unexpected of results.

"I came to this court to prove that Fayed was a willing participant in the purchase of documents stolen from my lawyers."

In the appeal, Mr Hamilton accused Mr Al Fayed of "gross impropriety" at the time of the trial, alleging that - unknown to his legal team - he was involved in paying £10,000 for stolen legal documents taken from dustbins outside the chambers of Mr Hamilton's lawyers.

He said he had proved that involvement and the part played by a "henchman" in the break-ins. "I had assumed that if one had proved a case one would have won," he added.

Mr Hamilton said he had been put in an "impossible situation" because he could never cross-examine a jury about their reasons for reaching their decision because it was forbidden in law.

Mr Hamilton, standing next to his wife Christine, said he was now consulting his lawyers about taking his case to the European Court of Justice.

"I have been fighting this case for six and a quarter years and I cannot believe that this is English justice," he said.

His formidable wife, Christine, was virtually speechless, on the steps of the high court.

Looking sombre and anxious, she said: "I feel as though I have been punched in the stomach and robbed. I am pretty speechless as you can see.

"I feel physically sick."

fields.headline: Thunderbirds have gone
fields.standfirst: It has caused fights in Harrods and rationing in Hamleys. It is this season's must-have toy - a model of Tracy Island, home of the suddenly fashionable Thunderbirds. And  Neil Robinson found one. Here he explains how
fields.trailText: It has caused fights in Harrods and rationing in Hamleys. It is this season's must-have toy - a model of Tracy Island, home of the suddenly fashionable Thunderbirds. And Neil Robinson found one. He explains how.
fields.body:
This time next year, or even next month, you will probably see them piled high at knockdown prices. Big blue boxes with strange writing that children will pass without a hint of curiosity or desire. But right now, a few days before Christmas, these same boxes are of indescribable value. They contain what every small boy wants: Tracy Island.

It is a plastic re-creation of the Tracy family's island home in the long-running children's TV puppet show, Thunderbirds. And it is this year's must-have toy. What is more, last weekend I achieved the seemingly impossible. Using extraordinary levels of cunning and dedication I tracked a Tracy Island down and bought it for my son. Brains would have been proud of me. I now consider myself a good parent.

It is not the children who have created the shortage that has led to emergency airfreight supplies and round-the-clock assembly lines. It is fathers like me who are the real problem, because after months of Buzz Lightyear and all the nonsense about "to infinity and beyond", boys are finally talking our language. That's why we have to buy Tracy Island: Thunderbirds are back and it's FAB.

Hence the mayhem that has gripped toy stores up and down the country. Two weeks ago, a fight broke out in Harrods, of all places, after two shoppers each made a grab for the last remaining Tracy Island. Hamleys has been reduced to handing out tickets - 50 a day - to parents queuing outside the store. All because we obsessives will not be denied. And, believe me, m'lady, you can still get one for Christmas. Nothing is impossible in Thunderbirds - and the manufacturers are delivering 20,000 TIs to shops this week.

My own mission began in Bentalls in Kingston on Friday morning. At this early stage I hadn't quite clocked on how desperate you have to be to get hold of one. I knew there weren't supposed to be many around, but that was all probably manufacturer's hype, right? Wrong.

Rule one is to plan your operation like an International Rescue mission: there is no margin for error. I arrived at the shop two hours after a consignment of 60 TIs had arrived. And they had all disappeared from the shelves within minutes of delivery. The girl behind the counter said they did not expect any more before Christmas. But do not be put off if this happens to you: experienced Tracy Island hunters know this is a ruse to prevent mission accomplishment.

It was the same story at John Lewis: "You must be joking sir." And Toys'R'Us: "We're not saying when we expect any more in". After two hours, I spotted a Thunderbirds satchel, and wondered briefly whether that might do. It would not. I couldn't have my boy arrive at school with a naff satchel, to be confronted with a load of Tracy Islands, bought by parents who really cared.

By Saturday morning I had discovered rule two: find out delivery times. I was up much earlier. None of this arriving at 11am nonsense. I was through the door at Selfridges at 9.30am, straight up the escalator to the toy department, and on to the counter. There were already people circling round. There was a rumour, no more than that, of a delivery at 11am, although the manageress was not sure if they would be put out "for security reasons". And so a group of us waited, surreptitiously eyeing each other with looks of quiet desperation.

Eleven came and went before the formal announcement that no Tracy Islands would go on sale before 5pm. The girl on the cuddly-toy counter beckoned me over and whispered that the smart thing to do was to return at 4.30pm because they might put them out early to fool everybody. I thanked her over-enthusiastically and failed to pass on the information (rule three: never help the opposition).

The street-smart among us knew that no matter what the manageress said, the big bosses might pull a fast one. That's why we didn't fall for the line about Tracy Islands going on sale at the main counter. We knew the rush would be too great. No, we kept our eyes open (rule four), and sure enough, at 4.47pm - 13 minutes early - I saw a discreet queue forming 50 yards from the toy department. There were 42 on sale, and they were snapped up before anyone else worked out what we were about.

The only delay was caused by the elderly lady in front of me who almost broke down in tears when told that purchases were restricted to one per person. She wanted two, one for each grandson, and admitted defeat only when they threatened to evict her. They said she could rejoin the queue after buying her first, but by then it was hopeless - the word was out. I wouldn't like to be in her house on Christmas Day.

All of which brings us to rule five: it's probably worth it. I know this because, for reasons that are too complicated to go into, my son has already opened his present this year and spent the entire weekend playing with it. Or rather we both did. It doesn't matter that the Thunderbird 2 I had 30-odd years ago was metal, and his is plastic. Or that his speaks, and mine didn't. Big blue boxes with strange writing that children will pass without a hint of curiosity or desire. But right now, a few days before Christmas, these same boxes are of indescribable value. They contain what every small boy wants: Tracy Island. It is a plastic re-creation of the Tracy family's island home in the long-running children's TV puppet show, Thunderbirds. And it is this year's must-have toy. What is more, last weekend I achieved the seemingly impossible. Using extraordinary levels of cunning and dedication I tracked a Tracy Island down and bought it for my son. Brains would have been proud of me. I now consider myself a good parent. It is not the children who have created the shortage that has led to emergency airfreight supplies and round-the-clock assembly lines. It is fathers like me who are the real problem, because after months of Buzz Lightyear and all the nonsense about "to infinity and beyond", boys are finally talking our language. Two weeks ago, a fight broke out in Harrods, of all places, after two shoppers each made a grab for the last remaining Tracy Island. Hamleys has been reduced to handing out tickets - 50 a day - to parents queuing outside the store. All because we obsessives will not be denied. My own mission began in Bentalls in Kingston on Friday morning. At this early stage I hadn't quite clocked on how desperate you have to be to get hold of one. I knew there weren't supposed to be many around, but that was all probably manufacturer's hype, right? Wrong. Rule one is to plan your operation like an International Rescue mission: there is no margin for error. I arrived at the shop two hours after a consignment of 60 TIs had arrived. And they had all disappeared from the shelves within minutes of delivery. The girl behind the counter said they did not expect any more before Christmas. webTitle: Consumer: How much can you pay for...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ...a party popper
fields.trailText: ...a party popper.
fields.body:
As every PR, ligger and C-list celebrity is well aware, parties are big business. Organisers constantly vie with one another for the smartest venue, the most exotic canapes, the most coveted goody bag and the most high-profile guests.

Entertainment-wise, etiquette demands a few fireworks at the very least and preferably a light-show rivalling the Tate Modern experience. A few party poppers just won't cut it - unless, of course, they happen to be the solid silver variety purveyed by Asprey & Garrard at £50 a pop.

To be fair, they are exceptionally pretty, with the Asprey's trademark logo rendering them more like the cartridges you'd put in your gun if you were that way inclined. "Bah, humbug!" I hear you cry. Well, if such an item needs a raison d'etre, it's this: the silver (solid) casing is recyclable.

After the contents have been sprayed over the Daniel Galvin-coifed locks of the girl in your line of fire, you can substitute a 24-for-99p affair from Honest John down your local market. Who says you can't make a silk purse out of a sow's ear?

 Available from Asprey & Garrard, 165 New Bond Street, London W1.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst:
Designer labels

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Designer labels
fields.body:
It's official, logos are back. Never before have we been so obsessed with designer labels. Even Ab Fab is jumping onto the zeitgeist bandwagon with its long-awaited comeback to our screens scheduled for the new year.

All Patsy wannabes will love Yoox. With everything at 50% of RRP, where even a rhinestone Fendi baguette (£350.79) teeters into the region of affordability - well, sort of - the name's enormous pretension is eminently forgivable.

Label junkies whose budgets fall short of Colombia's GDP should try Luxlook. Specialising in the accessory ranges of luxury brands - Bvlgari, Dolce & Gabbana, Moschino and Vivienne Westwood to name but a few - the site has collaborated with said brands so that each "boutique" is a virtual flagship store experience. It certainly beats a trog down Bond Street.

Some designers have even created signature items exclusive to Lux customers - which, let's face it, is as close to haute couture as most of us are gonna get.

The online equivalent of an out-of-town designer village is Designerdealsdirect. The site is boring, basic and bargain bucket basement but having said that, they do a great line in designer sunnies (CKs retailing at around £80 are only £39.99). They're also good on Ralphie shirts and I spotted a Polo rugby effort for £24.99 (down from £90) - ideal if you're on your last warning for pinching the boyfriend's. It's "me, me, me, sweetie" all the way.

fields.headline: Hamilton loses court appeal
fields.trailText: 4pm: Former Tory MP Neil Hamilton today lost his appeal against last year's crushing cash for questions libel defeat.
fields.body:
Former Tory MP Neil Hamilton today lost his appeal against last year's crushing cash for questions libel defeat.

The decision comes a year to the day after a vicious five-week high court contest against Harrods boss Mohamed Al Fayed, which left the former Tatton MP with an estimated £2m costs bill.

Mr Hamilton, who was in the Court of Appeal today with his wife, Christine, wanted Lord Phillips, the Master of the Rolls, Lord Justice Sedley and Lady Justice Hale to set aside the verdict and enter judgment for him.

He was also seeking a change in the crippling costs order which means he is facing imminent bankruptcy.

The Hamiltons showed no emotion at the announcement of the judgment which in effect was a refusal of permission to bring an appeal against the jury's unanimous verdict.

Mr Hamilton had sued over claims made by Mr Al Fayed in a January 1997 Channel 4 Dispatches programme that he had corruptly demanded and accepted cash payments, gift vouchers and a free holiday at the Paris Ritz in return for asking parliamentary questions on behalf of Harrods.

Today, Lord Phillips, the Master of the Rolls, Lord Justice Sedley and Lady Justice Hale made no order for costs arising out of the appeal but lifted "stays" on costs orders relating to the trial which means that Mr Hamilton must now contemplate meeting an estimated £2m costs bill and the loss of his home at Nether Alderley, Cheshire.

In the appeal, Mr Hamilton accused Mr Al Fayed of "gross impropriety" at the time of the trial, alleging that - unknown to his legal team - he was involved in paying £10,000 for stolen legal documents taken from dustbins outside the chambers of Mr Hamilton's lawyers.

Lord Phillips said today that the court had concluded "that the appeal which Mr Hamilton has sought permission to bring against the verdict in this case would have no reasonable prospect of success and that his application in that regard should be dismissed".

He ruled that Mr Al Fayed's conduct in relation to the documents was "discreditable".

But, he added: "It did not, in fact, impact upon the way in that he, let alone his legal representatives, conducted his defence."

webTitle: Canal Plus board members ejected as takeover looms

fields.headline: Canal Plus board members ejected as takeover looms
fields.standfirst: Dec 20: Canal Plus set for shake-out
fields.trailText:
4pm: Canal Plus has ousted four board members as it prepares to be swallowed up by media giant Vivendi Universal, writes Dan Milmo.
Dec 20: Canal Plus set for shake-out
fields.body:
Canal Plus has ousted four board members as it prepares to be swallowed up by media giant Vivendi Universal.

Pierre Lescure, boss of the French pay-TV channel, has removed four of his closest colleagues, including StudioCanal chairman Vincent Grimond.

Earlier today, Mr Lescure denied that the reorganisation was forced by parent company Vivendi, which this month became one of the biggest media companies in world after completing its £50bn merger with Seagram of Canada.

The company has been dogged by rumours a fallout between Mr Lescure with Vivendi Universal chairman Jean-Marie Messier, who appears to have got his way with demands of a reshuffle.

Analysts see the management revamp as a step in the right direction, but remain sceptical about a company that does not consistently hit its financial targets.

"It's a step in the right direction. Canal needed to bring new blood in and get rid of some previous managers. But they will also have to clarify what their European strategy is and how they are going to produce profitability," said Marc Loneux at Commerzbank.

The Vivendi Universal merger, which incorporated US film giant Universal Studios and Universal Music into the Vivendi group, has been attacked by the financial community, who doubt its future as a moneyspinner. Vivendi Universal's shares have fallen 4%.

webTitle: Time to act on old age home closures

fields.headline: Time to act on old age home closures
fields.standfirst: The government should enact legislation to protect the residents of old age homes that are being closed down, writes Les Bright
fields.trailText: The government should enact legislation to protect the residents of old age homes that are being closed down, writes Les Bright.
fields.body:
Moving into a care home is a big step - it is one that is not taken lightly and can generally be seen as a sign of failing health and a high level of family concern for an older person's welfare. So what must it feel like when, caught in the crossfire of a social care market in which prices are being driven down along with the determination to improve standards, the owners decide that enough is enough and are forced to close the home?

This has become an increasingly frequent occurrence, with nearly 800 closures of independent sector residential care and nursing homes in the past year.

At the same time, local authorities in a number of areas have been closing down their own homes, citing concern that they will not be able to comply with the new national required standards which will take effect from April 2002.

It is interesting that the physical space standards which are presented as causing them the greatest concern will not be fully implemented for some years after that, so why are local authorities pulling out, and what will the impact be on the care of older people?

Over the past decade, local authorities have found it increasingly beneficial to purchase places in the independent sector rather than to go on providing care themselves. Initially, this could be attributed to the fact that there were financial incentives in making placements with other providers, and the transitional financial arrangements for community care were weighted heavily against use of their own homes. Another important factor was - and still is - that their own costs tend to be higher than private providers, largely due to the better terms and conditions they offer care staff. Exercising their power, as the largest single purchaser of residential care, they have now driven prices to such a high level that their own homes are unable to compete, and best value requirements make this even more obvious.

Reducing capacity, either in a planned way, through local authorities closure programmes, or in a more erratic way, through financial failures of private providers, brings heartache to many. Staff lose their jobs, owners may lose their livelihoods and the substantial investment they have made, but above all older people - who may have already felt a strong sense of loss after conceding that they are no longer capable of looking after themselves independently - lose their home.

It is difficult to imagine the level of anxiety that must be felt by those who begin to see telltale signs of trouble brewing - longstanding staff leave; there are recruitment difficulties; newspapers and others who monitor council committees show interest and public consultations are launched. The signs are probably very different in a smaller enterprise, where the owners may be feeling the pinch without any public knowledge or discussion and all that shows are frayed tempers as yet another bill arrives, with too little income to meet it.

It is time to act and that the government should devise some "closure protocols" that should be enforced as vigorously as other standards with which legislation demands providers should comply. If a home is earmarked for closure, present residents and patients must be protected, and their views sought to ensure that the level of anxiety and distress they experience is minimised. Many residents have no close family and will need the support of active citizens to act as their advocates to make sure that their needs are not lost in pursuit of balanced budgets. And what of those living in homes that are subject to market forces? How can they be protected? At the risk of sounding as though I want to prop up failing businesses, my first suggestion would be to review the rate being paid by the largest purchaser - the local authority - and, if necessary, to make an immediate increase.

Homes that close are no longer available for future placements and so the health service may find even more older people "trapped in hospital beds", the concern that led to the establishment of the charity that I work for.

 Les Bright is deputy chief executive of Counsel and Care, a charity that offers advice and help to older people.

webTitle: Freed Britons describe Colombia kidnap terror

fields.headline: Freed Britons describe Colombia kidnap terror
fields.trailText: Two Britons held captive in Colombia for nine months today told of their terror as they were captured at gunpoint by guerrillas.
fields.body:
Two Britons held captive in Colombia for nine months today told of their terror as they were captured at gunpoint by guerrillas.

Paul Winder, from Chelmsford, Essex, and Tom Hart Dyke, from Eynsford, Kent, said they had been taken hostage after stumbling across the rebels while hunting for rare species of orchid.

The two men flew into Gatwick at around 2pm today for an emotional reunion with their families.

Mr Hart Dyke's father Guy said: "This is the best Christmas present we could have hoped for."

Mr Hart Dyke had not seen his family since he set off on a round-the-world trip in November 1997. Wearing flip-flops and jeans, he said: "It is fantastic, unbelievable to be back on British soil."

Looking tired but pleased to be home Mr Hart Dyke, 24, said he had been frightened during the ordeal but that there had been moments of camaraderie with the guerrillas.

The two men emerged from the rainforest on Tuesday after trekking through wilderness for eight days following their unexpected release on December 10.

Describing their capture, Mr Hart Dyke said: "They had us on the floor with our hands tied up.

"Initially they used their guns to get us on to the ground, they tied us up for half an hour and said 'are you going to run?'

"After that it never happened again."

He said they had been well looked after by their captors, who had fed them well and even built a bed with cushions for them to lie on.

Mr Hart Dyke said he had put on weight during the ordeal after being fed large amounts of beef and bananas.

At one point the rebels had told them that they wanted a ransom.

"They did mention that we had to pay a ransom and they said $5m [£3.3m] for each person," Mr Winder, 29, said.

"There were low times, high times, terrifying times and fantastic times.

"It was a huge rollercoaster of emotion," he added.

Mr Winder said that the guerillas had kept them moving throughout the area during their nine months of captivity, making them move on when there was any danger of them being discovered.

On one occasion they walked for a month on end. However, he said, "we always had confidence that we would get back to England and see our families."

webTitle: Online travel agent threatens price war

fields.headline: Online travel agent threatens price war
fields.trailText: 3.45pm:The First Resort has pledged to undercut by £20 any agent offering the same summer holiday, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Online travel agency The First Resort is set to spark a holiday price war in the new year by pledging to undercut by £20 any travel agent offering the same summer holidays.

The agency, which has 10m holidays on its database, is trying to boost sales at a time when there is growing scepticism about the online booking market.

The First Resort, in which tour operator Thomson owns a 30% share and Channel 5 a minority stake, is deliberately launching the deal in January - the peak holiday booking period.

Matthew Prior, The First Resort managing director, said: "We are looking to shake up the travel market with the first ever price-beating promotion on summer holidays."

The brand will run heavy TV advertising and programme sponsorship during Channel 5's Christmas Day and Boxing Day schedules.

It is believed to be the first time any company has guaranteed to discount every holiday on the market.

The company's gamble comes just days after British Airways pulled the plug on Project Quicksilver, its internet portal aimed at Executive Club members.

Meanwhile the share price of high-profile leisure brand Lastminute.com continues to fall.

Forrester Research said it was downgrading growth in the online travel sector.

Analyst Shobhit Kakkar said earlier forecasts of £4bn of online bookings by 2005 were "over optimistic".

He expected only £600m of holidays to have been booked online by the end of 2000.

fields.headline: Zeta-Jones to sue Hello!
fields.trailText: Hollywood stars Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas are to sue Hello! magazine for publishing "surreptitious" photographs of their wedding.
fields.body:
Hollywood stars Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas are to sue Hello! magazine for millions of pounds for publishing "surreptitious" photographs of their wedding in New York.

The move follows a landmark ruling by the Court of Appeal today which for the first time recognised that celebrities have rights to privacy.

The couple had signed a £1m deal with OK! magazine for exclusive pictures of their wedding last month - but rival Hello! hit the streets three days earlier than OK! with their own "exclusive" photographs of the stars.

OK! and the newlyweds were too late to stop 15,750 copies already on sale, but immediately won an injunction in the High Court banning the rest of the 755,900 print run.

This was overturned on November 23 by the Court of Appeal which today gave its reasons for lifting the injunction - but held that the couple were likely to prove at trial that publication of the photographs should not have been allowed.

Lord Justice Brooke said that if the couple and OK! sue and succeed, "the bill which Hello! will have to pay is likely to be enormous, but this is a risk it decided to take, with its eyes open, after we discharged the injunction".

The claim against Hello! will take the form of damages for invasion of privacy, or will be coupled with the profits made from the particular issue of the magazine.

fields.headline: Guardian rehires 'Skinhead' agency
fields.trailText: 2.45pm:The Guardian has hired BMP DDB, the agency behind its award-winning 'Skinhead' ad, to handle its advertising account., reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Guardian has hired BMP DDB, the agency behind the newspaper's award-winning "Skinhead" commercial, to handle its advertising account.

BMP was the Guardian's advertising agency in the mid-80s, when it created one of the most famous British adverts of all time for the newspaper.

The 1986 commercial featured a skinhead who appeared to be wrestling a man's briefcase from his hands. But the camera then cuts and viewers see that he is in fact trying to rescue the man from falling bricks.

"We had some inspirational pitches over the last few weeks but BMP's work really stood out," said Marc Sands, Guardian Newspapers marketing director.

"Their intuitive understanding of our brands and the demands placed upon them was impressive. We look forward to some fantastic work springing from a genuine partnership."

BMP will create advertising for the Guardian Unlimited websites as well as for the Guardian newspaper.

The Guardian has historically spent about £3m a year on advertising but is expected to increase its marketing spend significantly next year.

The agency pitched against M&C Saatchi, Fallon, HHCL & Partners and Publicis. The incumbent, Partners BDDH, declined to repitch.

webTitle: Bill looks to improve conduct of GPs

fields.headline: Bill looks to improve conduct of GPs
fields.trailText: Measures to tighten up the conduct of GPs, including forcing doctors to publically declare gifts they receive from patients, were announced in the health and social care bill published today. By Patrick Butler
fields.body:
Measures to tighten up the conduct of GPs, including forcing doctors to publically declare gifts they receive from patients, were announced in the health and social care bill published today.

The bill, which will allow the government to press ahead with reforms outlined in its NHS plan, also contains proposals to give patients more of a say in health services, and gives local authorities powers to scrutinise local health decisions.

Health authorities will have more powers to deal with "poorly performing" doctors. They will be required to hold a list of approved GPs in their area and will have the right to remove or suspend those who fail to come up to scratch.

The bill will change the current arrangements, under which removal and suspension of GPs is carried out centrally by an NHS tribunal. Ministers hope that devolving this power will speed up action against poorly performing doctors.

GPs will also have to declare on a public register gifts they receive from patients over the value of £25. The proposal - which is likely to be fiercely resisted by GPs - will bring them into line with guidance for all other NHS staff.

The gift register is a legacy of the case of Harold Shipman. The former Manchester GP, who was convicted in January 2000 of murdering 15 of his patients, received several gifts from patients as well as several legacies, one of which he forged.

Health minister John Denham said: "Sweeping reforms to frontline primary care services will ensure that patients receive first-class care, day and night, and put in place new safeguards to deal with poorly performing doctors."

Many parts of the bill, including plans to set up care trusts to allow health and social services to work together under one organisation, and the abolition of community health councils, were trailed in the NHS plan and the Queen's speech earlier this month.

The bill includes:

· A statutory duty on all NHS organisations to consult with patients and the public, and to introduce "powerful" new independent statutory patient forums for every NHS trust, as well as patient representation on trust boards.

· Scrutiny of the local NHS by local councillors - although this power will be extended to metropolitan boroughs and county councils only.

· Extension of powers to the secretary of state for health to enable him to intervene in poorly performing trusts and health authorities, and to make extra cash payments to those that perform well.

· Powers that will allow the health secretary to introduce standard national contracts for chief executives of primary care groups and trusts, which are currently negotiated locally.

The bill was welcomed by Stephen Thornton, NHS Confederation chief executive. He said: "This bill is important because it contains long-overdue measures necessary to modernise primary care and integrate it more fully within the NHS."

webTitle: Patients forum plan to head off revolt

fields.headline: Patients forum plan to head off revolt
fields.trailText: The government will today try to head off a Labour backbench revolt against a key plank of its NHS reforms by publishing legislation giving patients a stronger say in the way hospitals and GP services are run. By John Carvel
fields.body:
The government will today try to head off a Labour backbench revolt against a key plank of its NHS reforms by publishing legislation giving patients a stronger say in the way hospitals and GP services are run.

The NHS and social care bill will establish 800 patient forums in England with statutory powers to oversee all aspects of health provision - from GP surgeries to nursing homes - and hold managers to account. Local authorities will be able to scrutinise NHS performance and also appeal against hospital closures and altered family doctor services.

A Whitehall source last night said it amounted to "a revolution in genuine patient power". The proposals follow growing unrest about the plan to abolish the 99 community health councils (CHCs), which monitor health authorities and pursue patient complaints.

More than 90 Labour MPs had signed a Commons motion calling for "a robust debate" on CHCs, and several groups, including the Law Society, British Medical Association, Co-operative party, and the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux, had expressed concern about their abolition.

Opponents of the change said the forums might be just toothless focus groups, and there was concern that the patient advocate and liaison service could not fight well for patients if staff were employed by NHS bodies receiving complaints.

The row had threatened to undermine the government's attempt to present its NHS reforms as a flagship policy in the run-up to the election.

The bill will establish the forums with guarantees of independence; they will not be managed by NHS trusts. The budget for patient representation will be more than £30m, about 50% more than allotted CHCs.

fields.headline: Vodafone buys Eircell for £2.8bn
fields.trailText:
2pm: Vodafone has bought Irish rival Eircell for £2.8bn, writes Dan Milmo.
Dec 20: Vodafone buys stake in Japan Telecom
fields.body:
Vodafone has rounded off its Christmas shopping spree with a £2.8bn acquisition of Irish rival Eircell.

The deal comes just days after the world's largest mobile phone company splashed out £1.5bn on a 15% stake in Japan Telecom.

Ireland's mobile market is the third-fastest growing in western Europe, with Eircell's market share standing at around 60%.

Julian Horn-Smith, Vodafone chief executive, said: "Vodafone is adding more than 1.2m customers to its base in an attractive mobile market with a high proportion of young people and a fast-growing population."

However, analysts are concerned that Vodafone has once again used new shares to clinch the deal.

Around 10% of Vodafone's stock is comprised of these shares, and their potential sale has kept down the company's stock market value.

The deal continues Vodafone's rivalry with BT, which owns 51% of Esat Digifone, Eircell's closest competitor.

Both companies are already vying for control of Japan Telecom, which is seen as the perfect gateway to the world's most mature mobile phone market.

webTitle: Academics pay may be 'connected to performance'

fields.headline: Academics pay may be 'connected to performance'
fields.trailText: English academics are to receive extra pay for good performance at work, including contributions to teamwork, under proposals unveiled this week.
fields.body:
English academics are to receive extra pay for good performance at work, including contributions to teamwork, under proposals unveiled this week.

Universities will also have to submit three-year strategies for developing staff to qualify for a share of the £330m unveiled by the government for pay increases.

Institutions only able to draft Ôemerging strategiesÕ outlining plans for the next academic year will receive one yearÕs funding.

The full three-year strategies will cover: plans for regular reviews of staffing needs; annual performance reviews of all staff "with rewards connected to the performance of individuals including, where appropriate, their contribution to teams", and action to tackle poor performance.

The Higher Education Funding Council for England plans to allocate grants for staff development in proportion to existing grants for teaching and research.

This will mean that University College London and the universities of Cambridge and Oxford will secure just under £10m over three years, while Essex and Keele universities and the London School of Economics receive under £2m over the period.

University strategies will need to address priority areas, including recruiting and retaining world class staff and modernising human resource management, says the council. Institutions would be free to determine their own objectives, and set specific targets that would be monitored through their annual operating statements.

The strategies will be reviewed by an advisory group of sector representatives and external experts.

Responses to the consultation are due by 12 February 2001.

fields.headline: Vaccine may cure Alzheimer's disease
fields.standfirst: Expained: the Alzheimer vaccine
fields.trailText: An experimental vaccine against Alzheimer's disease, the devastating brain illness which affects some 600,000 Britons, appears to restore memory and reasoning power, according to new research.
fields.body:
An experimental vaccine against Alzheimer's disease, the devastating brain illness which affects some 600,000 Britons, appears to restore memory and reasoning power, according to new research.

The vaccine is undergoing safety trials in human volunteers in Britain and the US and is due to be tested on Alzheimer's sufferers next year.

Two tests in mice that were genetically modified to reproduce some of the symptoms of Alzheimer's already suggest it can halt the dementia.

Previously, the vaccine had been shown to clear microscopic clumps, or plaques, of a protein called beta amyloid - thought to be at the centre of the Alzheimer's chain of cause and effect - from the brains of the transgenic mice.

In a series of articles published today in the journal Nature, researchers in Toronto and Florida, using tests developed by neuroscientists at Edinburgh University, reveal that the vaccine not only clears plaques but protects the mice from further mental decline.

The vaccine, developed by a Californian subsidiary of the Irish firm Elan Pharmaceuticals, has created a buzz in the Alzheimer's research community because the science behind it is unexpected.

"Almost everybody who believes this story - as I do now - started out very sceptical," said Paul Chapman, professor of neuroscience at Cardiff University.

Traditionally vaccines have been used to train the body's immune systems to recognise and destroy viruses before the patient is infected. But Alzheimer's is not thought to be viral, and in trials the vaccine will be administered to people who already have the disease.

Elan's vaccine is a version of the beta amyloid protein itself. Its apparent effectiveness relies on the fact that the brain and the body have separate immune systems. By introducing high doses of the vaccine into the body, the immune system seems to produce enough antibodies for some to migrate into the brain and begin attacking beta amyloid there, where it is doing damage.

The key to the new vaccine experiments in Canada and the US was a complex test of short and long-term memory in mice, devised by Professor Richard Morris and his team at Edinburgh University.

But researchers caution that even if trials go well, it could be five years before a vaccine reaches patients. There are also several caveats: the dissimilarity of humans and mice and that any vaccine may attack benign body chemicals.

Sceptics point out that another rogue protein, not replicated in the GM mice, is associated with Alzheimer's. But optimists argue that there is growing evidence beta amyloid is the key and other means of destroying it, like drugs, could be also be used.

All three research groups used Elan's patent brand of Alzheimer's mouse, modified to carry a human gene which produces the problem protein. Prof Chapman said Elan would gain scientific credibility if it made its mouse more widely available so other labs could replicate the experiments.

But Prof Morris said: "From my point of view, If I'm embarking on experiments taking two years, I don't want Elan to be giving animals to another lab behind my back."

fields.headline: Volkswagen in $10m Superbowl ad deal
fields.trailText: 1.45pm:Volkswagen has paid CBS an estimated $10m for a car advertisement exclusive in the US Superbowl, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Volkswagen has paid an estimated $10m to be the only car maker to advertise in the US Superbowl in a deal with broadcaster CBS.

The Superbowl is the advertising event of the year for US TV, with advertisers prepared to pay as much as $3m for a single 30-second slot during the game.

VW has bought four 30-second spots during the January 28 broadcast of the game as part of an exclusive deal with CBS.

The deal freezes out rival car makers BMW and General Motors, both of which traditionally advertise in the Superbowl. They will be able to advertise before and after the game but not during it.

No car maker has ever paid out for such an exclusivity deal before, although Budweiser brewer Anheuser-Busch previously spent $20m to buy 10 30-second slots in the game and secure an exclusive deal, freezing out rival Miller.

VW has bought four 30-second spots during the January 28 broadcast of the game as part of an exclusive deal with CBS. The deal freezes out rival car makers BMW and General Motors, both of which traditionally advertise in the Superbowl. They will be able to advertise before and after the game but not during it. No car maker has ever paid out for such an exclusivity deal before, although Budweiser brewer Anheuser-Busch previously spent $20m to buy 10 30-second slots in the game and secure an exclusive deal, freezing out rival Miller.

fields.headline: The Alzheimer vaccine
fields.standfirst: According to new research, an experimental vaccine against Alzheimer's disease appears to restore memory and reasoning power, and will be tested on sufferers next year. Simon Jeffery explains.
fields.trailText:
What is Alzheimer's disease?
Alzheimer's is a degenerative brain disorder that affects 600,000 people in Britain. Symptoms include memory loss, language deterioration, poor judgment and indifferent attitude - a sufferer loses much of what makes them who they are. It is the most widespread form of dementia and, although sufferers can be under 40-years-old, it is especially prevalent among the elderly.
fields.body:
What is Alzheimer's disease?
Alzheimer's is a degenerative brain disorder that affects 600,000 people in Britain. Symptoms include memory loss, language deterioration, poor judgment and indifferent attitude - a sufferer loses much of what makes them who they are. It is the most widespread form of dementia and, although sufferers can be under 40-years-old, it is especially prevalent among the elderly.

What causes it?
Nobody is certain and, as yet, there is no cure. The disease was discovered in 1906 by Alois Alzheimer, a German doctor, who noticed microscopic clumps and tangles in the brain tissue of a woman who had died of an unusual mental illness. These clumps, or plaques, are believed to block sufferers' ability to learn and remember.

What is the breakthrough?
Neuroscientists at Edinburgh university have carried out an experiment which, they say, distinguishes between recent memories (the kind Alzheimer's sufferers find hard to keep) and those from early in life, which do not cause as much trouble.

What was it?
Mice were put in an elaborate water maze where the exits kept changing. Those with raised levels of a protein called beta-amyloid, thought to cause the clumps in an Alzheimer's sufferers' brain, got confused and found it harder to remember the exits than the mice with less. All the mice were fine when the escape location did not change.

What did it show?
That the clumps associated with the protein beta-amyloid block short term memories but do not affect those from earlier in life. This is consistent with Alzheimer's disease - a relationship that had until now eluded researchers.

So how can a vaccine help?
Researchers in Toronto and Florida have found that brain clumps clear in affected mice who are vaccinated against the protein. Significantly, the mice are protected against further decline and in both experiments demonstrated improved memories.

How long until it's available for people?
At least five years. The vaccine is undergoing safety trials on humans but, as with any similar discovery, the dissimilarity of mice and men means that the vaccine may have an unexpected affect on humans. Sceptics say that another protein, not beta-amyloid, may be responsible for the disease.

What are the current treatments?
Alzheimer's is a progressive disease, meaning it gets worse the longer a sufferer has it. The damage starts with mild memory problems and ends with severe mental damage. For some people in the early and middle stages of Alzheimer's, the drug Aricept may alleviate some symptoms but not halt the disease.

fields.headline: Liverpool poet Adrian Henri dies
fields.trailText: Adrian Henri, part of the Liverpool literary scene of the 1960s, has died aged 68
fields.body:
The poet Adrian Henri has died, aged 68, following a long illness.

Henri, along with Brian Patten and Roger McGough, was at the vanguard of the Liverpool literary scene in the 1960s, achieving critical and popular acclaim for a brand of poetry which drew inspiration from the immediate environment and the art and music of the time.

Henri was the oldest of the trio and the only one who remained in Liverpool. His contribution to the city was recognised just this week when he received the Freedom of the City on Wednesday night and an honorary degree from Liverpool University on Monday.

Born in 1932 in Birkenhead, Henri studied Fine Art at Durham University and later became a lecturer at both Manchester and Liverpool's Academies of Visual Arts. In 1963 he and McGough formed a pop group, the Scaffold, and went on to have a number of hits, including Thank You Very Much and Lily the Pink. In 1967 he founded the poetry group Liverpool Scene, publishing the hugely successful collection The Mersey Sound in 1967 which sold over a quarter of a million copies.

Henri always considered himself to be an autobiographical poet. His collection Autobiography, published in 1971, looked back at the first 35 years of his life. Love poems took up most of his early work; later on the themes shifted to towns and landscapes.

In addition to his achievements in the fields of poetry and music, Henri wrote children's books, a novel (with Nell Dunn) and television and stage plays. He was also a successful artist, holding the presidency of the Liverpool Academy of Arts from 1972-81.

webTitle: Sainsbury's and Asda in propaganda war

fields.headline: Sainsbury's and Asda in propaganda war
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Asda is claiming to have replaced Sainsbury's as the UK's number two supermarket, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
A fierce row has broken out between two of the UK's leading supermarkets after Asda claimed to have replaced Sainsbury's as the country's number two store.

Asda claims that its aggressive price-cutting strategy is outsmarting Sainsbury's, which is bucking the trend in grocery marketing by continuing to invest in big-hitting TV campaigns

Sainsbury's is currently running a £25m ad campaign featuring celebrity chef Jamie Oliver.

Asda said that new figures from analysts Taylor Nelson Sofres show it had grabbed a record 15.4% share of grocery sales over the past three months, giving it a lead over Sainsbury's, which has a 15% stake in the market.

Tesco remains in the number one spot with 23%.

But Sainsbury's hit back by claiming that Asda had spun retail figures in the past to make it look like it is ahead in sales.

Asda's claims were also disputed by Mike Godliman, director at retail specialist Verdict Research, who branded the supermarket's claims as "nonsense".

"Certainly Asda is catching up but in terms of total market share my latest figures show Sainsbury's with 12.6% of the market compared with Asda's 9.1%.

"At its current rate of growth it could take Asda another six years to take over."

Despite Asda's focus on low prices, recently boosted by the buying power of new US parent Walmart, Sainsbury's continues to invest heavily in building its reputation as a high quality retailer.

At the beginning of the year it brought in Abbey National's high-flying marketing director Sara Weller for its own top marketing position and the Prudential's Sir Peter Davis as chief executive.

Since then it has re-hired the UK's largest ad agency, Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, and created the Jamie Oliver campaign in a bid to revive its image as the supermarket with the freshest food.

Sainsbury's, the number one supermarket in the 1980s, lost its position in the mid-90s to a resurgent Tesco.

Tesco has concentrated on direct marketing through its Clubcard scheme and superior distribution techniques.

Sainsbury's says Asda is using volume sales rather than till roll receipts, which clearly still show Sainsbury's as the UK number two.

Ms Weller, Sainsbury's director of marketing, said: "As usual Asda is being very selective in the data it has chosen in yet another attempt to mislead consumers."

fields.headline: Shimon Peres: sixth time lucky?
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: Shimon Peres, who has thrown his hat into Israel's prime ministerial ring yet again, is one of the great survivors of politics, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Shimon Peres, who has thrown his hat into Israel's prime ministerial ring yet again, is one of the great survivors of politics.

He is also, paradoxically perhaps, one of the great all-time losers.

He has tried five times before to win the top job, and every time he has lost, either in party primaries or in subsequent general elections. And yet he has actually been prime minister twice; the first time as the result of a murky coalition deal, and the second a consequence of the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin.

Perennial Peres, as he should perhaps be known, has been active in the snakepit of Israeli politics since before the founding of the state. Born 77 years ago in what is now Belarus, he emigrated to Palestine with his family when he was 11.

As a teenager he helped found a kibbutz in 1940. Three years later, at 20, he was elected secretary of the Hano'ar Ha'oved youth movement. By the time Israel proclaimed its independence in May 1948, Peres was already close to the centre of power.

Working with David Ben Gurion and other leaders, he swiftly rose to the top civilian job in the key ministry of defence. He was first elected to the Knesset (parliament) in 1959, and has been a member ever since.

A consummate wheeler-dealer, Peres has adroitly jumped from party to party, always remaining on the centre-left but never being too picky in his choice of allies.

After the hung election of 1984 he tried and failed to form a government as the leader of the biggest parliamentary bloc, and promptly did a deal with the rightwing Likud movement which gave him a two-year stint as prime minister.

For more than 20 years, Peres was locked into a remarkable rivalry with Yitzhak Rabin for the leadership of the Israel Labour Party. Rabin, the gruff old soldier, invariably beat the consummate politician, only being forced out of the leadership through a minor financial scandal.

In 1992 Rabin again wrested the party leadership from Peres, and went on to form a government with his old foe as foreign minister. It was in some respects a dream team, with Rabin playing the hard man, and Peres the polished diplomat.

In the summer of 1993, after months of secret negotiations in Norway, they produced a bombshell: the Oslo peace accord with the Palestinians. Peres, Rabin and Yasser Arafat were given the Nobel peace prize but in reality their peace was flawed by muddle and distrust.

The agreement was achieved only by putting aside the remaining, enormous, disagreements. Arafat came back to a Palestine that was truncated, fragmented and impoverished. As the peace process moved ahead at snail's pace, disillusion swiftly set in.

Palestinians, angered by the continued occupation, turned increasingly to the Islamist and other militant groups. Israelis in their turn were outraged by the continuing 'terror' campaign.

In the autumn of 1996 Rabin was gunned down by a fanatical young Jew, as he left a peace rally in Tel Aviv. Once again Peres was catapulted into the top job, and the shocked aftermath of the assassination, it seemed that he would easily win the looming election.

It all went horribly wrong. Many commentators believe that Peres was brought low by the series of hideous suicide bus bombings in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv just before the election. But those bombings, though they did indeed inflame opinion and tilt the election towards Likud, were the direct consequence of another, quite different assassination.

The victim - if he can indeed be called that - was Engineer Yayha Ayyash, the mastermind of the Hamas bombing campaign. He was killed, appropriately enough, by a booby-trapped mobile telephone which the Israeli secret service delivered to him via a collaborator.

It was a brilliant cloak-and-dagger operation, and a colossal misjudgement by Peres. He thought that by sanctioning the elimination of Ayyash, he would prove himself to the Israeli electorate as a man of action as well as words.

Instead, he sparked a ghastly wave of retaliation which swept him from office and, a year later, from the Labour leadership. The party is now known as One Nation, and is led by prime minister Ehud Barak, whose minority coalition government has been brought close to collapse by nearly three months of almost open warfare with the Palestinians.

Barak has decided to seek a fresh mandate for his prime ministership - but not for the party. The direct prime ministerial election on February 6 will be in effect a referendum on the peace process, which Barak wants to bring to a conclusion with a final settlement paving the way for a Palestinian state.

His main opponent is likely to be Ariel Sharon, the fire-breathing head of the Likud faction. Opinion polls show them fairly evenly matched. But they also suggest that the old warhorse Sharon would find it harder to beat the old thoroughbred Shimon Peres.

Israelis, as a general truth, respect Peres more than they love him. He's slick, smooth, and ruthless, with a quicksilver mind and a boundless appetite for intrigue. For more than half a century, he has manoevred and manipulated his way to power. Now, yet again, he is making a bid for the top job he has always craved.
