fields.headline: £1m prize for academic entrepreneurs
fields.standfirst: XACP and Brainspark launch £1m competition for IT and telecoms ventures, backed by The Guardian
fields.trailText: XACP and Brainspark launch £1m competition for IT and telecoms ventures, backed by The Guardian
fields.body:
Students and academics around Britain are being invited to demonstrate their entrepreneurial prowess, with a prize fund of £1m.

Launchit2001, a competition announced today by Cross Atlantic Capital Partners (XACP), a venture capital management firm, and Brainspark, an internet and technology incubator, and supported by The Guardian, hopes to unlock the innovation hidden in university campuses and find Britain's next big name in the IT and telecoms industries.

The competition is open to any individual in higher education or teams that include a student or academic staff member.

XACP and Brainspark will select the best new business ventures submitted from universities, engineering and business schools in Britain. The best two or more winning ventures will be eligible for direct investment from XACP and Brainspark from a fund of £1m in total, ranging from £100,000 to £500,000 packages.

XACP and Brainspark are seeking entries for concepts that are beyond the initial research phase. Ideally, entries will have products and services that are ready to be commercialised or ideas that have passed a successful proof of concept. Entries will address one of four key areas within the IT and telecoms sectors: new enabling technologies (including nanotechnology and optoelectronics), internet infrastructure, enterprise software, e-communications and wireless infrastructure and applications.

Launch2001 is supported by The Guardian, whose Online section has taken a special interest in technology and has reported extensively on the venture capital industry and the challenges associated with raising money.

Victor Keegan, editor of Online, said: "Editorially, The Guardian has welcomed the revival of the venture capital industry in Britain, and the successful development of ideas originating in universities. We are delighted to be supporting Launchit2001's £1m competition.

"Though each team must include a student or member of the academic staff, members are encouraged to add senior management from outside the university. The deadline for online registration and submission of a two-page executive summary is February 5, 2001. Selected entrants will be notified by March 2 and will have until March 30 to submit their full business plan."

fields.headline: Britons freed after nine months
fields.standfirst: Orchid hunters kidnapped in perilous area of Colombia walk to freedom after hostage ordeal
fields.trailText: Two British orchid hunters kidnapped nine months ago in the Colombian jungle have walked to freedom unharmed after they were suddenly released by their captors.
fields.byline: Martin Hodgson in Bogota and Rebecca Allison
fields.body:
Two British orchid hunters kidnapped nine months ago in the Colombian jungle have walked to freedom unharmed after they were suddenly released by their captors.

Tom Hart Dyke, 24, a horticulturalist and Paul Winder, 29, a merchant banker, emerged from the rainforest on Tuesday after trekking through wilderness for eight days following their release on December 10.

The exhausted pair flagged down a park ranger at Sautata, on the Colombian border with Panama, who called the British embassy in Bogota. The embassy arranged for them to be flown back to the capital.

A visibly exhausted Mr Winder read a brief statement at a press conference in Bogota last night, but did not reveal details of their ordeal.

"We are well and in very good spirits in spite of our experiences during the past nine months. Now we just want to get home for Christmas and be with our families," he said. "We were never told who was holding us nor why."

No group has claimed responsibility for the kidnapping, and officials say no ransom demand was ever made.

The men were debriefed by embassy staff after a full medical examination, an embassy spokesman said. They are expected to arrive at Gatwick airport today.

Mr Hart Dyke, from Eynsford, Kent, and Mr Winder, from Chelmsford, Essex, had been searching for rare orchids when they went missing.

Mr Hart Dyke is one of Britain's leading young horticulturalists and has spent the past two years travelling the world in search of orchids. He met Mr Winder, who was taking six months off from Salomon Brothers in the City, while travelling in Puerto Rico.

The last their families heard was that they were heading out on a trek from Yaviza in Panama to the infamous Darien Gap, a roadless region on the border with Colombia.

It is a lawless no man's land where leftwing rebels and rightwing paramilitaries battle to dominate key drug- and arms-smuggling routes. The two men were reported to have ignored warnings from locals about the area.

"After a few months we thought they were probably dead, because there are so many ways you can die in the Darien Gap," said Jeremy Thorpe, the British ambassador in Bogota. "You can just get lost. There are all sorts of military groups there, or they could just have been robbed and killed for what they had."

Colombia's largest rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, is believed to have 600 guerrillas in the region while rightwing paramilitaries control most towns near the border.

"From what they've told us, no violence was used against them, and they were reasonably well treated. Certainly they were well fed," Mr Thorpe said.

Initially it was feared the pair could have become lost and died in the dangerous terrain.

Relatives of both men flew to the region in attempts to discover what had happened. Mr Hart Dyke's mother Sarah met leading Colombian horticulturalists in Bogota, while Mr Winder's father Paul contracted a Panamanian ex-US marine and a Kuna Indian guide to retrace the journey of his missing son.

Mr Hart Dyke was travelling with the assistance of a £500 grant from the Merlin Trust, founded by Valerie Finnis to encourage research abroad by young horticulturalists. She said she was "overjoyed" at his release.

There are all sorts of military groups there, or they could just have been robbed and killed for what they had." Colombia's largest rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, is believed to have 600 guerrillas in the region while rightwing paramilitaries control most towns near the border. "From what they've told us, no violence was used against them, and they were reasonably well treated. Certainly they were well fed," Mr Thorpe said. Initially it was feared the pair could have become lost and died in the dangerous terrain. Relatives of both men flew to the region in attempts to discover what had happened. Mr Hart Dyke's mother Sarah met leading Colombian horticulturalists in Bogota, while Mr Winder's father Paul contracted a Panamanian ex-US marine and a Kuna Indian guide to retrace the journey of his missing son. Mr Hart Dyke was travelling with the assistance of a £500 grant from the Merlin Trust, founded by Valerie Finnis to encourage research abroad by young horticulturalists. She said she was "overjoyed" at his release. fields.headline: Ex-inmate Mel slates Big Brother
fields.standfirst: Listen to Melanie Hill talk about Big Brother
fields.trailText:
12pm: Former Big Brother contestant Melanie Hill has said the hit show "wasn't reality TV, but a dramatisation", reports Jessica Hodgson.
Listen to Melanie Hill talk about Big Brother
fields.body:
Former Big Brother contestant Melanie Hill has said that the hit show "wasn't reality TV, but a dramatisation".

Ms Hill told Guardian Unlimited Radio that she was "horrified" when she saw the press coverage of the TV phenomenon after emerging from the house.

And she slammed the production team for portraying her as a "man eater".

She criticised both the show's producers and tabloid journalists for creating "caricatures" based on the contestants in the UK's first big taste of reality TV.

"When I watched the tapes I understood that stories and storylines were made to fit any piece of footage into the storyboard and or the caricature that we were portrayed or playing."

Ms Hill said she felt "naive" and "stupid" after she realised the way the production team, from independent producer Bazal, had manipulated the real lives of the participants to fit their storylines.

"It was foolish of me to think that they would give a fair portrayal of every single person," she said. "In fact we were so boring that they had to find stories that weren't happening".

Asked about the second series of the programme, Ms Hill said she thought it would attract "more interesting" people than the first series.

She said that of all the Big Brother contestants, "Nasty" Nick Bateman had made "by far the most money".

But she said he was the only one who had joined to make money. "The reasons people went on to the show were very wide and broad," she said, adding that Mr Bateman, who had a link-up with the Sun, was the only one who used it to launch his career.

Ms Hill will be returning to TV screens in March next year to present Chained, a reality show on the new Channel 4 digital channel E4.

She also hopes to get involved with travel programmes and travel writing.

webTitle: Technology and telecoms stocks fall in US and Europe

fields.headline: Technology and telecoms stocks fall in US and Europe
fields.trailText: 11.45am: European technology and telecoms stocks dropped today after a fall in the tech-heavy Nasdaq list, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
European technology and telecoms stocks took a hammering this morning, as their US partners continue to falter.

An overnight fall of 7% in the tech-heavy Nasdaq list in New York left the benchmark FTSE 100 index down 49.2 points in early trading, with technology firm Autonomy tumbling 6.8%.

Fears of a downturn in the US economy and broker downgrades for leading tech companies sparked the recent run on the Nasdaq, which has lost more than 50% of its value since March.

"The Nasdaq list went up sharply last year, and the correction has been severe, but we were not expecting this level of severity," said Alan Torry, a fund manager at SG Asset Management.

"It is certainly the biggest tech stock sell-off in 40 years. The market has become very emotional."

He said that fund managers have dumped tech stocks from their portfolios in order to avoid losses in their end of year figures, but that they should start buying back into the sector after new year.

The US losses have been compounded by recent profit warnings from big hitters such as Microsoft and Apple.

Technology losers in London included Logica, which fell 5%, and Dimension Data, which was off 4.5%. In telecoms, BT fell 2.5% and Kingston Communications shed 4%.

Although fund managers expected a correction in the buoyant technology markets, they have been taken aback by the scale of the panic selling, which they claim is the heaviest they have ever seen.

Germany's high-tech Neuer Markt Nemax 50 index continued to hit fresh lows after tumbling 1.1%. Telecoms heavyweight Deutsche Telekom shed 2.2%.

The slump in technology, media and telecoms shares has added to concerns about the financial well-being of the sectors.

This week, it was revealed that a third of all bank lending to European businesses this year was made to TMT companies.

The Bank of England has warned regulators to monitor banks in case they suffer from over-exposure to a single sector.

fields.headline: Auto pilot
fields.standfirst: Mike Lynch is the chief executive and founder of Autonomy Corporation
fields.trailText: Mike Lynch is the chief executive and founder of Autonomy Corporation
fields.body:
What does Kenjin offer that conventional search engines don't? Kenjin is an extremely effective way of showing users how information can be brought to them, as opposed to their having to seek it out. You can ask Kenjin to keep an eye on whatever you're typing or reading. It can then suggest related resources and present them to you as links. These can be web pages as well as documents and emails on your hard drive and the email addresses of other people in the Kenjin community whose interests are similar to yours. So if you are emailing a friend about a holiday in Mexico, it will automatically bring up links to maps, tourist information, flights and accommodation and your emails on the subject, all displayed at the bottom of your screen.

Why don't personal agents do all this for us? They can, but only if the technology behind them is intelligent. Most personal agents are keyword-based. This is useless for anyone who uses puns, jargon, slang or archaic expressions. The keyword agent simply would not understand, for example, that 'Michael Heseltine', 'Hezza' and 'Tarzan' are all part of the same concept. Kenjin, which is a consumer version of our Active Knowledge corporate software, is able to understand the links between these concepts.

What will be on offer in five years' time? Managing and processing all digital information automatically will be the rule rather than the exception. Convergence will become a reality, with the web, digital TV, voice and mobile telecommunications all integrated in mobile as well as desktop computers.

Where is the boom-to-bust dot.com world going from here? Companies providing software which is fundamental for doing business digitally are in the strongest position. Sure, there are many companies swept away by the market mudslides, but there are e-tailers out there turning a profit now, too. By combining a great idea with a sound, scalable business model you'll have a chance in any market, whether it's clicks or bricks.

What single thing could government do to help UK web companies? Reduce tax on share options. The Silicon Valley model is unbeatable; financial incentives help to attract the best employees and reward them for their productivity.

Your introduction to computers? During my time at Cambridge I realised there was a need to make computers more human. I set out to develop a way to make them function in a way that could understand the 'grey' in any given situation, rather than unrelentingly drawing conclusions on the basis of black and white, on and off, one and zero.

Favourite web sites? I spend about half my life in strange cities in the US, so it's nice to be able to catch up with the local news back home in Suffolk, which I do thanks to the Eastern Counties Network. I also keep an eye on business news at www.reuters.com and www.bloomberg.com. When I'm not CEO-ing, I'm a big jazz fan, so sites such as www.ronniescotts.co.uk are a regular stop for me. I played my sax onstage at Ronnie Scott's recently, a very proud moment!

webTitle: Vodafone insists BT is an ally in Tokyo

fields.headline: Vodafone insists BT is an ally in Tokyo
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Vodafone's global ambitions took a £1.5bn step forward yesterday when the group bought a 15% stake in Japan Telecom.
fields.body:
Vodafone's global ambitions took a £1.5bn step forward yesterday when the group bought a 15% stake in Japan Telecom.

The deal increases Vodafone's presence in one of the world's fastest growing mobile phone markets and the first market to see the introduction of third-generation services.

But it could intensify the rivalry between Vodafone and British Telecom, which also has a 15% stake in the Japanese mobile phone compnay.

Yesterday both companies were at pains to play down the possibility of conflict, pointing to their existing good relations in Japan where both are shareholders in J-Phone, Japan Telecom's mobile phone subsidiary.

But, with another Japan Telecom shareholder - AT&T -prepared to sell at least part of its holding, analysts scent a potential battle.

BT is perceived to be keen on the Japanese market while Vodafone, which has usually preferred to build up majority stakes in groups in which it has shareholdings, may not be content to stick at 15%.

However, the deal with Japan Telecom does give the British group two seats on the board of the Japanese operator and both UK companies will be anxious to avoid being seen to be bringing aggressive Anglo-Saxon business practices to consensus-oriented Japan.

But, if a battle does develop over which British company will take the leading role at Japan Telecom, analysts believe that Vodafone could have an edge. "If it depends upon price, Vodafone has the deeper pockets," one analyst said.

Japan is seen as a crucial market for mobile phone companies because it has a high penetration of mobile internet services and because 3G services will be rolled out next May - giving operators in the market valuable early experience.

Japan has the third-largest cellular subscriber base in the world, behind the US and China. Vodafone bought its Japan Telecom stake from two railway companies - JR West and JR Central - although both retain small stakes. Another rail company, JR East, retains 15%.

Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent said it demonstrated his company's confidence in the Japanese market and in Japan Telecom and J-Phone. "We look forward to working together with existing Japan Telecom partners, BT and AT&T and the JR companies, to achieve [the future growth and development of Japan Telecom and J-Phone]."

BT said that it already had a good business relationship with Vodafone through their respective involvements in J-Phone and that it expected that relationship to extend to Japan Telecom.

J-Phone has some 3.9m users of its internet service, J-Sky, although that is still well behind NTT DoCoMo, which has some 15.6m users of its i-mode service.

DoCoMo, which recently bought a stake in AT&T Wireless, is seen as Vodafone's leading rival in 3G mobile telephones on a global basis.

fields.headline: Bergg quits Sky One after a year
fields.standfirst:
Dec 19: Marsh set for Sky job
Dec 13: Sky One chief in shock departure
fields.trailText:
11.30am: David Bergg, Sky One general manager, is quitting less than a year after he was poached from ITV, writes Jason Deans.
Dec 19: Marsh set for Sky job
Dec 13: Sky One chief in shock departure
fields.body:
BSkyB has confirmed that David Bergg, Sky One general manager, is quitting less than a year after he was poached from ITV.

The announcement comes seven days after reports first emerged of a falling out between the former ITV golden boy and BSkyB.

The company today said Mr Bergg would be leaving "immediately" in a deal agreed "by mutual consent".

BSkyB has also confirmed that Kate Marsh will be joining from the BBC as deputy director of broadcasting and production.

Ms Marsh, BBC Birmingham head of lifestyle and features, will take up her post next month and report to BSkyB production and broadcasting boss Mark Sharman.

She will be responsible for developing new programming for all BSkyB's non-sports channels, including Sky One.

The abrupt departure from Sky One of Mr Bergg, who is regarded as one of the best schedulers around, was greeted with surprise by the TV industry.

He was seen as a rising star following stints as scheduler of BBC1 and Channel 5, and most recently as director of planning and strategy for ITV.

However, one insider said: "The world of satellite is very different. It is a very competitive marketplace."

Sky One's position in the marketplace has been vulnerable ever since the station lost its top shows, including ER and Friends, to Channel 4's new digital entertainment station, E4.

Mr Bergg was charged with redefining the station and famously declared he was after the BBC and ITV's audiences.

"I am after the Sunny Delight family," he said at the time.

Today Mr Bergg said he was disappointed it hadn't worked out.

"I am very sad to be leaving a very talented and hardworking group of people after such a short period of time, but I would like to wish everyone at Sky One every success for the future," he said.

Mark Sharman, BSkyB director of broadcasting and production, is reviewing the Sky One management structure in the wake of Mr Bergg's departure.

He said: "I would like to pay tribute to David's contribution to the development of the channel and his role in maintaining Sky One's position."

Ms Marsh was responsible for programmes including Top Gear, Gardeners' World and Delia's How to Cook at BBC Birmingham. Before that she was development executive for BBC new channels.

fields.headline: AOL expands Kingfisher marketing deal
fields.trailText: 11.15am: AOL has expanded its marketing distribution deal with retail group Kingfisher, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
AOL has expanded its marketing distribution arrangement with high street retail group Kingfisher.

Under the deal, more than 2,000 Comet, B&Q, Woolworths and Superdrug stores will distribute co-branded software for AOL's new "flat rate" service from the new year.

In return, B&Q will become a key online shopping partner across AOL and CompuServe's member areas and Netscape Online's home page.

Karen Thomson, AOL UK managing director, said: "This retail agreement positions us to penetrate even more deeply into the UK mass market."

Kingfisher recently set up e-Kingfisher and took an 85% stake in online entertainment retailer Streets Online for £15.7m.

Kingfisher's own internet service provider, LibertySurf - in which it owns a one-third stake - has no distribution arrangement in its stores.

AOL's Flat Rate plan, launched on September 19, offers unmetered internet access for £14.99 a month. AOL also has a similar marketing distribution arrangement with Littlewoods.

webTitle: Thirteenth person arrested in Damilola case

fields.headline: Thirteenth person arrested in Damilola case
fields.standfirst: More about the Damilola case
fields.trailText: A 15-year-old boy was arrested in a dawn raid today by police investigating the murder of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor, the 13th person to be picked up in connection to the November 27 stabbing.
fields.body:
A 15-year-old boy was arrested in a dawn raid today by police investigating the murder of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor, the 13th person to be picked up in connection to the November 27 stabbing.

The youth was arrested at an address in Camberwell and was being questioned at a London police station, said a Scotland Yard spokeswoman.

The 15-year-old, who is black, had not been arrested before, the spokeswoman said. Police also searched another address this morning but made no further arrests.

The arrest is the latest development in the investigation into the murder of Nigerian-born Damilola, who bled to death in a stairwell on a run-down estate in Peckham, south London after being stabbed in the leg as he walked home from an after-school computer class.

He dragged himself 100 yards along the street before collapsing.

Last Thursday, 11 boys aged between 12 and 16 were arrested in London in a series of dawn raids involving about 200 officers.

Six of them were released on bail pending further inquiries. Another, aged 14, was released with no further action to be taken. A 39-year-old woman was also arrested and questioned over Damilola's death.

The spotlight fell on this already high-profile case again today when it emerged that a police officer whose job as schools liaison officer in the area of south London where Damilola lived was about to be axed shortly before the murder.

PC Ian Wright worked to improve relations between police and youngsters on the Peckham and Camberwell beat, and headteachers were furious when the Metropolitan Police announced last month that his post would be withdrawn.

Scotland Yard said PC Wright had instead been "seconded" to a team designed to tackle violent crime among young people.

Today the Police Federation said they were concerned that important work to build trust between officers and local youngsters will seriously damaged by PC Wright's move.

Among the schools on the constable's patch was the Oliver Goldsmith primary school in Peckham, which was attended by Damilola before his fatal stabbing.

The chairman of the Metropolitan Police Federation, Glen Smyth, said: "PC Wright built up such a good relationship with the children that when they were told he was being withdrawn, the headteachers of the schools wrote independently of each other saying they were desperate to keep him.

"If these tragic events hadn't taken place he would have gone. Even with his new role we are very concerned about the impact it will have on relations with young people in the area."

PC Wright, who is qualified as a teacher, concentrated on primary schools in the area, added Mr Smyth. "It is important to catch them early because by the time they go to secondary schools you have lost them.

"This area has a large refugee population and some of them may come from countries where policing is done down the barrel of a gun. It's vital to build trust for the police in those circumstances, because these children could become the gang members of the future," said Mr Smyth.

The move of an officer from a community role was typical of the shortages being suffered by the Met, which is 3,250 officers below strength, he added.

A Met spokesman said: "As part of our creation of a team to help tackle youth crime on the estate it was important to ensure that this team was linked closely with schools that had a catchment area that included the North Peckham Estate.

"Because of Ian's local knowledge and expertise he has been seconded into this team for three months. This team reports directly to the inspector for the Peckham and Camberwell sector and so, although he has changed his role, he will still be working in the same area with the same schools, but with a particular focus on violent crime and young people."

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, said two schools in his Southwark North and Bermondsey constituency covered by PC Wright had protested at his withdrawal.

He said: "The police are under such pressure that these sorts of jobs are jobs they have to consider losing in order to do a simple response job. This is exactly the sort of job we need people to do - police officers in schools, police officers becoming role models for youngsters are crucially important. The reality is that they are desperately short of police."

A Met spokesman said that PC Wright's job had been re-advertised, although he was free to re-apply for the post, which he has held for 10 years. "The decision to re-advertise his post was taken two weeks before Damilola's murder," the spokesman said.

The time taken to fill the vacancy would depend on "the quality of the candidates" but it would, he hoped, be fairly quick.

fields.bodyText: A 15-year-old boy was arrested in a dawn raid today by police investigating the murder of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor, the 13th person to be picked up in connection to the November 27 stabbing. The youth was arrested at an address in Camberwell and was being questioned at a London police station, said a Scotland Yard spokeswoman. The 15-year-old, who is black, had not been arrested before, the spokeswoman said. Police also searched another address this morning but made no further arrests. The arrest is the latest development in the investigation into the murder of Nigerian-born Damilola, who bled to death in a stairwell on a run-down estate in Peckham, south London after being stabbed in the leg as he walked home from an after-school computer class. He dragged himself 100 yards along the street before collapsing. Last Thursday, 11 boys aged between 12 and 16 were arrested in London in a series of dawn raids involving about 200 officers. Six of them were released on bail pending further inquiries. Another, aged 14, was released with no further action to be taken. A 39-year-old woman was also arrested and questioned over Damilola's death. The spotlight fell on this already high-profile case again today when it emerged that a police officer whose job as schools liaison officer in the area of south London where Damilola lived was about to be axed shortly before the murder. PC Ian Wright worked to improve relations between police and youngsters on the Peckham and Camberwell beat, and headteachers were furious when the Metropolitan Police announced last month that his post would be withdrawn. Scotland Yard said PC Wright had instead been "seconded" to a team designed to tackle violent crime among young people. Today the Police Federation said they were concerned that important work to build trust between officers and local youngsters will seriously damaged by PC Wright's move. Among the schools on the constable's patch was the Oliver Goldsmith primary school in Peckham, which was attended by Damilola before his fatal stabbing. The chairman of the Metropolitan Police Federation, Glen Smyth, said: "PC Wright built up such a good relationship with the children that when they were told he was being withdrawn, the headteachers of the schools wrote independently of each other saying they were desperate to keep him. "If these tragic events hadn't taken place he would have gone. Even with his new role we are very concerned about the impact it will have on relations with young people in the area." PC Wright, who is qualified as a teacher, concentrated on primary schools in the area, added Mr Smyth. "It is important to catch them early because by the time they go to secondary schools you have lost them. "This area has a large refugee population and some of them may come from countries where policing is done down the barrel of a gun. It's vital to build trust for the police in those circumstances, because these children could become the gang members of the future," said Mr Smyth. The move of an officer from a community role was typical of the shortages being suffered by the Met, which is 3,250 officers below strength, he added. A Met spokesman said: "As part of our creation of a team to help tackle youth crime on the estate it was important to ensure that this team was linked closely with schools that had a catchment area that included the North Peckham Estate. "Because of Ian's local knowledge and expertise he has been seconded into this team for three months. This team reports directly to the inspector for the Peckham and Camberwell sector and so, although he has changed his role, he will still be working in the same area with the same schools, but with a particular focus on violent crime and young people." The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, said two schools in his Southwark North and Bermondsey constituency covered by PC Wright had protested at his withdrawal. He said: "The police are under such pressure that these sorts of jobs are jobs they have to consider losing in order to do a simple response job. This is exactly the sort of job we need people to do - police officers in schools, police officers becoming role models for youngsters are crucially important. The reality is that they are desperately short of police." A Met spokesman said that PC Wright's job had been re-advertised, although he was free to re-apply for the post, which he has held for 10 years. "The decision to re-advertise his post was taken two weeks before Damilola's murder," the spokesman said. The time taken to fill the vacancy would depend on "the quality of the candidates" but it would, he hoped, be fairly quick. webTitle: Carew scores and is sent off as Valencia go top

fields.headline: Carew scores and is sent off as Valencia go top
fields.trailText: John Carew scored a brilliant 81st-minute equaliser to earn Valencia a 1-1 draw at Athletic Bilbao to send his side top of the Primera Liga - but his joy was short-lived as he then received a second yellow card for an over-exuberant celebration and was sent off.
fields.body:
John Carew scored a brilliant 81st-minute equaliser to earn Valencia a 1-1 draw at Athletic Bilbao to send his side top of the Primera Liga - but his joy was short-lived as he then received a second yellow card for an over-exuberant celebration and was sent off.

On a dramatic night of action going into the 18-day Christmas break in Spain, Valencia's draw was enough to take them back above Real Madrid on goal difference.

Deportivo La Coruna moved third with a 3-0 win at home to Real Oviedo, with goals from Djalminha (2) and Roy Makaay. Meanwhile Barcelona stayed in touch with the leaders after a nerve-jangling 3-2 victory over Alaves at the Nou Camp.

Valencia lead on 32 points from 16 games, with Real Madrid second but with a game in hand following their impressive 3-1 triumph over Rayo Vallecano on Tuesday. Reigning champions Deportivo have 31 points, with Barcelona fourth on 27.

Barcelona were 3-0 up in their game against Alaves after an excellent display for the opening 70 minutes.

Marc Overmars set up Rivaldo for the opener after three minutes with the first of a series of incisive runs down the left. The same combination provided the second shortly after the break as Magno attempted to clear an Overmars cross but only managed to send the ball cannoning in off Rivaldo's chest.

The Brazilian playmaker then set up Kluiviert on 69 minutes and Barca must have thought the game was over.

But Alaves pulled one back through a Javi Moreno penalty after Cosmin Contra was brought down and two minutes later Magno took a Moreno pass to make it 3-2. Magno then thought he had the equaliser with two minutes to go but his effort was ruled out for a marginal offside.

"You can't suffer so much when you're leading 3-0," said Barca coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer. "It was a strange game but conceding so many goals is always worrying."

Elsewhere, Numancia beat Celta Vigo 4-2 to move off the bottom, Mallorca stayed in fifth place with a 3-2 win over Espanyol, Las Palmas beat Osasuna 3-2 and Malaga thrashed Real Sociedad 3-0.

There were draws between Racing de Santander and Valladolid (2-2) and Villarreal and Zaragoza (1-1).

webTitle: Getting fair price for indigenous remedies

fields.headline: Getting fair price for indigenous remedies
fields.trailText: For centuries traditional healers in Samoa have ground up the stem of the plant Homolanthus acuminatus and steeped it in hot water as a treatment for the yellow fever virus. Recently, the age-old remedy caught the interest of the US National Cancer Institute which took a closer look and found prostratin, a drug with potential for HIV reports Keith Perry
fields.body:
For centuries traditional healers in Samoa have ground up the stem of the plant Homolanthus acuminatus and steeped it in hot water as a treatment for the yellow fever virus.

Recently, the age-old remedy caught the interest of the US National Cancer Institute which took a closer look and found prostratin, a drug with potential for HIV. Bulk samples of the plant were collected and shipped back to the US.

Now under development, it has the potential to earn millions as a successful drug for treating viral infections.

It might have been a good example of traditional medicine and modern science working hand in hand, with the financial rewards being channelled back to the developing countries which originally shared the medical knowledge of their ancestors.

But sadly for the Samoan villagers, there is no record of the American scientists having sought any prior agreement with the Samoan government, local communities or healers for the collection and use of the plant and the associated knowledge. They are unlikely to receive a penny.

Now, the world is facing up to the insidious threat of biopiracy whereby prospecters scour fragile habitats for exotic plants.

Since 1989 a group of environmental lawyers from a London-based charity, Field, has been seeking to help developing countries to reform the laws and improve their capacity to defend themselves against the scourge of biopiracy.

Carolina Lasen Diaz, a Field lawyer, said Field had been focusing on fragile ecosystems such as the Pacific Islands.

"We are working with a regional governmental organisation in the Pacific and WWF to support countries that are trying to regulate access to genetic resources."

Ms Lasen Diaz says one of the many examples of biotechnology firms taking natural resources out of the country of origin that had led to pharmaceutical applications was kava, a plant found throughout the Pacific and used for 3,000 years for its medicinal properties.

Overseas companies keen to cash in on the surge in herbal medicine were quick to seize on kava's appeal. Americans spent $15m (£10m) on kava in 1996 and twice as much in 1997, with the Nutrition Business Journal projecting sales of almost $50m for 1998. But little or no profit is going back to islanders.

Ms Lasen Diaz said: "The big concern is that the commercial benefits that would accrue from the plant or herbal remedy would only go to the drug company and you end up with the product being licensed back to the countries from where it originates."

Her point was amplified by another recent controversy. One of Africa's oldest tribes, which discovered "Nature's Prozac" thousands of years ago, is set to lose out on a multi-million pound deal to market the remedy worldwide. Sceletium, a rare creeper that grows only in the Cape region of South Africa has been used by the San people since prehistoric times for treatment of depression and alcohol and drug dependence. Tribal leaders criticised the Johannesburg drug company Pharma Natura which is selling the patent rights, resentful that they would not profit from the commercial development of their ancestors' discovery.

"This is the kind of situation we are trying to avoid in the South Pacific by ... raising awareness about the relevant legislation and options to protect the Pacific Islands' biodiversity and associated knowledge of their indigenous communities," Ms Lasen Diaz said.

In 1997, Field established a programme on biodiversity and marine resources to coordinate activities. "We have worked on a range of issues relating to the objectives of the convention on biological diversity: conservation, sustainable use, and benefit sharing. Now 178 countries have joined."

Field lawyers hope their work in building the capacity of developing countries to fight their corner in the World Trade Organisation can help to ensure that communities which have been victims of globalisation may instead benefit from it.

Action on Disability and Development helps disabled people in 12 of the poorest countries by assisting them to form self-help organisations and influencing decision makers to invest more in their needs.

Refuge offers a national lifeline for women suffering domestic violence, providing accommodation and emotional support. Its aim is to help women and their children enjoy a future free from physical and emotional abuse.

Foundation for International Environmental Law and Development provides legal advice on environmental issues, often to smaller countries that cannot afford commercial lawyers, to ensure they are fairly represented at international negotiations and conferences.

The Place 2 Be sends specialist counsellors into primary schools to offer emotional and therapeutic support to children who are troubled, unhappy and confused.

webTitle: In brief: Toronto critics honour Crouching Tiger as year's best film

fields.headline: Toronto critics honour Crouching Tiger as year's best film
fields.standfirst: Plus: Ang Lee keen to take on Hollywood musical; Kevin Costner pays Russian soldier for saving the world; Spider-Man cast now complete; Catherine Zeta-Jones puts Mumbles on the map
fields.trailText: Plus: Ang Lee keen to take on Hollywood musical; Kevin Costner pays Russian soldier for saving the world; Spider-Man cast now complete; Catherine Zeta-Jones puts Mumbles on the map
fields.body:
 Ang Lee's martial art-house movie Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon(pictured) was last night named as the best film of 2000 by the Toronto Film Critics Association. The Canadian award further muddies the waters in the run up to Oscar night, arriving hot on the heels of rival award triumphs by Steven Soderbergh's Traffic (from the New York critics), the coming-of-age rock movie Almost Famous (the Boston critics) and Ridley Scott's Gladiator (the Broadcast awards). With no apparent consensus on the year's most significant movie, expect the 2001 Academy Awards to throw up a few surprises.

 As he waits to see whether his film will connect with the Academy voters, Crouching Tiger director Ang Lee is mulling over his next move. Having dabbled in British high society with Sense and Sensibility, Nixon-era angst in The Ice Storm and American Civil War strife in Ride With the Devil, Lee appears likely to try his hand at a big-style Hollywood musical next. In an interview with Wednesday's Washington Post, the director confessed that he wants to: "Work in the [Hollywood] system, see how it takes. I'm curious. I might do a singing movie in New York. But I have to use the genre to tell a personal story. That's important for me. I hope my career can be like a long film school."

 Having researched the Cuban missile crisis in preparation for his role in the thriller, Thirteen Days, Kevin Costner identified one of the crisis's unsung heroes - and sent the man a cheque. According to Costner, the true hero of the day was a lowly Russian soldier who turned the world back from the brink of nuclear catastrophe. These days the retired soldier survives on a scant state pension. "He lives off of $50 a month, so I'm sending him $500," said the millionaire actor. "That should last him a few years by that standard." $500 for saving the planet? Sounds like Costner has got himself a bargain.

 The final pieces of the Spider-Man jigsaw have been filled with the casting of a trio of supporting actors, Cliff Robertson, Rosemary Harris and JK Simmons. Robertson and Harris will appear as Uncle Ben and Aunt May, the gentle guardians of the youthful Peter Parker (who, unbeknown to them, is also Spider-Man). Simmons takes on a more meaty role as the cigar-chomping J Jonah Jameson, irascible editor of the New York newspaper where Parker works. They join Tobey Maguire (as Spiderman), Kirsten Dunst (as love-interest Mary Jane Watson) and Willem Dafoe (as the Green Goblin). The film begins shooting next month.

 Catherine Zeta-Jones is to be honoured by her home town when she becomes the first person ever to receive the freedom of Mumbles, a village near Swansea. John Pickard, clerk of Mumbles Community Council, told the Sun newspaper that, "Before her wedding to Michael Douglas not many people had heard of Mumbles. But that's history now." Thanks to Zeta-Jones' marriage, the world now rings with Mumbles.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Visa rip-offs revisited

Dark warnings from a London reader who, for reasons that will become clear, requires to remain anonymous. He has noticed advertisements in the national press for a company called Visaplus which promises to help customers obtain a US visa and a job out there for a fee of several thousand pounds. It is, he fears, a reinvention of a previous company called First Point International which, he says, ripped him and numerous others off a year ago.

"They charged £3,000 for their relocation service, which I was to pay in installments, but I refused to pay any more after receiving no service from them and having been sent to New York for non-existent interviews," he says. "They tried to sue me, I countersued and they ended up offering to withdraw if I agreed to a vow of silence. I reluctantly agreed, but I still lost £1,000 and a wasted fare to New York."

 Ominously, attempts to access the First Point's website transfer one straight to Visaplus's own site and the contact address for the two companies is one and the same. Moreover, the directors of Visaplus are John Gillespie, formerly sales director of First Point, and Graham Copsey, who is also director of First Point International's finance arm, First Point Finance (Europe) Ltd.

A trawl of Companies House and trading standards records reveals that First Point International was complusorily liquidated in July after its chief, David Webster, was arrested in the US on $1m bail for allegedly failing to disclose his criminal record on his own visa application and encouraging illegal entry to the US.

Among the clients who lost out were 200 British lorry drivers who had paid First Point up to £5,000 each to secure work in the US. Cospey, however, insists that Visaplus has nothing to do with First Point International, although he admits that he was a "manager" with the latter as well as director of First Point Finance.

"I had no idea what was going on there," he says. "I was in a different department." He claims that Visaplus was incorporated at the request of First Point's bankers, who "were anxious to secure continuity of service to First Point clients". But he's oddly reluctant to reveal the identity of the bank. It turns out to be NatWest, which insists that, on the contrary, it was Cospey who had approached it with the venture. Copsey's protests that he is a separate enterprise from First Point would be more convincing if his website wasn't linked to the latter's.

"We've been trying to get a webmaster to sort this out," he laments. "It's because we purchased First Point's premises off the liquidator and inherited the same lines." As for the hundreds clients left out of pocket by First Point, "the contracts stated that there was no guarantee they'd get a visa. They didn't read their contract. At Visaplus, however, we only take on people who will definitely qualify for a visa."

Westminster trading standards, which has been investigating First Point International, remains to be persuaded. "There are still no guarantees because clients have to pay up as soon as the visa is 'in process', not when they actually receive it," says a spokeswoman.

Moreover, First Point clients who had yet to pay for a service that never materialised when First Point was wound up have been sent letters by Visaplus informing them that their contracts have been taken over by the company and that their payments via Copsey's First Point Finance should continue. Those who had already paid up, on the other hand, have been told there's nothing that can be done for them.

Copsey admits that First Point customers who do continue to pay up have no contractual agreement with Visaplus and therefore no guarantees of service. "We're just trying to do people a favour, otherwise they'd be left in the lurch, but it seems to be backfiring on us," he says. "We're very ethical, you see. We're not First Point and, God Almighty, the comparison is driving us mad." The Department of Trade and Industry is currently investigating Visaplus.

Unprotected homes

Richard Anderson of Glasgow has recently bought a new house from Beazer Homes. Before moving in he inspected it and identified several faults, ranging from wonky door hinges to a faulty shower, but none had been dealt with by the time he moved in. "I have written to and phoned Beazer customer services, but can't get the work carried out satisfactorily," he says.

 A month after Consumer jogs Beazer's memory it remembers to reply. "Mr Anderson has had some snagging problems which needed to be completed," says a spokesman. "Each issue will be completed shortly." If the purchase had been a car or a stereo Anderson would, of course, have been protected by his statutory rights but, unbelievably, property, the biggest investment most of us ever make, is not covered by the Sale of Goods Act.

"You are extraordinarily unprotected when you buy a new home," says a spokesman for the Institute of Trading Standards. "Even the National House-Building Council guarantee which accompanies new homes is non-statutory and doesn't cover anything like the extent of the act."

Problems with gas

David Lucas of Derbyshire thought he would do his bit for the envirnoment by buying a new Vauxhall Astra which would run on the newly available liquid petroleum gas. Alas, when he took his new purchase abroad he discovered that his petrol tank could not accommodate continental petrol dispensers. "We were told that the same fitting was used throughout Europe, but not in Britain," he says. Vauxhall duly sent him an adaptor, but it turned out to be the wrong kind. Two months later he was still chasing Vauxhall, who seemed to have no idea how to lay its hands on the device.

 It gets worse. Vauxhall explains to Consumer that adaptors do vary across Europe. In Britain, Holland and Poland, it's a Dutch bayonet you'll be needing - while the French, Germans and others prefer an acme thread. That would be of little use in Italy, Portugal, Greece and Spain, however, where the dish coupling reigns supreme. The only hope for green-minded travellers is a standard model developed by the European LPG Association which with luck will be ratified in June 2002. In the meantime, filling stations are supposed to provide the appropriate adaptor on request. Vauxhall has now given Lucas one of these varieties and told him how to get hold of the others.

No sewer, lower rates

On the subject of green consciences, Alan Marshall was astonished to be told that he should have reduced water rates because the rainwater from his roof runs into a ground sump, not the main sewer. "No one informed us of this until we decided to go on to a water meter," says Marshall. "It seems to me that a lot of people will be unaware of this saving."

 In fact, last year's Water Industry Act required companies to point this fact out to customers although few seem to have got round to it. "You can certainly get a reduction in your rates if you can show that you're not using that part of the company's service," says a spokesman for the industry regulator Water UK.

 Write to us at 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com.

Cospey, however, insists that Visaplus has nothing to do with First Point International, although he admits that he was a "manager" with the latter as well as director of First Point Finance. "I had no idea what was going on there," he says. "I was in a different department." He claims that Visaplus was incorporated at the request of First Point's bankers, who "were anxious to secure continuity of service to First Point clients". But he's oddly reluctant to reveal the identity of the bank. It turns out to be NatWest, which insists that, on the contrary, it was Cospey who had approached it with the venture. Copsey's protests that he is a separate enterprise from First Point would be more convincing if his website wasn't linked to the latter's. "We've been trying to get a webmaster to sort this out," he laments. "It's because we purchased First Point's premises off the liquidator and inherited the same lines." As for the hundreds clients left out of pocket by First Point, "the contracts stated that there was no guarantee they'd get a visa. They didn't read their contract. At Visaplus, however, we only take on people who will definitely qualify for a visa." Westminster trading standards, which has been investigating First Point International, remains to be persuaded. "There are still no guarantees because clients have to pay up as soon as the visa is 'in process', not when they actually receive it," says a spokeswoman. Moreover, First Point clients who had yet to pay for a service that never materialised when First Point was wound up have been sent letters by Visaplus informing them that their contracts have been taken over by the company and that their payments via Copsey's First Point Finance should continue. Those who had already paid up, on the other hand, have been told there's nothing that can be done for them. Copsey admits that First Point customers who do continue to pay up have no contractual agreement with Visaplus and therefore no guarantees of service. "We're just trying to do people a favour, otherwise they'd be left in the lurch, but it seems to be backfiring on us," he says. "We're very ethical, you see. We're not First Point and, God Almighty, the comparison is driving us mad." The Department of Trade and Industry is currently investigating Visaplus. Unprotected homes Richard Anderson of Glasgow has recently bought a new house from Beazer Homes. Before moving in he inspected it and identified several faults, ranging from wonky door hinges to a faulty shower, but none had been dealt with by the time he moved in. "I have written to and phoned Beazer customer services, but can't get the work carried out satisfactorily," he says.  A month after Consumer jogs Beazer's memory it remembers to reply. "Mr Anderson has had some snagging problems which needed to be completed," says a spokesman. "Each issue will be completed shortly." If the purchase had been a car or a stereo Anderson would, of course, have been protected by his statutory rights but, unbelievably, property, the biggest investment most of us ever make, is not covered by the Sale of Goods Act. "You are extraordinarily unprotected when you buy a new home," says a spokesman for the Institute of Trading Standards. "Even the National House-Building Council guarantee which accompanies new homes is non-statutory and doesn't cover anything like the extent of the act." Problems with gas David Lucas of Derbyshire thought he would do his bit for the envirnoment by buying a new Vauxhall Astra which would run on the newly available liquid petroleum gas. Alas, when he took his new purchase abroad he discovered that his petrol tank could not accommodate continental petrol dispensers. "We were told that the same fitting was used throughout Europe, but not in Britain," he says. Vauxhall duly sent him an adaptor, but it turned out to be the wrong kind. Two months later he was still chasing Vauxhall, who seemed to have no idea how to lay its hands on the device.  It gets worse. Vauxhall explains to Consumer that adaptors do vary across Europe. In Britain, Holland and Poland, it's a Dutch bayonet you'll be needing - while the French, Germans and others prefer an acme thread. That would be of little use in Italy, Portugal, Greece and Spain, however, where the dish coupling reigns supreme. The only hope for green-minded travellers is a standard model developed by the European LPG Association which with luck will be ratified in June 2002. In the meantime, filling stations are supposed to provide the appropriate adaptor on request. Vauxhall has now given Lucas one of these varieties and told him how to get hold of the others. No sewer, lower rates On the subject of green consciences, Alan Marshall was astonished to be told that he should have reduced water rates because the rainwater from his roof runs into a ground sump, not the main sewer. "No one informed us of this until we decided to go on to a water meter," says Marshall. "It seems to me that a lot of people will be unaware of this saving."  In fact, last year's Water Industry Act required companies to point this fact out to customers although few seem to have got round to it. "You can certainly get a reduction in your rates if you can show that you're not using that part of the company's service," says a spokesman for the industry regulator Water UK.  Write to us at 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com.

webTitle: MPs thrown off the trail by lack of common scents

fields.headline: MPs thrown off the trail by lack of common scents
fields.trailText: Outside the Commons, countryside protesters were screaming and yelling and blocking the Christmas traffic. Why, I wondered, do people with strong feelings think they can convert waverers to their cause by behaving as objectionably as possible?
fields.body:
Outside the Commons, countryside protesters were screaming and yelling and blocking the Christmas traffic. Why, I wondered, do people with strong feelings think they can convert waverers to their cause by behaving as objectionably as possible?

Inside, Jack Straw was cautious. The bill offered three options; he supported the middle way, the compromise, the one that allows foxes a free vote on whether they wish to be killed. Or something on those lines.

Edward Leigh wondered if, since the Scottish parliament can make up its own mind on the subject, Scots MPs should abstain. Mr Straw replied with magnificent sophistry. The Scottish parliament had been set up by the Commons, and so was subordinate. The case was closed. Meaningless? Of course. It was that great political achievement, resonant bollocks. Jesuits would pay millions for talent like that.

Denis MacShane pointed out that during the Peninsular war the Duke of Wellington had hunted every Friday - though there were no foxes in Spain. Couldn't the Tories do the same? That was historical bollocks.

Mr Straw hoped that the house would not confuse things by voting in favour of all three options. "That would be a dog's breakfast," he said mildly - a bowl of fox's bollocks perhaps.

He snuffled on for half an hour like a hound who is in danger of losing the scent but doesn't really care.

David Lidington, the Tory spokesman (his boss, Ann Widdecombe, is ferociously anti-hunting) was opposed to "lamping", which means blinding foxes with lights, then shooting them with high-powered rifles. It could be dangerous to humans, he said, and he's right: for centuries amorous swains and sportive maids have regarded the countryside at night as one huge knocking shop.

Mike Foster, the MP who first moved a ban three years ago, was pinned down on his own sport, fishing. Wasn't that cruel to the fish?

"I do not go fishing with a pack of dogs," he said. Eh? Was anyone on either side going to deploy any logic here?

John Major, who knows a bit about being hunted to destruction, defended it for animals. "All violent death is distasteful, unless the fox dies in comfort, surrounded by his friends, and mourned by the neighbouring chickens." Mr Major uses sarcasm like a pugil stick on Gladiators, designed to unbalance rather than to wound.

Then the debate began to become truly bonkers, the landscape strewn with bollocks. Geoffrey Clifton-Brown solemnly warned: "There is a danger animals might be arrested." Tony Banks said pro-hunters were "the political descendants of slavers and people who sent little boys up chimneys".

"Grow up!" shouted furious Tories. "It's about human pleasure, it's about the chase, the bloodlust and the kill!" he yelled, and I swear I heard a rousing cry of "Bollocks!"

Then Michael Heseltine produced a fabulous rant, 10 minutes of the noise you hear at a speedway without the relief of the Doppler effect. When Mr Banks went fishing, he asked, "does he pat the fish on the head, throw it back, and say 'Do your best to survive, after I have taken the guts out of you'?" Was this really the most important issue facing the nation? Of course not! The bill existed purely in the narrow class interests of the Labour party.

At this, Labour's Ronnie Campbell was reproved for saying something roughly similar to "bollocks", but nothing would slow Hezza down. "His backside is pretty eloquent!" he raved.

And this is not the real debate on the three options: that's next year. I may need to flee the country, possibly to comfort Sir Richard Branson on his tropical paradise.

webTitle: Expansion on hold as Salon.com cuts back

fields.headline: Expansion on hold as Salon.com cuts back
fields.trailText: 11am: Online newspaper Salon.com has cut 25 jobs and shelved its UK launch, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
US-based online newspaper Salon.com is feeling the pinch and has announced a series of cost-cutting initiatives.

Twenty-five jobs - 20% of its workforce - will go and expansion plans, including Salon's mooted entry into the UK, have been shelved.

The five-year-old site said the cuts were necessary in order to lower operating expenses and reach profitability.

"This was a difficult decision because it involves talented people who have worked very hard to make Salon a success," said Michael O'Donnell, Salon chief executive officer.

Andrew Ross, a co-founder of Salon.com and the man who was charged with UK and European expansion, has resigned from the company.

The cutbacks come despite Salon announcing that November was its busiest month yet, with more than 50m page impressions recorded.

Meanwhile, US music website Farmclub.com, owned by Universal Music, has laid off 15% of its workforce - some 17 people.

webTitle: Tory health spokesman apologises for racist joke

fields.headline: Tory health spokesman apologises for racist joke
fields.trailText: The race row engulfing the Tories intensified last night after shadow health spokesman Liam Fox was forced to apologise for telling a joke that was both racist and sexist.
fields.body:
The race row engulfing the Tories intensified last night after shadow health spokesman Liam Fox was forced to apologise for telling a joke that was both racist and sexist.

Dr Fox, an increasingly prominent frontbencher, was told to apologise by William Hague's office after the joke, told at a Christmas party, found its way into the Guardian's Diary column.

Conservative central office stressed that Mr Hague had not demanded the apology, but the fact it was pushed for hints at the Tories' sensitivity over allegations that they are willing to play the race card.

At the party, held on Monday night by his colleague, the shadow foreign secretary Francis Maude, Dr Fox asked fellow guests: "What do you call three dogs and a blackbird?" Receiving no response, he supplied the answer: "The Spice Girls."

Yesterday he issued a statement apologising for the joke, which he repeated at the party and uttered in the presence of journalists.

"In repeating a widely circulated joke, I very much regret if anyone was offended," the statement read. "I naturally apologise if any offence was caused."

Last night, Dr Fox was unavailable for comment, and an aide said he did not know if the apology amounted to an admission that the joke was sexist and racist.

The apology came just days after Dr Fox's leader, Mr Hague, sparked the current race storm when he claimed that Sir William Macpherson's description of the Metropolitan police as "institutionally racist" had led to a decline in morale among officers.

While the Tory leader rejected claims that he was playing the race card as "truly disgusting and disgraceful", his comments drew fierce criticism. Bill Morris, the transport union leader, likened Mr Hague's stance to Enoch Powell's "rivers of blood" speech in 1968, and dismay was expressed by Steven Norris, the Conservative party vice-chairman who has been outspoken in support of racial and sexual inclusivity.

Gurbux Singh, chair of the commission for racial equality, has warned Mr Hague against "throwing away" the good race relations built up in Britain, while the bishop of Southwark, Tom Butler, has turned on him for making political capital out of the Macpherson report.

fields.headline: Once more Inter the breach
fields.standfirst: Football Italia's expert on the sorry state of Internazionale and the Rome derby
fields.trailText: So, farewell then, Roberto Keane. The Irishman is off on loan from Inter to Leeds, and there he'll probably stay. Probably it's for the best.
fields.body:
So, farewell then, Roberto Keane. The Irishman is off on loan from Inter to Leeds, and there he'll probably stay. Probably it's for the best.

As it happens, I had the opportunity last weekend to witness what would have been Robbie's last game for the club, had the manager bothered to call him up for it. At the San Siro, Inter were taking on minuscule neighbours Brescia - who bizarrely now rank as their relegation rivals. Inter escaped defeat when Baggio's back-heeled Brescia goal was ruled out for offside, but the 0-0 draw still left them in deep trouble, just three points from Serie A's relegation zone.

Now, in all of Serie A's long history, there are only two sides that have never tasted the bitter sweetness of going down, as the French like to call it. One is Juventus, the other is Inter. Chances are they won't slip under this year either, even without Keane - but things are set to get much worse. Consider: in Inter's next four fixtures, they face revelations Atalanta, Parma, Lazio and the derby with AC Milan. Thus by the end of January the smart money is on them being actually in - gasp! - the bottom four.

"My first task," Inter's latest manager Marco Tardelli had announced in more innocent times, "is restoring serenity to this team." After two months in the job though, things are tenser than ever. Last Thursday, the team bus was attacked with a Molotov cocktail as it arrived at the San Siro. Thankfully no-one was hurt - but had the ordinance broken through the bus window it would have been a very different story. The players' association - the union, not the Seventies disco outfit - have announced that all Serie A matches this weekend will kick off 15 minutes late in protest at the violence. Sadly, that'll hardly stop Inter driving their fans to the flaming bottle.

Let's recap: apart from their antics in the league so far, Inter have crashed out of the Champions League, losing in the preliminaries to the mighty Swedish carpenters of Helsingborg. In the Italian Cup, they exited courtesy of a 6-1 humiliation at Parma.

How is this possible? Two reasons. Firstly, the Inter squad is overpriced and overrated - Keane wasn't the only player they spent over the odds on. Secondly, they keep panicking. With old rivals Juventus and Milan pretty much divvying up the silverware over the last decade, Inter want success right now, if not sooner. Hence the club's endless revolutions, and hence their permanent position back at square one. This season, club president Massimo Moratti has already fired manager Marcello Lippi - and come January, Keane's departure will likely be just the start of yet another major shake-up. (There's even talk of bringing over the 34-year-old Brazilian Romario, which frankly is all Inter need.)

Meanwhile, after the excitements at the San Siro last weekend it was off to the capital for the Rome derby. Here was a classic Italian match - racist fans, a threadbare pitch and some of the world's finest players. Roma won 1-0 and were thus toasted by their tifosi (without the aid of molotovs).

As anyone though who's visited a Roman derby or two will tell you, what happens on the pitch is only part of the story. Since for years this game was (a) of little consequence to anyone outside of Rome, and (b) pretty dull for Romans too, the clash between the two sets of supporters has become almost as important as the match itself.

Each fixture is preceded by an hour of choreographed displays of flags and banners aimed at provoking the opposition. Great store is set on discovering the rival slogans in advance. A few years back the Romanisti proudly unveiled a giant banner reading: "Roma! Above you there's only the Sky." "Yes, and it's blue & white!" came the rapid riposte raised at the other end. (Lazio's colours readers - do try and keep up.)

Perhaps it was the importance of this year's fixture - Roma six points clear in the lead, Lazio struggling - but Sunday's slogans weren't quite so memorable. With a bemused Leonardo di Caprio and Cameron Diaz watching in the VIP box, Lazio's entire end donned coloured t-shirts to depict the shield of the Scudetto. "Your Dreams, Our Reality" was the message. Then came the stinger: "Roma, You Have a Team of Eleven Blacks." As fate would have it, Lazio subsequently lost 1-0 thanks to a deflection from their own Paolo Negro - sweet irony.

A final thought. Inter will be having their derby first game back after Christmas. Lord knows what abuse they'll receive, probably from both sets of supporters. Keane will probably miss this world about as much as it'll miss him.

webTitle: £58,000 for choir head hounded from job

fields.headline: £58,000 for choir head hounded from job
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A choir school headmistress was awarded £58,000 damages yesterday after being hounded from her job by a parents' campaign which was "riddled with sexism from top to bottom".
fields.body:
A choir school headmistress was awarded £58,000 damages yesterday after being hounded from her job by a parents' campaign which was "riddled with sexism from top to bottom".

The bill will cause fresh financial problems for the prep school at Ripon Cathedral in North Yorkshire, where some parents threatened a crippling withdrawal of pupils at the prospect of a woman in charge.

Susan Cave, 43, an experienced independent school head, was sacked last summer before she had even taken up the post at the school where pupil fees are £8,000 a year. Her dismissal split the nine governors and four of them, including the Marquess of Zetland and the Dean of Ripon, the Very Rev John Methuen, resigned in protest.

The dean gave evidence at the industrial tribunal in Leeds, whose chairman, Colin Grazin, ruled last night that Mrs Cave had been sexually discriminated against, and also treated less fairly than she would have been if she were single. One of the parents' complaints against her was that the law firm of her husband - Jeremy Cave, one of North Yorkshire's coroners - had been suspended by the Law Society for alleged overcharging.

Parents denied that Mrs Cave's gender had ever been an issue but admitted in evidence to the tribunal that her husband's problems had caused concern, and fears that the school's reputation could be threatened.

The hearing was also told of claims of "betrayal and deeply unprofessional conduct" by some of the 13 staff at the school, who circulated a questionnaire about their attitudes to having Mrs Cave as head.

Mrs Cave hugged the former chairman of the choir school's governors, Canon Michael Glanville-Smith, after the hearing and said: "I'm sorry that these proceedings had to be brought. I would have been very happy to have settled my loss of earnings without the need for a tribunal case.

fields.headline: Student debt 'getting out of control'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Student debt is spiralling out of control, student leaders warned yesterday, as new government-funded research revealed that the vast majority of those on degree courses were in serious financial difficulties.
fields.body:
Student debt is spiralling out of control, student leaders warned yesterday, as new government-funded research revealed that the vast majority of those on degree courses were in serious financial difficulties.

Not only were students borrowing more money than ever before from banks and credit card companies, the research showed, but prospective undergraduates were also being deterred from applying to university because of fears about being saddled with debt.

Opposition MPs claimed the findings proved the government's higher education policies - including the controversial introduction of tuition fees - were in disarray, and criticised ministers for putting a "positive spin" on them.

The research into student finances is carried out by the Department for Education every three years, and was commissioned this time from Claire Callender of South Bank University and NOP Research.

The survey, based on personal interviews with 2,800 students on degree courses in the 1998-99 academic year, showed that student debts had trebled since 1995-96 when the last research took place. Nearly nine out of 10 students faced financial difficulties, while nearly two-thirds of respondents said a member of their peer group had opted not to go into higher education because of worries about debt.

In the three years of the study, between 1996 and 1999, student expenditure rose above the rate of inflation, fuelled by a 66 % increase in money borrowed from banks and credit card companies, in addition to official student loans.

The average student debt was £2,473, compared with £777 three years earlier.

The research covered the 1998-99 academic year, a transitional period involving the first students affected by the Labour government's introduction of tuition fees.

Since 1995-96 younger students have experienced a drop of 30% in grant income and a fall of 17% in regular parental contributions.

Students are also supplementing their income by taking on more paid work, and using up more of their savings to fund their university education.

Owain James, president of the National Union of Students, warned: "The DfEE's own survey is a damning indictment of the government's student funding system."

He added: "These figures show that student hardship is widespread."

Higher education minister Tessa Blackstone said in a statement: "The survey evidence confirms that the great majority of full time students are taking our new fairer income loans, which are interest free in real terms with repayment linked to income."

Evan Harris, the Liberal Democrat higher education spokesman, said that the survey was a condemnation of the government's policy on students.

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, said: "No one should be deceived by this outrageous example of Labour spin."

£5,100 to pay back and not enough money

Gemma Cantelo, 21, knows only too well the burden of debt facing graduates when they leave university. Gemma graduated last year and has a £3,100 student loan to pay off. She pays £10 a month interest on that.

She also has a £2,000 overdraft which she ran up with her bank, as she had to borrow more money to live on during her three year history and philosophy course at Cardiff University.

Because she earns less than £16,000 a year as a trainee librarian, she cannot afford to start paying off the loan until next year. She received a three quarter grant from her local authority and her parents topped up the remaining quarter.

Gemma was determined to finish her course. One of her friends, a chemistry undergraduate dropped out of his course in the first year because he could not afford to continue. Another friend dropped out five years ago with the intention of returning after he had paid off his loan but so far has been unable to find the funds to return to his course.

Gemma gained an upper second and is keen to take a masters degree in information sciences but cannot afford to return to university.

She said: "I think university was a worthwhile experience and my parents encouraged me to go as they are both graduates. But I think it is ridiculous that we are left facing this huge debt when we leave. I try not to think about how much I owe as it keeps me awake at night just worrying about how I am going to pay it off.

"I cannot borrow any more money because I am up to my overdraft limit. My parents are now having to find both grant money and tuition fees for my younger sister who is at university.

"With my starting salary there's little chance of me starting to pay off the loan at the moment and I am finding it quite tough affording rent in London.

Gemma, from Canterbury, said that she managed to work during all her holidays but even this failed to make sufficient inroads into paying off the debt. Some of her friends had up to three term-time jobs, working as office cleaners or waitressing, which left precious little time for studying.

webTitle: How the Grinch stole the box office

fields.headline: How the Grinch stole the box office
fields.trailText: Jim Carrey's Christmas caper has become the most successful film of the year at the US box office after only five weeks on release
fields.body:
The Grinch (aka How the Grinch Stole Christmas) has emerged as the most successful film of 2000 in the USA scarcely a month after it went on general release. The latest figures that have been tallied show Universal's Christmas fable trumping its nearest rival, Paramount's Mission: Impossible II, by a slender but decisive margin.

As well as scoring a major victory for Universal, the film is also seen as a vindication for star Jim Carrey whose bankability had started to be questioned after the poor box office performance of his previous two pictures: Man on the Moon and Me, Myself and Irene.

Buried beneath pea-green prosthetics, the actor stars in the title role as a curmudgeonly creature (a sort of cross between Scrooge and Oscar the Grouch) who attempts to sabotage the Christmas of a fairytale township. Despite lukewarm reviews, Ron Howard's film, which marks Hollywood's first stab at the stories of children's author Dr Seuss, has effectively monopolised the Christmas family market on both sides of the Atlantic.

In the 33 days since its US release, The Grinch racked up an astonishing $216.4m (£146.8m), nudging it ahead of the Tom Cruise action thriller, M:I-2, which amassed $215.4m (£146.1m) over a four month period. Other top grossers from the year include The Perfect Storm, Toy Story 2 and X-Men. Due to The Grinch's end of year release date, the film's success looks set to spill over into the first months of the new year. So Carrey could yet wind up with the biggest film of 2001 as well.
