webTitle: Crouching Tiger's Kung fu expert Yuen Wo Ping

fields.headline: Come fly with me
fields.standfirst: Yuen Wo Ping is the man who turned Jackie Chan into a superstar and made Keanu Reeves look like a kung fu expert. He tells  Stuart Husband  about his latest project, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.trailText: Yuen Wo Ping is the man who turned Jackie Chan into a superstar and made Keanu Reeves look like a kung fu expert. He tells Stuart Husband about his latest project, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.
fields.body:
They call him Master Yuen - and so they should. Yuen Wo Ping is widely acknowledged as the world's foremost action choreographer. A veteran of 50 Hong Kong kung fu movies, he is widely credited with catapulting Jackie Chan to international superstardom with his first two films as director, Snake in the Eagle's Shadow (1978) and Drunken Master (1979).

But it is his airborne stunt choreography, known as "wirework", that has brought Wo Ping world renown. Not only does he make you believe a man can fly; he makes you believe he can glide, soar, hover, swoop, and all the other tricks in which birds had previously cornered the market. When you consider that he did all this for Keanu "I know kung fu" Reeves in The Matrix - 55-year-old Yuen's first Hollywood movie - the awesome scale of his achievement becomes apparent.

Yuen takes things a stage further in Ang Lee's remarkable fantasy epic, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, in which Chow Yun-Fat, Michelle Yeoh and newcomer Zhang Ziyi, as crusading 17th-century warriors, do battle across rooftops, over mountains and lakes and, in one remarkable sequence, while swaying in the tops of bamboo trees.

How did you get started in the business?

My family were all involved in Chinese opera, and my father, Simon Yuen HsaioTien, was a movie actor and stuntman. He was my trainer, my own master, if you like. I used to go to movie sets to watch him work and got involved in my own right as a stuntman and background fighter in old-style martial arts movies in the 1950s. In the early days, they always picked me to be the one to die first. I was very good at falling down dead.

How did you get into wirework?

The turnover in movies in Hong Kong is pretty fast, so you get to try out all kinds of different styles. I started off doing period movies, then cop movies with a kung fu flavour, then we went back to swashbuckling heroics, where you have a freer hand with the choreography; you can heighten the swordplay and make it more operatic. I am more into the softer styles, rather than the hard, fast cut-cut-cut of a lot of movies, so I use the wire to bring that out.

How does it work?

The actors have to wear a heavy canvas corset attached by metal cables to a wire, which hoists them 75ft in the air. These are worked by a team of "puppeteers", working in tandem with the opposing actor's team to avoid mid-air collisions. There is no computer trickery involved - the only "special effect" is when we remove the wire in post-production.

Would you say that you are the best wireworker in the world?

That's not for me to say. I've done around 50 movies now, but it would be wrong ethically for anyone in our field to compare themselves. We admire each other's work. There's no jealousy: if someone comes up with a great new movie, it inspires the rest of us to do better next time.

But you did 'make' Jackie Chan?

The movies I did with Jackie put him on the map, but that was mainly because we changed the genre a little by taking some of the grimness out that had been there since Bruce Lee. We made it more slapstick, more fun.

How does training Hollywood actors compare with working with Hong Kong actors?

American actors aren't brought up in the Hong Kong tradition: Jackie Chan or Jet Li will already know how to fight, whereas those in Hollywood have to be trained. For instance, it took four months to teach Keanu Reeves the techniques.

Kung fu has gone mainstream in Hollywood with movies such as Charlie's Angels. How do you account for its popularity?

I don't really understand why this has happened. I think it must be that audiences in the US don't see too many Hong Kong movies, and they're not familiar with this kind of movement. And when they do see it, they love it, and they want more of it.

Purists argue that the art of kung fu is being devalued because the likes of Keanu and Drew Barrymore claim they 'know kung fu' after a few months of training. Do you think this is the case?

I didn't work on Charlie's Angels, but I know that Drew trained for five months. But I wouldn't call it devaluation; it's just a different way of working. You tailor-make the movement to the physicality and flexibility of the actor or actress. You can't compare Drew or Keanu to, say, Jet Li, or Jackie. There's a huge difference there in terms of movement, and I think everyone realises that.

Have CGI and new technology changed the way you work?

The major difference is that they have extended the boundaries of what is possible. I can do movements now that couldn't be done before. There has also been a transformation from the short cut to the longer take, so you can see more of the movement in a single shot. In Crouching Tiger, when they start flying over the rooftops, you can watch their movements in single takes. The technique was probably tailor-made for this project. So maybe "evolve" is a better word. As for CGI, I never use it.

Have you done things in Crouching Tiger you've never done before?

The main difference was that I had a lot of time to prepare, which you don't normally get in Hong Kong, where everything is so rushed, so I was able to work with the difficulties of the movement on the wire, and work out how to extend the movements over the rooftops and in the bamboo forest. When I first started in films like Iron Monkey, I wanted the martial arts to be very down to earth. That's a more practical and realistic approach.

But in Crouching Tiger, I was trying to express the more magical characteristics of old-fashioned wu xia ["martial chivalry", a genre akin to sword and sorcery]. I still tried to incorporate some realistic touches, though. You might notice that they fly through the air, but for every leap they make they come back down to earth at some point. I knew that working with Ang Lee would bring out some incredible chemistry. He has strong ideas and I'm a great admirer of that.

How did you shoot the bamboo forest scene?

It was probably the hardest scene I've ever done, mainly because it was location work instead of studio work, so you couldn't put the usual precautions in place. You have to work out where to peg the wires in, try and find a supportive enough spot for the crane ... it's precision working. I usually have a team of 15, but for that scene it went up to about 40. If I'd had more time I'd have made it better.

How long would, say, the first swordfight scene take to shoot?

Ang Lee would tell me his requirements and I'd choreograph the scene in the studio. From conception to training to shooting, the whole thing would probably take about a week.

Are the actors ever spooked by the things they're asked to do?

It is normal to be scared of heights, of course, but we have very specific safety demonstrations to try and make the actors feel comfortable; safety is our first priority. If I'm not 100% focused every second, someone could end up dead. I'll work on the movement until I'm satisfied, and only then will I get the actor or actress involved. Crouching Tiger was only Zhang Ziyi's second movie, I think, but she'd been training with a coach for some months. Michelle Yeoh was already experienced in all kinds of movement. The biggest surprise for me was Chow Yun-Fat. He'd maybe only done one or two action films before, and it was his first time with wirework, but I was amazed. His movement was great. Maybe he saw a lot of Hong Kong movies beforehand.

Do you think you've advanced the art form in Crouching Tiger?

Again, it's not for me to say. It's a kind of trial, this movie. It's very nuanced, so it looks very different, and I tried to improvise a lot more on the wire, so hopefully it looks more artistic. Whether it's a "new way" or not is probably up to the future to decide. Basically on every project I just do the best I can. The director and actors are the stars, not me. If the market likes what I do, the boss will be happy. But even if it doesn't do so well, I know I've worked to the best of my ability.

 Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is released on January 5.

fields.headline: Tory apologises for racist joke
fields.trailText: The race row engulfing the Tories intensified last night after a shadow cabinet minister was forced to apologise for telling a joke that was both racist and sexist reports Sarah Hall
fields.body:
The race row engulfing the Tories intensified last night after a shadow cabinet minister was forced to apologise for telling a joke that was both racist and sexist.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary and an increasingly prominent frontbencher, was told to apologise by William Hague's office after the joke, told at a Christmas party, found its way into the Guardian's Diary column.

Conservative central office stressed that Mr Hague had not demanded the apology, but the fact it was pushed for hints at the Tories' sensitivity over allegations that they are willing to play the race card.

At the party, held on Monday night by his colleague, the shadow foreign secretary Francis Maude, Dr Fox asked fellow guests: "What do you call three dogs and a blackbird?" Receiving no response, he supplied the answer: "The Spice Girls."

Yesterday he issued a statement apologising for the joke, which he repeated at the party and uttered in the presence of journalists.

"In repeating a widely circulated joke, I very much regret if anyone was offended," the statement read. "I naturally apologise if any offence was caused."

Last night, Dr Fox was unavailable for comment, and an aide said he did not know if the apology amounted to an admission that the joke was sexist and racist.

The apology came just days after Dr Fox's leader, Mr Hague, sparked the current race storm when he claimed that Sir William Macpherson's description of the Metropolitan police as "institutionally racist" had led to a decline in morale among officers.

While the Tory leader rejected claims that he was playing the race card as "truly disgusting and disgraceful", his comments drew fierce criticism. Bill Morris, the transport union leader, likened Mr Hague's stance to Enoch Powell's "rivers of blood" speech in 1968, and dismay was expressed by Steven Norris, the Conservative party vice-chairman who has been outspoken in support of racial and sexual inclusivity.

Gurbux Singh, chair of the commission for racial equality, has warned Mr Hague against "throwing away" the good race relations built up in Britain, while the bishop of Southwark, Tom Butler, has turned on him for making political capital out of the Macpherson report.

fields.headline: Scotland unveils new care regulations
fields.trailText: New measures to improve the protection of children and vulnerable adults were unveiled by the Scottish Executive today when the regulation of care bill was laid before the Scottish Parliament. David Mitchell reports
fields.body:
New measures to improve the protection of children and vulnerable adults were unveiled by the Scottish Executive today when the regulation of care bill was laid before the Scottish Parliament.

The bill will establish two new independent bodies - the Scottish commission for the regulation of care, which will regulate care services, and the Scottish social services council, which will regulate the workforce.

The Scottish commission for the regulation of care, which is due to come into force in April 2002, will regulate all care services, including early education services, and seek to improve the quality of services.

The Scottish social services council, which is due to come into force in October 2001, will set up registers of particular groups of staff, publish codes of conduct and practice for workers and employers, and regulate the education and training of social workers.

The first phase of registration will include all qualified social workers, staff in residential child care, heads of residential care homes, heads of adult day care services and registration and inspection staff. In the second phase, all staff in adult residential care and in early education and childcare services will be registered.

Malcolm Chisholm, deputy minister for health and community care, said: "The bill is an important step forward in safeguarding the interests of Scotland's most vulnerable, including children and older people.

"We want high quality care services, focused on the needs of users. Regulation plays an important part in ensuring that good services are available to all and that a system is in place to address any shortcomings.

"I am confident that the new national, independent system of care regulation which the bill introduces will be flexible, and focused on the needs of service users and their families. It will provide better protection for our older people, children and young people, and it will ensure that those delivering services are well trained and motivated."

Social work directors have welcomed the bill as a major step forward.

"We now want to see the reality of these new arrangements focus on quality and the interests of users and carers. That is the test - they have got to be at least as good as they are now, and in some cases certainly a lot better," said Carole Wilkinson, vice-president of the Association of Directors of Social Work.

Ms Wilkinson said the Scottish Executive has listened to concerns about which groups of staff should be registered and widened the initial scope of the Scottish social services council to include extra groups, with a promise to extend the list as soon as is practical.

"We felt the register should be as inclusive as possible. Now we want to see a timetable for the remaining groups of staff, such as care assistants, home helps, day care workers and supported accommodation workers, who deliver the vast bulk of care services," she said.

The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) welcomed the drive to modernise care regulation, but said there were a number of areas where changes should be made to improve the protection and welfare of service users.

"One area we are currently discussing with the Scottish Executive is whether it is sensible to have two new bodies - the Scottish commission for the regulation of care and the Scottish social services council - rather than a single body with overall responsibilities," said social work spokeswoman Rita Miller.

"By their nature, these two bodies will need to have close links. Yet they will require separate management and support structures. Given wider concerns about the number and role of non-departmental public bodies, Cosla would want to make sure this gives best value," she said.

Cosla is also concerned that there is nothing in the bill which will ensure the continuing involvement of local advisory committees in inspection and registration services.

"Our experience is that advisory committees have provided users, carers, service providers and local elected members with an opportunity to positively contribute from a local perspective. This significant and valuable role will be lost if similar arrangements are not made in the future," said Ms Miller.

Community Care Providers Scotland, which represents voluntary care providers, said the bill would go a long way towards addressing some of their fundamental concerns about the regulatory system by making it entirely independent and introducing an even-handed approach to all care providers.

Development coordinator Annie Gunner said: "We will be monitoring the progress of the legislation carefully. One of our key concerns will be to ensure that the interests of voluntary and charitable organisations are fully taken into account as the proposals are taken forward. We need to make sure the financial burdens of implementing the new system do not fall disproportionately on the voluntary sector."

webTitle: Patients forum plan to head off revolt

fields.headline: Patients forum plan to head off revolt
fields.trailText: The government will today try to head off a Labour backbench revolt against a key plank of its NHS reforms by publishing legislation giving patients a stronger say in the way hospitals and GP services are run reports John Carvel
fields.body:
The government will today try to head off a Labour backbench revolt against a key plank of its NHS reforms by publishing legislation giving patients a stronger say in the way hospitals and GP services are run.

The NHS and social care bill will establish 800 patient forums in England with statutory powers to oversee all aspects of health provision - from GP surgeries to nursing homes - and hold managers to account. Local authorities will be able to scrutinise NHS performance and also appeal against hospital closures and altered family doctor services.

A Whitehall source last night said it amounted to "a revolution in genuine patient power". The proposals follow growing unrest about the plan to abolish the 99 community health councils (CHCs), which monitor health authorities and pursue patient complaints.

More than 90 Labour MPs had signed a Commons motion calling for "a robust debate" on CHCs, and several groups, including the Law Society, British Medical Association, Co-operative party, and the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux, had expressed concern about their abolition.

Opponents of the change said the forums might be just toothless focus groups, and there was concern that the patient advocate and liaison service could not fight well for patients if staff were employed by NHS bodies receiving complaints.

The row had threatened to undermine the government's attempt to present its NHS reforms as a flagship policy in the run-up to the election.

The bill will establish the forums with guarantees of independence; they will not be managed by NHS trusts. The budget for patient representation will be more than £30m, about 50% more than allotted CHCs.

webTitle: Brit Budweiser ads make TV comeback

fields.headline: Brit Budweiser ads make TV comeback
fields.trailText: 8.15am: The Budweiser "Whassup!" ads are back, this time featuring British beer drinkers, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Just when you thought it was safe to turn on your telly again the Budweiser "Whassup!" ads are back.

But instead of irritating loud American drinkers, this campaign will feature irritating loud British beer drinkers.

The new campaign will break on ITV tonight from 11pm to 2am in time to catch bleary-eyed post-pub TV watchers. It will run until Christmas Eve.

Different versions of the British "Whassup!" ad have been shot in local pubs for each of the 16 ITV regions.

The 30-second ads will still be topped and tailed with the original US "Whassup!" characters talking to each other on the phone.

But in the middle they cut to clips of people in British pubs and bars pretending to hold a phone to their ear and saying the "Whassup!" catchphrase.

More than 10,000 people were auditioned in 180 pubs, bars and clubs in 14 cities around the country for the ads in October and November.

The Budweiser ads have captured the public imagination, with "Whassup!" becoming the most-copied catch phrase of the year.

The campaign has also achieved huge recognition in the advertising world, clinching the top prize at Cannes, the most prestigious international awards festival. And even Bart Simpson aped it in an episode of The Simpsons.

The ads were created by Inferno, with airtime bought by OMD. In addition, Circle.com have created 58 UK "Whassup!" internet ads, which can been viewed at www.budweiser.co.uk.

fields.headline: Movie channel gets go-ahead
fields.trailText: 9.45am: EU watchdogs have given the all-clear to The Studio, a movie channel venture between Universal Studios and NTL, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
EU watchdogs have given the all-clear to The Studio, a joint venture movie channel between US film giant Universal Studios and cable operator NTL.

The pay-TV venture combines the UK's largest broadband company with a major Hollywood studio and its a back catalogue of blockbusters including The Mummy and Notting Hill.

Following the thumbs-up from the European Commission, the channel will broadcast from next year.

"The commission's analysis showed that the creation of The Studio Channel will neither create nor reinforce a dominant position on any market," the commission said in a statement.

Universal Studios is now part of the Vivendi Universal media conglomerate, which was formed by the £50bn merger of French media company Vivendi and Seagram of Canada.

When the deal was announced in September, it was expected to put a strain on relations between Vivendi boss Jean-Marie Messier and Rupert Murdoch, owner of NTL rival BSkyB.

Vivendi owns 23% of BSkyB and was seeking to fold its stake into Mr Murdoch's Sky Global Networks operation, but EU regulators have ordered Mr Messier to sell the BSkyB holding as a condition of passing the Seagram merger.

webTitle: Branson delays decision on legal action over national lottery loss

fields.headline: Branson delays decision on legal action over national lottery loss
fields.trailText: The uncertainty hanging over the future running of the National Lottery will drag on for at least a few more weeks after Sir Richard Branson yesterday put off until the new years a decision on whether to press his claim in the courts reports David Teather
fields.body:
The uncertainty hanging over the future running of the National Lottery will drag on for at least a few more weeks after Sir Richard Branson yesterday put off until the new years a decision on whether to press his claim in the courts.

Sir Richard, whose People's Lottery lost in the bidding to win the next licence on Tuesday, said his lawyers would be poring over documents from the lottery commission giving its reasons for rejecting his bid. The commission awarded the seven-year licence to Camelot after a process which has taken more than a year.

"Our people will be sitting down with lawyers over the next week or two," he said, before flying to the Caribbean to join his family on holiday. "We have a three month period in which we are able to go to the courts and we will decide early in the new year whether to pursue court action or not. The whole thing has been sad and unfortunate. The process has been worse than the American election."

Sir Richard said the commission's statement was "inconsistent" and raised a number of complex issues that would need time to evaluate.

The prospect of further delays was not welcomed by Dianne Thompson, Camelot chief executive. "It puts the timetable under jeopardy," she said.

"We are not going to start ordering new terminals with this going on. It puts the whole process under pressure again."

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, meanwhile acknowledged the need to overhaul the bidding process which over the past 12 months has frequently descended into farce.

"I think this was a fair process," he said. "The lottery commission has made a robust decision - part of the process has resulted in Camelot's profit margin being halved."

But he said that the government would have to examine the licencing process in the future.

"I am not entirely happy with the process, because I think anyone looking back over the last five or six months has to ask whether this is the right way to make a decision between two rival bidders for a lottery franchise," he said. "Once the dust has settled, I think we are going to have to have a look, speak to everyone involved and ask if we can come up with a better process the next time."

He said a large concern was whether Camelot, as the incumbent operator, had an unfair advantage.

He denied suggestions that the government had betrayed its pre-election pledge to install a not-for-profits lottery. "What depended absolutely was making sure that we found a viable bid that raised the most for the good causes."

Sir Richard may be encouraged to pursue a legal challenge by Camelot's success in the high court over the summer which allowed it back in the race to run the lottery.

webTitle: Peres to run for Israeli PM

fields.headline: Peres to run for Israeli PM
fields.trailText: The 77-year-old Nobel prize winner Shimon Peres entered the race for Israeli prime minister last night, driven by the belief that he has the credibility with the Palestinians to negotiate a peace deal.
fields.body:
The 77-year-old Nobel prize winner Shimon Peres entered the race for Israeli prime minister last night, driven by the belief that he has the credibility with the Palestinians to negotiate a peace deal.

A perennial loser in Israel's elections, Mr Peres has failed to capture the office in five previous contests. The latest polls, however, show him running ahead of the prime minister, Ehud Barak, and tied with the rightwing hawk Ariel Sharon.

One of his aides said Mr Peres had made his decision after meeting Yossi Sarid, leader of the doveish Meretz party, whose support Mr Peres needed to back his candidacy.

A key architect of Israel's land-for-peace strategy, Mr Peres told MPs of his intention earlier in the day. "This is the first time in my experience that I did not approach the people, but the people approached me," he said. "So I ask you - should I run?"

After 50 years in Israeli politics, Mr Peres has won a Nobel prize for his peace efforts and worldwide acclaim as a statesman, but he has yet to win a major election at home.

Despite his tireless advocacy of Middle East peacemaking, Mr Peres has never connected emotionally with Israeli voters. Many regard his vision of an Israel at ease with its Arab neighbours as too starry-eyed, given the decades of bitter conflict.

Israeli troops in Gaza opened fire on a Palestinian fire engine yesterday, killing a Palestinian civil-defence officer and critically injuring a second, hospital officials said.

In south Gaza, two young Palestinians, aged 14 and 18, were killed during a six-hour gunbattle with Israelis.

In Washington, US and Israeli mediators held preliminary talks, trying to bring both sides back to the bargaining table. A cabinet minister, Amnon Lipkin-Shahak, said he was convinced that in the coming days "we won't be able to conclude everything but we will be able to tell... if we bridge some gaps". AP

webTitle: Winter fuels the health service woes

fields.headline: Winter fuels the health service woes
fields.trailText: The government is welcoming privatisation by the back door, writes George Monbiot
fields.body:
There's not much to be said for the privatisation of the railways, but at least it was honest. The Conservatives told us what they were doing, so we fought them, and when we lost, we kicked them out of office.

Governments and their lobbyists will never make that mistake again. Privatisations, from now on, will be so subtle, so complex, that even the ministers implementing them may not be fully aware of what they're doing. This is the means by which the greatest prize of all is now being delivered to the private sector.

This Christmas, as every Christmas, will be marked by a massive rise in hospital admissions. And, in accordance with venerable tradition, the NHS won't be able to cope. But the "concordat" published by the government six weeks ago will ensure that patients will now have somewhere to go: they will be settled in private beds, for which the NHS will pay the full commercial rate.

Viewed in isolation, this is a sensible decision: it will be costly, but will mean that fewer patients will be left to die in hospital corridors. Viewed in conjunction with the developments of the past three years, this signals the beginning of the end of public health provision in the United Kingdom. The NHS is being privatised.

The first step towards privatisation was a change in the way the budgets were allocated. Health services used to receive a single payment to cover all their needs. Now every patient commands a separate account. The NHS is drowning in paperwork, but the new system means that its services are now interchangeable with those of the private sector.

Allyson Pollock, a professor of health policy, has pointed out that this arrangement also enables health trusts to start charging patients for certain services. This is precisely what the government proposed in the NHS plan it published in July. From October next year, patients in "intermediate care" will be charged for services other than nursing.

The fees will encourage trusts to subcontract their services to the private sector, and pocket the difference. By such gentle means, the last government brought the public provision of most long-term care to an end. Public services can be closed down one by one, until the NHS is dismantled before voters even become aware that it is threatened.

Still greater dangers are presented by the private finance initiative. This, the government insists, is a means of bringing private money into the public sector. In truth it is draining public money into the private sector. Across Britain, hospital improvement schemes are being rejected not because they are too expensive, but because they are too cheap.

Private companies don't want to renovate existing buildings, as the potential profits are too small. But the government has made it clear to the health authorities that if the improvements they seek are not privately funded, they won't be funded at all. So, instead of being renovated, perfectly sound hospitals in city centres are being torn down, and new ones built at great expense on inaccessible greenfield sites. The companies boost their profits still further by selling the city centre land.

To pay for these white elephants, the NHS must butcher its services. Government consultants have calculated that every £200m spent on the private finance initiative leads to the loss of 1,000 doctors and nurses. The government has promised an extra 7,000 beds, but the NHS will have to lose far more than this to pay the contractors' extortionate fees, which it is legally obliged to prioritise. The initiative, according to a member of the government's private finance panel, is "the Heineken of privatisation - taking the private sector to the parts of the government machine not reached by previous privatisations".

All this is documented in my book Captive State, which was published 10 weeks ago. No minister has yet sought to contradict my findings. But while the government has consistently failed to engage with opponents of privatisation, all over the country workers and local people are beginning to form alliances of the kind which characterise Britain's new opposition politics. In Dudley in the West Midlands, for example, hospital workers, with massive public backing, have sustained one of the longest strikes in the history of the NHS.

People are slowly coming to see that this government is implementing plans the Conservatives would scarcely have dared to suggest. We will defend the NHS only by fighting the party which built it.

webTitle: Tory treasurer says sorry after blazing diplomatic row

fields.headline: Tory treasurer says sorry after blazing diplomatic row
fields.standfirst:
Ashcroft says sorry for bust-up in Belize

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Ashcroft says sorry for bust-up in Belize
fields.body:
The controversy over the Conservative treasurer, Lord Ashcroft, came back to haunt the party last night after leaked Foreign Office memos disclosed details of a blazing row with the British high commissioner in Belize.

According to the memos, the billionaire peer told the commissioner, Tim David, during a Christmas drinks party that he was pompous, a liar and that he "could fucking well get out now".

The row was so heated that the following day Lord Ashcroft sent a handwritten letter of apology and offered to make a donation to a charity of Mr David's choice.

The party was held on December 9 in Belmopan, the capital of the former colony, and was hosted by the Belize Bank, in which Lord Ashcroft is a major shareholder. The diplomat described Lord Ashcroft's behaviour as shocking and deeply offensive.

The 54-year-old peer is a close ally of the Conservative leader, William Hague, who has stuck by him despite a series of revelations that have damaged the party.

Lord Ashcroft's links with the tiny Commonwealth country have been the source of embarrassment to the Conservative party, to which he has donated at least £3m.

The flare-up at the drinks party took place against the background of a British government investigation, being conducted by the accountants KPMG, into the secretive financial set-up in Belize, a tax haven where Lord Ashcroft has substantial holdings.

A friend of Lord Ashcroft last night confirmed there had been a confrontation between the two men and described it as a sensitive issue.

He said the latest disclosures were politically motivated and that the government was "putting the bite on Michael [Ashcroft] to weaken him" by trying to undermine his financial base.

He insisted that the KPMG investigation had only been mentioned in passing during the row.

Mr David, 43, who has been based in Belize for two years, having previously served in in Zimbabwe, Geneva, and Tanzania, told the Foreign Office that the Belize Bank had phoned him on December 8 to check he would be at its party the next day.

Mr David said that after arriving at the party Lord Ashcroft had begun berating him over various issues, including attempts by the Labour party to block his elevation to the peerage.

In the memo, which was intended to be seen by only a restricted number of people in the Foreign Office, Mr David said Lord Ashcroft had then raised the KPMG study.

The British government is angry that KPMG's report, which is still at a draft stage, failed to look into the tax exemptions enjoyed by big multinationals operating in Belize.

The government has suspended debt relief promised to Belize until it ends tax breaks for companies such as Lord Ashcroft's.

Mr David said Lord Ashcroft had raised several points about the KPMG inquiry. He described the peer as having then gone nuclear, accusing the diplomat of having been nothing but trouble since being posted to Belize. Lord Ashcroft then advanced towards him and Mr David said he feared he was about to be hit. The diplomat told him he would finish his drink and leave in his own time.

The following day, a Sunday, Lord Ashcroft faxed a letter, marked strictly private, to Mr David at the high commission. The peer said: "To varying 'degrees' I don't suppose our diplomatic skills yesterday evening would have obtained a first. For my part, I sincerely apologise where such skills would not have made a third."

He asked Mr David to contact Phil Johnson, who works at the Belize Bank, to nominate a charity to which he would make an appropriate donation.

Mr David sought guidance from the Foreign Office on how he should reply, rejecting any suggestion that he himself had been undiplomatic and expressing no desire to apologise.

Tim Roberts, director of corporate media relations for KPMG, refused to comment yesterday, referring the inquiry to the government: "Our position on any report is we do it for a client and it is up to the client whether they want to comment on them."

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, promised tax relief to Commonwealth countries but the government was uneasy about helping a country that had both ended VAT and was offering substantial tax exemptions. It is understood that KPMG has told government officials that it could not look into either the VAT question or the tax breaks because to do so would run foul of a treaty between Belize and Britain in 1982, the year after independence.

This is the second time Lord Ashcroft has fallen foul of the British diplomatic service. In July last year a former high commissioner, David Mackilligin, wrote to the Times saying Conservatives should be questioning Lord Ashcroft's suitability for high office because of his involvement in Belize.

He said the system of offshore trusts that Lord Ashcroft had established in Belize had left the country vulnerable to drug runners and others wanting to launder money.

Lord Ashcroft helped to rescue a heavily indebted Tory party after the 1997 general election but ran into trouble when an honours scrutiny committee twice turned down a proposal that he become a peer.

Having finally overcome this hurdle, he became a peer in October after promising to take up residency in Britain.

He sued the Times last year over allegations about his business dealings in Belize but both sides later backed down.

Questions have continued about whether someone who is the Conservative party's main benefactor should also be the party treasurer.

Lord Ashcroft made his maiden speech in the Lords last week, condemning the "cancer" of drug trafficking in the Caribbean - an apparent rebuke to his critics.

Such was his hold on Belize that he was until recently the country's ambassador to the UN. Giving up the post was part of the deal that allowed him to become a peer.

webTitle: Inquiry called into GP's serial sex abuse

fields.headline: Inquiry called into GP's serial sex abuse
fields.trailText: The health secretary, Alan Milburn, yesterday announced an inquiry into the case of a GP found guilty of the serial sexual abuse of women patients which went on for at least eight years reports Sarah Boseley
fields.body:
The health secretary, Alan Milburn, yesterday announced an inquiry into the case of a GP found guilty of the serial sexual abuse of women patients which went on for at least eight years in spite of complaints to the health authority and a hospital where he temporarily worked.

Clifford Ayling, a GP in Folkestone, Kent, was yesterday found guilty of 13 indecent assaults on women who went to his surgery for minor problems such as coughs and colds. He was jailed for four years. Maidstone crown court heard that he carried out unnecessary internal examinations on his women patients and fondled their breasts in the pretence of looking for cancerous lumps.

A patient complained to the police as early as 1991, but the crown prosecution service decided the case was not strong enough. A second complained of abuse while Ayling, who has a gynaecology qualification, was working as a clinical assistant to the disgraced gynaecologist Rodney Ledward at the William Harvey hospital. She dropped her complaint when told that Ayling would be leaving the hospital.

The allegations grew, but the East Kent health authority which paid the GP's contract, could neither sack nor suspend him without mounting a legally watertight case against him to the cumbersome NHS tribunal. It embarked on that long procedure, but the case had to be dropped once criminal proceedings began.

The GP was arrested in 1998, but carried on working. A magistrate barred him from practising while on bail, but he got the ruling overturned at the high court, on condition he was chaperoned by a female nurse when he saw women patients.

The government has plans to abolish the NHS tribunal and will give health authorities summary powers of suspension and dismissal over the GPs they employ in April.

The inquiry will seek to see what else can be done to stop abusive doctors.

The health authority welcomed the inquiry. Jacqui Stewart, a director of the East Kent health authority, said: "We will be cooperating fully with any investigations commissioned by the Department of Health and will be examining our action to make sure the NHS, locally and nationally, learns all the lessons from the case."

Ayling, 69, was found guilty of abusing 10 patients. Not guilty verdicts were returned on a further five charges involving three more women. A further 11 counts of indecent assault against eight women were allowed to lie on file.

Judge David Croft QC said in passing sentence: "You are indeed a dirty doctor. You held your patients in contempt. What you did was wicked. These were vulnerable people who came to you for help and you used them for your own sexual gratification."

One witness, a 34-year-old woman, said Ayling gave her a breast and internal examination on most of her visits. She registered as his patient when moving to Folkestone at the end of 1995, when she was 30, and sought treatment for a cyst on one of her ovaries.

The first time she saw Ayling he told her to take off all her clothes but she was given nothing with which to cover herself. She said: "I felt uncomfortable, I thought it unusual. He then said that he normally likes to start, particularly with new patients, with a breast examination."

Another patient went to see Ayling about pins and needles in her arms - but was told to get on her hands and knees "like a dog" for a breast examination. The GP then straddled her back and examined both her breasts at the same time for at least two minutes.

fields.headline: Vaccine may cure Alzheimer's disease
fields.trailText: An experimental vaccine against Alzheimer's disease, the devastating brain illness which affects some 600,000 Britons, appears to restore memory and reasoning power, according to new research reports James Meek
fields.body:
An experimental vaccine against Alzheimer's disease, the devastating brain illness which affects some 600,000 Britons, appears to restore memory and reasoning power, according to new research.

The vaccine is undergoing safety trials in human volunteers in Britain and the US and is due to be tested on Alzheimer's sufferers next year.

Two tests in mice that were genetically modified to reproduce some of the symptoms of Alzheimer's already suggest it can halt the dementia.

Previously, the vaccine had been shown to clear microscopic clumps, or plaques, of a protein called beta amyloid - thought to be at the centre of the Alzheimer's chain of cause and effect - from the brains of the transgenic mice.

In a series of articles published today in the journal Nature, researchers in Toronto and Florida, using tests developed by neuroscientists at Edinburgh University, reveal that the vaccine not only clears plaques but protects the mice from further mental decline.

The vaccine, developed by a Californian subsidiary of the Irish firm Elan Pharmaceuticals, has created a buzz in the Alzheimer's research community because the science behind it is unexpected.

"Almost everybody who believes this story - as I do now - started out very sceptical," said Paul Chapman, professor of neuroscience at Cardiff University.

Traditionally vaccines have been used to train the body's immune systems to recognise and destroy viruses before the patient is infected. But Alzheimer's is not thought to be viral, and in trials the vaccine will be administered to people who already have the disease.

Elan's vaccine is a version of the beta amyloid protein itself. Its apparent effectiveness relies on the fact that the brain and the body have separate immune systems. By introducing high doses of the vaccine into the body, the immune system seems to produce enough antibodies for some to migrate into the brain and begin attacking beta amyloid there, where it is doing damage.

The key to the new vaccine experiments in Canada and the US was a complex test of short and long-term memory in mice, devised by Professor Richard Morris and his team at Edinburgh University.

But researchers caution that even if trials go well, it could be five years before a vaccine reaches patients. There are also several caveats: the dissimilarity of humans and mice and that any vaccine may attack benign body chemicals.

webTitle: Children's home in sex abuse inquiry

fields.headline: Children's home in sex abuse inquiry
fields.trailText: Detectives are investigating allegations that dozens of children might have been sexually abused at a home for young people with learning difficulties reports Keith Perry
fields.body:
Detectives are investigating allegations that dozens of children might have been sexually abused at a home for young people with learning difficulties.

The abuse was claimed to have taken place "several years ago" at Betts Way children's home in Bromley, Kent, Scotland Yard said last night.

It is understood that child protection officers have interviewed about 40 people so far, but not all are alleged victims.

One woman claimed that her daughter, who has Down's syndrome, was raped at the home, but said the abuser was unlikely to be prosecuted due to lack of evidence. She claimed that he was now working at another children's home.

The mother, named as Sarah, told Radio 4's Today programme she was one of 11 parents told by police last year that their children had made allegations of sexual abuse. Since then at least 28 other families have been given similar news. The allegations are thought to go back 12 years.

"I had two police officers sit in my living room and interview my daughter," the woman said. "They said they totally believed she was sexually abused, but there was no proof to back up that belief. The person who abused my child is about to walk free. I will have to live with this fact for the rest of my life, and I don't want police coming back in 10 years' time saying the case has been reopened because they have abused some other child."

Betts Way, which closed temporarily last spring, is owned by Bromley council and run by the Ravensbourne NHS trust. It offered respite care for children with learning disabilities.

A council spokeswoman said the interviews were being conducted "sensitively, skilfully and thoroughly. Every effort is being taken to safeguard confidentiality and to protect the children.

"Matters cannot be made public until the investigation is concluded and the crown prosecution service has considered whether there is evidence to warrant further action."

A Metropolitan police spokeswoman said she could not give details of the investigation for fear of prejudicing the outcome. The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children said it was involved in the inquiry but could make no comment until it was completed.

A University of Kent study suggested that up to 1,500 adults and children with learning difficulties were sexually abused each year, yet only 3% of cases were prosecuted.

Alan Corbett, of the charity Respond, which helps children with learning difficulties who have been sexually abused, said that often "they are simply not believed or not considered reliable enough witnesses.

"It is often assumed that they won't be able to give evidence well enough because their story is not consistent and they have problems of time and memory. Of course they can give evidence well - it just needs more working at it."

However, a CPS spokesman said he did not believe that such cases were prevented from going to court. Judges often allowed video evidence to be used if they feared that the atmosphere in the court would cause the witness to "clam up".

This year a report by Sir Ronald Waterhouse found that hundreds of children in Welsh care homes were systematically exploited sexually and brutalised over 20 years.

The report called for an independent children's commissioner to make sure that children who made allegations of abuse were listened to.

webTitle: NTL re-enters bidding for Premiership rights

fields.headline: NTL re-enters bidding for Premiership rights
fields.trailText: Cable company NTL is back in the bidding for the pay-per-view rights to Premiership matches - just months after withdrawing a £328m bid, reports Julia Finch.
fields.body:
Cable company NTL is back in the bidding for the pay-per-view rights to Premiership matches - just months after withdrawing a £328m bid.

The company, which is the UK's biggest cable operator, is understood to be offering a fraction of the cash it was originally prepared to put up and is bidding for the rights for cable customers only.

The League is considering two options. It might sell the rights to a single bidder who will then sell them on to four separate buyers representing the four TV platforms - cable, satellite, digital terrestrial and ADSL, or high speed internet.

Alternatively, it might sell the rights directly in four parcels to bidders from each platform. It is expected to confirm the new pay-per-view arrangements, which will cover three seasons, in January.

NTL abandoned its first bid amid growing doubts that the potential audience for live pay-TV matches would generate sufficient revenue to cover the outlay.

Now the Premiership is believed to be ready to accept a much lower total take from pay per view. It is understood the League is now considering a revenue-sharing agreement through which it would take a percentage of viewer's payments, subject to a minimum guarantee.

The League favours a 50:50 revenue split until the guaranteed minimum is reached, with a 60:40 split in the League's favour thereafter.

ONdigital is interested in the terrestrial digital rights while BSkyB wants the satellite rights in addition to the standard live broadcasting rights it has agreed to buy for £1.2bn.

That deal gives it the right to the top two fixtures each week. The pay-per-view bidders will select their match after BSkyB.

U-direct, which bought the rights to the England v Finland international, is chasing the rights to all four platforms. It has links with Britain's second-largest cable operator, Telewest, and Kingston Commuications, which has an ADSL licence.

fields.headline: QXL joins the 99% club
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: QXL has joined a band of dot.coms which have lost more than 99% of their share price value, reports John Cassy.
fields.body:
Beleaguered online auctioneer QXL Ricardo yesterday received the dubious honour of becoming the first British member of the " 99% club " - a select band of dot.coms which have seen their share prices lose 99% of their value.

The shares slumped a further 24% yesterday to an all time low of 6.5p - compared to a high of 800p eight months ago. They closed at 8.5p.

At the height of the internet share-buying frenzy QXL was valued at more than £2bn. Today the loss-making firm is valued at just £62m, less than its available cash of £65 to £70m.

Punters who bought £1,000 worth of QXL shares when they were trading at their high would now find they were worth only £7.50.

The share certificates in effect would be worthless, because even the cheapest stockbrokers charge between £10 and £15 to carry out a trade, and it would cost money to sell them.

"You'd be better off putting them up for auction on eBay" one analyst quipped.

QXL has been a leading member of the 99% club - a growing group of internet stocks that have lost 99% or more of their value.

Other members include WILink and Billum in the UK and CMGI, Buy.com and Agency.com in the US.

webTitle: Hospital plan to put patients in hotels worries doctors

fields.headline: Hospital plan to put patients in hotels worries doctors
fields.trailText: Consultants have expressed concern about a hospital's proposal to book patients into hotels to ease waiting lists. Jeevan Vasagar reports
fields.body:
Consultants have expressed concern about a hospital's proposal to book patients into hotels to ease waiting lists.

Managers at Derriford hospital in Plymouth would pay a minimum of £65 a night for hotel beds rather than keep patients in hospital after their operations. The hospital is even considering sending some emergency cases to hotels and having a nurse on standby.

A management memo circulated to consultants said: "Clearly we would only be transferring patients to a hotel if it was safe to do so and with consultant agreement ... Are there are any emergency admissions which could use hotels at all? ... Any ideas?"

But consultants argued that hotels did not have the facilities to cope should anything go wrong. According to internal documents leaked to a local newspaper, one doctor said: "I am not sure I would be happy for any of my patients to be in a hotel following surgery. If I was that happy, they could simply go home."

Managers said the hotel plan would help them to treat patients who lived too far away to travel home after surgery.

A spokeswoman said the hospital trust was looking at a number of schemes to help ease pressure over the winter.

By accommodating locally those patients who lived some distance away "we are able to provide more patients with routine day-case surgery", she said.

Consultants in the orthopaedic department have said it is at "crisis point", with concerns raised about hygiene. A leaked internal document said: "The operating theatres are so poorly equipped that it was recommended that patients sign a consent form to say they know they are taking a risk over and above the normal."

The trust said orthopaedic services were "of excellent quality and perfectly safe". Paul Roberts, chief executive, said: "While we all agree the need for further investment, we have no doubt the managers and doctors will work together to keep services going and improving."

Derriford hospital has been dogged by problems this year. The former chief executive and his deputy resigned after it emerged that waiting lists had been massaged to hit targets.

One surgeon is taking the hospital to an employment tribunal claiming sexual discrimination and victimisation under the race relations act.

Two other consultants settled out of court over claims that they had missed out on merit awards because of their race.

webTitle: Radio DJ censured following rape comments

fields.headline: Radio DJ censured following rape comments
fields.trailText: 8.15am: A radio DJ has been censured by TV watchdogs after he asked a caller whether she had ever been raped, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
A radio DJ has been censured by the Broadcasting Standards Council after he asked a caller whether she had ever been raped.

The broadcasting watchdog upheld a complaint against Piccadilly Key 103 DJ James Stannard for a verbal attack on a caller in a phone-in debate about the boxer Mike Tyson.

The caller had argued that Mr Tyson, who has been imprisoned for rape, had served his punishment and should be allowed to box in the UK.

Mr Stannard then said he hoped that she was personally assaulted by Mr Tyson and asked whether she had ever been raped.

The watchdog said that Mr Stannard's response to the caller's remarks was "unnecessary, gratuitous and an abuse of the presenter's position."

Channel 5 also incurred the wrath of the watchdog over a programme about the pornography industry.

The BSC ruled that the show, called X-Rated, went "beyond acceptable boundaries" of taste and decency.

It also slammed Channel 5 for promoting X-rated videos and other sex products that cannot be advertised on television and for including clips from an 18-certificate video in the programme.

Channel 5 had argued that the show was "a light-hearted entertainment review show focusing on the adult entertainment industry".

It said it was part of the channel's policy to seek to extend the boundaries of what was acceptable with regard to the depiction of sexual activity on free-to-air television.

fields.headline: 'Campus care' for psychopaths
fields.trailText: A campus-style special hospital to detain up to 2,000 people with dangerous personality disorders is proposed in a white paper, published yesterday, for the biggest shake-up in mental health policy in England and Wales for more than 40 years. John Carvelreports
fields.body:
A campus-style special hospital to detain up to 2,000 people with dangerous personality disorders is proposed in a white paper, published yesterday, for the biggest shake-up in mental health policy in England and Wales for more than 40 years.

Ministers promised legislation after the next election to establish indefinite detention of people with untreatable personality disorders - formerly known as psychopaths - even if they had never committed any crime.

The white paper also proposed compulsory procedures to ensure that patients living in the community take their medication, and extra safeguards to protect the human rights of vulnerable people. "Reducing the stigma which attaches to people with mental illness should be a priority for any caring, civilised society," said Alan Milburn, the health secretary.

Home Office officials said there were 1,400 dangerous and severely personality disordered people, many in prison, 400 in hospitals and 300-600 living in the community.

Inquiries into the special hospitals at Ashworth and Rampton recommended that such people should not be detained in units larger than 50. But there were likely to be serious difficulties in getting planning approval for up to four units for disordered people.

The government is considering solving the problem by building a "modular" special hospital with clusters of small units. Ministers do not yet have a location in mind.

The white paper said people with personality disorders could not be detained under the Mental Health Act because their condition was considered medically untreatable.

This legal loophole caused public outrage in the case of Michael Stone, who was diagnosed as having a severe personality disorder several years before he bludgeoned Lin Russell and her six-year-old daughter Megan to death as they walked through fields near their home in 1996.

The white paper said there should be powers to detain people for up to 28 days if a doctor decided they had a personality disorder, with futher reviews at six-month intervals.

Mr Milburn said: "At present neither the law nor services are geared to cope with the risks posed by dangerous people with severe personality disorder. There has been a gap in the protection mental health laws should afford the public - a gap we will now close."

The white paper included plans to ensure that mentally ill people living in the community stick to an agreed treatment plan. Those failing to take med ication could be forcibly detained and taken to hospital for treatment. "There will be no powers for patients to be given medication forcibly except in a clinical setting," the paper said in an attempt to reassure mental health charities which feared that patients might be forcibly treated at home.

The proposal followed the case of Anthony Joseph, a mentally ill man who killed a woman after refusing to take his medication.

These extra compulsory powers will be balanced by extra safeguards for patients including a new right to independent advocacy and a statutory requirement to develop care plans. A new commission for mental health will look after the interests of people subject to care and treatment under mental health legislation.

Mr Milburn said the reforms would build on extra investment in mental health, including £300m in the NHS plan in July and national standards making mental health a priority for health authorities.

Cliff Prior, chief executive of the National Schizophrenia Fellowship, said: "The white paper is an early Christmas present for everyone who believes that the time is right to end the Cinderella status of mental health.

"But it is a Christmas present that carries a demand for payment. There can be no buy now, pay later period when it comes to investing in mental health."

The mental health charity Mind claimed a victory in getting the government to drop plans to introduce forced medical treatments in the community.

The National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders said the plan to detain people with personality disorders because of what they might do rather than what they had done was "an excessive reaction to a genuine and legitimate public concern.

"There is a very real danger that wrong diagnoses could lead to some people being detained inappropriately while others who are dangerous may be missed or still pose a risk to the public even after treatment," said Graeme Sandall, its spokesman on mental health.

Liberty, the human rights group, said it was "seriously concerned" by the new criteria for detaining people who had not done anything wrong.

Main points

The white paper, Reforming the Mental Health Act, proposes:

 Indefinite detention of potentially dangerous people with untreatable personality disorders who had not committed a crime;

 powers to force patients living in the community to take their agreed medication;

 an independent tribunal to determine all longer term use of compulsory powers and a patient's right to independent advocacy;

 new rights for victims of crime to know when someone with a mental health disorder was to be released;

 a commission for mental health to look after people who were subject to care and treatment;

 increases in staff and services for people with mental health problems.

webTitle: Mental health proposals flawed, says ex-psychiatric patient

fields.headline: Mental health proposals flawed, says ex-psychiatric patient
fields.trailText: Clare Horton talks to clinical psychologist and former psychiatric patient Rufus May about his belief that relationships between patients and professionals could deteriorate as a direct result of the mental health white paper.
fields.body:
Relationships between patients and professionals could deteriorate as a direct result of the mental health white paper, believes clinical psychologist Rufus May.

"There's already an 'us and them' attitude," he said. "Compulsory treatments will only increase that."

Mr May was diagnosed as schizophrenic at the age of 18 and now uses his experience of being a psychiatric patient to challenge the traditional approaches to treatment.

As someone who has knowledge of mental health care from a user's and a professional's perspective, he has deep concerns about some of health minister Alan Milburn's proposals.

"I came off medication against advice," said Mr May. "And if community treatment orders had been around when I stopped taking medication, I might not be where I am today.

"I am concerned that this will further undermine the civil rights of people with mental health problems - especially black people, who are more likely to be given diagnoses of severe mental health problems."

webTitle: Shops on the Net seeks rescue bid

fields.headline: Shops on the Net seeks rescue bid
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Shopping portal Shops on the Net is seeking a rescue bid after being hit by the slowdown in the online shopping market. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Shopping portal Shops on the Net is seeking a rescue bid after being caught short by the slowdown in the online shopping market.

Staff have been cut back to a bare minimum and the remaining director, Jeremy Pocock, who set up the website in 1997, is working to secure a rescue funding package.

Repeated calls to Shops on the Net yesterday went unanswered and emails to key staff bounced back.

Southampton-based ShopsontheNet.com began life with five staff in 1997 but then geared up for the dot.com boom by staffing up to 60 this summer, bolstered by a funding injection of some £2m.

It was one of the first retail portals to hit the market, but was soon joined by the likes of shopsmart, ValueMad and more recently Kelkoo.com and easyValue.

The website, ShopsOnTheNet.com, remains unchanged and staff that have since left are still flagged up as contactable on the site.

The site claims to be Europe's largest shopping portal with more than 18,000 sites in its directory.

fields.headline: BBC eases privacy edict
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC has relaxed its ban on mentioning Peter Mandelson's sexuality, imposed after the Northern Ireland secretary was "outed" on Newsnight, writes Jamie Wilson.
fields.body:
The BBC has relaxed its ban on mentioning Peter Mandelson's sexuality, imposed after the Northern Ireland secretary was "outed" by the columnist Matthew Parris on Newsnight.

The edict, which was attacked by politicians, presenters and producers, was discussed at a BBC editorial policy meeting this week. Executives argued that since Mr Mandelson openly lived with Reinaldo da Silva any mention of his private life should not be so strictly censored.

A BBC spokesperson said yesterday that the policy - that public figures are in a special position but retain their right to a private life - remained the same. However, "sensible editorial judgments should be applied in the light of changed circumstances".

BBC journalists were outraged when in September 1998 Ann Sloman, chief political adviser, told editorial staff in a memo: "Under no circumstances should the allegation about the private life of Peter Mandelson be repeated or referred to on any broadcast."

It later emerged the then trade and industry secretary had telephoned Sir Christopher Bland, chairman of the BBC board of governors, and the Press Complaints Commission to protest at what he saw as an invasion of his privacy. It also emerged that Mr Mandelson had received a letter of apology for Mr Parris's remarks from Sir Christopher.

Journalist and politicians accused the BBC of caving in to the minister's demands and affording him special treatment.

Jonathan Dimbleby, presenter of Radio 4's Any Questions, wrote to Ms Sloman, protesting at the corporation's "ineptitude and impertinence".

Jimmy Mulville, executive producer of Have I Got News for You?, which has flouted the ban ever since, described the memo as "chilling".

webTitle: Scottish Radio signals start of takeover trend

fields.headline: Scottish Radio signals start of takeover trend
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Consolidation of the radio industry began in earnest yesterday when Scottish Radio Holdings confirmed it had been approached by a number of potential buyers.
fields.body:
Consolidation of the radio industry began in earnest yesterday when Scottish Radio Holdings confirmed it had been approached by a number of potential buyers.

A statement from the company, which owns the Herald newspapers as well as a cluster of radio stations, confirmed discussions are taking place -with the usual caveat that they might or might not lead to an offer. Shares in Scottish Radio closed 102.5p higher at £17.05, valuing the company at £563m.

The discussions are expected to be the first in a wave of takeover talks in anticipation of the limits being lifted on radio ownership. The communications white paper has asked for further comment but suggested that an overhaul of the regulations is likely.

SMG, formerly known as Scottish Media Group, sparked interest in Scottish Radio after building a stake in the company of 20.8% in the past few weeks

A spokesman for SMG said the company's position remained unchanged from the statement issued a week ago. "We have no current intention of making a bid unless someone else does. If an offer is made, we would look to explore our options."

Under existing legislation, no single company may own more than 15% of the national commercial radio audience. SMG has 4% while Scottish Radio has 7%.

SMG, however, would still face regulatory hurdles in acquiring Scottish Radio. SMG owns the ITV franchises Scottish and Grampian, and would not be allowed to own radio stations in the same regions.

This year the company demonstrated its intent to expand in radio with the £225m acquisition of Chris Evans' Ginger Media Group and there has been some speculation that the company would be prepared to quit TV.

The timing is not ideal, however. If it were to sell its TV assets, SMG would prefer to do so after white paper proposals becames law and increased the number of potential buyers.

Most of the other large companies, including Capital Radio and GWR, are already pressing against the ceiling on radio ownership and would be unable to make an outright acquisition of Scottish Radio.

There was some speculation that Clear Channel International, part of the US radio, entertainment and outdoor advertising group, would be interested in making an offer. Foreign ownership restrictions, however, would mean the company was forced to enter into a joint venture with a British company.

Clear Channel entered a joint venture with Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Guardian, to bid for Virgin Radio this year.

SMG's dawn raid on Scottish Radio shares was viewed as the first in a series of markers put down ahead of anticipated changes to ownership rules which will not take effect for another two years.

The white paper said the government would "consider the possibility of devising a simpler, fairer regime for radio ownership to replace the current points system or revoking the scheme completely".

Scottish Radio was considered to be "in play" in April when it lost a hostile bid for Border Television, eventually snared by Capital for £146m.

The company last month reported a 27% increase in pre-tax profits to £20m for the year to October, on sales of £72m.

webTitle: Brown tipped to launch new men's magazine

fields.headline: Brown tipped to launch new men's magazine
fields.trailText: 8am: Former Loaded editor James Brown is poised to return to men's magazines, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
James Brown, the maverick former Loaded editor, is poised to return to men's magazine publishing.

I Feel Good, the magazine publishing company Mr Brown now runs, is planning a mature men's lifestyle title in the same mould as IPC's Later.

Mr Brown, the godfather of the lad's mag and chief executive of I Feel Good, which publishes HotDog magazine, refused to comment on his plans.

He said: "We're a publicly listed company and we have to tell the stock market before we tell the press.

But I Feel Good is recruiting for "the best young magazine editor in the business", as well as journalists, a publisher and art staff.

And industry sources say Mr Brown is putting together ambitious plans for a lifestyle title aimed at older men.

I Feel Good, formed last year with £2m of venture capital from investors including Dennis Publishing chief executive Felix Dennis, already publishes the official Leeds United magazine, Leeds, Leeds, Leeds, and a film magazine, Hotdog.

The company is already behind on its stated plan to launch a further two magazines by the end of this year.

webTitle: BBC cash lure for big name presenters

fields.headline: BBC cash lure for big name presenters
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC has launched a starkly commercial campaign to lure big name stars with a £1m offer to former footballer and ITV presenter Ian Wright, reports Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The BBC has launched a starkly commercial campaign to lure big name stars with a £1m offer to the former footballer and ITV presenter Ian Wright.

Executives at the BBC's entertainment department are close to signing an exclusive deal with the former Arsenal and England player which would lead to him presenting the Saturday night game show, Friends Like These.

Wright became an unexpected star on ITV with a successful chat show and spin-off projects. The BBC needs to fill the gap left by Ant and Dec who are leaving Friends Like These to concentrate on developing a Saturday night primetime show for the commercial network.

The former footballer is seen as an ideal replacement - he is hugely popular with a young audience and is a natural performer on television.

The offer to Wright is worth £1m a year and, if signed, will be announced in the new year. It is part of a wider BBC strategy to recruit and retain talent. The BBC has lost a number of high profile stars, and thas admitted that it needs to nurture and support its talent better.

The Guardian has revealed that the BBC is in advanced negotiations over a deal with Audley Harrison, the Olympic medal-winning boxer. It has also signed an exclusive deal with Jonathan Ross. Exclusive deals can be problematic, however. The BBC signed the former Heartbeat actor, Nick Berry, without a firm idea of the sort of programmes he would be offered. His main vehicle, Harbour Lights, was a flop. The corporation also had trouble with Vanessa Feltz when her talk show hit the rocks.

ITV has had its own share of problems. Signing the former EastEnders actor Ross Kemp was not an unqualified success. The drama titled In Defence, in which Kemp played a solicitor, was a critical failure, although the actor had more success in Without Motive, which played better to his tough guy image.

Wright's arrival at the BBC would be a boost for the corporation. Friends Like These, in which teams of teenagers compete to discover how much they know about each other, was a success when it was presented by Ant and Dec. It is believed the format would work equally well with another presenter.

The departure of Ant and Dec was a blow since the BBC had hoped to sign them up on an exclusive basis too. But Anthony McPartlin, 24, and Declan Donnelly, 25, decided their future lay with ITV.

They have already delivered a pilot version of material for the proposed Saturday night entertainment show provisionally titled Slap, Bang! Executives believe Ant and Dec, who triumphed at the British Comedy Awards this month, are perfect for bringing the variety show format to a new audience.

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Branded email | Mail fails
fields.body:
Branded email
Further to the article on branded email (Online, November 30) and letters in Feedback, how do I go about putting a logo and live hyperlink at the top of all my emails? Do I need to know HTML coding, or is there a Wizard of some form that will help me? I do not wish to force recipients to be online to see the logo: I want it sent with the email. David Fardon
DFardon@igroup.co.uk

Jack Schofield replies: Probably the simplest way is to create a letter with the embellishments you want and save it as stationery. In Outlook Express, do this using the File|Save as Stationery menu command.

To create stationery, you must have elected to send HTML mail, which is email in web page format. To set this globally in Outlook Express, go to View|Options, choose the tab for Send, and click the radio button for HTML, which is under Mail Sending Format. However, you can also select this format for an individual email message by using its Format menu to select Rich Text (HTML).

With HTML selected, you can use the Format|Apply Stationery menu item to load your own stationery, or one of the pre-written examples Microsoft supplies.

With Microsoft Outlook - a different program from Outlook Express - go to Tools|Options, select the Mail Format tab, and set HTML mail. Then click the Stationery Picker button half way down the sheet, and click New to create your stationery.

When creating stationery, you can import pictures and graphics such as company logos. It may be simplest to keep these in the stationery directory, which is usually

C:\Program Files\Common Files\Microsoft Shared\ Stationery

Any complete internet address (including the http://) that you type in will automatically be converted into a live link.

Alternatively, you can create similar branded email in a word processor such as Microsoft Word, using your logo and live links, then send the resulting doc file as an attachment. In Word, go to Tools|Options, select the General tab, and click Email Options (in the bottom right-hand corner) for the Personal Stationery settings.

However, it is not necessarily a good idea to use branded email. Images and stationery greatly increase the size of the email you send, and you should make sure your messages are as small as possible. Clueless and stupid PRs often send me messages with multicoloured logos that add up to half a megabyte, and this has a very negative impact on my opinion of their company's competence.

HTML email is also inconvenient for people whose mail software does not recognise HTML formatting. It should never be used when posting to Usenet newsgroups, writing to mailing lists, or writing to Online.

Mail fails
Two months ago we had the KAK virus on our home PC and installed Norton AntiVirus. Since then we have been unable to receive incoming mail via Outlook Express. Mailing out is no problem. Can you advise?
Margaret Weaver
M.Weaver@derby.ac.uk

JS: Norton AntiVirus interposes itself between your email software and your mailbox so as to check email for viruses. If it does not install correctly, this can disable either incoming or outgoing mail, and this seems to be a fairly common problem. Go to Symantec's online support service and read a document called How to configure Outlook Express 5.0 with Norton AntiVirus 2000. (It is Document ID: 1999120717064306 but unfortunately Symantec's system cannot find a document from its official ID.) Alternatively, you may find www.io.com/~robertl/nav-help.html useful.

Back off
In preparation for transferring material from my old computer, running Windows 95, to its replacement running Windows Me, I prepared a large number of backup discs using the MS Backup program in Windows 95. To my horror, Windows Me does not seem to support msbackup. How can I make use of the discs that I prepared?
P T Sherwood
psherwood@waitrose.com

JS: Don't. MS Backup is designed for backing up a particular PC: it is not intended or recommended for transferring files or moving programs between PCs.

There are lots of different ways to move files between two machines. If they are side by side, the easiest is to use a cable to connect the two (preferably via their parallel printer ports) with Microsoft Direct Connection, which is part of Windows. A commercial alternative is Laplink, which is usually used with a Laplink serial cable. The latest version is called PCsync.

Do not try to use DCC with a Laplink cable.

An alternative is to transfer files using Iomega Zip disks that nominally hold 100MB or 250MB each or CD-R discs that hold more than 550MB. A standalone Zip, CD-R or other high-capacity drive can be plugged into the old PC via its parallel printer port or, better, USB port for copying, then plugged into the new PC to upload the files. However, your old PC is unlikely to have a USB port and Windows 95 does not support USB.

I use a MicroSolutions Backpack CD writer, which is excellent, but expensive unless you do this all the time.

Word switch
I have installed Microsoft Word 2000. Is there any way by which to transfer my files from MS Works to Word 2000? Sometimes Wordpad is transferred but not MS Works. Any ideas, please?
Eric Powell
e.e.powell@btinternet.com

JS: Word comes with a file called Works432.cnv to load files created with Works for Windows 4.0. It should be in C:\Program Files\Common Files\Microsoft Shared\ TextConv but if not, install it from your Word CD.

A converter for Works 3 files (Works332.cnv) is available in The Microsoft Office Converter Pack on the web at www.microsoft.com/office/ork/2000/appndx/toolbox.htm

You may have to load earlier files into Works and re-save them in a format that is easier to transfer between programs and between PCs. The best choices are RTF (Rich Text Format) and plain text.

It is always a good idea to make RTF and/or text files to back up your work in case your main program - Works, Word, or whatever - fails.
