fields.headline: Adoption white paper: Key points
fields.trailText: The key points of the adoption white paper:
fields.body:
The key points of the adoption white paper:

 Some £66.5m to improve services and support for children and their adoptive families.

 A new national target to increase the numbers of adoptions of looked after children by 40% by 2004-05.

 New national standards setting out what children and parents involved in the adoption process can expect.

 Timescales for children so that a plan for their permanent future will be made within six months of becoming continuously looked after, and implemented promptly. Where a decision is made that adoption is the plan, a new family should be found within a further six months.

 An adoption register for England and Wales to be established by next July. This will match children with adoptive parents from across the country where a local family cannot be found or the child needs to move away from the area.

 An adoption and permanence taskforce will be set up to tackle poor performance and spread best practice.

 A new right to an independent review for the potential adopter if the agency plans to reject their application to adopt. An independent body appointed by the secretary of state will set up a new adoption panel to look at all the evidence again and make a new recommendation to the agency. The agency must take account of the new recommendation before making its final decision.

 Adoptive families will have the right to an assessment for support once their child starts to live with them. Councils will be required to provide a full package of support services including financial help, where appropriate.

 A new legal framework for deciding who should get adoption allowances will be set up.

 An option called "special guardianship" will be established when the court decides it is in the child's interest. This could apply to some older children who do not wish to be legally separated from their birth parents even though they cannot live with them.

 In addition a website has been launched today www.doh.gov.uk/adoption which provides detailed information on government adoption policy and the adoption process. It signposts the reader to associated information and links to the web sites of adoption organisations and other government departments.

fields.headline: Government to make adoption easier
fields.trailText: Ministers have announced sweeping reforms to increase the number of adopted children and tackle a shortage of adoptive families which has left thousands of children languishing in care homes.
fields.body:
Ministers have announced sweeping reforms to increase the number of adopted children and tackle a shortage of adoptive families which has left thousands of children languishing in care homes.

The reforms - billed as the biggest changes to adoption law in 25 years - will give parents more power to appeal against decisions which prevent them adopting because they are of a different race to the child.

Local authorities that fail to meet stringent targets aimed at speeding up the adoption process could find themselves stripped of their powers to handle adoptions.

The proposals, contained in a white paper on adoption, were widely welcomed by adoption experts and lobbyists.

Felicity Collier, chief executive of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, said: "The emphasis on more support for adoptive families and their children and the promised allocation of funds will make a tremendous difference to society's most disadvantaged children."

The white paper is designed to speed up the process and clear the backlog of more than 2,000 children waiting for a permanent home.

Under the proposals, launched by health secretary Alan Milburn, children should have to wait no longer than six months for a family to be found for them.

There is a new national target to increase the number of adoptions by 40% by 2005. At present only 6,000 youngsters a year are adopted, compared with more than 20,000 in the 1960s.

Shortages of potential adoptive families mean thousands of children are left in care homes for years while social workers try to find a home for them. The white paper aims to free up the process and set down new national adoption standards. Within six months of being in permanent care, children should be given a plan for their future and if it is decided that they should be adopted, a family should be found within six months.

People have complained that the adoption process screens out suitable parents on the grounds of race or other criteria and stops thousands of children from being found a home.

The proposals will give potential adopters the right to an independent review if their application is rejected.

Mr Milburn said: "Last year there were 2,400 children waiting to be adopted. These children need the safety, stability and loving care of a permanent new family. And they need that stability as quickly as possible. That is not the case at present. Children stay in the care system far longer than they should."

The proposed reforms are the biggest overhaul of adoption law for 25 years. The government has committed £66.5m to improving services.

Wide regional variations mean that some local councils ensure more than 10% of children in care are adopted each year, while in other areas only 0.5% are found a permanent new family.

The government has proposed a new adoption register for England and Wales, which will match children with families from across the country if a suitable home cannot be found in the youngster's area.

An adoption and permanence task force will be set up to raise standards spread best practice.

A new legal option is to be introduced for children who cannot live with their birth parents but do not want to have all ties with them completely broken. The "special guardianship" option will be a permanent arrangement, which may be chosen by older children who cannot live with their parents but do not want complete legal severance for them.

The all party parliamentary group on adoption, made up of interested agencies and groups, welcomed the white paper.

A spokesman said: "We are extremely pleased to see the commitment of the government to reform adoption and planning for permanence for those children who cannot remain with their birth-families.

"We look forward to seeing the promised legislation as soon as practicably possible."

He added: "We are particularly pleased to see an independent appeals mechanism for aggrieved potential adopters controlled directly by the secretary of state, and the proper assessment and provision of post-adoption support to adoptive families."

Moira Gibb, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said: "All directors of social services will welcome the adoption white paper which has been based on extensive consultation."

webTitle: Blair: 'Why adoption is close to my heart'

fields.headline: Blair: 'Why adoption is close to my heart'
fields.trailText: Prime Minister Tony Blair spoke publicly today about how his father, Leo, was adopted after his travelling entertainer parents left him with a couple they met on tour.
fields.body:
Prime Minister Tony Blair spoke publicly today about how his father, Leo, was adopted after his travelling entertainer parents left him with a couple they met on tour.

Mr Blair was speaking as he met a group of adopted children and their families, with his wife, Cherie, to coincide with today's launch of the adoption white paper on adoption.

Mr Blair had taken a personal interest in the adoption shake up, chairing a cabinet committee which led to the introduction of new laws.

After listening to the families' problems coping with the bureaucracy of the adoption system during an informal chat at the Coram Family Centre in St Pancras, north London, Mr Blair told the families: "My own father was fostered. In those days there weren't any rules at all."

He said: "I don't think my grandmother would have passed any tests at all. But then a framework of rules grew up in a very random and ad hoc way.

"Now is the right time to get back to basics and ask what we want to achieve for children."

Later Mr Blair added: "I know how much difference a loving and caring family made to me. My own father was adopted and not brought up by his own parents."

Mr Blair's father, Leo, was the illegitimate son of travelling entertainers Celia Ridgeway and Charles Parsons.

The social stigma of having a child out of wedlock and their hectic lifestyles prompted Leo's parents to give him to poor Clydesdale ship worker James Blair and his wife, Mary, who they met on tour in Glasgow.

Leo Blair went on to become a successful barrister, although his foster mother, Mary, prevented contact between him and his biological family.

The prime minister's father was later reunited with his biological half-sister Pauline Harding. The prime minister, his wife and their three eldest children were present at the emotional family reunion.

Mr Blair said the adoption system needed national co-ordination to reduce arbitrary regional differences, and a nationwide register to match children with suitable parents.

He said: "The whole purpose of this is to clear away the clutter of rules that stop children having a decent home. We have got to get some common sense back into the system.

"No matter how good a care home is, it isn't as good as having a loving family."

Earlier, Mr and Mrs Blair sat down for an informal chat with a few of the 300 adoptive families and children placed through the Coram Family Centre.

The families told the Blairs of their struggles with the bureaucracy of the adoption system, the stresses caused by the drawn out legal process, financial problems faced by adoptive families and the detrimental effects of the process on children.

Amuda and Ian, who declined to give their surnames to protect their children, said they adopted Gareth, now nine, six years ago and called for more financial support for adoptive families.

At the age of three Gareth had already been looked after by eight different families.

The couple, both social workers, said it then took a further two-and-a-half years to battle through the legal system to adopt Gareth.

Poor post-adoption care meant his behavioural problems were not diagnosed until he was eight.

Amuda, 47, told the Blairs: "Adoption is a very long road. It's that commitment beyond normal parenting.

"It will take Gareth a whole lifetime to overcome what he experienced in the first three years of his life."

Another adoptive mother, Margaret, said her 17-year-old son, David, waited five years to be placed with a family.

She said: "People were doing their best but there was no feeling of hope."

The Coram Family, England's oldest charity, is an adoption agency which specialises in helping children who have suffered abuse or neglect, and those who have disabilities or learning difficulties.

webTitle: Bush fills key posts and meets his guru

fields.headline: Bush fills key posts and meets his guru
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the US elections
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: George W Bush elevated four senior Republicans and old friends into key jobs in his new administration yesterday.
fields.body:
George W Bush elevated four senior Republicans and old friends into key jobs in his new administration yesterday, but perhaps more significant than any of those appointments was his meeting with the guru of his "compassionate conservatism" campaign.

In an overtly traditionalist choice, Mr Bush named Paul O'Neill, chairman of the Alcoa aluminium corporation and a veteran of Gerald Ford's administration to be his treasury secretary, saying that signs of an economic slowdown made it "incredibly important" to have a man of vast experience and a steady hand in the job.

Mr O'Neill is an old friend of the vice-president-elect, Dick Cheney, who was the Ford administration's chief of staff . He is the first treasury secretary for nearly 50 years with a background in manufacturing. Few in the Bush team deny that Mr O'Neill is a compromise or that his selection is another tribute to Mr Cheney's influence.

Mr Bush was also set to announce that one of his own closest Texas business friends, Don Evans, would become commerce secretary. The Florida-based Cuban-American politician Mel Martinez, who is head of the state's Orange county, which includes Orlando, is the new housing secretary, while Ann Veneman, who was a deputy secretary under Mr Bush's father, becomes agriculture secretary.

The next wave of appointments may feature some better-known national political names than the four named yesterday. The moderate Republican New Jersey governor, Christine Todd Whitman, could become head of the environmental protection agency, a high-profile post in an administration likely to allow oil and natural gas drilling in protected areas.

The Wisconsin governor, Tommy Thompson, who is credited with promoting his state's pioneering welfare-to-work reforms, is set to become health and human services secretary. The Montana governor, Marc Racicot - a prominent defender of Mr Bush during the Florida election row - is in the running for attorney general.

The latest speculation in Washington is that Mr Bush will offer the defence secretary's job to Dan Coats, who, until 1998, was the highly conservative Republican Senator for Indiana. The prospect of Mr Coats taking over at the Pentagon has already alarmed women's and gay rights activists who fear he will reverse the Clinton administration's sexual equality programmes.

As the jobs were being handed out in Austin, however, Mr Bush took time out to attend a multi-racial conference of religious leaders where a keynote contributor was Marvin Olasky, the originator of the compassionate conservatism doctrine and the man with more claims than most to be Mr Bush's intellectual tutor.

The notion of compassionate conservatism to Mr Olasky, who is professor of journalism at the University of Texas, is a far more radical world view than the words may suggest. His compassionate conservatism is a more far-reaching "faith-based" philosophy of government in which religion plays the central role in social policy and social service provision.

webTitle: Comment: US special relationship under fire

fields.headline: A special relationship under fire from missile defence
fields.standfirst:
Bush's interest in military technology may force Britain to make a stand

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Bush's interest in military technology may force Britain to make a stand.
fields.body:
There's a man in Downing Street, close to Tony Blair, who is rather keen on NMD, the national missile defence system which George W Bush has said he will deploy. He believes there will soon be so many loose missiles in rogue states that appropriate counter-missiles may be essential. His voice won't be decisive.

Most official British opinion is strongly, if discreetly, opposed to NMD. But a straw flutters in the wind. An accommodation is possibly being prepared. What Bush proposes and Colin Powell disposes, Tony Blair may decide he cannot oppose. Not far over the horizon, the ground is opening up for the most awkward struggle in the modern history of Anglo-American relations.

General Powell upped the ante on Monday, his first outing as Bush's secretary-of-state designate. The ambiguities of the Clinton attitude to NMD are already being dispelled. "We're going to go forward," Powell firmly said. There would be tough negotiations with those countries that "don't yet understand our thinking with respect to national missile defence". The thinking is very committed. Bush made that clear several times in the election campaign. Powell, though once listed as a Pentagon man who feared NMD would take money away from more treasured military ventures, is now the voice of an opposite decision already made in principle.

His statement coincided with another. A CIA study-project, making an assessment of the next 15 years, asserts that the threat to the mainland US from nuclear missiles, among other weapons, is greater than it was for most of the cold war. This will, the CIA thinks, get worse. Terrorists and rogue states will have the power and motivation to launch attacks that produce "mass casualties".

This wasn't said to justify NMD. But it nourishes the mind-set that is demanding a new $60bn defence programme, irrespective of what might happen in the rogue states in question. Both North Korea and Iran arguably show reason for mild optimism. Iraq could soon be the solitary credible danger. No matter. No matter, either, that Russia, with whom the US has an anti-ballistic missile treaty, is fiercely opposed. Russia no longer matters, argues Richard Perle, a close Bush associate. The lead-time to build NMD is long, the world is usually changing for the worse, and the Washington voices prepared to speak up against unilateral defence may soon be hard to hear.

At present, Downing Street professes to be quite comfortable. Blair got Clinton and Russian president Putin talking about NMD. He wants to be, as ever, the contact man, mediator, bridge. Since the election, his people have talked to Powell and, at greater length, to Condoleezza Rice, Bush's new national security adviser. The talks have apparently been more reassuring than Powell's public statement. Rice vowed to proceed with caution, sensitive to allied worries.

Maybe she will. These advisers matter hugely. Bush's personal contribution to all complicated subjects will be far less creative than Clinton's. He will be heavily adviser-dependent. Rice says she is interested in sea-based defence missiles aimed to hit rogues at the point of launch, rather than the scheme Clinton half-backed which depended on the hit being made in space. The work required to switch schemes would be massive. But a boost-phase system would at least not depend on British and Danish tracking stations.

As presently conceived, NMD proposes a new hi-tech skyscraper on Fylingdales moor, a project which, as British ministers have tried to explain in Washington, would be relentlessly picketed not only by CND and Greenpeace but by the north Yorkshire branch of the Women's Institute, furious at defilement of the countryside.

Under Clinton, British and European objections to NMD fed into an administration inclined to take them seriously. They weren't limited to the region's interest in not being targeted, as helpless accomplices to American unilateralism, but put most weight on the global instability provoked by a new arms race. If NMD ever did happen, Russia and especially China would feel obliged to counter it. Whitehall, like Paris and Berlin, has made these arguments copiously. A quiet turmoil of alarm has gripped the Foreign Office and Ministry of Defence for months.

They now face a Washington being peopled by voices that make a different analysis: scornful of Russia, arrogant about China, intolerant of European sensitivities, overwhelmingly impressed by the case for defending US territory - and confident that the practical failure of NMD so far, like the untested capacities of a boost-phase project, are mere blips on the relentless American path towards technological mastery.

One answer being given to the choice between space- attack and launch-attack systems is that both should be pursued. Though it remains to be seen how Congress will react to the financial burden, missile defence is not guaranteed to be one of the aspects of the Bush programme that founders on a bitterly divided legislature. My conversations tell me that the commitment to build and deploy is likely to be made: much more likely, at any rate, than not.

This will present Tony Blair with a challenge he has not so far faced. His time in office has been spent with a fellow spirit in the White House, someone to whom he grew close. We may be sure he will attempt to attain real intimacy with Bush, and he's likely to be more successful at it than John Major was with Clinton. Mr Blair makes a good fist of being friends with every species on the political spectrum, the only exception being a certain kind of Tory politician.

He will strain every muscle to get on with Bush. And Bush, never having visited a major European country, will be more than usually susceptible to the charms of a land whose language he understands, whose history his father knows, and which matters more than Aznar's Spain, the only other contender.

Blair, in other words, could become a safe haven for the Texas ingenu. His personal instincts will be to do whatever he can to help Bush; and now he has a voice or two whispering words of encouragement to persuade him that NMD may not, after all, be as dangerous as the defence and diplomatic establishment has been telling him. There are, after all, a lot of loose missiles about. Maybe NMD, if the Americans can produce one that works, is just what we need. Maybe the big picture says that it's the prime minister's duty to rise above conventional wisdom.

If this became Blair's formal position, it would create his deepest rupture with continental Europe. A moment of truth almost certainly beckons. Will NMD become a pretext that requires one more affirmation of the old special relationship? Or the project that at last obliges Britain to recognise she cannot continue as the compliant poodle? Without doubt it will be the issue that shatters the Blair axiom that there's no choice to be made.

At present, Downing Street professes to be quite comfortable. Blair got Clinton and Russian president Putin talking about NMD. He wants to be, as ever, the contact man, mediator, bridge. Since the election, his people have talked to Powell and, at greater length, to Condoleezza Rice, Bush's new national security adviser. The talks have apparently been more reassuring than Powell's public statement. Rice vowed to proceed with caution, sensitive to allied worries. Maybe she will. These advisers matter hugely. Bush's personal contribution to all complicated subjects will be far less creative than Clinton's. He will be heavily adviser-dependent. Rice says she is interested in sea-based defence missiles aimed to hit rogues at the point of launch, rather than the scheme Clinton half-backed which depended on the hit being made in space. The work required to switch schemes would be massive. But a boost-phase system would at least not depend on British and Danish tracking stations. As presently conceived, NMD proposes a new hi-tech skyscraper on Fylingdales moor, a project which, as British ministers have tried to explain in Washington, would be relentlessly picketed not only by CND and Greenpeace but by the north Yorkshire branch of the Women's Institute, furious at defilement of the countryside. Under Clinton, British and European objections to NMD fed into an administration inclined to take them seriously. They weren't limited to the region's interest in not being targeted, as helpless accomplices to American unilateralism, but put most weight on the global instability provoked by a new arms race. If NMD ever did happen, Russia and especially China would feel obliged to counter it. Whitehall, like Paris and Berlin, has made these arguments copiously. A quiet turmoil of alarm has gripped the Foreign Office and Ministry of Defence for months. They now face a Washington being peopled by voices that make a different analysis: scornful of Russia, arrogant about China, intolerant of European sensitivities, overwhelmingly impressed by the case for defending US territory - and confident that the practical failure of NMD so far, like the untested capacities of a boost-phase project, are mere blips on the relentless American path towards technological mastery. One answer being given to the choice between space- attack and launch-attack systems is that both should be pursued. Though it remains to be seen how Congress will react to the financial burden, missile defence is not guaranteed to be one of the aspects of the Bush programme that founders on a bitterly divided legislature. My conversations tell me that the commitment to build and deploy is likely to be made: much more likely, at any rate, than not. This will present Tony Blair with a challenge he has not so far faced. His time in office has been spent with a fellow spirit in the White House, someone to whom he grew close. We may be sure he will attempt to attain real intimacy with Bush, and he's likely to be more successful at it than John Major was with Clinton. Mr Blair makes a good fist of being friends with every species on the political spectrum, the only exception being a certain kind of Tory politician. He will strain every muscle to get on with Bush. And Bush, never having visited a major European country, will be more than usually susceptible to the charms of a land whose language he understands, whose history his father knows, and which matters more than Aznar's Spain, the only other contender. Blair, in other words, could become a safe haven for the Texas ingenu. His personal instincts will be to do whatever he can to help Bush; and now he has a voice or two whispering words of encouragement to persuade him that NMD may not, after all, be as dangerous as the defence and diplomatic establishment has been telling him. There are, after all, a lot of loose missiles about. Maybe NMD, if the Americans can produce one that works, is just what we need. Maybe the big picture says that it's the prime minister's duty to rise above conventional wisdom. If this became Blair's formal position, it would create his deepest rupture with continental Europe. A moment of truth almost certainly beckons. Will NMD become a pretext that requires one more affirmation of the old special relationship? Or the project that at last obliges Britain to recognise she cannot continue as the compliant poodle? Without doubt it will be the issue that shatters the Blair axiom that there's no choice to be made. hugoyoung@compuserve.com

webTitle: Film: The best overnight success scene

fields.headline: The best overnight success scene
fields.standfirst: Small Time Crooks
fields.trailText: Small Time Crooks.
fields.body:
After his plan to use a cookie shop as the front for a bank robbery goes awry, small-time hustler Ray Winkler (Woody Allen) has inadvertently found himself becoming a baked goods magnate. On a TV show, he explains his ascendancy to a reporter (Dana Tyler).

"We've got about 600 cooks and, yeah, we're distributed all over the country. And Canada. You know, we make a lot of different cookies now. Whatever you want. We got pistachio, we got pretzels..."

Now the reporter speaks direct to camera.

"We're standing on the grounds of Sunshine Cookies, looking at how a small mom'n'pop cookie store became something resembling a baking empire."

Cut back to Ray, showing the reporter through the cookie plant.

"And uh yeah, this is where the cookies get made. You smell that great smell? That wonderful smell? That's put there with a chemical spray."

Back to Ray, relaxing in his lavishly appointed office.

"So, Ray, you decorated yourself?"

"Well, a lot of that's down to Frenchie. But yeah," he says, gesturing at the paintings and sculptures which fill the room, "all this stuff is real. That's how I operate. I mean, a lot of this stuff goes back to Louis."

He hesitates.

"Yeah, uh... Louis the Fourteenth, Louis the Fifteenth. Uh..."

He scratches his head.

"You know, actually I don't know how the Louis go_"

See also: The Hudsucker Proxy, The Kids In The Hall: Brain Candy, EDtv

Don't see also: Protocol

Pointless trivia: Small Time Crooks has been number one at French box offices since its release earlier this month.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: MPs thrown off the hunting trail

fields.headline: MPs thrown off the trail by lack of common scents
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Outside the Commons, countryside protesters were screaming and yelling and blocking the Christmas traffic. Why, I wondered, do people with strong feelings think they can convert waverers to their cause by behaving as objectionably as possible?
fields.body:
Outside the Commons, countryside protesters were screaming and yelling and blocking the Christmas traffic. Why, I wondered, do people with strong feelings think they can convert waverers to their cause by behaving as objectionably as possible?

Inside, Jack Straw was cautious. The bill offered three options; he supported the middle way, the compromise, the one that allows foxes a free vote on whether they wish to be killed. Or something on those lines.

Edward Leigh wondered if, since the Scottish parliament can make up its own mind on the subject, Scots MPs should abstain. Mr Straw replied with magnificent sophistry. The Scottish parliament had been set up by the Commons, and so was subordinate. The case was closed. Meaningless? Of course. It was that great political achievement, resonant bollocks. Jesuits would pay millions for talent like that.

Denis MacShane pointed out that during the Peninsular war the Duke of Wellington had hunted every Friday - though there were no foxes in Spain. Couldn't the Tories do the same? That was historical bollocks.

Mr Straw hoped that the house would not confuse things by voting in favour of all three options. "That would be a dog's breakfast," he said mildly - a bowl of fox's bollocks perhaps.

He snuffled on for half an hour like a hound who is in danger of losing the scent but doesn't really care.

David Lidington, the Tory spokesman (his boss, Ann Widdecombe, is ferociously anti-hunting) was opposed to "lamping", which means blinding foxes with lights, then shooting them with high-powered rifles. It could be dangerous to humans, he said, and he's right: for centuries amorous swains and sportive maids have regarded the countryside at night as one huge knocking shop.

Mike Foster, the MP who first moved a ban three years ago, was pinned down on his own sport, fishing. Wasn't that cruel to the fish?

"I do not go fishing with a pack of dogs," he said. Eh? Was anyone on either side going to deploy any logic here?

John Major, who knows a bit about being hunted to destruction, defended it for animals. "All violent death is distasteful, unless the fox dies in comfort, surrounded by his friends, and mourned by the neighbouring chickens." Mr Major uses sarcasm like a pugil stick on Gladiators, designed to unbalance rather than to wound.

Then the debate began to become truly bonkers, the landscape strewn with bollocks. Geoffrey Clifton-Brown solemnly warned: "There is a danger animals might be arrested." Tony Banks said pro-hunters were "the political descendants of slavers and people who sent little boys up chimneys".

"Grow up!" shouted furious Tories. "It's about human pleasure, it's about the chase, the bloodlust and the kill!" he yelled, and I swear I heard a rousing cry of "Bollocks!"

Then Michael Heseltine produced a fabulous rant, 10 minutes of the noise you hear at a speedway without the relief of the Doppler effect. When Mr Banks went fishing, he asked, "does he pat the fish on the head, throw it back, and say 'Do your best to survive, after I have taken the guts out of you'?" Was this really the most important issue facing the nation? Of course not! The bill existed purely in the narrow class interests of the Labour party.

At this, Labour's Ronnie Campbell was reproved for saying something roughly similar to "bollocks", but nothing would slow Hezza down. "His backside is pretty eloquent!" he raved.

And this is not the real debate on the three options: that's next year. I may need to flee the country, possibly to comfort Sir Richard Branson on his tropical paradise.

webTitle: Branson delays decision on legal action over national lottery loss

fields.headline: Branson delays decision on legal action over national lottery loss
fields.standfirst: Special report: The lottery
fields.trailText: The uncertainty hanging over the future running of the National Lottery will drag on for at least a few more weeks after Sir Richard Branson yesterday put off until the new years a decision on whether to press his claim in the courts.
fields.body:
The uncertainty hanging over the future running of the National Lottery will drag on for at least a few more weeks after Sir Richard Branson yesterday put off until the new years a decision on whether to press his claim in the courts.

Sir Richard, whose People's Lottery lost in the bidding to win the next licence on Tuesday, said his lawyers would be poring over documents from the lottery commission giving its reasons for rejecting his bid. The commission awarded the seven-year licence to Camelot after a process which has taken more than a year.

"Our people will be sitting down with lawyers over the next week or two," he said, before flying to the Caribbean to join his family on holiday. "We have a three month period in which we are able to go to the courts and we will decide early in the new year whether to pursue court action or not. The whole thing has been sad and unfortunate. The process has been worse than the American election."

Sir Richard said the commission's statement was "inconsistent" and raised a number of complex issues that would need time to evaluate.

The prospect of further delays was not welcomed by Dianne Thompson, Camelot chief executive. "It puts the timetable under jeopardy," she said.

"We are not going to start ordering new terminals with this going on. It puts the whole process under pressure again."

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, meanwhile acknowledged the need to overhaul the bidding process which over the past 12 months has frequently descended into farce.

"I think this was a fair process," he said. "The lottery commission has made a robust decision - part of the process has resulted in Camelot's profit margin being halved."

But he said that the government would have to examine the licencing process in the future.

"I am not entirely happy with the process, because I think anyone looking back over the last five or six months has to ask whether this is the right way to make a decision between two rival bidders for a lottery franchise," he said. "Once the dust has settled, I think we are going to have to have a look, speak to everyone involved and ask if we can come up with a better process the next time."

He said a large concern was whether Camelot, as the incumbent operator, had an unfair advantage.

He denied suggestions that the government had betrayed its pre-election pledge to install a not-for-profits lottery. "What depended absolutely was making sure that we found a viable bid that raised the most for the good causes."

Sir Richard may be encouraged to pursue a legal challenge by Camelot's success in the high court over the summer which allowed it back in the race to run the lottery.

webTitle: Straw spurns call for ban on hunting

fields.headline: Straw spurns call for ban on hunting
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Cabinet divisions over fox hunting emerged last                                                       night when the home secretary, Jack Straw, told                                                       MPs he opposed an outright ban and would                                                       instead support the option of tighter licensing of                                                       hunts.
fields.body:
Cabinet divisions over fox hunting emerged last night when the home secretary, Jack Straw, told MPs he opposed an outright ban and would instead support the option of tighter licensing of hunts.

His remarks, at the outset of the reading of a government bill setting out three options for the future of hunting, will strengthen the hand of those who oppose a ban.

It may also increase support for the licensing option in the Lords, where the ban proposal is expected to meet passionate opposition in the run-up to the general election.

Last night MPs voted to give the bill a second reading by 373 votes to 158, a majority of 215. The size of the majority does not give a clear indication if there is support for Mr Straw's choice, but backers of an outright ban were pleased.

Mr Straw insisted the expression of his personal views on the subject for the first time in 21 years was not designed to give a lead to other government members. But it may encourage other cabinet ministers, such as Robin Cook, to support licensing rather than an outright ban.

He said his opinion had been informed by the official inquiry into the economic impact of a ban on fox hunting which was led by Lord Burns.

Under the licensing scheme, only hunts which have been granted permission from a statutory hunting authority would be allowed to ride. Downing Street indicated that Mr Blair would vote for a full ban when MPs come to vote for one of the three options early in January.

Mr Blair's advisers believe a confrontation with the hunting lobby in the run-up to a general election could enthuse voters in the 20- to 30-year-old age group, who are believed to have become disillusioned with the government.

More than 1,000 hunt protesters demonstrated outside Westminster yesterday, severely disrupting traffic in central London and forcing Mr Blair to change his route.

Meanwhile, inside the Commons Tories attacked the ban proposal as illiberal and intolerant and warned that pro-hunting groups would carry out a campaign of civil disobedience if it was approved.

The three options before MPs are a complete ban; voluntary self-regulation, in which only hunts registered with the independent supervisory authority on hunting would be immune from prosecution on grounds of animal cruelty; or the compromise option favoured by Mr Straw.

This would require all hunts to apply for a licence from a hunting authority, which would appoint inspectors to visit hunts and draw up codes of practice.

webTitle: Zone sues BT over unmetered access

fields.headline: Zone sues BT over unmetered access
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: An internet service provider has began a legal assault on British Telecom.
fields.body:
An internet service provider has began a legal assault on British Telecom.

Zone Corporation has filed in Manchester high court, claiming that BT reneged on repeated promises to provide support for its unmetered service. The company says it is seeking £37.5m in compensation for losses incurred since a contract was signed in March.

Zone, which had planned to begin its freephone internet access service through www.08002go.com in June, claimed BT breached contractual commitments over connection costs.

Dennis Cawley, chief executive of the ISP, said BT had agreed to offer Zone unmetered connection to web users by buying line access for a fixed price.

He said that BT later told Zone that it would be charged by the minute for the service. He added that Zone, a privately owned company, was preparing for a costly legal battle and had secured considerable funds from shareholders to pursue BT through the courts.

A spokesman for BT said he was aware of the writ but added that the claim amounted to £500,000, not £37m. "We will contest it vigorously," he said. "We strongly refute any claim of liability."

In August, BT was reported as claiming that "no contract was entered into by the parties".

webTitle: Nato in talks to curb Serb border clashes

fields.headline: Nato in talks to curb Serb border clashes
fields.standfirst:
Kosovo peacekeepers find large haul of Albanian arms

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Kosovo peacekeepers find large haul of Albanian arms
fields.body:
The commander of K-For, the Nato-led peacekeeping force in Kosovo, held high-level talks in Serbia yesterday aimed at calming tensions on the boundary with the province.

Lieutenant General Carlo Cabigiosu met the Serbian deputy prime minister, Nebojsa Covic, in Bujanovac, close to where ethnic Albanian guerrillas and Yugoslav security forces have clashed over the last month.

The meeting came hours after British troops arrested 13 ethnic Albanians found carrying a large number of heavy weapons. They had been travelling towards Serbia. Around the same time a UN police station in Serb-dominated northern Kosovo came under attack from machine-gun fire and a rocket-propelled grenade. No one was hurt.

The talks in Serbia followed calls from the Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, for a renegotiation of a peace agreement which prevents Yugoslav troops entering a three-mile exclusion zone along the boundary with Kosovo.

The area has been used by ethnic Albanian rebels to attack Serbian troops with virtual impunity. Calls for a change to the agreement have been repeated by Serb politicians in the run-up to Serbian parliamentary elections due this Saturday.

But a K-For spokesman, Major Steve Shappell, denied that the accord, signed by Nato and Yugoslavia at the end of war in Kosovo, was up for discussion. "There will be no change to the military technical agreement," he said.

He added that the meeting was part of an "ongoing dialogue to look for a peace solution to the situation".

The arrest of the armed men took place early yesterday near the village of Draghibac Mahala. A K-For spokesmen said the group offered no resistance, when stopped by the patrol. The soldiers had been deployed in the area the day before, specifically to prevent the flow of weapons and men across to Serbia.

The weapons seized included 30 rocket-propelled grenades, 50 hand grenades, rocket launchers, anti-tank mines and heavy machineguns.

The group was taken to the main American army base in the region, Camp Bondsteel, for questioning.

While K-For has been concentrating its attention on the border with Serbia, the UN administration in Kosovo has been struggling to cope with a wave of violence in the north of the province.

A UN spokeswomen, Susan Manuel, condemned the attack on the police station, which also houses the local council headquarters, as "another act of mindless violence".

Four police cars were raked with automatic gunfire and another blown up by a grenade late on Tuesday night. A rocket-propelled grenade was fired through a window.

Police were out on patrol at the time.

The attack follows a weekend of violence in which one Serb was shot dead by K-For soldiers and seven Belgian troops were taken hostage for three hours in the town of Leposavic.

Following the violence, the UN ordered its international and locally recruited police service and all UN personnel to withdraw from the town.

"We definitely think there is some kind of pattern going on. We don't know where it's coming from and where it going, though," Ms Manuel said.

The UN has yet to return its police and staff to Leposavic, where the role of law enforcement appears to have been taken on by the local community. It is unclear if they will return before the ballot for the Serbian parliament gets under way at the weekend.

The weapons seized included 30 rocket-propelled grenades, 50 hand grenades, rocket launchers, anti-tank mines and heavy machineguns. The group was taken to the main American army base in the region, Camp Bondsteel, for questioning. While K-For has been concentrating its attention on the border with Serbia, the UN administration in Kosovo has been struggling to cope with a wave of violence in the north of the province. A UN spokeswomen, Susan Manuel, condemned the attack on the police station, which also houses the local council headquarters, as "another act of mindless violence". Four police cars were raked with automatic gunfire and another blown up by a grenade late on Tuesday night. A rocket-propelled grenade was fired through a window. Police were out on patrol at the time. The attack follows a weekend of violence in which one Serb was shot dead by K-For soldiers and seven Belgian troops were taken hostage for three hours in the town of Leposavic. Following the violence, the UN ordered its international and locally recruited police service and all UN personnel to withdraw from the town. "We definitely think there is some kind of pattern going on. We don't know where it's coming from and where it going, though," Ms Manuel said. The UN has yet to return its police and staff to Leposavic, where the role of law enforcement appears to have been taken on by the local community. It is unclear if they will return before the ballot for the Serbian parliament gets under way at the weekend.

fields.headline: You've been quangoed
fields.standfirst:
The controversial rulings of successive lottery commissioners have led to uproar. But it's not easy to find independent decision-makers

The lottery
fields.trailText: Were Lord Burns of the National Lottery Commission less shy and retiring he might well complain at his treatment over the past 48 hours. He got the culture secretary, Chris Smith, off the hook - deciding between Camelot and the Branson bid was always going to be ticklish. Assembled on the commission was some formidable brain power and a heap of experience from both public and private sectors - theirs was, at least, an informed judgment. For their pains Burns and his colleagues have been thrust into the maw of political controversy. Hung out to dry is the American phrase.
fields.body:
Were Lord Burns of the National Lottery Commission less shy and retiring he might well complain at his treatment over the past 48 hours. He got the culture secretary, Chris Smith, off the hook - deciding between Camelot and the Branson bid was always going to be ticklish. Assembled on the commission was some formidable brain power and a heap of experience from both public and private sectors - theirs was, at least, an informed judgment. For their pains Burns and his colleagues have been thrust into the maw of political controversy. Hung out to dry is the American phrase.

Assailed from the liberal left for being unaccountable, the right says they are all too close to the government of the day. All they have to cling to is the idea that they are indeed "independent".

It is a key attribute. We attach it to the police complaints authority, the Audit Commission, Lord Neill's committee on standards in public life, to assorted ombudsmen. But the quality of independence is deeply puzzling. In a democracy it smacks of aristocratic high-mindedness. In a post-Marxist, post-Freudian age does anyone have no interests, no "side"?

For practical purposes independence may mean little more than not belonging to a political party. The public is convinced that, say, the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority is not owned by politicians and so tend to respect its judgments the more. Yet the formula is beset with difficulties. Why should a government elected on a manifesto with a large majority appoint people to executive bodies who are not committed to its cause and might obstruct its will?

Tony Blair gets accused of Napoleonic tendencies and Labour's detractors cite the host of task forces it has created to do its bidding. Yet this is also the government that has surrendered a key tool of economic policy making to the monetary policy committee of the Bank of England (MPC). Its members show every sign of thinking for themselves. Similarly the National Institute for Clinical Excellence has defied critics by its tough-minded independence in approving - or not - drugs and treatments, whether or not the NHS budget can sustain them.

To be independent means to be untied from the apron strings of public accountability through elected politicians. There are other kinds of answerability. The minutes of the MPC are published - the latest set out yesterday - and they provide a kind of public checking. Decisions by quangos are subject to review by the courts and challenges under the Human Rights Act are growing. But bringing the judges in just shifts the problem of independence one stage further on. Why are judges any more trustworthy than quangocrats? They too are appointed by the state and are notably biased in terms of their education and social formation.

One response to criticism of governance by quango has been to make the National Lottery Commission and similar bodies more representative of the population at large. The chart shows the percentage of women and ethnic minorities serving on quangos under the wing of Chris Smith's Department of Culture, Media and Sport; the targets that have been set for increasing these proportions by 2004, are 50% women and 7% ethnic minorities.

But representativeness, while valuable, is not the same as accountability. The trouble is the kind of accountability to which politicians are subject - publicly answering questions, appearing on Newsnight, being doorstepped by tabloids - is unpalatable to many potential quangocrats. If they liked that kind of exposure they would have become party politicians in the first place.

So here is the conundrum. Accountability may require more partisanship yet decisions that are motivated by party considerations are increasingly distrusted by the public. The growth of appointed bodies, the MPC's DeAnne Julius says in an interview to be broadcast this evening*, is itself a sign of lack of trust in government.

That is a self-inflicted wound. Pre-Thatcher the great and good got on with it, in a hinterland where their lack of formal accountability went unquestioned. Under the Tories public bodies snapped to attention and were tied closer to the state by means of audits and performance targets. For all her anti-quango rhetoric, Thatcher created many more while downgrading elective politics both locally and at Westminster.

Post-Thatcher the Tories have discovered the virtues of political oversight. Yesterday the European Policy Forum (EPF), a right-leaning think-tank, listed the various bodies that take executive decisions that properly belong to politicians. They range from the Learning and Skills Council to the Food Stan dards Agency. But while these are not directly accountable, they do give the state access to talent and expertise and they are cheap. Graham Mather of the EPF admits they also tend to operate in a "more rational" framework than the politicians and civil servants they have superseded. He usefully suggests better training for their members and tighter terms of reference.

But ultimately there is only one source of "proper" accountability and that is the elected portion of parliament, the Commons. (Lords reform opens possibilities for a second chamber.) Unless and until MPs themselves become less partisan, more rational and more capable of sharing government, they are the weakest link.

 The independents, BBC Radio Four Analysis tonight at 8.30pm.

webTitle: Russia's spies reveal their greatest hits

fields.headline: Russia's spies reveal their greatest hits
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russia's security organs abandoned their custom of secrecy yesterday for a public celebration of the services' achievements with a Kremlin banquet and the release of a special compilation CD.
fields.body:
Russia's security organs abandoned their custom of secrecy yesterday for a public celebration of the services' achievements with a Kremlin banquet and the release of a special compilation CD.

Officers have compiled a collection of intelligence agents' favourite songs about their profession - the tunes chosen to help operatives to relax after a hard day's spying - to mark the country's annual Chekist's Day, which commemorates the establishment of the Soviet secret police, the Cheka, on December 20 1917.

The CD, titled Being an Agent is Their Difficult Job, is unlikely to be a chartbuster in Russia, where memories of Stalinist secret police repression are fresh, so it will not go on sale to the public.

Instead veterans and active security service officers who attended last night's celebrations in the Kremlin were given the 22-track disc. Many of the songs were written and performed by serving officers and most have never been heard by civilians. Titles include I Obey Orders, From Kabul to Washington, and Here Goes Your Friend, Off on a Mission.

A fleeting extract from one patriotic ballad, sung by a retired officer, was broadcast on state television yesterday. Its mournful chorus is: "The words intelligence, motherland and honour were always sacred to us."

Boris Labusov, a spokesman for the Foreign Intelligence Service which is celebrating its 80th anniversary, said the songs had been chosen to represent the realities of life as an intelligence officer, and added that many of the lyrics would be incomprehensible to those not initiated in the traditions and jargon of the force.

The project was primarily motivated by gratitude to retired officers, he said, many of whom missed the excitement of their years of service.

"I spoke to many veterans who admitted that they often dream at night of the Forest," he said, referring to the security services headquarters which are hidden in a forest at Yasenevo, near Moscow. "We hoped to soften these moments of nostalgia for them by releasing this compact disc."

Russia's most famous former spy is the president, Vladimir Putin, a career KGB officer. He was due to receive his own copy at last night's celebrations. In a speech to Kremlin guests, he said that security officers had for too long been "considered guilty for the mistakes and crimes of those who were in authority".

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Code targets oil firms
fields.body:
Code targets oil firms

A joint British-American code of conduct published yesterday says oil and mining companies must take human rights more seriously if they are to avoid controversies such as those faced by BP in Colombia, Shell in Nigeria and Rio Tinto in Papua New Guinea.

The guidelines require companies to observe the UN declaration of human rights and similar international codes, to recognise the importance of business in supporting human rights and to be open about their actions and experiences.

The new code was issued jointly by the foreign office and the US state department after 18 months of negotiations between companies and campaign groups such as Amnesty International.

Oil companies involved include US operators Texaco, Chevron and Conoco as well as Shell and BP from Britain.

This is the first time the government has brokered an international code of conduct between companies and non-governmental organisations, and the first British-American co-operation in such a venture.

The code aims to prevent human rights abuses in war-torn countries such as Colombia and Burma, where western companies are obliged to employ their own armies or pay state forces for protection.

Court clears drugs merger

Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham cleared the final hurdle in their £120bn merger yesterday, as the high court approved the creation of new shares in the combined company.

The merged firm will begin trading on Wednesday. It will be the world's largest drugs group, and the second biggest company in the FTSE 100, behind Vodafone.

The deal has taken almost a year to complete because of lengthy negotiations with the US Federal Trade Commission.

Freeserve joins the lottery

The web portal Freeserve yesterday confirmed it would create a lottery ticket sales website under a deal struck with Camelot, the lottery operator which was awarded another seven-year licence this week.

Freeserve refused to reveal the duration of the deal or forecast online sales. "These are confidential terms between us and Camelot," a spokesman said.

Freeserve shares fell 8.5p to 95.5p yesterday after dipping to an all-time low of 93p in another bad day for technology shares.

Bass chief to get big pay-off

The head of Bass's brewing operations, Iain Napier, was paid £1.24m last year and could get another £978,000 if he loses his job following the business's takeover by Belgian firm Interbrew.

Mr Napier was one of three million-pound earners on Bass's board, according to the leisure group's annual report. Chairman Sir Ian Prosser received £1.17m , while hotels boss Tom Oliver enjoyed £1.03m.

webTitle: Hunting ban is threat to freedom, warn Tory MPs

fields.headline: Hunting ban is threat to freedom, warn Tory MPs
fields.standfirst:
Straw rejects fears on policing law

Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Banning hunting with hounds is a "wicked proposal" with severe civil liberties implications, the Tories claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Banning hunting with hounds is a "wicked proposal" with severe civil liberties implications, the Tories claimed yesterday.

As several thousand pro-hunt protesters ringed Parliament, Conservative backbenchers said a ban would be an affront to the rights of minorities.

"This wicked proposal would separate liberty from justice and is a thoroughly undesirable thing to do," warned Nicholas Soames, MP for Mid Sussex.

The former agriculture minister, John Gummer, said: "This is a serious matter, very deep, about freedom, which, if it is carried through, will threaten every minority in this country."

Tories also took the opportunity to link a hunting ban with the decline in police numbers, with Nigel Evans, MP for Ribble Valley, saying many of his rural constitutents rarely saw "a local bobby" and this situation could only worsen if officers were diverted into "pursuing a group of people who have now become criminals".

Questioned on how many more police would be required to enforce the ban, the home secretary, Jack Straw, quoted an Association of Chief Police Officers estimate that the police resources channelled into this would be similar to those currently brought in to deal with protests by hunt saboteurs.

Mr Straw stressed that after 22 failed backbench attempts to deal with fox hunting, the bill had not been determined by the government itself, but rather contained three options suggested by leading interest groups. The first option, self regulation, was put forward by the Countryside Alliance.

The second option, regulation, was put forward by the Middle Way Group and based on the premise that hunting with dogs should be allowed to continue but only on a statutorily licensed basis.

The third option, a complete ban, was put forward by the RSPCA, the League Against Cruel Sports and the International Fund for Animal Welfare. Mr Straw stressed that his preference for regulation was purely a personal opinion and added: "We believe that the time has come to deal with the issue of hunting with dogs once and for all."

The shadow home affairs spokesman, David Lidington, warned a ban would prove "an acutely damaging act on families and communities."

Up to 7,000 full-time jobs would be at stake, and, while this number was small in terms of the national aggregrate, "if you are a young father living in a tithed house who knows Parliament is debating today whether to deprive you of your home and your livelihood," this was little consolation.

If Parliament "were to decide quite deliberately to take away the livelihood of even one man or woman in this country that would be a matter which should cause real heart-searching in the house", he added.

Describing the ban as "misguided and unecessary", Mr Lidington said the case for a ban on animal welfare grounds was "shaky". In animal welfare terms, a ban would lead to more wounded animals suffering due to different methods of animal control such as snaring and shooting.

Labour MP Michael Foster, whose private member's bill to ban hunting was supported by 411 MPs in November 1997, said the chase involved in fox hunting inflicted unnecessary pain on the prey and that this chase was intrinsic to hunting.

"The chase is unnecessary but it is the very essence of the sport which is associated with hunting.

"It causes the animal unnecessary suffering and therefore is by definition cruel and no amount of regulatory approaches can fail to reach the same conclusion."

The Burns inquiry had disproved hunters' claims that foxes suffered a quick death from "a nip to the back of the neck", he said, cataloguing the serious injuries uncovered by post mortems on hunted animals.

He warned the end of hunting was nigh. "For all those people that enjoy the ride, the countryside and the camaraderie, I say take the hint. Hunting foxes is going to be banned so develop the alternatives now."

fields.headline: The worst cut
fields.standfirst:
This week, a GP has been struck off because of it. Last month, the government published a report on it. Audrey Gillan reveals how female genital mutilation is finally being brought out of the shadows

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: This week, a GP has been struck off because of it. Last month, the government published a report on it. Audrey Gillan reveals how female genital mutilation is finally being brought out of the shadows.
fields.body:
The first thing Ara Weelo remembers is the smell. Even now she doesn't know what it was but it was acrid and unpleasant. She was just seven years old. There were seven other girls there, some bigger, some smaller, all waiting on something they knew very little about.

When an older girl told Ara that she was about to have her genitals cut, she fled, but one of the village women ran after her and brought her back. Four women did the cutting and they took the girls into a small hut, one by one.

Ara winces as she speaks. "They did it without an anaesthetic. I think I fainted. Four women held me down and they cut something, I don't know, maybe the clitoris, because I fainted and I didn't know anything else of what happened to me. When I woke up, I was in a hut. All of these girls, their legs were bandaged together and they were lying like that and they were not saying anything, but I screamed when I woke up. My grandmother said: 'Look at all these girls, it has happened to them, too'."

The next thing Ara remembers is the pain - Ara was not just circumcised but infibulated, the most severe form of genital mutilation. "You have pain, you have sores, you cannot wee, you cannot do anything for four or five days. You cannot get up, you cannot move. After this day, the woman who did the cutting comes back. They put a thorn through you to make the stitches and she comes back and rips it out and puts that stuff that smells horrible on you.

"Sometimes, the cutting doesn't heal up. What I will never forget in my life is that two of the girls' stitches never came together - when they take the thorn out, the skin must stitch together; if it comes apart, you have to do it again. Those two girls had to have it done again. Even now, if I see a knife or blood, I can't bear it. It shouldn't happen to anybody."

Ara, who is from Somalia but now lives in east London, was a victim of female genital mutilation, one of 2m girls worldwide who have their genitals cut each year. The age of the child can vary; cutting can happen to babies as well as to young girls whose cultures believe it is a rite of passage.

The prevalence of FGM in the UK is unknowable, the subject itself taboo. Euphemisms such as "cutting the rose" have allowed us to hide from its horrible reality. In the past, debates over cultural integrity - given credence by Germaine Greer's recent claim in her book The Whole Woman that "one man's beautification is another man's mutilation" - have distorted the issue.

Now, though, FGM is becoming increasingly discussed in some major institutions and the brutality of the practice is clear. This week, a GP was struck off the register after he agreed to carry out genital mutilation at £50 a time. Abdul Ahmed was videotaped in 1997 agreeing to cut an eight-year-old girl and "circumcise and stitch" two older girls. The General Medical Council did not believe his claims that he was talking about circumcising boys, not girls.

Last month, the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Population, Development and Reproductive Health published its Parliamentary Hearings report on Female Genital Mutilation. At the same time, a conference in Brussels heard campaigners call for women to be allowed asylum if they were fleeing from the practice; the European Union is considering the implications of FGM as a fundamental abuse of human rights.

The Parliamentary Hearings report notes that "there is currently a severe shortage of data on the prevalence of FGM in the UK and overseas". However, the hearings were told that around 6,000 girls in the UK are at risk of FGM.

The World Health Organisation now believes that the average age at which it is performed is falling.

It is the lack of any real action or investigation into the prevalence of FGM in the UK that frustrates campaigners working to eradicate the practice.

webTitle: Council's reminder on rent arrears hits dud festive note

fields.headline: Council's reminder on rent arrears hits dud festive note
fields.standfirst: Special report: Christmas 2000
fields.trailText: At first sight it was a greeting anyone would be happy to receive: a picture of a jolly Father Christmas bearing a teddy bear and other gifts. But council tenants in Torfaen county in south-east Wales were startled to read its seasonal message: pay up or lose your home.
fields.body:
At first sight it was a greeting anyone would be happy to receive: a picture of a jolly Father Christmas bearing a teddy bear and other gifts. But council tenants in Torfaen county in south-east Wales were startled to read its seasonal message: pay up or lose your home.

The festive flyers about rent arrears have brought little cheer to council occupants, who are furious at what they see as sick and tasteless tactics.

"The best Christmas present is a secure home," the leaflet reads. "Remember to pay your rent - don't lose your home this Christmas."

Advice agencies had numerous calls from upset tenants. The Torfaen Federation of Tenants and Residents' Associations condemned the tone of the leaflet as intimidating. "It's insensitive," said a spokesman. "The intention was probably genuine, but it's gone down like a lead balloon.

"I thought I was being wound up when I first saw it. It's a low income area with high poverty and unemployment, and a lot of people genuinely do want to pay rent - and struggle at the best of times."

He added: "A lot of these arrears cases are due to housing benefit underpayment or slow payment. Some people have gone into arrears through no fault of their own."

Torfaen county council yesterday insisted it was simply sending a "kindly" reminder.

"It's not a strongly worded or disagreeable message," said a spokeswoman. "It's a positive message that part of providing for your family is paying rent as well as buying them Christmas presents. That's something people who are paying their rent can be proud of ...

"We are very receptive to people who have fallen into difficulties with rent arrears. The message is: please call us and let us know what you can do about them, and we will do whatever we can to help you."

webTitle: Imber residents mourn village requisitioned in 1943

fields.headline: It is Christmas and the gates open to a village the army never gave back
fields.standfirst: Imber residents mourn the day in December 1943 when the US army took their homes
fields.trailText: Imber residents mourn the day in December 1943 when the US army took their homes
fields.body:
It is no longer on the map, its parish status was withdrawn years ago and you can only take the road there on certain dates. The village of Imber in Wiltshire is all but a spectre of rural life. For on December 17, 1943, its tenants were evicted for D-Day manoeuvres - the few hundred residents were told they had to make way for the American army. They were led to believe that when the war ended, they could move back to their homes, but it never happened and Imber stayed in the midst of a massive firing range.

On November 1, 1943, the people of Imber were summoned to the local school. They were shocked to learn that their village had been requisitioned under crown prerogative, which effectively allowed the War Office to evacuate the place without consultation or compensation. The villagers were told they were leaving their homes for king and country, but only until the war was over. They never returned.

For two weeks over Christmas (and on other days over the year), you can drive to this desolate place in the middle of Salisbury Plain and marvel at the ruins of buildings that locals will tell you were stolen from the people of Imber.

The road up over the downs has a warning sign: Live Firing Range Closed To Public: Keep Out. On most days of the year, the Imber ranges are used for military manouevres. In the new year it will be host to a massive display of firepower.

Tank tracks scar the rolling hills and bollards, fences and barbed wire line the side of the road.

When the villagers left in the days before Christmas, 1943, they were, they felt, cruelly deprived of their usual celebrations in the Bell Inn. The village had a church, four farms, a blacksmith, two big houses, and about 40 cottages and newly-built council houses. Now, these buildings are little more than shells.

The church of St Giles has an out-of-bounds sign and a perimeter fence of barbed wire. In front of it is a notice saying: "This plaque was erected by Wiltshire county council to commemorate VE and VJ days in tribute to the considerable sacrifice to the war effort made by the people of Imber, who gave up their home in December 1943 in order that the military training area could be extended. Imber has remained under military control and the parish was abolished in 1991."

The once grand Imber Court has been stripped bare, the oak staircase has gone along with the ornate plasterwork, and the first battalion of the Royal Hampshire regiment have left their mark, saying they "Were 'ere 1986", while other soldiers have noted "Any women welcome". The word "Freedom!" has been scrawled across the top of the bullet-riddled building.

Down the hill, the council houses - built less than 18 months before the villagers were asked to leave - are carcasses.

Imber has always been remote, the local rhyme had it right when it said: "Little Imber on the down, five miles from any town." But its people loved their distance and never imagined it would become remote in their memories as well as reality.

Perhaps because of its isolation, the war department started buying up the land around Imber at the turn of the century. In 1932, it bought the freehold from the farmers, leaving just the Bell Inn, the blacksmith and the church. But the villagers did not think they would be forced to leave.

Richard Hooper, whose family came from Imber, says: "They were given six weeks to clear everything out of the village and the floods were up like they are now. It was typical MoD: they broke their promises.They said after the war, when the Americans had finished with it, they promised they would give it back. The Americans cleaned up all the ranges and filled up the trenches in the fields but the day the Americans walked out the British army walked in. It was still inhabitable until the British walked in."

In 1961, the Defence of the Realm Act, which sanctioned the taking of Imber, expired and the villagers joined together in the hope that they might get their homes back. The Association for the Restoration of Imber called for a mass invasion on January 22 and 2,000 people turned up, including more than 200 old villagers. A message read from Sir John Betjeman said: "Success to your campaign! Wiltshire and the rolling downs for ever! God save Imber!"

After two more demonstrations, a further rally on March 26 was obstructed by an MoD announcement that the ranges would be in use that day. The people said they would fight on, but an injunction was served that they could not afford to break. The government called for a public inquiry which would look at stopping up the right of way through Imber forever.

Ultimately, the villagers were to be given access to Imber for up to 50 days a year; the church would be kept up and the people would have the right to hold a service there every September. It was also promised that should the need for the range ever disappear, the village would, as had been originally said, be given back to the people.

Walk through the village today and you can see the road built by US troops. All around lies evidence that this place is the site of secret military activity: there are empty ration tins, silver sachets of Instant Dried Skimmed Milk, a Pepsi can, a wrapper for a safety light.

Once a year the army will go in and clear up their mess around the church and put some pews in so that those remote from Imber can return to the graves of their dead.

Yet the ranges, in spite of their purpose, are also places of remarkable ecological interest on this, the largest chalk downland in Europe. All around Imber the scent of fox is intense and the fairy shrimp, one of the rarest crustaceans, is thriving in the puddles and pools created by tank ruts. There has also been an increase in the number of barn owls because of barn boxes put in barns used for military training: five years ago there were only two breeding pairs and now there is in excess of 150.

But for those that remember Imber, this is a bitter consolation.

Lionel Daniels, whose father Fred was a farm labourer, left the village when he was seven. "It must have been heartbreaking ... most of the older people because had never been out of the village. Most of them had to find a house and a job, all within about a month or so,"

"I don't think they gave them any compensation. They promised they could go back. It's lost now forever, isn't it?

"If they were ever to let it go back, property developers would move in. It wouldn't be what it was. It would turn into a yuppie village."

fields.headline: Ministers 'ignored flood warnings'
fields.standfirst:
MPs say EU rules should have stopped farmers creating excess run-off of water, while conservators rescue business records

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: MPs say EU rules should have stopped farmers creating excess run-off of water, while conservators rescue business records
fields.body:
The floods which ravaged Britain this autumn could partly be blamed on the Ministry of Agriculture, a cross-party group of MPs ruled yesterday, because of its failure to impose rules on farmers to prevent flooding.

A Commons environment select committee report issued a "grave condemnation" of ministers for failing to implement an EU directive requiring the risk of flooding to be assessed if farmers wished to plough up their uncultivated grassland.

Without such rules, farmers have ploughed up unsuitable land leading excess water to run off the fields, explained Andrew Bennett, the committee's chairman.

The Ministry of Agriculture admitted the rules should have been imposed, and pledged they would be addressed in a new year consultation paper. "We recognise that this should have been implemented but it wasn't and that goes back to the last administration," a spokeswoman added.

The MPs' criticism came in a report calling for urgent government action to slow the rate of house building and agricultural development on flood plains to counter the risk of floods such as this autumn's, when 6,500 homes were swamped and the nation suffered the most extreme floods since records began in 1766.

The report - which came as Devon suffered its 100th consecutive day of rain - is particularly timely since it comes three days after the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, gave the go-ahead for 39,000 homes a year to be built in the south-east, despite the environment agency warning the risk of flooding would rise if they were built on flood plains.

The government is sympathetic to the report's proposals, with the housing minister, Nick Raynsford, describing the committee as "pushing at an open door" in its demands for tougher planning regulations.

The publication of a draft planning policy guidance notice concerning building on flood plains has been postponed to take into account the recommendations of the committee.

The report, which warned that climate change could mean floods overcome the Thames barrier in south-east London within 50 years, called for the guidance to be strengthened to limit future flood plains building.

Some 1.85m homes, 185,000 commercial properties and 5m people were now at risk from flooding in Britain, the report noted, and the risk was growing with pressure for more brown site building.

The committee recommended that councils should only authorise flood plain development in exceptional circumstances, and that local plans should be revised to remove flood risk land from areas designated for development.

Home buyers should also be told of the likelihood of their new home flooding with information on flood risk being a standard part of local authority searches.

A Commons environment select committee report issued a "grave condemnation" of ministers for failing to implement an EU directive requiring the risk of flooding to be assessed if farmers wished to plough up their uncultivated grassland. Without such rules, farmers have ploughed up unsuitable land leading excess water to run off the fields, explained Andrew Bennett, the committee's chairman. The Ministry of Agriculture admitted the rules should have been imposed, and pledged they would be addressed in a new year consultation paper. "We recognise that this should have been implemented but it wasn't and that goes back to the last administration," a spokeswoman added.
