webTitle: The Queen's English of today: My 'usband and I ...

fields.headline: The Queen's English of today: My 'usband and I ...
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Once she sounded like Celia Johnson in Brief Encounter. Now, according to Australian researchers, the Queen sounds just a little more like Jonathan Ross in Film Night.
fields.body:
Once she sounded like Celia Johnson in Brief Encounter. Now, according to Australian researchers, the Queen sounds just a little more like Jonathan Ross in Film Night.

After tuning in to three decades of Christmas messages they found that, over the years, the royal vowels had shifted daintily down the social scale.

"Our analysis reveals that the Queen's pronunciation of some vowels has been influenced by the standard southern British [SSB] accent of the 1980s, which is more typically associated with speakers younger and lower in the social hierarchy," said Jonathan Harrington and three colleagues at Macquarie University in Sydney. "We conclude that the Queen no longer speaks the Queen's English of the 1950s, although the vowels of the 1980s Christmas message are still clearly set apart from those of an SSB accent."

The researchers report in Nature today that they see the gentle shift from cut-glass to cockney as part of the blurring of class distinctions in Britain. Modern received pronunciation, for instance, resists the dropped "h" of those born within the sound of Bow bells, but there is a cockney-influenced tendency to pronounce the "l" in milk as if it were a vowel. Some of these changes have been led by younger people who reject establishment pronunciation, the researchers say. Could the older generation have resisted the influence of the young?

So Dr Harrington and his colleagues went straight to the older generation at the pinnacle of the British establishment. "The Queen's Christmas broadcasts were ideal for addressing this issue. Firstly they have been annual for a long period of time; secondly the Queen's accent is obviously not going to be influenced by geographical changes; thirdly any changes we observe are not going to be influenced by changes to style and content of the messages, because these have been quite consistent throughout."

With the blessing of Buckingham Palace and help from the BBC archives, the team compared the royal vowels of the 1950s and 1980s with the vowels of other female broadcasters. They found that in each case the Queen's accent had drifted towards the vowels of the younger generation.

"We are all familiar with the change that has taken place in the vowels of words like 'that man' where, in the 1930s, we still had something like 'thet men,' " said Jonathan Wells, professor of linguistics at University College London. "She is only following along trends that exist in any case. She still remains well behind them, shall we say, and of course she still sounds upper-class, the way she always did."

fields.headline: Hague cash problem over police
fields.standfirst:
Special report: policing crime
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague last night tried to give greater credibility to the Conservative assault on crime by promising for the first time to match planned government spending increases in the police budget.
fields.body:
William Hague last night tried to give greater credibility to the Conservative assault on crime in the wake of the Damiola Taylor murder by promising for the first time to match planned government spending increases in the police budget.

The commitment came as Mr Hague and Tony Blair clashed over falling police numbers at prime minister's questions. Mr Hague accused Mr Blair of being "tough on crime fighters", rather than on the causes of crime.

The prime minister held back from directly accusing Mr Hague of racism, or of playing the race card, but sparked Tory outrage by accusing the opposition leader of being guilty of opportunism over Damiola's death.

With tempers fraying, Mr Hague warned of a crisis in morale in the police service, reflected by a fall of 3,000 in officer numbers since Labour came to power. The Conservative leader told Mr Blair: "If you think we are going to be proposing a cut in the police budget, you are off your head."

Tory sources acknowledged Mr Hague's spending pledge follows pressure from Ann Widdecombe, shadow home secretary, who has been discomfited in her attacks on Jack Straw's crime policies by her inability to pledge matched spending on the police budget.

However, the new pledge severely reduces the options for Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, as he struggles to meet his commitment to find £8bn annual cuts in overall government spending within three years. So far Mr Portillo has located only £5.6bn worth of cuts.

In a further sign of the pressure on Mr Portillo, the shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan-Smith, yesterday signalled he was also locked in a tough talks with the shadow chancellor over defence spending. He said on BBC radio yesterday that because of increasing commitments the Tories would have to "look seriously at increasing defence spending".

During yesterday's Commons exchanges Mr Blair confirmed that almost 27,000 prisoners had been released early under Labour's electronic tagging scheme, including 1,000 who had gone on to commit other offences.

Tory strategists believe the 3,000 cut in police numbers since the election, the recent rise in robbery and the example of 1,000 crimes committed by prisoners on early release add up to a powerful cocktail with which to hit the government.

Ministers are pinning their hope on a fall in violent crime figures due to be released in mid-January. They also hope figures in March will show a slight rise in police recruits.

webTitle: Stop internet dirty tricks, says Speaker

fields.headline: Stop internet dirty tricks, says Speaker
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The Speaker, Michael Martin, yesterday told political parties to stamp out "dirty tricks" campaigns being waged between political rivals on the internet.
fields.body:
The Speaker, Michael Martin, yesterday told political parties to stamp out "dirty tricks" campaigns being waged between political rivals on the internet.

Mr Martin expressed his "strong disapproval" of such tactics after an MP complained that he had been the victim of "cyber impersonation".

Bob Russell, the Lib Dem MP for Colchester, told colleagues that a website had been set up in the name of Bob Russell MP "but I can assure you that is not I who has done so. Inquiries reveal the web page has been set up by a leading member of a political party - of which I am not a member - in my constituency".

Rather than taking web users to Mr Russell's own website, a search for www.bobrussellmp.co.uk allegedly led directly to the Conservative party's own website.

The Speaker yesterday expressed his "strong disapproval", adding: "I do not expect officers or employees of political parties to seek to register on the internet names of members of other parties with a view to misleading members of the public.

"I expect all political parties represented in the house to take steps to ensure that no such activity is undertaken by them or on their behalf."

Mr Martin's warning came after Mr Russell raised his complaint as a point of order.

webTitle: Catherine Bennett on the national lottery

fields.headline: Another fine mess
fields.standfirst:
How the fat cats finally beat the Cheshire cat to the lottery cream

The lottery
fields.trailText: How the fat cats finally beat the Cheshire cat to the lottery cream.
fields.body:
Has a glass ever looked more half-full? And yet, at the same time, more half-empty? Those of us who have doubted Tony Blair's wisdom in applying this form of efficacy-evaluation to the political mainstream can only concede its aptness to the work of the national lottery commission, and hang our heads. For it is, in its way, a perfect summary of the lottery outcome.

On the one hand the glass is half-full: Branson, the crown prince of gittishness, has lost. On the other, the glass is half-empty: Camelot, a practised gang of profiteers, has won. You don't know whether to laugh or cry, do you Tone? Well, you do actually. That little tear glistening in the corner of one of Branson's eyes, as he took in the tragic scale of this abrupt fortune-reversal, was the funniest thing since the death of little Nell.

Then again, the revival of Camelot's fortunes must be terribly distressing for New Labour. It is only five years, after all, since the first waves of revulsion caused by Camelot's surging, £1m-a-week profits had Blair and his shadow cabinet queueing up to denounce Camelot and promise their own, cleansing reforms. "Camelot has a licence to print tickets and another to print money", objected Jack Cunningham, then shadow heritage spokesman, who went on to describe the operator as "another private monopoly set up by a Conservative government".

In his celebrated "People's Lottery" speech, Tony Blair confirmed that he would open bids for a non-profit-making operator in 2000, "so we can release more money for the benefit of good causes". He pointed out that "No other country in Europe runs a private profit-making lottery". Meanwhile, Chris Smith, shadow heritage secretary, declared that Labour would make sure that, "the lottery serves the people". He said: "The government promised that the lottery would benefit every man, woman and child in Britain. Instead, the distribution of money has become a joke."

Since when the joke has got progressively more side-splitting. In fact the story of Labour and the lottery is, in some ways, even more comically terrible than that of Labour and the dome. Labour had not, in opposition, set its face against the dome. And where the dome builders were culpably vainglorious, the lottery commissioners seem to have been plain thick. The great similarity between these two calamities, of course, is that no one of political consequence is going to be held accountable for the mess.

Just as the dome emerged as a natural disaster, a force of nature no man could possibly have tamed, so the awarding of the lottery licence is already being portrayed as a task so impossibly huge and complex - think of all those awesome piles of papers! Think of all those big sums! - that we should be grateful that anyone has been found to run it at all, even the beastly old monopoly we all despised back in 1995.

Like the genesis of the dome, the selection of a lottery licence will turn out to be so Byzantine a procedure that its complexities can never be satisfactorily explained. We shall never know, for example, why Smith chose to fill his spanking new quango, the national lottery commission, with five people who so consummately lacked any sign of having the "wider range of knowledge, experience, and expertise" that this body was supposed to "bring to bear on lottery regulation". The emergence of Dame Helena Shovelton will remain, for ever, a mystery.

Perhaps the commission's task might have been easier had it received more bids. But when the deadline fell, it had just two to consider: one from the fat cats, one from the Cheshire. Branson, recently dubbed Sir Richard by Blair and appointed to Smith's creative industries taskforce, would describe winning the lottery as "the most important thing in my life".

Why did he want it so? Not, we know, out of "self-glorification", because Branson has decided to sue Tom Bower, his unauthorised biographer, for supplying this explanation. But if not self-glorification, then what? The simple desire to do good? Possibly. Then again, a job as Britain's Lord Bountiful could not adversely affect Branson's other interests, all of which depend on the bearded person of Branson for their successful branding.

Far from instilling doubts about his motivation, the potent Branson brand seemed to appeal powerfully to the commission's chairman Dame Helena and her band of Shoveltons. So much so, that when the dame announced in August that neither bid would do, it was Branson, alone, who got a second chance, a piece of favouritism which would have most toddlers reeling with sympathetic indignation. Branson exulted that his success would make it "worthwhile being born".

Camelot, having been everywhere obituarised, successfully sought a judicial review. At this point another cabinet minister might have disbanded his commission and started again. Smith did not. In court, his commission defended itself on the grounds that its process had been like "an architectural competition", in which the People's Lottery had produced a building that was "very nearly there" (a claim which hardly conforms with this week's revised "risky" verdict). The judge, as we know, disagreed, describing the commission's behaviour as "conspicuously unfair", "unlawful" and "an abuse of power".

Astonishingly, Dame Helena did not instantly resign. Quite the opposite: she defended her decision, and was, even more incredibly, supported by Smith - who presum ably believes that "conspicuously unfair" conduct is something that might afflict anyone. Only after a week did Dame Shovelton resentfully agree to go, attributing her departure - in a very dome-like way - to "media vilification".

Her four, equally conspicuously unfair colleagues (for the judgment had been unanimous) chose - presumably with Smith's blessing - to remain. It must have been obvious to Lord Burns, Shovelton's successor, that the commission was now irredeemably discredited as well as none too bright - but thanks to the earlier prevarication and mistakes, there was now no time to replace these incompetents.

The appointment of new commissioners, Lord Burns said, "would delay the process by several months ... the risks regarding that are much greater than the risks in carrying on". Well, we shall see. Burns will just have to hope that a spokesman for the People's Lottery was being honest, in October, when he said: "We have absolute confidence that Lord Burns will be fair and impartial."

Branson is not famed, however, for shrinking from litigation. On the contrary. According to Bower, Branson considered seeking a judicial review back in 1994, when he was first refused the lottery licence. This week he was already asking "do we or do we not go to court?"

If he does go, then the referral of this extraordinary mess back to courts will be no more than the logical continuation of a saga which seems, in the absence of any competent leadership from those nominally in charge, to have been settled from the start, by the wrangling of professional lawyers. The commission made its initital "conspiciously unfair" decision with the approval of the treasury solicitors. This was overturned in court after successful argument by Camelot's QC. Lord Burns' deliberations have been overseen by the city firm, Freshfields, which has also, by coincidence, previously worked for Branson, Camelot and GTech.

And, some may think, why not? Given a choice between Shovelton and Smith and these brainy solicitors and barristers, which would you choose? Wouldn't it be simpler and quicker, given the obvious shortage of suitably qualified public figures, if we just abandoned the pretence of democratically elected government, and appointed a bunch of tip-top lawyers to do the job instead? Then you think of Lord Falconer and Lord Irvine, Lord Grabiner and Lady Kennedy - and remember, that's exactly what Blair is doing. It's just that he hasn't quite finished.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Zelig | The Man In The Iron Mask | Primary Colors
fields.body:
Zelig
(Woody Allen, 1983)
8pm, FilmFour

A prime-form, brilliant Woody comedy in which he plays the human chameleon Leonard Zelig, a nebulous figure who, like Forrest Gump only funnier, crops up on the periphery of all sorts of historical events: with the pope on the balcony; in the garden with F Scott Fitzgerald; behind a Hitler giving it the sturm-und-drang. A superbly crafted treatise on conformity.

The Man In The Iron Mask
(Randall Wallace, 1998)
8.15pm, Sky Premier

Wallace, scriptwriter of Braveheart, delivers an oddly muted, at times sombre version of the great Alexandre Dumas adventure. Golden boy Leonardo DiCaprio is touching as the naive and wronged man of the title, though less convincing as Louis XIV, the more worldly and cruel twin brother who incarcerated him. (Mike Nichols, 1998)
12.10am, Sky Premier

Funny, clever adaptation of the bestselling satirical novel that digs the dirt on Bill Clinton's 1990 campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination. fields.headline: My friend Kirsty
fields.standfirst: The death of the singer-songwriter Kirsty MacColl in a boating  accident in Mexico was a great loss to music.  Frances Dickenson  remembers a remarkable musician, mother and, above all, a mate
fields.trailText: The death of the singer-songwriter Kirsty MacColl in a boating accident in Mexico was a great loss to music. Frances Dickenson remembers a remarkable musician, mother and, above all, a mate.
fields.body:
Under any other circumstances I would have cheered to see Kirsty's photo on the front page of so many newspapers. It was the sort of acclaim that she deserved and never quite achieved - despite her hits. But as her friend I flinch from each new headline as if it were a callused fist. I wasn't Kirsty's best friend, and I definitely was not her only friend. But Kirsty had a talent for friendship that was matched only by her talent for music.

My girlfriend Caz Gorham introduced us. It was at a party thrown for another of Kirsty's mates, and Kirsty had agreed to sing. This alone was a measure of her friendship. She had a horror of performing then, that even now - 10 years later - she was only just coming to terms with (perhaps helped by the fact that her partner James, the saxophonist in her band, was with her on the stage). I remember one time asking if she'd be a guest on a TV programme that I was producing. "Do you really want a plank of wood on your show?" she said.

The music industry is famous for its early deaths but Kirsty was its least likely candidate. She survived punk, success, cancelled contracts, the break-up of her marriage, and had probably entered one of the happiest periods of her life, both professionally (her current album was perhaps her best) and personally. Not least of all, the great job she's made of bringing up her two sons, Jamie and Louis, is becoming more and more apparent. Last time I saw her she talked proudly about how Jamie had played guitar on some tracks she'd recorded.

Kirsty's mind was flick-knife sharp, but she was ruled by her passions as much as by her intellect. She had a huge appetite for new things and for underdog causes. Caz worked with Kirsty on a television documentary in which Kirsty spoke out about the way in which we in Britain needlessly pollute and squander our water supplies.

It was typical of Kirsty that this was no pop star rant but something she really knew about and acted on at a personal level. She had a reed-bed system set up in her back garden which recycled the waste water from her home so that it could be used to irrigate the garden and fill an ornamental pond. Last time I saw the pond it was filled with fish the size of squirrels.

On another occasion I remember her opening her front door and pulling me into her music room to listen to a track on an album she'd just bought. "You'll love it," she said, "unless you've turned into a plonker." It was by The Pale Saints, a little-known band from Australia or New Zealand - I can't remember which. But I remember the song. I still love the album.

Kirsty had one of the prettiest faces I've ever seen. Yet like most women I know she seemed to doubt that she was attractive, particularly as she struggled with her weight. When I picture her I mostly see her laughing. Yet she was no Pollyanna. I saw how the break-up of her marriage plunged her into despair, as did the cancelling of her record deal by Virgin.

And if Kirsty thought you were talking rubbish, she let you know. We argued once about whether I saw homophobia where there was only fatuousness. Yet soon after I heard she'd publicly berated a pop star for anti-gay remarks he'd made.

Kirsty's parties were famous. They were the sort you took champagne to if you could, and you made sure you had no plans for anything the next day. Not suprisingly, many of her friends were musicians and walking from room to room at Kirsty's home could be like rifling the pages of a pop and rock encyclopaedia.

But there were never any pop star tantrums there. As a humanising, democratising force, Kirsty was better than any revolution. She took particular pleasure in introducing you to people that she thought you'd like. And it's a measure of her sense of people that I met two of my closest friends through Kirsty.

On Tuesday night, lying in bed, trying to come to terms with her death, I berated myself for the times I'd meant to call or see her, but - in the way of friendships that you assume will go on for ever - had neglected to do so.

Last week I meant to phone her to tell her that Tower Records in Kensington had put her album on their "recomended" shelf. I even missed her birthday dinner (I had a family crisis). I've still got the books Caz and I had bought as her birthday present - Willa Cather's Death Comes For The Archbishop and Ted Hughes's book of poems, Birthday Letters. I don't know what to do with them.

This year, as always, Kirsty's Christmas card was one of the first to arrive, written in her swirly handwriting and signed by her, her sons and James. "Have fun girls," she's written. I think it will be a while before I can.

fields.headline: Sweet rescue for rocky LCI
fields.trailText: Timing is important in playing the stock market. Take London Clubs International. The case at the moment for investing in the owner of top London casinos Les Ambassadeurs and St James's appears a touch risky. In fact - to use a stock market adage - it is not one for widows and orphans.
fields.body:
Timing is important in playing the stock market. Take London Clubs International. The case at the moment for investing in the owner of top London casinos Les Ambassadeurs and St James's appears a touch risky. In fact - to use a stock market adage - it is not one for widows and orphans.

Last week shareholders saw the value of their investment halved after LCI admitted to serious cashflow problems which almost put it in breach of its banking covenants.

But sometimes it pays to go where others fear to - as did Trevor Hemmings, the multimillionaire owner of Blackpool Tower.

It emerged yesterday that Mr Hemmings has over the past week built up a near 5% stake in LCI.

Although he was unavailable for comment, sources close to him suggested he had taken the stake for "friendly reasons" - and because he sees an improvement on LCI's price from last night's closing price of 55.5p, down 1.5p.

Mr Hemmings is working with LCI on a project attempting to turn Blackpool into Britain's Las Vegas. With LCI, Mr Hemmings is lobbying the government for permission to build a huge hotel and casino complex on the seafront.

If successful, the gossips claim, the plan is to build another two complexes and watch the cash roll in.

The entrepreneur has made some smart investments. He bought into racecourse owner Arena Leisure, unchanged at 110.5p, when it was a loss-making shell company named Farringford and trading at 4p.

Mr Hemmings was also instrumental in the recent acquisition of the Littlewoods Pools company by Sportech, down 0.75p to 27.5p.

In the wider market, meanwhile, there was no sign of the gentle wind-down to the Christmas break most dealers have been expecting. On one hand there was the fallout from Tuesday's meeting of the US Federal Reserve to deal with; on the other, a wave of takeover speculation.

Utility outfit BG was in demand again, climbing 10.5p to 272p with the chatter of a bid from the US starting to be taken more seriously. Nevertheless, the cynics are yet to be convinced. They point out that a number of punters have been left with BG shares after the bid from Shell - down 12.5p to 522p - failed to materialise, and are only too happy to encourage such rumours.

After a week of a sharp losses it was no surprise to see Chubb, the security services specialist recently demerged from Williams, the centre of frenzied takeover speculation. Apparently Tyco, the acquisitive US conglomerate that once held takeover talks with Williams, is poised to make an offer. Chubb shares ended 23p, or 16.2%, better at 165p.

Elsewhere, Scottish Radio Holdings advanced 107.5p to £17.10 after revealing it was in talks which might lead to an offer and bus group Arriva, up 7p to 265, continued to be driven higher on talk of an overseas approach.

All of which was a welcome diversion from a terrible session for leading shares. The FTSE 100 closed 118.3 points lower at 6,176.7, unsettled by another Nasdaq hammering and the Federal Reserve's statement, issued after its meeting on Tuesday.

The Fed kept interest rates on hold, of course, but dealers were alarmed by its gloomy analysis of the American economy.

"When the Federal Reserve starts talking about stress in financial markets and slowing economic growth, it is time to worry," one dealer said.

Predictably it was the more expensive end of the market - that dealing in technology and telecommunications shares - that was hit hardest.

Chip designer ARM Holdings, down 81.5p to 518.5p, was the biggest blue-chip loser, closely followed by Autonomy Corporation, off 271p to £21.36, Marconi, 65p lower at 707p, and Energis, 38.5p weaker at 442p. The FTSE Techmark 100 closed 117.7 points weaker at 2,544.12.

fields.headline: Aggregate starts to build
fields.trailText: Traders are starting to watch the performance of Aggregate Industries, the building materials group, very closely.
fields.body:
Traders are starting to watch the performance of Aggregate Industries, the building materials group, very closely.

Since the start of the month, the stock has proved a strong performer and yesterday the price advanced a further 6.25p, or 8.5%, to 80p - a 12-month high - on speculation that a bid from Anglo American at 100p might be around the corner.

While the company refused to comment on the chatter, informed sources reckon there could be a more straightforward explanation for the gains. It seems that US value funds - led by Fidelity - have been aggressive buyers of the stock in recent weeks.

Unlike some of its peers, notably Hanson which issued a profits warning last month, Aggregate is said to be coping with the impact of strong oil prices and the awful British weather. The City will get a chance to see just how well when Aggregate delivers a trading update in January.

fields.headline: At this price?  Geo Interactive
fields.trailText: Stock market sages always claim it is better to travel than arrive - and the performance of Geo Interactive Media, the Israel-based but London-listed technology group, provides a case in point.
fields.body:
Stock market sages always claim it is better to travel than arrive - and the performance of Geo Interactive Media, the Israel-based but London-listed technology group, provides a case in point.

Its shares fell 2% yesterday after the deal which the market has been awaiting for the best part of the year finally arrived.

Geo has at long last licensed its Emblaze technology, which enables video and music files to be downloaded on to mobile phones, to one of the industry's heavyweights - Ericsson.

The lacklustre performance of the shares can probably be explained by the fact that Geo shares have risen by 15% so far this month on expectations of the deal and disappointment that it does not extend to handsets.

Ericsson plans to use Emblaze in its back-office systems - servers to you and me - not that one would have guessed it from Geo's statement to the market.

Nonetheless, the deal is a milestone for Geo. For months, the company been telling anyone who will listen that its technology is 12 to 18 months ahead of the competition - that is, US group PacketVideo. Its acceptance by Ericsson seems to have proved that. Further deals with big cellular players - and Geo chief executive Eli Reifman was saying yesterday that others are on the way - should put that beyond doubt.

However, the case for investing in Geo has moved on and is no longer about the acceptance of its technology but the take-up of video watching on mobile phones. In theory, that market is huge. Some analysts are forecasting a market worth £15bn by 2008. But how many similar claims were made about the internet and shopping?

So what is a share in Geo worth? In reality, it is probably no more than an option on the future market for mobile video, and an expensive one at that. One for the brave.

fields.headline: What the Dickens?
fields.trailText: A Christmas Carol | Back To The Floor | Coronation Street
fields.body:
Charles Dickens invented Christmas in Devonshire Terrace. There should probably be a blue plaque on his house to that effect. The Dickensian Christmas sprang forth like a jack-in-a-box, complete, coherent and fully fashioned, as if it had always been like that. But, before A Christmas Carol, it hadn't.

Dickens's first words reach out like a bony hand to grip your throat. "Marley was dead." It takes nerve to start a story like that. As the late Duke of Gloucester said hopefully when Tosca threw herself from the ramparts "Oh well, if she's dead we can all go home."

A Christmas Carol is still so potent that that we have Alastair Sim, untrustworthy charm playing fluently over his face, in an old film (Channel 5), Patrick Stewart in a new film (Channel 4) and last night a modern reworking with Ross Kemp as Scrooge in A Christmas Carol (ITV). The idea of a loan shark living on a council estate, feeding off small fry, was Kemp's idea, inspired by his student days in Peckham.

This version does wrench the whiskers off Scrooge, who now stands revealed as a south London gangster. On a good day, he has a serrated sense of humour. On a bad day, he is indirectly responsible for the death of Marley. Marley - it now sounds logical - is black. So is the setting, full of shadows and illuminated only by the blue flicker of television sets.

The prize for the most imaginative arrival by a ghost goes to Warren Mitchell, who appears on Scrooge's TV in a storm of interference then bursts through the glass like an out-of-condition burglar. There is quite a frisson in the thought that they are in there, waiting to come and get you.

Scrooge emerges like king rat from his underground flat, which is cold, clinical and upholstered in black hide (as he is himself), seeking someone to put the bite on. The mother who owes him money says, just before he drops her TV set off the balcony, "We want a traditional Christmas like everybody else. That telly goes on at seven in the morning and stays on till midnight." Bob Cratchett, who always looks on the bright side of life, tries to console the bereaved family. "There's a lot of excellent stuff on the radio at this time of year. And books, there's always books." There are certainly plenty of cookery books, which is a little hard on the hungry.

The repentant Scrooge's most entertaining largesse is a pair of his-and-her stairlifts for an old couple (Liz Smith and 91-year-old Charles Simon), who ascend joyfully like elderly cherubs, blowing whistle-ticklers. It is positively the only play where I have seen Stannah Stairlifts credited.

The dialogue can drop dead at your feet. "Christmas, when the stupid and the bone idle join forces to celebrate the birth of catalogue shopping!" is the new, improved version of "Bah, humbug!" But, in general, Scrooge is better value than that. As he says to his nephew, a curly headed copper, "This is the man that shot Jacob Marley. I've written the name down in case you arrest the wrong bloke. I know what you lot are like." The irony leads you to hope there is a bit of the old devil left in the new man.

There is a Scottish exclamation which sounds something like a stag at bay. It is usually written "Harumph!" There is no English equivalent. In the last Back To The Floor (BBC 2) John Coleman, chief executive of the House of Fraser, was working incognito in his space age Oxford Street store. The new computerised cash registers are cutting edge. I can feel my mouth start to widen at the very words. A nice woman was trying to buy a discounted frying pan from Coleman. He swiped and typed. Time passed. The earth turned. "I think help is needed. Help! Help!" cried the nice woman, who seemed suspiciously good humoured.

"HARUMPH!" said the Monarch of the Glen. "You will get better" said the nice woman soothingly. "Don't worry! I've enjoyed your agony."

The furiously combative team now running The Rovers in Coronation Street (Granada) reminds me of the three tenors who, as Victoria Wood memorably put it when accepting her comedy award on ITV, "are murdering Jingle Bells on the other side". There's "Big Fred" Elliott, "Crusher" Ferguson and, in the middle, little Mike Baldwin, who has to be lifted up to reach the high notes.

That telly goes on at seven in the morning and stays on till midnight." Bob Cratchett, who always looks on the bright side of life, tries to console the bereaved family. "There's a lot of excellent stuff on the radio at this time of year. And books, there's always books." There are certainly plenty of cookery books, which is a little hard on the hungry. The repentant Scrooge's most entertaining largesse is a pair of his-and-her stairlifts for an old couple (Liz Smith and 91-year-old Charles Simon), who ascend joyfully like elderly cherubs, blowing whistle-ticklers. It is positively the only play where I have seen Stannah Stairlifts credited. The dialogue can drop dead at your feet. "Christmas, when the stupid and the bone idle join forces to celebrate the birth of catalogue shopping!" is the new, improved version of "Bah, humbug!" But, in general, Scrooge is better value than that. As he says to his nephew, a curly headed copper, "This is the man that shot Jacob Marley. I've written the name down in case you arrest the wrong bloke. I know what you lot are like." The irony leads you to hope there is a bit of the old devil left in the new man. There is a Scottish exclamation which sounds something like a stag at bay. It is usually written "Harumph!" There is no English equivalent. In the last Back To The Floor (BBC 2) John Coleman, chief executive of the House of Fraser, was working incognito in his space age Oxford Street store. The new computerised cash registers are cutting edge. I can feel my mouth start to widen at the very words. A nice woman was trying to buy a discounted frying pan from Coleman. He swiped and typed. Time passed. The earth turned. "I think help is needed. Help! Help!" cried the nice woman, who seemed suspiciously good humoured. "HARUMPH!" said the Monarch of the Glen. "You will get better" said the nice woman soothingly. "Don't worry! I've enjoyed your agony." The furiously combative team now running The Rovers in Coronation Street (Granada) reminds me of the three tenors who, as Victoria Wood memorably put it when accepting her comedy award on ITV, "are murdering Jingle Bells on the other side". There's "Big Fred" Elliott, "Crusher" Ferguson and, in the middle, little Mike Baldwin, who has to be lifted up to reach the high notes.

webTitle: TV and Radio: The price is right

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Who will play the part of George W Bush in the live-action sitcom about the president and his family?
fields.trailText: Who will play the part of George W Bush in the live-action sitcom about the president and his family?
fields.body:
Trey Parker Evens

Matt Stone 3-1

George Clooney 4-1

Les Claypool 8-1

Jay Leno 16-1

No sooner are the votes in for the American presidency, than Matt Stone and Trey Parker of South Park fame announce that their next project will be a live action spoof of the presidential family. There is every expectation of corrosive satire, and one Family First script posted on the internet is certainly fulfilling that, with incest gags about the Bush sisters.

An important decision will be the actor to play George W Bush. "People need to decide how likely Stone and Parker are to cast themselves", says Andy Clifton, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler.

Matt Stone (curly hair), has voiced some of the funniest roles in South Park: Dr Spook-a-lot, Big Gay Al and Cheesy Poofs Director. He has also taken to the chat-show circuit like a converted hot shot player, and appeared with Parker naked, but for essentials, in a recent Absolut vodka advert. "I don't see him being able to put a wig over that mountain of curls", notes Andy.

Trey Parker (the blonde), real name Randolph Parker III, has a slight margin. "People say he's the better actor." He has previous experience in presidential roles, voicing Bill Clinton, the Australian Mayor and President Hirohito in South Park.

"George Clooney is an interesting one", says Andy. His playing the parts of Doctor in the film of South Park and Sparky the gay dog in the TV series "has probably done his image some good". About wise-cracking chat-show host Jay Leno, Andy comments that he has a unique gag style that might not sit well with the South Park creators. When Leno appeared on South Park, he voiced himself.

The final contender, less well known over here but big in the States, is Primus bassist and singer Les Claypool, who also appeared as himself in South Park. "However, this is the sort of project that will be high profile, even if it doesn't get the ratings, which makes Claypool too risky."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Performance On 3 | Analysis
fields.body:
It's hard to believe that Dave Brubeck turned 80 at the beginning of the month. He has barely paused in his stride, celebrating the anniversary by appearing with his four sons and the London Symphony Orchestra in Performance On 3 (7.30pm, Radio 3). With himself on piano and the boys on cello, electric bass, another piano, and drums, the family run through some of Dad's best-known compositions. As a bonus it also offers the world premiere of son Darius's Four Scores In Seven.

David Walker questions the burgeoning use of "independent" consultants for inquiries and other chores which the authorities would rather avoid. Exactly what, he asks in Analysis (8.30pm, Radio 4), are these experts independent of? Their expert background can mean they may well have close ties with some of the protagonists in their inquiry. Yet the public seems far readier to trust them than a public official who may, in fact, be much less partisan.

webTitle: Guardian Christmas appeal: Fair trade for indigenous remedies

fields.headline: Getting fair price for indigenous remedies
fields.standfirst: Special report: Christmas appeal 2000
fields.trailText: For centuries traditional healers in Samoa have ground up the stem of the plant Homolanthus acuminatus and steeped it in hot water as a treatment for the yellow fever virus. Recently, the age-old remedy caught the interest of the US National Cancer Institute which took a closer look and found prostratin, a drug with potential for HIV.
fields.body:
For centuries traditional healers in Samoa have ground up the stem of the plant Homolanthus acuminatus and steeped it in hot water as a treatment for the yellow fever virus.

Recently, the age-old remedy caught the interest of the US National Cancer Institute which took a closer look and found prostratin, a drug with potential for HIV. Bulk samples of the plant were collected and shipped back to the US.

Now under development, it has the potential to earn millions as a successful drug for treating viral infections.

It might have been a good example of traditional medicine and modern science working hand in hand, with the financial rewards being channelled back to the developing countries which originally shared the medical knowledge of their ancestors.

But sadly for the Samoan villagers, there is no record of the American scientists having sought any prior agreement with the Samoan government, local communities or healers for the collection and use of the plant and the associated knowledge. They are unlikely to receive a penny.

Now, the world is facing up to the insidious threat of biopiracy whereby prospecters scour fragile habitats for exotic plants.

Since 1989 a group of environmental lawyers from a London-based charity, Field, has been seeking to help developing countries to reform the laws and improve their capacity to defend themselves against the scourge of biopiracy.

Carolina Lasen Diaz, a Field lawyer, said Field had been focusing on fragile ecosystems such as the Pacific Islands.

"We are working with a regional governmental organisation in the Pacific and WWF to support countries that are trying to regulate access to genetic resources."

Ms Lasen Diaz says one of the many examples of biotechnology firms taking natural resources out of the country of origin that had led to pharmaceutical applications was kava, a plant found throughout the Pacific and used for 3,000 years for its medicinal properties.

Overseas companies keen to cash in on the surge in herbal medicine were quick to seize on kava's appeal. Americans spent $15m (£10m) on kava in 1996 and twice as much in 1997, with the Nutrition Business Journal projecting sales of almost $50m for 1998. But little or no profit is going back to islanders.

Ms Lasen Diaz said: "The big concern is that the commercial benefits that would accrue from the plant or herbal remedy would only go to the drug company and you end up with the product being licensed back to the countries from where it originates."

Her point was amplified by another recent controversy. One of Africa's oldest tribes, which discovered "Nature's Prozac" thousands of years ago, is set to lose out on a multi-million pound deal to market the remedy worldwide. Sceletium, a rare creeper that grows only in the Cape region of South Africa has been used by the San people since prehistoric times for treatment of depression and alcohol and drug dependence. Tribal leaders criticised the Johannesburg drug company Pharma Natura which is selling the patent rights, resentful that they would not profit from the commercial development of their ancestors' discovery.

"This is the kind of situation we are trying to avoid in the South Pacific by ... raising awareness about the relevant legislation and options to protect the Pacific Islands' biodiversity and associated knowledge of their indigenous communities," Ms Lasen Diaz said.

In 1997, Field established a programme on biodiversity and marine resources to coordinate activities. "We have worked on a range of issues relating to the objectives of the convention on biological diversity: conservation, sustainable use, and benefit sharing. Now 178 countries have joined."

Field lawyers hope their work in building the capacity of developing countries to fight their corner in the World Trade Organisation can help to ensure that communities which have been victims of globalisation may instead benefit from it.

Action on Disability and Development helps disabled people in 12 of the poorest countries by assisting them to form self-help organisations and influencing decision makers to invest more in their needs.

Refuge offers a national lifeline for women suffering domestic violence, providing accommodation and emotional support. Its aim is to help women and their children enjoy a future free from physical and emotional abuse.

Foundation for International Environmental Law and Development provides legal advice on environmental issues, often to smaller countries that cannot afford commercial lawyers, to ensure they are fairly represented at international negotiations and conferences.

The Place 2 Be sends specialist counsellors into primary schools to offer emotional and therapeutic support to children who are troubled, unhappy and confused.

fields.headline: Bobby Sheen
fields.standfirst: Lead singer who played a key role in the creation of Phil Spector's Wall of Sound
fields.trailText: Lead singer who played a key role in the creation of Phil Spector's Wall of Sound.
fields.body:
Whenever he made records under his own name, Bobby Sheen, who has died aged 57, was out of luck. But as Bob B Soxx, the ostensible leader of a group called the Blue Jeans, he briefly became one of the figures identified with the Wall of Sound, the style of pop music devised in the early 60s by the record producer Phil Spector, whose musical innovations and eccentric behaviour also established the archetype of the brilliant and autocratic Svengali of early rock and roll.

Born in St Louis, Missouri, Sheen's family moved to southern California and, like Spector, he grew up in West Hollywood, then a mixed district. His early showbusiness experience came as a member of various touring versions of the Robins and the Coasters, two of the most popular Los Angeles vocal groups of the late 50s. A tall young man who dressed his hair in a fashionable pompadour, he sang in a high voice heavily influenced by Clyde McPhatter, who was the Drifters' first important lead singer in the early 50s before he embarked on a successful solo career.

In 1962 Sheen hooked up with Spector through a recommendation from Lester Sill, a prominent Hollywood music business figure who had just gone into partnership with the 21-year-old pro ducer to form the Philles label. Spector was also briefly employed as head of A&R for Liberty Records, and his first venture with Sheen was a single for that label titled How Many Days, a competent copy of McPhatter's solo records, recorded in New York.

A few months later Spector moved his recording operation to Los Angeles, where he booked time at a studio, Gold Star, located at the corner of Santa Monica Boulevard and Vine Street. The site of many hit recordings, Gold Star was noted for its exceptionally resonant echo chamber, located in the bathroom. It also employed a young engineer, Larry Levine, who was eager to collaborate in Spector's more unorthodox notions. Their first session together produced He's A Rebel, released under the name of the Crystals, even though all the singing was done by session singers - one of whom was Sheen. It was at a second Gold Star session, in the autumn of 1962, that Sheen found himself singing the lead part on a version of Zip-A-Dee-Doo-Dah, a children's song from a 1940 Walt Disney film, Song Of The South, which Spector had reimagined as a mini-epic of avant-garde rhythm and blues.

At the session, Spector had assembled three guitarists, three bass players, at least two pianists, four saxophonists, a drummer and a percussionist. Levine spent almost three hours trying vainly to capture the correct sound balance on the studio's primitive three-track desk. In frustration, he turned off all the microphones. One by one he turned them back on, until Spector shouted: "That's it! That's the sound!" But one microphone had been inadvertently left off, and the distant, metallic sound of Billy Strange's electric guitar solo leaking into the microphones of the other musicians became the signature of a record also distinguished by the disembodied clanging of its weirdly ponderous rhythm track - a sound unlike anything heard before. A top 10 hit over the Christmas of 1962, it helped prepare the way for the records by the Crystals and the Ronettes which established Philles as the last great phenomenon before the arrival of the Beatles ended pop's age of innocence.

With Darlene Love and Fanita James, two session singers who did duty as the Blue Jeans, Sheen released two more Bob B Soxx singles in 1963, the charming Why Do Lovers Break Each Other's Heart? and the rowdy Not Too Young To Get Married, on both of which Love sang the lead part - as she had, uncredited, on He's A Rebel and the Crystals' next hit, He's Sure The Boy I Love.

When neither Bob B Soxx follow-up matched the success of Zip-A-Dee-Doo-Dah, Spector turned his interest elsewhere. But the group's final appearance, as contributors to the producer's legendary Christmas Album, also permitted Sheen his finest hour, delivering a soaring lead vocal on a magnificently thunderous arrangement of The Bells Of St Mary's. An unlikely vehicle for one of Spector's "little symphonies for the kids", it now seems fully the equal of Be My Baby or River Deep - Mountain High, the acknowledged classics of Spector's Wagnerian style.

Sheen signed a contract with Capitol, and in 1966 released an excellent single called Dr Love, which failed to make the pop charts but nevertheless found - and continues to find - favour with the dancers of Britain's northern soul scene (an original UK promo copy is currently available on an internet site for £60). Later, he resumed his earlier career as a member of one of several groups trading under the name of the Coasters, and for a while ran a label of his own, Salsa Picante. In later years he continued to take late-night phone calls from Spector in which the First Tycoon of Teen - who, incidentally, celebrates his 60th birthday on Boxing Day - outlined grand plans to revive the splendours of the past.

 Bobby Sheen, singer, born 1943; died November 23 2000

webTitle: Iain Hay Gordon cleared of murder, after 48 years

fields.headline: Cleared of murder, after 48 years
fields.standfirst: Airman sent to asylum for killing of MP's daughter that shocked Ulster is cleared
fields.trailText: Airman sent to asylum for killing of MP's daughter that shocked Ulster is cleared.
fields.body:
It was a nightmare few could begin to imagine: an innocent, sane young man found guilty of a brutal murder and locked away in an asylum for most of his 20s before being quietly freed and told never to talk publicly about the case again.

But now, almost half a century on, Iain Hay Gordon found it hard to believe that the Kafkaesque ordeal that eclipsed most of his adult life was finally over.

The frail, bespectacled pensioner, painfully thin and ghostly pale in a neat navy blue suit, sat bolt upright listening intently to every word in the Belfast court of appeal's 52-page judgment summary.

It took just over an hour for Sir Robert Carswell, Northern Ireland's lord chief justice, to read the finding, but it was the verdict that the 68-year-old Glaswegian had waited 48 years to hear: not guilty of the notorious killing that shocked 1950s Ulster.

The court ruled the enforced confession that led to him being found guilty but insane of the frenzied stabbing of Patricia Curran, 19, a judge's daughter, was inadmissible, and quashed his conviction.

The story began on a cold, dark night in November 1952, when the young woman's body was discovered lying in the grounds of her family's stately home in Whiteabbey, Co Antrim. Although medical experts found later that she had been dead for more than four hours, the family bundled her corpse, stiff with rigor mortis, into a car and drove to a local doctor.

She had 37 stab wounds and must have struggled with her murderer, who would have been drenched in blood, yet her belongings were piled neatly several yards from the body. Further conflicting evidence on Mr Hay Gordon's whereabouts later multiplied the contradictions.

Patricia's father, Lancelot Curran, the local Unionist MP, an eminent judge and a former Stormont attorney general, was a member of Northern Ireland's ruling elite. Her mother, Doris, disapproved of her headstrong daughter's unconventional lifestyle, particularly her relationships with older men, and there had been serious rows when Patricia took a year out between school and starting Queen's University, where she was a first-year student at the time of her death, to drive a van for a builders' firm.

Questioning

Desmond, her only sibling, was a member of a crusading religious group, Moral Rearmament, into which he tried to recruit Iain Hay Gordon, a rather naive 20-year-old RAF technician, whom he met at the local Presbyterian church.

Mr Hay Gordon, who was stationed at a base near the Curran home, had only met the family a handful of times and swears he was nowhere near the house on the night of the murder. But two months later, in January, he was arrested and charged.

After two days of intense questioning, which he now describes as a "game of charades" where detectives suggested certain scenarios and pushed him to acquiesce, he broke, terrified the police would reveal his past gay experimentation in an age when homosexuality was still illegal and considered a mortal sin by many.

He said that at this stage he would have done anything to stop the interrogation. Psychologists later described it as a kind of brainwashing. So, with no legal presence or advice, he signed a confession and after the trial was packed off the Holywell mental hospital for seven and a half years.

Freed in 1960, he lived a quiet, exemplary life in Glasgow, where few knew his history, but remained determined to clear his name. The legal battle began in earnest in 1993 and seven years later, he succeeded.

"I'm delighted," he said, almost overwhelmed by the hugs of his legal team and supporters. "I feel a great burden has been lifted off my shoulders.

"I never had any doubt I would clear my name. I didn't know when or how but I always believed it would come to pass and I've been vindicated."

Hay Gordon's solicitor, Margot Harvey said she hoped a claim for compensation would be settled speedily in the light of his age and failing health.

"Iain is a very frail, vulnerable person, who is not in the best of health, and what happened to him was heinous," she said.

"The debris of this case is scattered throughout his family and his poor mother died bankrupt trying to clear his name."

It will probably never be known who did murder Patricia Curran. John Linklater, a journalist who has campaigned for Mr Hay Gordon for many years, has said in public lectures that he suspects her mother, but there is no way this can be proved conclusively.

The Curran family never got over the tragedy. Although Lancelot was knighted in 1964, another prominent QC, Richard Ferguson, described him as a cold, aloof figure who carried a tremendous sorrow. Doris Curran, too, was a broken woman after her daughter's death She and her husband died in the 1970s.

Desmond underwent a dramatic conversion to Catholicism five years after his sister's murder and his Orangeman father broke ranks with the loyal order to attend his ordination as a priest in Rome in 1964.

Tenement

Now in his 70s, he ministers in a black township just outside Cape Town, South Africa, where he lives in a tiny prefabricated hut with no electricity and is known as "The Lamp" by his flock.

Mr Hay Gordon, who lives in a bed-sit in a run-down Glasgow tenement, has displayed a surprising lack of bitterness about the case.

"It turned my life upside down," he admitted. "You only pass this way once, you don't get a second bite of the cherry but I refuse to be bitter or have any feelings of vengeance towards the murdered girl's family."

For now, his plans are to celebrate Christmas with his disabled partner in hospital.

"I'm just trying to get on with my life," he said, his eyes shining with joy. "It hasn't really sunk in yet after so long but it's come at a good time before Christmas."

It took just over an hour for Sir Robert Carswell, Northern Ireland's lord chief justice, to read the finding, but it was the verdict that the 68-year-old Glaswegian had waited 48 years to hear: not guilty of the notorious killing that shocked 1950s Ulster. The court ruled the enforced confession that led to him being found guilty but insane of the frenzied stabbing of Patricia Curran, 19, a judge's daughter, was inadmissible, and quashed his conviction. The story began on a cold, dark night in November 1952, when the young woman's body was discovered lying in the grounds of her family's stately home in Whiteabbey, Co Antrim. Although medical experts found later that she had been dead for more than four hours, the family bundled her corpse, stiff with rigor mortis, into a car and drove to a local doctor. She had 37 stab wounds and must have struggled with her murderer, who would have been drenched in blood, yet her belongings were piled neatly several yards from the body. Further conflicting evidence on Mr Hay Gordon's whereabouts later multiplied the contradictions. Patricia's father, Lancelot Curran, the local Unionist MP, an eminent judge and a former Stormont attorney general, was a member of Northern Ireland's ruling elite. Her mother, Doris, disapproved of her headstrong daughter's unconventional lifestyle, particularly her relationships with older men, and there had been serious rows when Patricia took a year out between school and starting Queen's University, where she was a first-year student at the time of her death, to drive a van for a builders' firm. Questioning Desmond, her only sibling, was a member of a crusading religious group, Moral Rearmament, into which he tried to recruit Iain Hay Gordon, a rather naive 20-year-old RAF technician, whom he met at the local Presbyterian church. Mr Hay Gordon, who was stationed at a base near the Curran home, had only met the family a handful of times and swears he was nowhere near the house on the night of the murder. But two months later, in January, he was arrested and charged. After two days of intense questioning, which he now describes as a "game of charades" where detectives suggested certain scenarios and pushed him to acquiesce, he broke, terrified the police would reveal his past gay experimentation in an age when homosexuality was still illegal and considered a mortal sin by many. He said that at this stage he would have done anything to stop the interrogation. Psychologists later described it as a kind of brainwashing. So, with no legal presence or advice, he signed a confession and after the trial was packed off the Holywell mental hospital for seven and a half years. Freed in 1960, he lived a quiet, exemplary life in Glasgow, where few knew his history, but remained determined to clear his name. The legal battle began in earnest in 1993 and seven years later, he succeeded. "I'm delighted," he said, almost overwhelmed by the hugs of his legal team and supporters. "I feel a great burden has been lifted off my shoulders. "I never had any doubt I would clear my name. I didn't know when or how but I always believed it would come to pass and I've been vindicated." Hay Gordon's solicitor, Margot Harvey said she hoped a claim for compensation would be settled speedily in the light of his age and failing health. "Iain is a very frail, vulnerable person, who is not in the best of health, and what happened to him was heinous," she said. "The debris of this case is scattered throughout his family and his poor mother died bankrupt trying to clear his name." It will probably never be known who did murder Patricia Curran. John Linklater, a journalist who has campaigned for Mr Hay Gordon for many years, has said in public lectures that he suspects her mother, but there is no way this can be proved conclusively. The Curran family never got over the tragedy. Although Lancelot was knighted in 1964, another prominent QC, Richard Ferguson, described him as a cold, aloof figure who carried a tremendous sorrow. Doris Curran, too, was a broken woman after her daughter's death She and her husband died in the 1970s. Desmond underwent a dramatic conversion to Catholicism five years after his sister's murder and his Orangeman father broke ranks with the loyal order to attend his ordination as a priest in Rome in 1964. Tenement Now in his 70s, he ministers in a black township just outside Cape Town, South Africa, where he lives in a tiny prefabricated hut with no electricity and is known as "The Lamp" by his flock. Mr Hay Gordon, who lives in a bed-sit in a run-down Glasgow tenement, has displayed a surprising lack of bitterness about the case. "It turned my life upside down," he admitted. "You only pass this way once, you don't get a second bite of the cherry but I refuse to be bitter or have any feelings of vengeance towards the murdered girl's family." For now, his plans are to celebrate Christmas with his disabled partner in hospital. "I'm just trying to get on with my life," he said, his eyes shining with joy. "It hasn't really sunk in yet after so long but it's come at a good time before Christmas."

webTitle: High street bail-out saves Labour's universal bank

fields.headline: High street bail-out saves Labour's universal bank
fields.standfirst:
Big Six agree to pay - but not as much as Treasury hoped for

Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Big Six agree to pay - but not as much as Treasury hoped for
fields.body:
The government and Britain's banking sector ended months of wrangling yesterday when the big high street clearers finally agreed to help finance Labour's plan for a post office-based universal bank.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, said that six banks - Barclays, Lloyds TSB, Royal Bank of Scotland/NatWest, HSBC, Abbey National and the Halifax - had agreed to contribute to the cost of the new service, designed to ease social exclusion by providing banking services for the less well-off.

Although haggling will continue over the sums to be paid by the banks, government sources insisted last night that they were delighted with the deal, particularly because the industry had said that it would not make any financial contribution to the scheme. Mr Byers said that talks would continue with other banks and building societies to see how they could contribute.

He added that the new bank would "bring those people currently without bank accounts into the financial mainstream" by offering basic bank accounts but without overdraft or borrowing facilities.

The British Bankers' Association said last night that the deal "clearly demonstrates the industry's commitment to tackling social exclusion", but it stressed that there was much work to be done on the detail including a memorandum of agreement in the new year.

"It's not a victory for Byers by any means," said one senior banker last night. "It's not over yet.

"This is a statement being made at what is only the beginning of the negotiations. A lot of detail still needs to be sorted out."

The first accounts for the so-called financially excluded will be made available in post offices early in the third quarter of 2002. These will not be "universal bank" accounts but those which the Treasury has demanded the retail banks set up to offer services to people who do not have bank accounts.

It is understood that these simple accounts will be connected to the post office and between the banks through the existing Link network.

The Post Office-based universal banks are unlikely to be come available until the end of 2002.

Basil Larkins, managing director, network banking, at the Post Office, said: "We are absolutely delighted. All the people who want to continue using the post office will be able to do so. It secures the income for sub-post office masters and mistresses going forward, and we've got the collaboration from the big banks."

Despite last night's announcement, the government will be left with a much bigger bill than it had hoped for in setting up the universal bank. The Treasury is expected to have to pay as much as £350m every year.

The banks are thought to have offered to pay about £75m each year for the next five years, considerably less than the £125m a year sought by the Treasury. Both sides said last night that talks about the final figure were ongoing.

fields.headline: David Chilcott
fields.trailText: David Chilcott was a stalwart of the Guardian composing room, from the time he joined the newspaper when the Manchester Guardian moved to London in 1961 until his retirement as head printer in 1994.
fields.body:
David Chilcott, who has died of cancer aged 66, was a stalwart of the Guardian composing room, from the time he joined the newspaper when the Manchester Guardian moved to London in 1961 until his retirement as head printer in 1994. He was in charge in the difficult transition period, after Wapping had finally consigned traditional "hot-metal" printing to the dustbin and before the onset of fully electronic computer publishing. At that time, with a method known as "cut and paste", he spent nearly as much time ensuring that copy was not lost stuck to people's soles as he did overseeing the smooth production of the paper.

He was born in Richmond-upon-Thames and attended Richmond county school for boys. A keen athlete, he won every 100 yards he raced as a schoolboy, was champion of Surrey Schools and became a junior member of Polytechnic Harriers in 1948. In 1956, he was selected for the Olympic Games relay squad, but glandular fever prevented him attending.

He joined the Richmond and Twickenham Times as an apprentice compositor in 1954, and returned after his national service. During the 1960s he did summer seasons on the Daily Herald and Mail before joining the Guardian as a compositor, transferring into junior management and then becoming head printer.

He was so dependable and, in terms of his management position, always so aware of the clock ticking and production responsibilites towards both the outside reader and his editorial colleagues. He had a great knack of getting the very best out of the production workforce, even during the Wapping dispute and the difficult times with the moves to new technology.

In later years his hobbies included walking in the New Forest and Dartmoor with his wife Anthea, a state registered nurse, whom he married in 1956. He developed cancer in 1997 and fought it with great courage. A charming man, full of laughter, he leaves behind a devoted and loving family: his wife, three children, Jayne, Adrian and Lucy, and two grandchildren.

 David Leslie John Chilcott, printer, born October 19 1934; died November 8 2000

fields.headline: John V Lindsay
fields.standfirst: A liberal Republican mayor of New York whose glittering promise was never fulfilled
fields.trailText: A liberal Republican mayor of New York whose glittering promise was never fulfilled.
fields.body:
John V Lindsay, who has died aged 79, was one of the last of the breed of liberal Republicans in American politics. Mayor of New York City from 1965 to 1973, he was briefly, as a Democrat, a presidential contender in 1972.

Linday presided over a time of union turmoil, rising crime and angry racial and political conflict in New York. He showed great physical courage in confronting rioting mobs in Harlem in 1967, but became involved in damaging confrontations with New York's teachers over "community control" of schools, and with the police over a proposed civilian review board. He left the city headed for the financial crisis that left it all but bankrupt two years after he had gone from office.

As a white Anglo-Saxon protestant from an upper-class background, Lindsay belonged to one of the smallest ethnic minorities in a city whose politics were largely defined by ethnicity, and that was bitterly divided in the 1960s between Jews and Catholics, whites and blacks. Elected to his first term as mayor largely by middle-class voters, he was widely seen as siding with poor black and Puerto Rican and some Jewish voters against middle-class Irish and Italian voters, and ended up being re-elected largely with black and hispanic votes. It was Lindsay's misfortune to serve as mayor of America's biggest city at the height of the urban crisis brought on by the coincidence of racial conflict, labour unrest, rashly generous liberal reforms, fiscal improvidence and political confusion.

He won election with the help of a campaign in the friendly New York Herald Tribune calling it "a city in crisis", and in many ways he left it a city in crisis too. Yet in spite of numerous mistakes, and the turbulent, troubled character of his years in Gracie Mansion, the mayoral residence, he has come to be seen as one of New York's better mayors.

When he left office in 1973 the New York Times acknowledged that he had alienated "blue collar and middle-class citizens", but judged that his accomplishments would "place him securely among the outstanding mayors of New York. And mayor Kevin White of Boston, another gifted man frustrated by the angry racial politics of the time, called Lindsay "probably the most significant politician in the history of municipal government in doing something for the cities".

Lindsay came from an upper-class family. His father was an investment banker and he was educated at the private boarding Buckley School, at St Paul's School, Concord, and at Yale University. He became a lawyer with the long-established New York firm of Webster and Sheffield. In 1958, aged 27, after serving briefly as a government lawyer in the Eisenhower administration, he was elected to Congress from the 14th "Silk Stocking" district on Manhattan's East Side; the wealthiest congressional district in the United States.

Six foot four, with blond hair and greenish eyes, Lindsay was often compared to John F Kennedy, and the same adjectives were applied to him as to Kennedy, four years his senior: patrician, elegant, cool, glamorous, stylish. He was fascinating to the media, and adept at manipulating them. From an early stage in his career he thought in terms of an eventual run for the presidency. But he was handicapped by his particular brand of Republican politics, which had an appeal to the predominantly liberal inhabitants of the Silk Stocking district, but was already going out of style by the late 1950s.

Lindsay belonged to the "goo-goo" tradition of Republican liberalism, so called by its opponents both in the Democratic party, dominated in New York by working-class Irish politicians, and in the increasingly conservative Republican party. Lindsay had an aristocratic disdain for corruption, which was rife among both politicians and policemen in New York in those days, and for racial prejudice, destined to be a menacing factor in the city's politics in his time.

In 1964, Lindsay was already sufficiently disillusioned with the party's shift to the right that he refused to endorse its conservative candidate for the presidency, Senator Barry Goldwater. In spite of the twin handicaps of birth and liberalism, Lindsay was elected mayor in 1965. He was a glamorous as well as a gracious figure. Few other mayors of New York, certainly none since his time, would have played the lead in a white tie and tails sketch at a press party supposed to lampoon him, dancing in the Fred Astaire manner with beautiful actresses. He gathered a brilliant assembly of aides around him, generally assumed to be the nucleus of a Kennedy-style Camelot that would take the shuttle down to Washington in due course.

When Lindsay moved into Gracie Mansion on New Year's Day 1966, a tiny shamrock was lying on his desk. It was an ominous reminder left behind by his Democratic opponents, of the tough Irish labour boss, Mike Quill, who brought the city's buses and subway trains to a halt on Lindsay's first day in office.

That was only the beginning of a time of labour disputes and disruptions comparable to the "winter of discontent" in Britain a decade and more later. The bus and subway strike was said to have been the "costliest and most paralysing" strike in American history. In 1968 the policemen went on a "sick-out", and the teachers and dustmen were on strike. In 1971 it was the turn of the bridge tenders, the sewage workers and the policemen again. Potentially most dangerous of all was the firemen's strike in 1973.

Yet although the period bulks large in New Yorkers' memories as a time of labour disturbances, the actual number of days lost through strikes was not especially high, and Lindsay succeeded in bringing a new efficiency and rationality to labour negotiations.

An admirer of Kennedy's hyper-numerate defence secretary, Robert McNamara, Lindsay also adopted managerial modernity to New York's government. He reorganised it into eight "super-agencies" and shook up the ancient cosy ways of patronage and plunder. Yet it was in his day that New York's finances began to deteriorate, thanks to reckless short-term borrowing that brought the city to the brink of bankruptcy in the mid-70s. New York was largely dependent for money on New York State, and Lindsay was on terrible terms with the state's Republican governor, Nelson Rockefeller. Throughout his time in office he quarrelled with Rockefeller, who had been one of his original sponsors, but who may well have been jealous of Lindsay's political appeal and ambitions.

Lindsay first installed a social worker, Mitchell Ginsberg, to run welfare. The welfare rolls promptly shot up, from 500,000 recipients in 1965 to 1.2m in 1969 - one in six of the population. The cost kept pace, going from $500m to $1.2bn. In 1969, realising that welfare spending was deeply unpopular, Lindsay changed tack and appointed a tough manager, Jule Sugarman, who held the line on numbers and costs.

It was only a couple of years after Lindsay left Gracie Mansion, however, that the New York Daily News ran its famous headline about President Ford's unwilling ness to back a federal bail-out for New York's budget: "Ford To City: Drop Dead".

His attempt to reform New York's once magnificent but already troubled, public school system turned out to be catastrophic. Lindsay brought in the Ford Foundation, led by President Kennedy's immensely able national security adviser, McGeorge Bundy, to advise how to tackle racial problems in the schools.

The foundation recommended "community control", which meant handing over control of the teachers, two thirds of them Jewish, and their powerful union, to local boards of control. In one district, Ocean Hill-Brownsville in Brooklyn, once the heart of New York's Jewish community, but by 1968 largely black, this led to angry confrontations and to a teachers' strike that left lasting resentments between blacks and many Jews.

That was absolutely the last thing Lindsay and his allies had intended. Yet Dr Kenneth B Clark, the black sociologist who had proposed the decentralisation plan, himself came to the conclusion that it had been "disastrous". The Ocean Hill-Brownsville affair had a lasting and damaging effect on the politics of the city, since in the past Jews and African Americans had formed a powerful liberal bloc; now many Jews drifted to the "neo-conservative" right, while many black New Yorkers were alienated from mainstream politics and driven to back more or less demagogic black politicians.

When he came into office. Lindsay issued a "white paper on crime and safety". "We will make New York City safe again," it promised, "no matter what the cost, no matter what the effort." The police department's strength grew from 24,000 to more than 30,000 in Lindsay's time, and a lot of money was invested in walkie-talkies and other new technology. But opinions differed as to whether New York was any safer - many thought it was not.

The mayor also instituted a civilian police review board which deeply alienated many of "New York's finest". He set up a commission to fight corruption after a shocking investigation by the New York Times, but the commission found that corruption was endemic and "indulged in to some degree by a sizeable majority of those on the force", and that Lindsay's administration had done little about it.

In 1969, guided by a brilliant journalist, Richard Aurelio, as his campaign manager, Lindsay was re-elected with only 42% of the vote, the city's new conservative majority being divided between a conservative Democrat, Mario Procaccini, and a conservative Republican, John Marchi.

The most remarkable thing about the re-election was the fact that Lindsay won with a completely different constituency in 1969 from that which had brought him into office in 1965. In his first election, he was supported by the Republican establishment of Wall Streeters and political lawyers, leading the city's largely Catholic middle class. In 1969, he found himself the tribune of the poor and disinherited blacks and Hispanics, while middle-class Jews, Irish and Italians for various reasons turned their backs on him.

When Lindsay left office, it was widely assumed that he had a promising political career ahead of him. In fact, he disappeared almost totally from political sight. At a time when the centre of gravity of American political life was moving to the right, he moved rapidly in the opposite direction.

Already in 1968 he came down on the side of the city's black and poor citizens, angering the middle class. In that year, too, he was spoken of as a possible vice-presidential candidate for the Republicans, but was persuaded to endorse the disastrous Spiro T Agnew, subsequently forced to resign for bribery. Asked how he could have done such a thing, Lindsay's salty-spoken wife Mary said "politics acquaints a man with strange bedfellows".

In late 1971, typically after a skiing holiday in Colorado, he announced that he was becoming a Democrat. This was supposed to be the opening move in a campaign for the presidency. The idea was that the newly radicalised Lindsay would knock out George McGovern in the early primaries and challenge Richard Nixon in the November election. It didn't work out like that. Jewish voters, on whom he had counted, were particularly disillusioned with him, according to the New York Times.

Lindsay made little impact and withdrew after being badly beaten in the Wisconsin and Florida primaries. It was generally assumed that he would have a glittering future somewhere, somehow, in American politics. But the caravan had moved on.

Lindsay returned to practising law in Manhattan, but even that was not a great success. He worked for two law firms, both of which were dissolved. His later years were sad. Both his health and his finances deteriorated. He was badly hurt when a dog knocked him off his bicycle in Central Park.

He had heart surgery in 1988, suffered a mild stroke in 1989 and was taken to hospital in 1990 after collapsing with low blood pressure at a public luncheon. In 1994, he had to be taken by ambulance to hospital after feeling faint on a hot, steamy day while waiting for a train at Track 18 in Grand Central station.

His wealth as well as his health suffered. In May 1996 mayor Rudolph Giulani agreed to find him two city jobs because Lindsay was broke; the jobs would qualify him for city health insurance and perhaps later for a pension. The reforming mayor of a "city in crisis" had become the victim of his own honourable failure.

He is survived by his wife Mary, three daughters and a son.

 John Vliet Lindsay, politician, born November 24 1921; died December 19 2000
