fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Reasons to post
If it is physical disability that prevents Paul Appleyard (Feedback, December 14) from licking a stamp and walking to the postbox then he has my sympathy.

However, inviting competition entries by post rather than e-mail has the twin advantages of enfranchising the majority of the population who do not have a computer and disqualifying those who just can't be arsed to tear themselves away from the screen for the time it takes to write a card.

Perhaps if Paul had experienced the problems I have had in keeping an e-mail service up and running (thanks, BT) he might share the view that - even in Gadget Heaven - snail mail is a service to cherish.
Root Cartwright
root.cartwright@btinternet.com

Why can't I send my competition entry by email? It's a bit old tech having to send it snail mail to a technology magazine.
Les Dean
led@aber.ac.uk

Exercise.
Jim Malone
Jim@malone78.freeserve.co.uk

Understated
David Birch (Online, December 14 - It's Location, Location, Location) says: "The magnitude of the LBS revolution... is impossible to understate". No need to bother about that then. Doug Welch
doug@mereheath.demon.co.uk

Safety gadgets
It is surely only a matter of time before one of the conditions for being licensed to drive a potential killing machine (ie a motor vehicle) on the roads is to have installed in every one ot these an electronic gadget to issue on response at least the following information: location; speed; owner; registration number and name of driver.

This will enable any infringements of speed limits to be listed and will also provide a most useful guide to a vast number of criminal acts that are regularly committed with the aid of these lethal vehicles.
John Roberts
jrmundialist@compuserve.com

Vinyl noise
Re Roger Perry's letter under a banner "Vinyl is Best": Perry means tape not vinyl, since that is the initial recording medium.

Tape is an inherently noisy medium, and, if recorded as analogue, the noise from the medium is inevitably mixed with the recorded signal. To get the tape onto vinyl, most of the bass must be extracted, otherwise the stylus wouldn't stay in the groove. To play back the vinyl, the bass must be restored. So another layer of corruption is added.

It is usually over-restored, which creates that "vinyl warmth" which fools non-musicians into thinking they are in the presence of high fidelity.

Plus, of course, scraping a stylus through plastic adds another level of corruption.

Vinyl is a very long way from "the closest approach to the original sound".
Conrad Cork
conradcork@tadleyewing.co.uk

Perhaps if Paul had experienced the problems I have had in keeping an e-mail service up and running (thanks, BT) he might share the view that - even in Gadget Heaven - snail mail is a service to cherish. Root Cartwright root.cartwright@btinternet.com Why can't I send my competition entry by email? It's a bit old tech having to send it snail mail to a technology magazine. Les Dean led@aber.ac.uk Exercise. Jim Malone Jim@malone78.freeserve.co.uk Understated David Birch (Online, December 14 - It's Location, Location, Location) says: "The magnitude of the LBS revolution... is impossible to understate". No need to bother about that then. Doug Welch doug@mereheath.demon.co.uk Safety gadgets It is surely only a matter of time before one of the conditions for being licensed to drive a potential killing machine (ie a motor vehicle) on the roads is to have installed in every one ot these an electronic gadget to issue on response at least the following information: location; speed; owner; registration number and name of driver. This will enable any infringements of speed limits to be listed and will also provide a most useful guide to a vast number of criminal acts that are regularly committed with the aid of these lethal vehicles. John Roberts jrmundialist@compuserve.com Vinyl noise Re Roger Perry's letter under a banner "Vinyl is Best": Perry means tape not vinyl, since that is the initial recording medium. Tape is an inherently noisy medium, and, if recorded as analogue, the noise from the medium is inevitably mixed with the recorded signal. To get the tape onto vinyl, most of the bass must be extracted, otherwise the stylus wouldn't stay in the groove. To play back the vinyl, the bass must be restored. So another layer of corruption is added. It is usually over-restored, which creates that "vinyl warmth" which fools non-musicians into thinking they are in the presence of high fidelity. Plus, of course, scraping a stylus through plastic adds another level of corruption. Vinyl is a very long way from "the closest approach to the original sound". Conrad Cork conradcork@tadleyewing.co.uk

webTitle: Who really wants to be a millionaire?

fields.headline: Who really wants to be a millionaire?
fields.trailText: Competition
fields.body:
Students and academics around Britain are being invited to demonstrate their entrepreneurial prowess, with a prize fund of £1 million. Launchit2001 is a competition announced today by Cross Atlantic Capital Partners (XACP), a venture capital management firm, and Brainspark, an internet and technology incubator. The competition, supported by the Guardian, hopes to unlock the innovation hidden in university campuses and find Britain's next big name in IT and telecoms.

The competition, www.launchit2001.com , is open to any individual in higher education or teams that include a student or academic staff member. XACP and Brainspark will select the best new business ventures submitted from universities, engineering and business schools in Britain. The best two or more winning ventures will be eligible for direct investment from XACP and Brainspark from a fund of £1m, ranging from £100,000 to £500,000 packages. XACP and Brainspark are seeking entries for concepts that are beyond the initial research phase. Ideally, entries will have products and services that are ready to be commercialised or ideas that have passed a successful proof of concept. Entries will address one of four key areas within the IT and telecoms sectors: new enabling technologies (including nanotechnology and optoelectronics), internet infrastructure, enterprise software, e-communications and wireless infrastructure and applications.

Launch2001 is supported by the Guardian, whose Online section has reported extensively on the venture capital industry and the challenges associated with raising money. Victor Keegan, editor of Online, said: "Editorially, the Guardian has welcomed the revival of the venture capital industry in Britain, and the successful development of ideas originating in universities. We are delighted to be supporting Launchit2001."

Though each team must include a student or member of the academic staff, members are encouraged to add senior management from outside the university. The deadline for online registration and submission of a two-page executive summary is February 5, 2001. Selected entrants will be notified by March 2 and will have until March 30 to submit their full business plan.

Visit www.launchit2001.com

fields.headline: NewMedia makes £46m writedown
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Technology investment group NewMedia Spark has written down the value of its investment portfolio by nearly 30% after the recent turmoil in technology, media and telecom shares.
fields.body:
Technology investment group NewMedia Spark has written down the value of its investment portfolio by nearly 30% after the recent turmoil in technology, media and telecom shares.

NewMedia is the largest quoted internet incubator fund. Its backers include entrepreneur Luke Johnson and Mark Slater, the son of controversial 70s financier Jim Slater.

Yesterday the company, which specialises in early stage financing and has widespread interests in Scandinavia, announced a first-half loss of £1.4m, compared to a £2.8m profit in the previous six months. The portfolio has been written down by £45.5m to £120.8m and the shares closed down 1.25p at 27.5p. At the turn of this year they were changing hands at 177p.

NewMedia's decision to write down the value of its investments and admit that some will go bust comes days after a profit warning from rival Durlacher as the value of its investments declined.

Chief executive Michael Whitaker said NewMedia did not share the "blanket pessimism of many commentators over the prospects for the dot.com sector". It would continue to invest despite the recent rollercoaster ride in technology, media and telecoms markets worldwide.

"We remain optimistic about the long-term future of many areas of the TMT markets. In particular, we continue to concentrate our investments on core software applications, communications infrastructure businesses and certain areas of digital media such as music and financial products."

The book valuation of NewMedia's two largest investments, eTV and DX3, had been left unchanged at £52.3m, Mr Whitaker said.

However, it was difficult to judge when the TMT markets would experience a sustained recovery.

NewMedia has been expanding aggressively this year. In May it bought Softechnet and last month acquired Internet Indirect - Mark Slater's company. It has opened offices in Berlin and Madrid, and started operations in India.

Most of the writedown - nearly £40m - relates to reductions in the carrying value of its business-to-consumer, auction and internet services ventures based in Sweden. NewMedia said it was taking "a conservative view"

The acquisition of Internet Indirect fell outside the reporting period but has boosted Newmedia's coffers. It now has some £100m cash and investments in 55 companies.

fields.headline: 'Campus care' for psychopaths
fields.standfirst: Biggest policy shake-up for 40 years includes idea to hold patients with untreatable personality disorders
fields.trailText: Mental health white paper: Biggest policy shake-up for 40 years includes idea to hold patients with untreatable personality disorders
fields.body:
A campus-style special hospital to detain up to 2,000 people with dangerous personality disorders is proposed in a white paper, published yesterday, for the biggest shake-up in mental health policy in England and Wales for more than 40 years.

Ministers promised legislation after the next election to establish indefinite detention of people with untreatable personality disorders - formerly known as psychopaths - even if they had never committed any crime.

The white paper also proposed compulsory procedures to ensure that patients living in the community take their medication, and extra safeguards to protect the human rights of vulnerable people. "Reducing the stigma which attaches to people with mental illness should be a priority for any caring, civilised society," said Alan Milburn, the health secretary.

Home Office officials said there were 1,400 dangerous and severely personality disordered people, many in prison, 400 in hospitals and 300-600 living in the community.

Inquiries into the special hospitals at Ashworth and Rampton recommended that such people should not be detained in units larger than 50. But there were likely to be serious difficulties in getting planning approval for up to four units for disordered people.

The government is considering solving the problem by building a "modular" special hospital with clusters of small units. Ministers do not yet have a location in mind.

The white paper said people with personality disorders could not be detained under the Mental Health Act because their condition was considered medically untreatable.

This legal loophole caused public outrage in the case of Michael Stone, who was diagnosed as having a severe personality disorder several years before he bludgeoned Lin Russell and her six-year-old daughter Megan to death as they walked through fields near their home in 1996.

The white paper said there should be powers to detain people for up to 28 days if a doctor decided they had a personality disorder, with futher reviews at six-month intervals.

Mr Milburn said: "At present neither the law nor services are geared to cope with the risks posed by dangerous people with severe personality disorder. There has been a gap in the protection mental health laws should afford the public - a gap we will now close."

The white paper included plans to ensure that mentally ill people living in the community stick to an agreed treatment plan. Those failing to take med ication could be forcibly detained and taken to hospital for treatment. "There will be no powers for patients to be given medication forcibly except in a clinical setting," the paper said in an attempt to reassure mental health charities which feared that patients might be forcibly treated at home.

The proposal followed the case of Anthony Joseph, a mentally ill man who killed a woman after refusing to take his medication.

These extra compulsory powers will be balanced by extra safeguards for patients including a new right to independent advocacy and a statutory requirement to develop care plans. A new commission for mental health will look after the interests of people subject to care and treatment under mental health legislation.

Mr Milburn said the reforms would build on extra investment in mental health, including £300m in the NHS plan in July and national standards making mental health a priority for health authorities.

Cliff Prior, chief executive of the National Schizophrenia Fellowship, said: "The white paper is an early Christmas present for everyone who believes that the time is right to end the Cinderella status of mental health.

"But it is a Christmas present that carries a demand for payment. There can be no buy now, pay later period when it comes to investing in mental health."

The mental health charity Mind claimed a victory in getting the government to drop plans to introduce forced medical treatments in the community.

The National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders said the plan to detain people with personality disorders because of what they might do rather than what they had done was "an excessive reaction to a genuine and legitimate public concern.

"There is a very real danger that wrong diagnoses could lead to some people being detained inappropriately while others who are dangerous may be missed or still pose a risk to the public even after treatment," said Graeme Sandall, its spokesman on mental health.

Liberty, the human rights group, said it was "seriously concerned" by the new criteria for detaining people who had not done anything wrong.

Main points

The white paper, Reforming the Mental Health Act, proposes:

 Indefinite detention of potentially dangerous people with untreatable personality disorders who had not committed a crime;

 powers to force patients living in the community to take their agreed medication;

 an independent tribunal to determine all longer term use of compulsory powers and a patient's right to independent advocacy;

 new rights for victims of crime to know when someone with a mental health disorder was to be released;

 a commission for mental health to look after people who were subject to care and treatment;

 increases in staff and services for people with mental health problems.

webTitle: Boy band pair charged after fight

fields.headline: Band pair charged after fight
fields.trailText: Two members of the British boy band Five are expected to appear in court today charged with public order offences after a fight outside a Dublin pub, Irish police said last night.
fields.body:
Two members of the British boy band Five are expected to appear in court today charged with public order offences after a fight outside a Dublin pub, Irish police said last night.

Ritchie Neville, 21, and Jason Brown, 24, were arrested yesterday and questioned in connection with an alleged assault in the Temple Bar area. They were released on bail from Pearse Street garda station last night after being charged. One was also charged with assault, a garda spokesman confirmed.

It is understood the alleged incident followed an argument between members of Five and a fan of the band Westlife, who had claimed that it was better than Five.

One man was assaulted and taken to hospital for stitches, the garda spokesman said.

All five members of Five are in Dublin for a promotional campaign.

webTitle: Patients forum plan to head off revolt

fields.headline: Patients forum plan to head off revolt
fields.trailText: The government will today try to head off a Labour backbench revolt against a key plank of its NHS reforms by publishing legislation giving patients a stronger say in the way hospitals and GP services are run.
fields.body:
The government will today try to head off a Labour backbench revolt against a key plank of its NHS reforms by publishing legislation giving patients a stronger say in the way hospitals and GP services are run.

The NHS and social care bill will establish 800 patient forums in England with statutory powers to oversee all aspects of health provision - from GP surgeries to nursing homes - and hold managers to account. Local authorities will be able to scrutinise NHS performance and also appeal against hospital closures and altered family doctor services.

A Whitehall source last night said it amounted to "a revolution in genuine patient power". The proposals follow growing unrest about the plan to abolish the 99 community health councils (CHCs), which monitor health authorities and pursue patient complaints.

More than 90 Labour MPs had signed a Commons motion calling for "a robust debate" on CHCs, and several groups, including the Law Society, British Medical Association, Co-operative party, and the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux, had expressed concern about their abolition.

Opponents of the change said the forums might be just toothless focus groups, and there was concern that the patient advocate and liaison service could not fight well for patients if staff were employed by NHS bodies receiving complaints.

The row had threatened to undermine the government's attempt to present its NHS reforms as a flagship policy in the run-up to the election.

The bill will establish the forums with guarantees of independence; they will not be managed by NHS trusts. The budget for patient representation will be more than £30m, about 50% more than allotted CHCs.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Ford recalls Mondeos
Police find body
British robot to land on Mars
Sir Elton spends £7,500 on ties
fields.body:
Britons freed in Colombia

Two Britons, Paul Winder and Tom Hartdyke, kidnapped while trekking in Colombia, have been freed, British embassy officials said yesterday. The Red Cross and diplomats helped secure the release of the pair who went missing in March after entering the jungle to hunt orchids.

Army leaves Ulster bases

The last British army patrol bases in Co Fermanagh, Northern Ireland, will be demolished in the new year. Mullan Bridge, Clonatty Bridge and Annagmartin are among seven bases which will vanish under the RUC's security revamp.

Radioactive watch alert

Shoppers were warned that wristwatches could prove a dangerous Christmas gift. The national radiological protection board said watches from a batch of 4,500 sold by the French store Carrefour were contaminated with cobalt 60.

Fourth suspect in PC killing

A fourth suspect is being hunted after a car struck a 30-year-old police constable, Jon Odell, in Margate on Tuesday, killing him while he was carrying out a drink-drive check.

Ford recalls Mondeos

Ford is recalling around 800 of its new Mondeo cars in the UK because of an airbag problem. There have been no reports of injuries or accidents because of the problem.

Police find body

Detectives investigating the disappearance of Kenneth Wilkins, 47, who went missing 12 days ago, found a body near his work in Birmingham yesterday. Officers earlier arrested a 22-year-old man in connection with the case.

British robot to land on Mars

Britain will make its first landing on another planet - with a tiny robot explorer called Beagle 2 - on Mars in 2003. The experiment, designed to probe the Martian soil and "sniff" for organic chemicals associated with water and life, is being built by a consortium led by Colin Pillinger of the Open University and will be delivered by a European spacecraft called Mars Express.

Sir Elton spends £7,500 on ties

Sir Elton John bought £7,500 worth of designer ties which will be sold to raise cash forUnicef. Sir Elton snapped up designs at £250 a go by artists like Jake and Dinos Chapman, Jeff Koons and Patrick Caulfield from a London gallery.

£3.6m lottery jackpot

The winning numbers in last night's National Lottery were 5, 8, 39, 41, 46, 49. The bonus number was 13. The estimated jackpot was £3.6m. The Lottery Extra numbers were 10, 14, 15, 19, 35, 45. The Lottery Extra jackpot was £7.1m.

fields.headline: Fresh start
fields.standfirst: Sacked dockers open night club
fields.trailText: Sacked dockers open night club
fields.body:
A group of former Liverpool dockers will modernise the concept of workers' control today when they open a bistro and nightclub on the street that links the city's two cathedrals.

The 185 men who accepted a pay-off at the end of a bitter two-year dispute have bought the old Casablanca club on Hope Street and fitted it out with the help of volunteer labour.

The Casa Club will be run on cooperative principles. Profits from its three bars will subsidise an employment training centre on the middle floor of the grade II listed building.

The project has already created 20 jobs, and the venue will host local bands and stand-up comedians as well as nurturing solidarity among the dockers.

Some of the bands which played to raise funds for the dockers during the dispute are likely to appear, and trade unionists from around the world who lent support will be invited to a launch party in February.

The dispute began in 1995 when they were sacked by the Mersey Docks and Harbour Company after refusing to cross a picket line. They maintained their protest for two years before accepting a settlement.

The 185 then became co-producers of a Channel 4 drama about the dispute - written by nine of the dockers and TV scriptwriter Jimmy McGovern. "Our revenue from that was £127,000. When we told the lads, they asked whether we might be able to buy premises where we could meet and keep up to date," a spokesman for the organising committee said. "So we bought the old Casablanca, which had been allowed to deteriorate over many years."

The training centre, the Initiative Factory, was set up to help dockers find work after the dispute, and many have developed computer skills. The centre will continue to help dockers' children and others learn skills to use in work.

The dispute began in 1995 when they were sacked by the Mersey Docks and Harbour Company after refusing to cross a picket line. They maintained their protest for two years before accepting a settlement. The 185 then became co-producers of a Channel 4 drama about the dispute - written by nine of the dockers and TV scriptwriter Jimmy McGovern. "Our revenue from that was £127,000. When we told the lads, they asked whether we might be able to buy premises where we could meet and keep up to date," a spokesman for the organising committee said. "So we bought the old Casablanca, which had been allowed to deteriorate over many years." The training centre, the Initiative Factory, was set up to help dockers find work after the dispute, and many have developed computer skills. The centre will continue to help dockers' children and others learn skills to use in work.

webTitle: Protests at military ban on disabled

fields.headline: Protests at military ban on disabled
fields.trailText: The chief of defence staff, Sir Charles Guthrie, yesterday provoked a storm of protest from campaigning groups - but was supported by the prime minister - for saying disabled people should not be recruited to the armed forces.
fields.body:
The chief of defence staff, Sir Charles Guthrie, yesterday provoked a storm of protest from campaigning groups - but was supported by the prime minister - for saying disabled people should not be recruited to the armed forces.

In a wide-ranging speech to the Royal United Services Institute, reported in yesterday's Guardian, Sir Charles said that to have disabled people serving in the army, navy or air force would be "detrimental" to the armed forces.

He praised defence ministers for securing an exemption for the armed forces from article 13 of the EU's directive on equal employment treatment banning discrimination on grounds of disability or age.

Margaret Hodge, minister for the disabled, is known to have opposed the exemption.

Yesterday, Bert Massie, the chairman of the disability rights commission, said: "It's ridiculous to exclude disabled people from serving in the armed forces because of some outdated stereotype." They should be considered for non-combat roles in logistics, supplies or communications, Mr Massie suggested.

The cerebral palsy charity, Scope, also attacked the general for overlooking the "valuable contribution" that the disabled could make.

The Royal Association for Disability and Rehabilitation (Radar) called Sir Charles' comments "inappropriate and patronising". The Royal National Institute for the Blind said that it strongly disagreed with Sir Charles. However, Colonel Bryan Gordon-Smith, of the charity Combat Stress, said: "From a personal perspective, I entirely endorse what he [Sir Charles] said. It's a nonsense to consider disabled people for going into combat."

The armed forces minister, John Spellar, was another who rushed to Sir Charles' aid. Discrimination, he said, was "absolutely necessary to maintain military effectiveness".

A spokesman for Tony Blair told reporters: "The prime minister's view... is that the armed forces cannot be just another employer. There is no such thing as a non-combatant job."

The Ministry of Defence reinforced the point. "We do not recruit for specialist roles," a spokesman said. "Everyone has to be physically fit and able to fight at the front line."

In his speech on Tuesday night, Sir Charles delivered a sweeping attack on what he called a culture of "risk aversion". He admitted that allowing homosexuals into the armed forces had turned out to be a "non-issue", but made it clear that he did not believe women should fight alongside men in the front line.

Sir Charles also said the army would not make up a shortfall of 8,000 men until 2008, three years later than the official target date.

The ministry admitted in its annual performance report yesterday that there were "significant shortages" in the infantry, the Royal Artillery, the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers, the Royal Signals, and among young pilots for the RAF.

The army's trained strength stands at 100,300. Three-quarters of all recruits fail to complete their training, army sources said yesterday.

 More than a year after the Kosovo campaign, the MoD still has not got the right combination of forces for such operations, the Commons public accounts committee said yesterday, also pointing out that the RAF had nearly run out of precision guided missiles during the conflict.

The armed forces remained under strength, a project to equip the RAF with an all-weather strike capability was years behind schedule, and the army was still without a reliable combat radio, said the committee. It urged the MoD to act quickly, if necessary buying in "stop-gap" equipment.

fields.headline: Protesters shut the London Eye
fields.standfirst: Third security breach at tourist attraction as 45 Kurdish demonstrators invade viewing capsules
fields.trailText: Third security breach at tourist attraction as 45 Kurdish demonstrators invade viewing capsules
fields.body:
Security was breached at one of London's newest tourist attractions for the third time in just over a year yesterday when around 45 Kurdish protesters seized two pods on the London Eye and threatened to set themselves alight.

The Kurds invaded the capsules on the wheel at 2.45pm, sparking a massive security operation involving more than 200 police, fire and ambulance crews.

Within an hour, police negotiators had secured the release of the 600 tourists who were riding the 135 metre-high wheel near Westminster Bridge.

But it took more than five hours for police to persuade the protesters to give themselves up. They were led off the wheel in groups of four. The last of the 45 were escorted from the scene at 8.40pm.

The protest was a reaction to the Turkish government's operation in its jails yesterday in which at least 19 people have been killed. Inmates in Buca, Umraniye, Diyar Bakar and Ulucalmar have been on indefinite hunger strike for the last two months to protest at plans to transfer hundreds of inmates to different jails.

One of the protesters, Sinan Unal, speaking on a mobile phone from a pod, said: "This is a protest against the Turkish government which has allowed the military to enter more than 20 prisons across Turkey armed with smoke and fire bombs.

"Our action was to get the British government to speak out on behalf of the prisoners and let the rest of the world know what is going on."

They were supported on the ground by a crowd of around 100 protesters on the ground from the Solidarity Committee with Political Prisoners in Turkey (Detudak). They waved placards and chanting slogans in English and Turkish calling for an end for the killings of political prisoners.

Meanwhile more protesters, believed to be Turkish Kurds, stormed the London offices of the European commission in central London. Witnesses said the protesters shouted and hung banners out of first floor windows but there were no reports of violence.

They later gave themselves up and were arrested

The two protests followed a similar incident last Friday when a group, believed to have been protesting in support of hunger strikers in Turkey, occupied the premises of the Cyprus-Turkish Association in Soho, central London.

The protest at the London Eye is the third time the attraction has been targeted by demonstrators wishing to draw attention to their cause.

When it was still under construction in October 1999, a group of eco-protesters climbed to the apex of the structure to demonstrate against dam projects in the Itoitz valley in the Basque region of Spain and the Narmada valley in India.

In August, a campaigner protesting about sanctions against Iraq managed to slip past security and clambered onto the wheel, where he tied himself to the rim with a length of rope. Police persuaded him to climb down after half an hour.

British Airways, which runs the attraction, refused to discuss security arrangements at the Eye but a spokeswoman said last night: "The security measures that we have in place at the attraction are the result of extensive consultation carried out with the police and advice from other organisations that run major attractions around the world."

webTitle: Inquiry called into GP's serial sex abuse

fields.headline: Inquiry called into GP's serial sex abuse
fields.trailText: The health secretary, Alan Milburn, yesterday announced an inquiry into the case of a GP found guilty of the serial sexual abuse of women patients which went on for at least eight years.
fields.body:
The health secretary, Alan Milburn, yesterday announced an inquiry into the case of a GP found guilty of the serial sexual abuse of women patients which went on for at least eight years in spite of complaints to the health authority and a hospital where he temporarily worked.

Clifford Ayling, a GP in Folkestone, Kent, was yesterday found guilty of 13 indecent assaults on women who went to his surgery for minor problems such as coughs and colds. He was jailed for four years. Maidstone crown court heard that he carried out unnecessary internal examinations on his women patients and fondled their breasts in the pretence of looking for cancerous lumps.

A patient complained to the police as early as 1991, but the crown prosecution service decided the case was not strong enough. A second complained of abuse while Ayling, who has a gynaecology qualification, was working as a clinical assistant to the disgraced gynaecologist Rodney Ledward at the William Harvey hospital. She dropped her complaint when told that Ayling would be leaving the hospital.

The allegations grew, but the East Kent health authority which paid the GP's contract, could neither sack nor suspend him without mounting a legally watertight case against him to the cumbersome NHS tribunal. It embarked on that long procedure, but the case had to be dropped once criminal proceedings began.

The GP was arrested in 1998, but carried on working. A magistrate barred him from practising while on bail, but he got the ruling overturned at the high court, on condition he was chaperoned by a female nurse when he saw women patients.

The government has plans to abolish the NHS tribunal and will give health authorities summary powers of suspension and dismissal over the GPs they employ in April.

The inquiry will seek to see what else can be done to stop abusive doctors.

The health authority welcomed the inquiry. Jacqui Stewart, a director of the East Kent health authority, said: "We will be cooperating fully with any investigations commissioned by the Department of Health and will be examining our action to make sure the NHS, locally and nationally, learns all the lessons from the case."

Ayling, 69, was found guilty of abusing 10 patients. Not guilty verdicts were returned on a further five charges involving three more women. A further 11 counts of indecent assault against eight women were allowed to lie on file.

Judge David Croft QC said in passing sentence: "You are indeed a dirty doctor. You held your patients in contempt. What you did was wicked. These were vulnerable people who came to you for help and you used them for your own sexual gratification."

One witness, a 34-year-old woman, said Ayling gave her a breast and internal examination on most of her visits. She registered as his patient when moving to Folkestone at the end of 1995, when she was 30, and sought treatment for a cyst on one of her ovaries.

The first time she saw Ayling he told her to take off all her clothes but she was given nothing with which to cover herself. She said: "I felt uncomfortable, I thought it unusual. He then said that he normally likes to start, particularly with new patients, with a breast examination."

Another patient went to see Ayling about pins and needles in her arms - but was told to get on her hands and knees "like a dog" for a breast examination. The GP then straddled her back and examined both her breasts at the same time for at least two minutes.

webTitle: Hospital plan to put patients in hotels worries doctors

fields.headline: Hospital plan to put patients in hotels worries doctors
fields.trailText: Consultants have expressed concern about a hospital's proposal to book patients into hotels to ease waiting lists.
fields.body:
Consultants have expressed concern about a hospital's proposal to book patients into hotels to ease waiting lists.

Managers at Derriford hospital in Plymouth would pay a minimum of £65 a night for hotel beds rather than keep patients in hospital after their operations. The hospital is even considering sending some emergency cases to hotels and having a nurse on standby.

A management memo circulated to consultants said: "Clearly we would only be transferring patients to a hotel if it was safe to do so and with consultant agreement ... Are there are any emergency admissions which could use hotels at all? ... Any ideas?"

But consultants argued that hotels did not have the facilities to cope should anything go wrong. According to internal documents leaked to a local newspaper, one doctor said: "I am not sure I would be happy for any of my patients to be in a hotel following surgery. If I was that happy, they could simply go home."

Managers said the hotel plan would help them to treat patients who lived too far away to travel home after surgery.

A spokeswoman said the hospital trust was looking at a number of schemes to help ease pressure over the winter.

By accommodating locally those patients who lived some distance away "we are able to provide more patients with routine day-case surgery", she said.

Consultants in the orthopaedic department have said it is at "crisis point", with concerns raised about hygiene. A leaked internal document said: "The operating theatres are so poorly equipped that it was recommended that patients sign a consent form to say they know they are taking a risk over and above the normal."

The trust said orthopaedic services were "of excellent quality and perfectly safe". Paul Roberts, chief executive, said: "While we all agree the need for further investment, we have no doubt the managers and doctors will work together to keep services going and improving."

Derriford hospital has been dogged by problems this year. The former chief executive and his deputy resigned after it emerged that waiting lists had been massaged to hit targets.

One surgeon is taking the hospital to an employment tribunal claiming sexual discrimination and victimisation under the race relations act.

Two other consultants settled out of court over claims that they had missed out on merit awards because of their race.

webTitle: Models of Winnie the Pooh go on show

fields.headline: Figures of fun
fields.standfirst: Models of Winnie the Pooh go on show
fields.trailText: Models of Winnie the Pooh go on show
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Four small slightly grubby Plasticine figures went on view in the treasures room of the British Library yesterday, among the priceless illuminated manuscripts and first editions. The two figures of Winnie the Pooh, and one each of Tigger and Piglet, were sent 70 years ago with a note to a small boy, explaining why their creator, EH Shepard, could not come to a tea party.

The note - purporting to be from the bear-of-little-brain, and therefore extremely badly spelled, and the figures were kept carefully until Harry Stopes-Roe presented them to the library.

"My memories of Pooh and friends go back to my earliest days. Shepard and Pooh were always invited to our parties. When they could not come, they wrote a letter. And I remember very well sitting in Shepard's studio while he made the little Plasticine figures, which I am also now giving to the British Library."

Dr Stopes-Roe has had a lifelong interest in moral philosophy, and since his retirement from Birmingham University has been vice-president of the British Humanist Association.

His happy memories of such childhood frivolities will probably startle those who remember his mother, Marie Stopes, a pioneer of birth control education, whose book Married Love was regarded as scandalous in its day.

The family lived in Surrey, near Shepard, the artist whose illustrations for AA Milne's text ensured the immortality of Winnie the Pooh, Christopher Robin and the Hundred Acre Wood.

Shepard loved children, who were always welcome at his house. Arthur Chandler, curator of an exhibition of Shepard drawings at the Dulwich Picture Gallery in south London, discovered hundreds of adults who had cherished his drawings: every child he visited, or who came to the house, went away with one. His last known drawing, at the age of 90 in 1970, showed Eeyore and Piglet playing.

The note to Harry Stopes-Roe was a typical whimsy. With Pooh sobbing it reads: "Dear Buffkins. I am verry sory that I cant come to yr party but I am going away to the igsle of wite on Saturday 24nd I am verry verry sory. Pooh."

 The letter and the figures will be on display until the new year.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: The Burren, Ireland
fields.trailText: The Burren, Ireland.
fields.body:
"Often when the weather is riotous, black clouds change then colour as they sail in, turning black and blue, the lightning shining every other minute, making crescents and crosses... Hailstones as big as pullets' eggs arrive..." I quote, from a translation of the Irish by Padraic de Bhaldraithe, from Seamas Maconlomaire's The Shores Of Connemara (Tireolas Publishing). Seamas, born in 1891, gives us a splendid account of island life, marine life, and the livelihood of a fisherman.

This day is the opposite of Seamas's description, for the sun shines, sea and sky are blue. A calm has settled on the land and what might pass for a miracle has occurred after these wet, windy and turbulent months: we have had three fine, sunny days in succession. We are almost stunned with our good luck.

Before I set out for my walk this morning, I saw a large female blackbird in our small pool; she drank long and deep and then had a luxurious bath while fieldfares, thrushes, a wren and a robin searched for food under still sodden leaves. A mistle thrush sang from the top of a holly tree and I remembered its old name, "storm-cock", and hoped it was not forecasting further tempests.

Our turloughs (seasonal lakes) are full to the brim and it will be a long time before they disappear. My walk took me past hedges of glittering green and fresh, linear rock gardens of ferns and mosses, each cluster laid out in its own unique design. At home, a goldcrest is perched between two golden flowers of furze (gorse), between "twisted torcs and gold new-moon-shaped lunulae" (Marianne Moore).

webTitle: Pernod looks at sell-off after Seagram deal

fields.headline: Pernod looks at sell-off after Seagram deal
fields.standfirst: Orangina and Oddbins in firing line as French firm attempts to recoup £600m
fields.trailText: Orangina and Oddbins in firing line as French firm attempts to recoup £600m
fields.body:
French drinks firm Pernod Ricard is to sell more than euro1bn (£600m) of assets following its successful bid for a slice of Seagram's spirits and wines portfolio, with Orangina and Oddbins among names on the block.

Swallowing Seagram brands such as Chivas Regal and Martell has transformed the shape of the Paris-based group.

More than a third of Pernod's sales will be of whisky, and the company will open a miniature head office in Scotland to co-ordinate its Scotch brands.

webTitle: Paul Bailey on his homophobic neighbour

fields.headline: Queer state of affairs
fields.standfirst: When  Paul Bailey had a run-in with his neighbour he heard a term of abuse that had not been thrown at him for more than 40 years. He was delighted...
fields.trailText: When Paul Bailey had a run-in with his neighbour he heard a term of abuse that had not been thrown at him for more than 40 years. He was delighted...
fields.body:
About three months ago, one of my immediate neighbours acquired a puppy. Each morning and afternoon, she watches appreciatively as it fouls the pavement. When I ask her politely if she could possibly train her pet to "do its business" (wondrous euphemism) in the gutter, her response was worthy of the theatre of the absurd: "Why don't you train it?" My answer, in turn, was ploddingly logical: "Because it's not my dog." She then ordered me to go back into my house. "You are being very anti-social," I said, as a plain statement of fact. "It's you that's anti-social," she screeched, "for picking on me."

Although I felt I had good reason for picking on her with as much courtesy as I could maintain, I left the matter at that. She was playing the racist trick of accusing me of racism. I was picking on her, she hinted, because she is black. My words and polite demeanour were of no avail. The white couple who live next door to her pretend she doesn't exist, even while their stretch of pavement is freshly decorated with piles of ordure. The truth would appear to be that people are afraid of her. They sweep or wash the turds away and say nothing.

I telephoned Hammersmith and Fulham council and related the whole scatological saga to a man who promised to take action. A week later, a red notice to the effect that anyone allowing their dog to foul the pavement is liable to a fine not exceeding £500 was attached to the lamppost outside my house. Then, on December 19, the woman received a visit from an especially pleasant dog warden named Tony. She was, it seemed, absolutely obliging when he suggested that she should pick up her animal's excrement. She assured him that he would have no need to call again.

At lunchtime on December 19, I opened my front door to see the dog, who is called Leck, or LEC, which the Collins Millennium Dictionary defines as "an acronym for Local Enterprise Company," squatting well inside the kerb. The woman was laughing as LEC let rip. Seeing me cross the road, she shouted: "It was you that told the council, you fucking queer cunt." That word - not "fucking", not "cunt", but "queer".

I tried to remember when it had last been slung in my direction. I realised as I went on walking that no one had used it as a term of abuse specifically aimed at me for more than 40 years. I was in my late teens at the time and had looked with too much interest at an attractive young man, who suddenly rounded on me with the question: "Are you staring at me, you queer?" I mumbled something like: "No, of course not" and quickly absented myself from his glowering presence.

In the late 1950s and early 1960s, when practising homosexuals (dear, dead phrase) were officially criminals, it was only the most outrageously effeminate queens, such as Quentin Crisp, who were routinely denigrated by the straight man or woman in the street. You had to be careful whom you called queer, since a false accusation could result in a court case.

The police were at their queer-bashing best in those days, sniffing out their prey in dingy cottages through the British isles in order to keep the number of arrests rising. In today's increasingly tolerant society many homosexual men prefer the appellation "queer". There are now queer, as well as gay, studies. It's our word, and we're happy to have it back.

How does LEC's owner know I'm queer? She's no slouch when it comes to guessing that two men occupying the same house might just be that way inclined. My duties as a responsible neighbour and citizen are done. Someone who isn't queer can tackle her next time. This queer will acknowledge her with a smile or a nod when the felicitous "fucking queer cunt" is next employed. Actually, I'm a fucking queer prick; a fucking queer cunt implies that I'm a lesbian. Don't worry, Jeanette, I haven't had the operation.

webTitle: G2: Interview with the Royle Family's Barbara

fields.headline: By Royle appointment
fields.standfirst: As Barbara, the long-suffering matriarch of the Royle Family, she is rather dim, and very plain. So what's Sue Johnston like in real life?  Emma Brockes  meets the woman voted the year's best comedy actress
fields.trailText: As Barbara, the long-suffering matriarch of the Royle Family, she is rather dim, and very plain. So what's Sue Johnston like in real life? Emma Brockes meets the woman voted the year's best comedy actress.
fields.body:
On Saturday night, Sue Johnston sat at a table with her Royle Family co-stars and rehearsed a state of grace for the moment when she would lose out in the best TV actress category at the British Comedy Awards. A rumour had gone round that all winners were tipped off before the ceremony in a bid to stop them drinking their way into a mortifying acceptance speech. "Well, that's me down the pan," thought Johnston, who had heard nothing. "It'll go to Victoria Wood or Kathy Burke."

In the event, she won the award for her role as Barbara Royle, long-suffering wife to Ricky Tomlinson's Jim in a sitcom that holds a mirror up to the grotesqueries of British family life and has driven Johnston into the nation's consciousness. "The life drained out of me when they called my name," she says. "Luckily, I'd decided to be sensible and stay off the champagne."

The role of Barbara is not for the faint-hearted actress with illusions of glamour. "Barbara's sweet and quite thick and very endearing," says Johnston "She doesn't have bad thoughts and she doesn't have any intellect. The big mystery is, she loves Jim. She actually wants to go upstairs with him for a bit of the other. You think, 'Oh Barbara, please!' But in a way I'm envious of her simplicity, the fact that she doesn't worry about the filth in the kitchen. I could never be like that."

Under her executive-style bob, cut for her role as a criminal profiler in the BBC drama Waking the Dead, Johnston looks sparky and blonde and metropolitan. As Barbara Royle, she is lank-haired, droopy-eyed and, along with the rest of her family, surgically attached to a horrible brown sofa. When she ventures into her badly ventilated kitchen, she emerges looking as if she's been steamed alongside the brussel sprouts. Caroline Aherne, writer and director, routinely apologises to Johnston for driving her appearance further and further downhill as the series develops.

"For the Christmas episode, she said, 'Do you mind letting your hair go? Letting the grey come out? Because I want you to look really sad in this.' I said, 'Great, yeah, fine.' I look appalling, worse than anyone has ever seen me. When I watched it back, I had to cover my eyes. Caroline said to me, 'I can't believe you've no vanity.' I'm not without vanity in everyday life - I ran to put on some lipstick for the photograph just now. But that is totally different to when I'm acting. If you start worrying about what you look like, you lose the truth of a role. If that sounds a bit grand then I can't help it because that's how I work."

Johnston, who is 57, learned these lessons in humility during a 20-year career in regional theatre. Her parents were against her becoming an actress. They wanted her to go to university and pursue a respectable career in her native Warrington, Cheshire. "I had no one to talk to about acting because no one in my family did it. I had a great drama teacher called Miss Potter, who said 'You've got a gift, you should go for it.' But my father had missed the opportunity to go to university and wanted me to go. To him, the thought of me being an actress was almost equivalent to me being a whore - my dad's beloved only child. But I always knew it would happen. I knew."

After winning a place at the Webber Douglas drama school at the age of 21, Johnston embarked on a career in repertory theatre. It was an environment in which actors weren't encouraged to view themselves as franchises. They weren't groomed for celebrity. They earned £6 a week and were taught not to look in the mirror too much.

"For years I never had to think about what I looked like, because in repertory theatre, you don't have to watch yourself back. One day you'll be an old bat, the next a beautiful lead, the next a cockney maid. At drama school they always insisted we never work in front of a mirror because it would make us concentrate on the outside of the role, not the inside. Then I got a part in Brookside and suddenly I was confronted with myself. It was frightening."

For eight years, Johnston played Sheila Grant, the working-class battleaxe of Brookside Close. Her screen husband, Bobby, was played by Ricky Tomlinson. "I think soaps have become the equivalent to weekly rep," she says, "because you get so much technical experience so quickly."

Her mother wasn't impressed with her leap in status, however. Johnston compares her to the nanna character in the Royal Family, always ready with a blinding non-sequitor or a crippling insult. "When I was on Brookside, my mother kept saying, 'Why do you have to dress like that?' She's never really understood how it works, my mum. She used to come and see me in plays and the first thing she'd say afterwards, was 'Well, you looked nice in that suit, why don't you dress like that when you're off the stage?'"

Such is the similarity between her mother and Barbara Royle's mother, that Johnston has been accused of leaking details of her family life to Caroline Aherne. "It started with the china cups," she says. "My mum and auntie always use china cups. I started keeping one for them at my house, because they used to bring one round rather than drink from what they call 'those beakers'. And of course, in the Royle Family, Nanna comes in and wants a china cup. My mum said, 'Did you tell them about that?' 'No,' I said. But there are times when I finish working with the actress Liz Smith, ring my mother and think where does art begin and life end?"

Apart from the awards, Johnston measures the success of her character by its public response. There is something about Barbara's devotion to her slobbish family that moves people in supermarkets to come up to Johnston and congratulate her. Only yesterday, while Christmas shopping at Harrods, a liveried doorman sidled up to her and out of the corner of his mouth confided: "We all love the Royle Family, we think it's great."

To Johnston this is just confirmation of the show's universality - its power to evoke recognition in viewers who have nothing in common with the Royle household and yet still see something of themselves in it. Each show is meticulously rehearsed, the long pauses timed to push the audience to the limits of what's tolerable, before resuming the dialogue.

"It's one of the most disciplined things I've worked on. The words are set in stone. The long pauses were a bit frightening at first. I used to find it so funny, seeing the camera pan round and there you were sucking a mint. You can leave it, and leave it some more, and you just have to trust that it will work. But we do have to do a lot of takes because of corpseing. Craig Cash (who plays Dave) is the worst and once he goes, he can't get it back. Once he goes, the rest of us go."

If Barbara Royle touches a nerve, she says, it is because of her goodness. "I didn't have anybody in my head to base her on. I just knew her. Maybe it comes from living in the north, although it's not necessarily a class thing. You think, this is how I would like to be. She doesn't agonise about what people think of her. She's oblivious to everything except being kind and loving that family."

As well as filming Waking the Dead alongside Trevor Eve, Johnston has recently completed a period drama called My Uncle Silas with Albert Finney, who has been a hero of hers since she saw him in an RSC production of Coriolanus at the age of 16. She is spending Christmas at her home in Warrington, with her 21-year-old son Joel, a graphic design student whom she brought up alone after the break-up of her second marriage.

After all the accolades, she is glad of the occasional reminder to stay humble. Johnston recently received a letter from an 80-year-old in Australia. "It was on lovely old-lady paper," she says. "She told me she'd adored me in Brookside and when the Royle Family came on in Australia, she made everyone she knew watch it. Then she wrote, heavily underlined, 'It's a disgrace. Choose your scripts better. I told everybody what a good actress you are and you let me down, using all that bad language.'"It is these encounters she most cherishes. "The old lady gave a name but no address," she beams. "Otherwise I'd have sent her my bank statement."

fields.headline: Digital piggyback
fields.standfirst: Ariane launches broadcast satellite
fields.trailText: Ariane launches broadcast satellite
fields.body:
Western Europe's new-generation Ariane-5 rocket put three satellites into orbit after a textbook launch late on Tuesday night from French Guiana.

Astra 2D, one of the satellites, will provide direct digital television broadcasting to Britain for the Luxembourg-based satellite operator Société Européenne des Satellites, or SES. Officials of the Ariane launch company said the Astra 2D separated from the Airane-5 rocket some 28 minutes after lift-off from the European Space Agency's centre in Kourou.

SES officials were not available to disclose the cost of the satellite's launch, but specialists estimated the cost of the satellite, launch and insurance at over $85m (£56.6m).

Astra 2D, weighing 1.4 tonnes, was built by Boeing Satellite Systems, a holding of the American aerospace corporation Boeing. Boeing Satellite Systems is a recent creation resulting from its parent's acquisition of Hughes Space & Communications.

Released a few minutes after the Astra 2D satellite was the GE-8, for US telecoms operator GE Americom - a subsidiary of General Electric. GE-8 will provide telecoms services throughout the US, Alaska and Hawaii.

LDREX, an experimental antenna for the Japanese space agency, was the last of the satellites to be put into orbit on Ariane's 12th and final mission this year. - Reuter

webTitle: Japan attacks debt with leaner budget

fields.headline: Japan attacks debt with leaner budget
fields.trailText: The Japanese government yesterday announced a leaner budget for 2001, the first decrease in overall spending for six years, but announced record sums for public works.
fields.body:
The Japanese government yesterday announced a leaner budget for 2001, the first decrease in overall spending for six years, but announced record sums for public works.

While there was nothing unusual about the government's reliance on pump-priming to kick-start the country's ailing economy, the draft budget, which is certain to be approved by the cabinet on Sunday, also signalled a willingness to address Japan's debt crisis.

It will reduce issuance of public bonds by 13.2% to 28.3 trillion yen, the first reduction in three years.

The draft budget is worth ¥82 trillion, down 2.7% from last year but general expenditure, which includes cash for public works, education, social security and other policy areas, rose by 1.2% to ¥48.6 trillion, the third rise in as many years.

Kiichi Miyazawa, the finance minister, said the budget was designed to stimulate demand and achieve sustainable economic recovery but admitted to being concerned by high unemployment figures and sluggish demand in the private sector.

Responding to criticism that the budget had failed to rein in government spending, finance ministry officials said other ministries and agencies would be pressed to collaborate to increase efficiency, adding that the time was not ripe for more ambitious fiscal reforms.

Some spending cuts have been made, however; official development assistance will be reduced by 3% - although some in the three-party ruling coalition had called for a cut 10 times that size; and cash reserves for additional public works will drop from ¥500bn to ¥300bn.

The budget will take Japan's burgeoning debt burden to ¥666 trillion by the end of March 2002, which is 128.5% of its GDP, far higher than the proportion in other industrialised nations. According to OECD figures for 2000, US debt-to-GDP ratio stood at just over 60%, Germany's at 63% and Britain's just under 50%.

In Tokyo, the Nikkei closed at a 22-month low. But Mr Miyazawa appeared unperturbed by the drop, which he attributed to the plunge in the US Nasdaq Composite index rather than the budget announcement.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText: The Opium advert.
fields.body:
"It's difficult to decide which is the most offensive image of the week - the fully dressed picture of emaciated Ally McBeal star Calista Flockhart after her treatment for 'dehydration and exhaustion', or the nude photograph of healthy size-14 Sophie Dahl in the now-banned Opium perfume ads. Perhaps it is true that the vision of Dahl, as the Advertising Standards Authority claims, is 'degrading to women', but I think the sight of Ms Flockhart is infinitely more damaging"
Jane Gordon
Times

"While the photographs of skinny models we see everywhere certainly denigrate women's looks and intelligence, the Opium advertisement celebrates the curves, lushness and passion of women ... It has been called 'porn chic'; I can see the chic but not the porn. Certainly it is a picture to provoke a strong reaction. It is almost too strong, too powerful ... There is nothing vulnerable about the girl in this advert, as there are in so many genuinely offensive pictures which treat women as objects. She is no victim, as women are victims in so much porn"
Sally Emerson
Daily Mail

"Personally, I find fully-clothed images of near-skeletal models ... far more offensive. With her well-rounded thighs and ample bosom, Sophie is more of a role model than the waifs who drive thousands of women to despair in an attempt to emulate them. Used to flog everything from designer clothes to breakfast cereal, they are an impossible act for women to follow"
Sharon Hendry
Sun

"It is ironic, in a society that is regularly convulsed by arguments over the relation between skeletal models and anorexia, that it is Sophie Dahl rather than Kate Moss whose photograph has been banned. Indeed, it is tempting to speculate that the Opium poster is not so much offensive as threatening, evidence of the disturbing impact of the adult (as opposed to the perpetually adolescent) female body"
Joan Smith
Evening Standard

"The Dahl picture is ... another contribution to the familiar genre of decadent sexual exoticism, in which we - usually assumed to be men - are privileged to peep at the unselfconscious inhabitants of a harem or steam bath ... The reason the poster arouses strong (if very different) feelings in men and women is that it resuscitates a dying taboo - the idea that there are things that women are allowed to see that men aren't"
Thomas Sutcliffe
Independent

webTitle: The move from bubbly to bathos

fields.headline: The move from bubbly to bathos
fields.standfirst: Price to pay for complacency
fields.trailText: Price to pay for complacency
fields.body:
For years, financial markets have believed that Alan Greenspan walks on water. Now they are starting to wonder whether their hero has feet of clay. Look no further than the reaction to this week's decision by the Federal Reserve to leave US interest rates on hold while recognising that the outlook for the American economy is far bleaker than it seemed at the time of the presidential vote in early November.

To an extent, the markets only have themselves to blame for being caught out by Mr Greenspan's caution. It was the markets which insisted that the boom in technology stocks 12 months ago was in a different category to all previous stock market bubbles. It was the markets which fell for their own rhetoric and became convinced that the good times would roll on for ever. They can hardly be surprised now the Fed chairman is reluctant to bail them out. Mr Greenspan, like any central banker, is always going to be more concerned about irrational exuberance than about a belated outbreak of realism.

So what is going to happen? Paradoxically, the markets may now be underestimating the speed and extent of rate cuts in the US next year. Mr Greenspan likes to take time to make up his mind and will want to see what is happening to demand, oil prices and - crucially - to the dollar. But it is already clear that demand is weakening rapidly, oil prices have fallen to below $25 a barrel - and will fall further if the American slow down continues - and there are plenty of analysts who believe that the dollar-euro rate will be back to parity by the middle of next year, thus giving a shot in the arm to business.

The consensus is that Mr Greenspan will only cut rates modestly next year, by perhaps three-quarters of a percentage point. But don't bet on it. There's still plenty of bad news out there, and the first six months of George W Bush's presidency could be very tough indeed. It will take time for Bush's promised tax cuts to have an impact, even assuming he can get them through Congress.

Meanwhile Mr Greenspan may need to cut rates far more aggressively than the markets expect.

Orange alert

Ugly news emerges on France Telecom's pending £50m flotation of its Orange mobile business in Paris and London whereby independent investment analysts attending a recent presentation had to agree to submit their research to the company's advisers for vetting if they wanted access to financial information on Orange.

Typically, in any big share issue or takeover, so many investment banks are involved that institutional investors can find it difficult to obtain unbiased investment advice. Often there is just one analytical City "name" outside the deal syndicate who then proceeds to clean up - being the regularly dissenting voice everybody listens to.

Orange stands accused of seeking to break this established order, making sure that nothing maverick appears from an analyst who has been helped by the company on the numbers.

Now it should quickly be pointed out that anybody who finds this shocking is probably a little naive when it comes to the inner workings of the Square Mile. On a routine basis, all analysts send drafts of their research to companies being covered, often triggering rows behind the scenes. Truly independent reseach does not exist. What is more, the Orange presentation attracting complaint was primarily for syndicate analysts and contained price-sensitive information. Some control was needed.

Yet even the suggestion of bullying by Orange - obliging analysts to sign bits of paper giving the company's advisers absolute discretion "to amend or correct anything with which they may disagree" - risks violent backlash from the investment community.

France Telecom is trying to raise buckets full of money just as the markets are going through their most traumatic time in years. Burning goodwill, unwittingly or otherwise, risks doing more damage than any unauthorised piece of research scribble.

Non sequitur

Malcolm Walker, Iceland's Greenpeace-supporting chairman, has sold 4m shares in the group he founded 30 years ago, raising more than £13.5m.

Ever since he started the frozen food business, the company explained, Mr Walker's Iceland shares have represented the bulk of his investment portfolio. Now he intends to settle back into a non-executive role and needs to "diversify his investments".

The company adds that the reason he has unloaded such a huge number of shares is simply because the chances he has to deal are very limited.

Come off it, Mr Walker. The only reason directors sell shares is because they do not believe they will make decent returns by keeping them. His actions show he believes there are better places than Iceland to keep his money.

webTitle: Feminist cause asylum seeker was fraud

fields.headline: Feminist cause was fraud
fields.trailText: A Ghanaian woman whose campaign against her deportation from the United States became a rallying point for prominent American women, including Hillary Clinton, Gloria Steinem and Julia Roberts, has been exposed as an impostor and faces prosecution for fraud.
fields.body:
A Ghanaian woman whose campaign against her deportation from the United States became a rallying point for prominent American women, including Hillary Clinton, Gloria Steinem and Julia Roberts, has been exposed as an impostor and faces prosecution for fraud.

Regina Danson successfully passed herself off as Adelaide Abankwah, a woman under threat of female circumcision if she was returned to Ghana. Her case generated instant media attention and her campaign to stay in the US became a feminist cause.

Her exposure as a fraud has brought a warm glow to America's conservatives and professional Hillary-haters.

The exposure of the deception follows a special Immigration and Naturalisation Service (INS) investigation. It discovered that the young Ghanaian woman claiming to be Ms Abankwah was in fact Regina Norman Danson, who had left Ghana simply because she had wanted to go to the US. The real Adelaide Abankwah, meanwhile, was already in the US, having been admitted as a student. She is living in Maryland.

Ms Danson arrived at New York's JFK airport in March 1997 carrying an altered Ghanaian passport identifying her as Ms Abankwah. When US immigration officials tried to deport her, she asked for asylum, claiming she faced the threat of female circumcision if she was returned to Ghana.

According to the self-described Ms Abankwah, she had recently become a tribal "queen mother" on the death of her mother. The position required her to be a virgin, she said, which she was not, opening her to the likelihood she would be punished by having her labia and clitoris cut.

In her initial asylum hearing in New York in late 1997, Judge Donn Livingston ruled against the claim, noting that Ghana had outlawed female circumcision in 1994 and that it was not, in any case, reportedly practised in the Biriwa area, in southern Ghana, where she claimed she was from.

In July 1998 an immigration appeal board upheld the judge's deportation ruling.

The case rapidly became a liberal cause célèbre. A "Free Adelaide" campaign lobbied for her to be allowed to stay in the US. The women's rights group Equality Now recruited Mrs Clinton's support, which was "very helpful in ensuring that INS was aware of the case at the highest level", according to the group's president, Jessica Neuwirth.

In July 1999, the false Ms Abankwah was finally allowed to stay in the US. "The White House wants you to release her, so they released her," an official at the INS New York district office said.

That outcome did not satisfy the INS, which launched an unusually thorough set of background investigations to prove she was not who she claimed to be. Agents in Ghana interviewed the parents of the real Adelaide, took statements from tribal leaders and local people, and established that the celebrated asylum-seeker was in fact Ms Danson.

Tracked down in New York this week by the Washington Post, Ms Danson admitted her true identity and said she had a job selling perfume.

She said she had started to use Ms Abankwah's name when she moved to Accra, the Ghanaian capital, in 1996, at about the time when the real Ms Abankwah's passport was stolen.

Although the apparent fraud was only made public yesterday, it has been more than a year since the INS recommended to US federal prosecutors that Ms Danson be prosecuted for fraud. The case remains with the US Justice Department amid press allegations that no action had been taken against Ms Danson for fear of embarrassing Mrs Clinton and other officials in the outgoing administration.
