webTitle: G2: The killer children of Rwanda

fields.headline: Children of genocide
fields.standfirst: Six years after one of the worst massacres in history, the killer children of Rwanda are going home.  Maggie O'Kane  visits the camp where they are being prepared for freedom, and encouraged to name the adults who ordered the killings
fields.trailText: Six years after one of the worst massacres in history, the killer children of Rwanda are going home. Maggie O'Kane visits the camp where they are being prepared for freedom, and encouraged to name the adults who ordered the killings.
fields.body:
At the foot of Misoko mountain, where mad, sad, gorilla-lover Dian Fossey lived out her life, stands the higher institute of agriculture and animal husbandry. Tomorrow, 10 white buses will pull away from the institute. Inside will be the class of 1994: the killer children of the Rwanda genocide. The 484 young men and two girls, who have spent the last six years locked up in prisons across the country, have been at this "solidarity" camp for six weeks now, preparing for a return to the real world.

Every war has its journalists' hotel: Rwanda had the Milles Collines in Kigali, the capital. At night, dinner is served on the top-floor balcony. Below is a swimming-pool lit from the side so that the rippling water looks like clear blue marble. The gardens are planted with giant cacti and the air smells of hibiscus. Beyond the pool and the garden is Kigali - a grid of the most perfectly swept streets in Africa.

"Imagine," says my dinner companion, looking down from the restaurant balcony, "imagine that you are sitting here and looking out over the wall at a group at a roadblock in the distance. They seem to be chatting among themselves and then you notice a woman and child to the side and the woman seems to be pleading, but nobody is paying any attention to her. The group breaks up and the men are about to move off. Then, one of them - almost as an afterthought - goes over and hacks the woman and child to pieces. That is what it was like here in 1994."

During the genocide, 800,000 Rwandans, most of them Tutsis, died in just 100 days - an average of about five a minute. Some of those responsible for the killings were these children: the class of 1994. Rwandan law, unlike British law, says that children under 14 are not criminally responsible - under the law, these children should never have been locked up. As it was, in the confusion that followed the horror, they were incarcerated along with the adults.

Faustian was 13 when he became a killer. The cow-tending son of an alcoholic father, he left home six years ago to get a job in the big town. He wanted to make money to buy himself good clothes. He sold beers and looked after cattle in the market. When he heard that there was killing in the villages, he started the long walk home in his three new shirts, wearing one on top of the other. A week later the killing began when the men in suits arrived by car from Kigali.

Now he walks along the corridor of the animal husbandry institute wearing a purple shirt with a cardboard tag around his neck: Faustian Nikirotiman, commune of Gikongoro. Here giant lillies mark the concrete walkways between the dormitories. This afternoon there is a football match. On the sloping hill above the pitch, the genocide children pose for the school photo. In the first part of a high-risk experiment in justice, these young genocidaires of 1994 are going home. They are being released without any further punishment: there will be no trials. But they will have a key role to play as witnesses in the next stage of the justice process.

This second stage will involve village-hall trials, called gacaca , for the 115,000 killers who were adults at the time of the genocide. The accused will be brought from prison in small groups to face the accusations of their own people. The problem is that most of the people they face will be Hutu, and many of them relatives. The Tutsis are dead or have fled.

Here it is hoped that the class of 1994 will play a crucial role - after all, they were present during the killings. It is hoped that the boys will point out the organisers in their own villages. The Rwandan government wants to punish around 1,000 "first category genocidaires " - the ringleaders, the multiple killers, the rapists. So far they have identified only 40 of them.

Faustian will be 19 when, tomorrow, he gets on the bus, carrying the past six years of his life in a rose-pink plastic bag: a pair of second-hand shorts, a green sports shirt with a frayed collar and his rosary beads.

When he talks about what he did, it is in the deadpan voice of someone who might be describing a minor traffic accident. He only comes alive when, moving the shy hands on his lap, he talks about God's forgiveness.

Faustian found God three years ago, and when he mentions God his reserved face sparkles. "Before I met God, I couldn't live with the sin and crimes I had committed. I prayed for the Lord to open the prison gates and set me free, but I am still inside and God has pardoned me and set me free in my heart."

He is open about being a 13-year-old and a killer. "They said that the Tutsis had killed the president. After that some guys started killing the Tutsis and singing songs about cockroaches. I didn't kill anyone in the beginning but then we caught Casian and we brought him home and they gave me a club. The boys I was with said I should kill Casian and get his trousers.

"Casian asked to say his prayers before he died, so we let him. Then I hit him two times on the head with a club. He fell down very easily because he had been hiding in the bush for two weeks and he was very weak. Then somebody said that was not the best way to do it and they took my club and began hitting him on the back of the head. He took a while to die. When he was dying he asked for water and I went to one of the neighbours' houses to get water for him but they wouldn't give any water for him."

A Seventh Day Adventist minister is pumping sweat and God at the teenagers to an African/Cajun beat. He cries: "The truth will set you free." His audience of former child killers look either rapt or mildly amused. Faustian is overwhelmed and on his feet. "Sinners," booms the minister into the microphone, tiny drops of sweat gathering on his upper lip, "Sinners - dance for the Lord."

Faustian and his fellow sinners sit on the floor, rapping and singing: "The truth sets you free/Those who see the crimes and the criminals/Tell what you see for the truth/Only the truth can set you free." Boys dancing and rapping, as evangelical and exhilarated by the call to truth as they were by the call to kill.

Rwanda's minister for justice, Jean de Dieu Mucyo, has just turned 39. He's a lawyer and the architect of the gacacas. Most of his family were murdered in 1994. "I will not tell you how many. I am the minister for justice. I do not speak of these things." His buzzword is "impunity": the culture of impunity must stop so everyone will face trial. It's ambitious in a country where most of the lawyers and judges were murdered. It sounds great on paper, but there isn't much else in the second-floor offices of the ministry of justice.

Even this early in the morning, the chipped marble stairways of the interior ministry have a thick coating of dust from the street. The lift is broken so the minister climbs the five flights slowly. You wonder why they don't fix the lift and then realise how ridiculous a notion that is when there isn't even enough money to pay a cleaner to mop the stairs. There are less than one hundred computers in the whole country to process the guilty, and in the minister's office visiting permits for waiting journalists are laboriously hammered out on an old typewriter. Yes, it has taken them six years to get this far, but they are ambitious.

Faustian says nobody in his village questioned the order to kill Tutsis. There were massacres in 1959, after all, and no one had been punished. "I didn't feel anything when I hit him," he says. "Everyone was doing it and if you killed a Tutsi you were the first person to get the meat at night when they cooked a Tutsi cow.

"Another time the group I was with killed a woman and her daughter. It was three in the afternoon and they were sitting in their demolished house. It was near the end and we had been hunting down survivors. They just sat there before they were killed. They knew there was no point asking for mercy. I didn't hit them, the others did. I didn't see anything wrong with what I was doing."

What the survivors now seem to want most is to be asked for their forgiveness. Vestine Ndikuryayo is a keeper of the dead. Most of her own family died in 1994. Afterwards she found a job as a genocide curator at Murambi Technical School, far from the village where her family were killed.

She shows the genocide tourists around the classrooms stuffed with some of the 50,000 bodies that have been dug up. Rwandans rarely go there. The visitors book has aid workers from Ohio and Sussex, who write things such as: "Lest we forget." These words fail to connect because Murambi is beyond the scope of human experience - even imagination. For 24 hours here, thousands of people were hacked to death in the green spaces between the classrooms.

Now all that is left of mothers and fathers and children and lovers has been reduced to a surreal mass of twisted cadavers. Their bodies were stripped by the killers, who wanted their clothes, although now the occasional glimpse of human life comes in the form of a scrap of a child's lemon-coloured party dress, a blue bra with a lace trimming, or a tuft of hair on a child's skull the size of a grapefruit.

The skeletons lie jumbled, their mouths frozen in their last dying scream, hands raised above their heads. You notice the skeleton of a young man with no right foot - cut off so that he couldn't run away. How long does it take to die, you wonder, when your foot has been chopped off? Then you close your eyes and you imagine the sounds coming from the wounded and the dying, lying on the blood-soaked grass, bodies wrapped around their already dead children.

Yet Vestine says she can forgive the men and children who killed her parents, her three sisters and her two brothers: "I think I could forgive, but I would like them first to say they are sorry and ask for forgiveness."

Faustian, once the killer child, asks to be excused for his lunch. He returns promptly at two in another clean shirt. "When we were in prison, people like the intellectuals and ringleaders were telling us that we would be stupid to confess. I feel that the majority of young people here have suffered and will tell the truth when the gacacas begin," he says.
fields.bodyText: At the foot of Misoko mountain, where mad, sad, gorilla-lover Dian Fossey lived out her life, stands the higher institute of agriculture and animal husbandry. Tomorrow, 10 white buses will pull away from the institute. Inside will be the class of 1994: the killer children of the Rwanda genocide. The 484 young men and two girls, who have spent the last six years locked up in prisons across the country, have been at this "solidarity" camp for six weeks now, preparing for a return to the real world. Every war has its journalists' hotel: Rwanda had the Milles Collines in Kigali, the capital. At night, dinner is served on the top-floor balcony. Below is a swimming-pool lit from the side so that the rippling water looks like clear blue marble. The gardens are planted with giant cacti and the air smells of hibiscus. Beyond the pool and the garden is Kigali - a grid of the most perfectly swept streets in Africa. "Imagine," says my dinner companion, looking down from the restaurant balcony, "imagine that you are sitting here and looking out over the wall at a group at a roadblock in the distance. They seem to be chatting among themselves and then you notice a woman and child to the side and the woman seems to be pleading, but nobody is paying any attention to her. The group breaks up and the men are about to move off. Then, one of them - almost as an afterthought - goes over and hacks the woman and child to pieces. That is what it was like here in 1994." During the genocide, 800,000 Rwandans, most of them Tutsis, died in just 100 days - an average of about five a minute. Some of those responsible for the killings were these children: the class of 1994. Rwandan law, unlike British law, says that children under 14 are not criminally responsible - under the law, these children should never have been locked up. As it was, in the confusion that followed the horror, they were incarcerated along with the adults. Faustian was 13 when he became a killer. The cow-tending son of an alcoholic father, he left home six years ago to get a job in the big town. He wanted to make money to buy himself good clothes. He sold beers and looked after cattle in the market. When he heard that there was killing in the villages, he started the long walk home in his three new shirts, wearing one on top of the other. A week later the killing began when the men in suits arrived by car from Kigali. Now he walks along the corridor of the animal husbandry institute wearing a purple shirt with a cardboard tag around his neck: Faustian Nikirotiman, commune of Gikongoro. Here giant lillies mark the concrete walkways between the dormitories. This afternoon there is a football match. On the sloping hill above the pitch, the genocide children pose for the school photo. In the first part of a high-risk experiment in justice, these young genocidaires of 1994 are going home. They are being released without any further punishment: there will be no trials. But they will have a key role to play as witnesses in the next stage of the justice process. This second stage will involve village-hall trials, called gacaca , for the 115,000 killers who were adults at the time of the genocide. The accused will be brought from prison in small groups to face the accusations of their own people. The problem is that most of the people they face will be Hutu, and many of them relatives. The Tutsis are dead or have fled. Here it is hoped that the class of 1994 will play a crucial role - after all, they were present during the killings. It is hoped that the boys will point out the organisers in their own villages. The Rwandan government wants to punish around 1,000 "first category genocidaires " - the ringleaders, the multiple killers, the rapists. So far they have identified only 40 of them. Faustian will be 19 when, tomorrow, he gets on the bus, carrying the past six years of his life in a rose-pink plastic bag: a pair of second-hand shorts, a green sports shirt with a frayed collar and his rosary beads. When he talks about what he did, it is in the deadpan voice of someone who might be describing a minor traffic accident. He only comes alive when, moving the shy hands on his lap, he talks about God's forgiveness. Faustian found God three years ago, and when he mentions God his reserved face sparkles. "Before I met God, I couldn't live with the sin and crimes I had committed. I prayed for the Lord to open the prison gates and set me free, but I am still inside and God has pardoned me and set me free in my heart." He is open about being a 13-year-old and a killer. "They said that the Tutsis had killed the president. After that some guys started killing the Tutsis and singing songs about cockroaches. I didn't kill anyone in the beginning but then we caught Casian and we brought him home and they gave me a club. The boys I was with said I should kill Casian and get his trousers. "Casian asked to say his prayers before he died, so we let him. Then I hit him two times on the head with a club. He fell down very easily because he had been hiding in the bush for two weeks and he was very weak. Then somebody said that was not the best way to do it and they took my club and began hitting him on the back of the head. He took a while to die. When he was dying he asked for water and I went to one of the neighbours' houses to get water for him but they wouldn't give any water for him." A Seventh Day Adventist minister is pumping sweat and God at the teenagers to an African/Cajun beat. He cries: "The truth will set you free." His audience of former child killers look either rapt or mildly amused. Faustian is overwhelmed and on his feet. "Sinners," booms the minister into the microphone, tiny drops of sweat gathering on his upper lip, "Sinners - dance for the Lord." Faustian and his fellow sinners sit on the floor, rapping and singing: "The truth sets you free/Those who see the crimes and the criminals/Tell what you see for the truth/Only the truth can set you free." Boys dancing and rapping, as evangelical and exhilarated by the call to truth as they were by the call to kill. Rwanda's minister for justice, Jean de Dieu Mucyo, has just turned 39. He's a lawyer and the architect of the gacacas. Most of his family were murdered in 1994. "I will not tell you how many. I am the minister for justice. I do not speak of these things." His buzzword is "impunity": the culture of impunity must stop so everyone will face trial. It's ambitious in a country where most of the lawyers and judges were murdered. It sounds great on paper, but there isn't much else in the second-floor offices of the ministry of justice. Even this early in the morning, the chipped marble stairways of the interior ministry have a thick coating of dust from the street. The lift is broken so the minister climbs the five flights slowly. You wonder why they don't fix the lift and then realise how ridiculous a notion that is when there isn't even enough money to pay a cleaner to mop the stairs. There are less than one hundred computers in the whole country to process the guilty, and in the minister's office visiting permits for waiting journalists are laboriously hammered out on an old typewriter. Yes, it has taken them six years to get this far, but they are ambitious. Faustian says nobody in his village questioned the order to kill Tutsis. There were massacres in 1959, after all, and no one had been punished. "I didn't feel anything when I hit him," he says. "Everyone was doing it and if you killed a Tutsi you were the first person to get the meat at night when they cooked a Tutsi cow. "Another time the group I was with killed a woman and her daughter. It was three in the afternoon and they were sitting in their demolished house. It was near the end and we had been hunting down survivors. They just sat there before they were killed. They knew there was no point asking for mercy. I didn't hit them, the others did. I didn't see anything wrong with what I was doing." What the survivors now seem to want most is to be asked for their forgiveness. Vestine Ndikuryayo is a keeper of the dead. Most of her own family died in 1994. Afterwards she found a job as a genocide curator at Murambi Technical School, far from the village where her family were killed. She shows the genocide tourists around the classrooms stuffed with some of the 50,000 bodies that have been dug up. Rwandans rarely go there. The visitors book has aid workers from Ohio and Sussex, who write things such as: "Lest we forget." These words fail to connect because Murambi is beyond the scope of human experience - even imagination. For 24 hours here, thousands of people were hacked to death in the green spaces between the classrooms. Now all that is left of mothers and fathers and children and lovers has been reduced to a surreal mass of twisted cadavers. Their bodies were stripped by the killers, who wanted their clothes, although now the occasional glimpse of human life comes in the form of a scrap of a child's lemon-coloured party dress, a blue bra with a lace trimming, or a tuft of hair on a child's skull the size of a grapefruit. The skeletons lie jumbled, their mouths frozen in their last dying scream, hands raised above their heads. You notice the skeleton of a young man with no right foot - cut off so that he couldn't run away. How long does it take to die, you wonder, when your foot has been chopped off? Then you close your eyes and you imagine the sounds coming from the wounded and the dying, lying on the blood-soaked grass, bodies wrapped around their already dead children. Yet Vestine says she can forgive the men and children who killed her parents, her three sisters and her two brothers: "I think I could forgive, but I would like them first to say they are sorry and ask for forgiveness." I feel that the majority of young people here have suffered and will tell the truth when the gacacas begin," he says.

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on David Soul

fields.headline: No: 1786
fields.standfirst: David Soul
fields.trailText: David Soul.
fields.body:
Age: 57.

Explanation for improbably cool surname: Changed from David Solberg when the young midwesterner took up a Dylan-esque singer-songwriting career.

Might not "David Folk" have made more sense, then? Soul was never one for the obvious. His musical breakthrough in the 60s was achieved by donning a mask and calling himself "The Covered Man".

Why, oh why? "I wanted to be known for my music and not some cheap, outward manifestation, like my face."

A man of principle! Soul was jailed in the 80s for his campaign against the shutdown of the steel industry in Pittsburgh.

But that's not how we know him... Indeed not. Soul was the blonder half of flare-totin', sharp-shootin', fire-escape-terrorisin' TV cop pair Starsky and Hutch. Fast cars! Big shades! Wheelchairs! Lollipops!

You're getting confused. Didn't he have hit records, too? Don't Give Up On Us, Baby and Silver Lady topped the charts in the late 70s, at which time Soul was the Robbie Williams de ses jours. Little ladies went gaga. Phonelines jammed on Swap Shop.

And then, the inevitable decline... The battle with the bottle, middle-age spread, involvement in British politics, Alan Ayckbourn...

Whoa there, cowboy! Soul campaigned alongside pal Martin Bell in 1997's Tatton election, and has been living and working in Britain for five years. He starred in Ayckbourn's Comic Potential in the West End last year.

It's a surefire route back to telly stardom. Spotted in the play by BBC head of drama Mal Young, Soul has been cast as a surgeon in hospital soap Holby City.

I wouldn't want Detective Ken "Hutch" Hutchinson operating on me. Not if Huggy Bear was passing the scalpel, that's for sure.

Handy catchphrase to apply liberally to dying patients: " Don't give up on us, baby."

Whatever next? Paul Michael Glaser in Peak Practice; Cagney and Lacey in Family Affairs; Peter Falk in Brookside.

webTitle: Leader: The Queen's English is modulating

fields.headline: The Windsor estuary
fields.standfirst:
The Queen's English is modulating

Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The Queen's English is modulating.
fields.body:
"My husband and I have had, y'know, a bituva tricky year, one way and annuvva. I mean, what with Chiles getting in all that hot wa'er about GM food and that, and then the flippin' Guardian sticking it to us with its, su'ov, anti-discrimination, Act uv Se'ulment thing. Anyway, bottom line: have a wikkid Christmas - plenty of turkey on the old plates, a few jars with your mates, you know the drill. You should all be well sorted."

The Queen's Christmas broadcast may not sound like that to us, but to the trained ears of the linguists at Sydney's Macquarie University, Her Majesty is getting closer to it with every year. Professor Jonathan Harrington and his team have listened closely to all the Queen's Christmas addresses (and they say academic work is tedious!), analysing the subtle changes in her accent over the decades.

What they found, in headlinese, is that the Queen no longer speaks the Queen's English. Instead she has, along with millions of her subjects, picked up the glottal stops and flattened vowels of "estuary English". According to Professor Harrington, the monarch has moved away from the plummy, received pronunciation of the 50s, and headed instead for the mockney tones of the lower reaches of our national hierarchy. Forget the way she still says "orf" for "off". Note instead her tendency to pronounce the "l" in milk as a vowel.

In any other country, such musings would interest philologists only. But since this is Britain, they amount to a significant discovery. For it means the boundaries between the classes are now so blurred that even the very summit of the class pyramid is becoming fuzzily indistinguishable from the rest of us.

Still, we suspect calculation here as well as mere social change. All today's most popular figures, from Jonathan Ross to Jamie Oliver, speak mockney. The Queen is simply trying to get in on the act. They are nothing if not adaptable, these royals. Ain't that the truth, yer madge?

fields.headline: Slobodan on the slide
fields.standfirst:
But Serbia's elections may not settle much

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: But Serbia's elections may not settle much.
fields.body:
Elections in Serbia this weekend are expected to consolidate the grip of reformers who led the charge to eject Slobodan Milosevic from the Yugoslav presidency last October. Despite talk of a comeback by the deposed war criminal and his sickening recent assertion that his "conscience is clear", his Socialist party seems certain to follow him into the political wilderness.

This will finally give the 18-party Democratic Opposition of Serbia alliance full control of the levers of power. Is this then the long-sought happy ending to a decade or more of Balkan tragedy? Far from it.

President Vojislav Kostunica faces a wide range of problems which, after the elections, he will be under rapidly increasing pressure to resolve. One is his own position relative to that of DOS leader Zoran Djindjic, tipped as Serbia's next prime minister. The Yugoslav presidency has few executive powers.

Its legitimacy, already undermined by the break-up of the federation during the Milosevic years, could be fatally wounded should Montenegro succeed in advancing its separatist aspirations. The DOS was in any case a marriage of convenience by widely disparate groups. Observers predict looming difficulties not only in the relationship between Mr Kostunica and Serbia's new leadership, but also within the DOS coalition.

Such continuing, possibly widening divisions will hardly help efforts to address urgent problems such as Serbia's post-war economic plight, the need to erect a law-based civil society amid the ruins of dictatorship and the attempt, still hardly begun, to inquire into and come to terms with the country's bloody past. Carla Del Ponte, the Hague tribunal's chief prosecutor, spoke angrily this week of the lack of progress in apprehending Serb war crimes suspects.

No one sought by the tribunal has been arrested since June. Most of all, Ms Del Ponte wants to get her hands on Milosevic. Pressure on Mr Kostunica to hand him over can only grow after the polls. But he still insists Yugoslavia will deal with Milosevic at home, in its own time.

On top of all this, there is the rising tension in Kosovo, a growing Albanian insurgency in the Presevo valley, the unresolved question of the province's future status, and the deeply unhelpful suggestion by George W Bush's advisers that the US may seek to withdraw its troops. After a short post-revolutionary lull, the Balkans are hotting up again.

webTitle: Threat of war in Indonesia's rebel province

fields.headline: Threat of war in Indonesia's rebel province
fields.standfirst:
President's visit to Aceh and his call for the army to treat locals as brothers fail to reassure separatist region

Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: President's visit to Aceh and his call for the army to treat locals as brothers fail to reassure separatist region.
fields.body:
A separatist leader has warned that civil war could break out in Indonesia's violence-racked province of Aceh, after nine people were killed in a rash of shootings.

The killing of seven villagers, one police officer and a rebel fighter in three separate incidents came within hours of a brief visit to the region by President Abdurrahman Wahid on Tuesday. Police said the officer was gunned down by rebels in eastern Aceh and the rebel was shot later in the same area. Each side blamed the other for the villagers' deaths.

"There will be war. It will get much worse," Zaini Abdullah said in a telephone interview from Stockholm, where he and other rebel leaders live in exile.

Mr Abdullah said the violence would escalate if a fragile six-month ceasefire that expires on January 15 is not renewed. But the Indonesian defence minister, Mohammad Mahfud, yesterday all but ruled out this possibility.

The visit to the region by President Wahid failed to achieve any semblance of a peace breakthrough between the separatists and the government.

With no sign of the ceasefire being extended, analysts are predicting the next 12 months will be much more violent than the past year, which has seen more than 800 people killed. At least 27 people have died in the last week alone.

Under heavy guard and wearing a bulletproof vest under his shirt, Mr Wahid tried to demonstrate his commitment to ending the conflict in a 30-minute speech in the Grand Mosque in the provincial capital, Banda Aceh.

But apart from government officials and some religious leaders, few people were there to hear him admit to making mistakes in his handling of the crisis and urge the security forces to treat the Acehnese "like brothers not enemies".

He also offered greater autonomy for the staunchly Islamic province that has been a separatist hotbed since 1976, when the Free Aceh Movement (GAM) was formed after decades of broken promises of self-rule by Jakarta.

"We have all made mistakes, including myself as president," Mr Wahid said. "I let this happen. We should punish the guilty, but the innocent should not suffer."

Maimul Fidar, one of the official monitors of the pause in the fighting, said people were too frightened of what the military and police might do to venture out of their homes. "People have no trust in the security forces anymore," he said. "They are being more brutal than they have been for several years."

The last round of peace talks, scheduled for Geneva last month, was cancelled after GAM pulled out, blaming mounting military brutality.

Among the most recent atrocities blamed on the military are the murders of three local members of a Danish-funded group helping victims of torture.

Ten GAM representatives were invited to attend the speech and meet the president but they boycotted the visit, saying it was irrelevant.

"This is for his benefit only. The Acehnese will not get anything from it," Cut Nur Asikin, a rebel spokeswoman, said. "He makes promises but never follows through on them."

Before he became president in October 1999, Mr Wahid said the Acehnese deserved to hold a referendum on their future ties with Jakarta. But since taking power, he has flatly refused all demands for an independence ballot.

Referendum activists believe more than 90% of Aceh's 4m people want independence but Humam Hamid, a human rights lawyer in Banda Aceh, is not so sure.

"What people want is peace and an end to the fighting," he said. "At the moment the security forces, and especially the police, are seen as the main aggressor which is why GAM seems to be getting so much support."

GAM's problem, he believes, is its lack of leadership. "They don't have any figure that the Acehnese can rally around," he said. "Their leader [Hasan Tiro] is in Sweden and the guys on the ground are not proving that appealing."

Mr Wahid's crisis is even more serious, Mr Hamid believes, because he cannot control what goes on in the field. "He might say he wants dialogue and an end to the violence but the reality on the ground is very different. He has no authority over what the military and police are doing."

The consequence is that neither side is likely to triumph in the short term.

"If the current conditions continue, I can only see more death and destruction," Mr Fidar said. "No one is taking responsibility for their actions and there is no accountability for what is happening."

There is a growing consensus among observers and diplomats that this downward cycle of violence is only likely to be halted with the help of an external mediator. "I see three choices," Mr Hamid said. "Either a neighbouring country, an Islamic country or an internationally respected figure."

Neither the government nor the military are countenancing any of these options. "This is an internal problem of Indonesia that we can solve ourselves without outside interference," said an assistant to senior security minister, Bambang Susilo Yudhoyono.

But with no sign of dialogue on the horizon and 2,000 more troops arriving recently in Aceh, it is clear that the use of greater force is the only solution being actively considered.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • You wouldn't believe it but that tigerish correspondent Lord Michael Henderson turns out to be a big woolly baa-lamb after all!
fields.body:
 You wouldn't believe it but that tigerish correspondent Lord Michael Henderson turns out to be a big woolly baa-lamb after all!

Although eager in his letters to lecture on everything from English drama and history to arse capacity, Lord H's form on his own speciality has not been great. Such was his scornful dismissal of the England cricket team, indeed, that before the triumphant series in Pakistan he promised his friend Mike Atherton to show his own bottom should Athers make a century.

Athers did in Karachi, so my colleague Marina Hyde rings for a mooning update. "I've ducked out of showing it," says a sheepish Hendo, going on to share his pain over the fury of Telegraph readers. "I am feeble." Indeed. Even the offer to send a photographer over to help him is rejected, Michael thinking it best if "I lie low for the time being". Not for too long, my lad, or we'll have to acquaint you with an old British tradition we call "debagging".

 Brass hats off to the MoD for a valiant rearguard effort on Tuesday to confound any prior media interest in Sir Charles Guthrie's speech about why there is no place in the military for the disabled.

The MoD press office fought valiantly not to send out advance copies, insisting there was little new or interesting in it. Perhaps so, but one passage caught the eye. "I do believe it's important that senior officers such as myself talk to the media," said the general, "to ensure that our message gets across."

 A preposterous rumour attaches itself to Richard Desmond, the man whose publishing career has had such positive collateral impact on other businesses, notably Kleenex. This suggests that Richard has approached Dominic Mohan, the Sun's moose-lookalike showbiz hack, over the editorship of the Daily Star. The thing about starting silly rumours, famously, is that by the time they boomerang back, the amnesiac will have forgotten putting them about in the first place and therefore believe them to be true. Let's hope Dominic's own memory is better than that.

 Meanwhile, I am still struggling to take in a weekend report that Richard has appointed Jonathan Holborow to the Express's advisory board. Readers will recall Jonathan as the shepherd who went on to co-edit the Mail on Sunday with Oswald (the white cotton handkerchief named after the wartime fascist leader Sir Oswald Mosley) which at times of stress, Jonathan would press to his mouth.

There is no word whether Oswald has a separate place on the advisory board. Then again, given the nub of Richard's magazine empire, there will always be work for a white cotton hankie (see Kleenex joke above). To this perplexing matter, we will return soon and with wearying regularity.

 Concern mounts for Virginia Bottomley after a source encountered her at the Readers' Digest Christmas party, where everyone was asked to wear a name tag. "I'm so sorry," said this source, recognising her face but not recalling the name, "but you're not wearing your tag." Smiling coquettishly, Mrs Bumley lowered her eyes.

He followed them and there, neatly stuck to her right shoe, was the name tag. Slightly alarmed, he asked the former health secretary to explain. "It's because I want people to worship at my feet," explained Virginia. Ah well, living with poor Bumley all those years could hardly fail to leave some mark. We wish her well.

 Can anyone think of a peg to justify an item about my friend Richard Littlejohn which is simply too old even for this column to run straight? It is so ancient that the events at the home of the sometime Milanese catwalk model Simon Heffer involved a then cabinet colleague of Virginia's and his lovely wife. Anyone who can supply a suitable peg, however contrived, will receive a bottle of champagne.

webTitle: Boris Berezovsky aims to defend Russia's oppressed

fields.headline: Oligarch hits out at his Kremlin monster
fields.standfirst:
Boris Berezovsky aims to defend Russia's oppressed - like himself

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Boris Berezovsky aims to defend Russia's oppressed - like himself.
fields.body:
Languishing in exile, a self-proclaimed target of political persecution, Boris Berezovsky has developed a sudden fascination with the victims of Russian oppression.

This week the multi-millionaire announced that he was donating $25m (£17m) to establish a foundation for the casualties of Russian authoritarianism. The International Foundation for Civil Liberties will support the abused and the vulnerable in society - prisoners, national minorities and, a press release reads, business people.

Claiming to be a martyr to an "utterly corrupt" legal system, Mr Berezovsky said his fund would donate money to a centre for judicial reform in Moscow. It would also focus on the oppression of people (like him) who work in the media and believe that they have been targeted as a result of their activity.

The irony of Mr Berezovsky's campaign to transform himself from a cynically ruthless businessman and Kremlin godfather into a champion of civil freedoms and legal justice in Russia has not gone unnoticed. While most Russians welcome the creation of a human rights body, there has been much eyebrow raising about the suitability of its founder - the most notorious of Russia's oligarchs, who grabbed his fortune by privatising state assets in the murky legal climate of the 1990s.

"We are delighted that a Russian-funded organisation has been set up, but there is concern that the director may hope to use the foundation to resolve some personal issues," Elena Zhimkova, acting director of Moscow's Memorial human rights group, said.

The almost bankrupt Andrei Sakharov foundation in Moscow has already received $3m from the tycoon - a gift which the Soviet dissident's widow accepted with ambivalence.

Sanguine in the knowledge that most of the Russian population loathes him for his political intrigues and for the money he made from state oil, aluminium, television and airline businesses, Mr Berezovsky professes to be immune to public cynicism about his motives. "I just hope to help people," he said.

Interpol

He may feel he could do with a little bit of this help himself. He is wanted for questioning in an investigation into whether senior executives of the national airline Aeroflot funnelled $970m into private Swiss companies. He fled Russia in November, claiming that the case was politically motivated. He believes that if he returns, he risks the same treatment meted out to media mogul Vladimir Gusinsky, in detention in Spain on fraud charges on an Interpol arrest warrant from Russia.

Mr Gusinsky owns a network of media companies, including Russia's main independent television channel, NTV. Yesterday one of his senior executives claimed in Spain that Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, plans to close down NTV in the new year.

"I will not return to Russia to explain myself in a purely political affair," Mr Berezovsky said.

Speaking by telephone from an undisclosed location in America), he comes across as a man whose latest venture is just one of many attempts to wrest back some of the influence he wielded under Boris Yeltsin's rule. He announced on Monday that he had begun negotiations with Chechen rebels, trying to help end the war in the separatist region.

His decision to champion the cause of Russia's underdogs came, he said, as a result of profound disaffection with the current regime. Mr Putin, he said with vitriol, was trampling on the country's rights.

Hitler

"We can't rely on our president to be a reformer - we've got a president who is trying to turn the country backwards. We have to rely on ourselves. If we organise ourselves we can begin to build a democratic state and liberal society," he said. "Putin's regime is becoming like the Germany which Hitler built - we're seeing a return of a dictatorship of the state, using nationalist motifs as a base. It isn't simply a question of anti-semitism, but a negative attitude towards all ethnic groups, under a flag of Great Russia, or Russia for Russians."

Now one of Mr Putin's most strident critics, Mr Berezovsky bears much responsibility for propelling the president to power. Exactly a year ago, his funding of the pro-Kremlin, pro-Putin Unity party cleared the way for Mr Putin to take the presidency, while the main state television channel ORT, which he controls, spewed out enthusiastic Putin propganda. His current venom is that of a Dr Frankenstein, horrified by the insolent independence of his own creation.

"I never counted precisely how much [I donated], but it came to millions of dollars," he said. "But Putin deceived me and the millions of people who voted for him in the election. He promised to support the course of reforms, and instead he has stopped them and reversed them."

It is debatable whether the tycoon really abandoned the Kremlin on a point of principle, or whether Mr Putin wanted a crowd-pleasing sacrifice of the government's Rasputin. From Mr Putin's point of view, the very public split with Mr Berezovsky conveniently distracts attention from the fact that other pro-Kremlin oligarchs remain in favour. Mr Berezovsky's former business partner, Roman Abramovich, is set on Sunday to be elected governor of gold-rich Chukotka.

Mr Berezovsky strongly criticises the president's stance on Chechnya, the rebuilding of government structures in Russia to concentrate power in the Kremlin and the crackdown on press freedoms. But his current favourite theme is the corruption of the Russian prosecution service which is pursuing both him and the Media Most head, Mr Gusinsky.

Mr Berezovsky said: "Europe and the United States should take note of what is happening in Russia. When the Russian prosecutor said [he] has all the material necessary to imprison Gusinsky, the Spanish prosecutors took this on faith - not understanding that the Russian prosecution service is utterly corrupt and under the influence of presidential structures which are using democratic institutions to realise totalitarian aims."

As Swiss prosecutors continue their investigation, Mr Berezovsky admitted that some of the $25m donation for his fund came from the contested Aeroflot funds - money which he accused Mr Putin of taking for his presidential campaign.

"I have never hidden the fact that the Swiss companies that worked with Aeroflot were profitable, and that part of the money which those companies earned came to me. I openly declared that," he said. "I've been in business since 1989. I made a lot of money because, unlike most people, I slept only three or four hours every night and spent the rest of the time working. I earned this money absolutely honestly. My conscience is clear."

Man with knack for figures

Boris Berezovsky, 54, transformed himself from an impoverished Soviet mathematician to a supremely successful entrepreneur as the Soviet Union collapsed. Later he used his charm and shrewd judgment to secure himself a controlling position in Boris Yeltsin's government.

His commercial career began by importing computer software from the west, but he began to earn serious money with the establishment at the end of the 1980s of the Logovaz car dealership, which allowed him to sell off Russian-made cars at a profit.

His business success is a result of his versatility, and the ease with which he obtained and developed serious stakes in banking, oil, aluminium and media, as well as in the state airline Aeroflot. In 1997, Forbes magazine named him the ninth most powerful entrepreneur in the world and his fortune was rated at $3bn.

In 1994 he took control of 49% of the state television channel ORT, and makes no secret of the role he played in the 1996 presidential election, when he and a group of influential business figures used their powers to cripple the communists and rescue Mr Yeltsin from defeat. He forged a strong friendship with Mr Yeltsin's daughter, Tatyana Dyachenko, and won himself a key role in Kremlin decision-making.

Ferocious

His control of ORT proved useful again in last year's parliamentary elections, when a ferocious slur campaign played out on the channel's news programmes effectively eliminated two of Vladimir Putin's key rivals for the presidential election in March. Mr Berezovsky won a seat in the state duma later, obtaining theoretical immunity from prosecution.

But despite funding Mr Putin's campaign, his central role in Russian politics began to disintegrate soon after the election, as the new president launched a selective campaign against the oligarchs who had flourished under Mr Yeltsin. Mr Berezovsky resigned from his seat in the duma in July, in protest at what he saw as "authoritarian trends" within Mr Putin's government.

Mr Berezovsky refuses to return to Russia to face prosecutors because he fears becoming a "political prisoner".

webTitle: Children's home in sex abuse inquiry

fields.headline: Children's home in sex abuse inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Detectives are investigating allegations that dozens of children might have been sexually abused at a home for young people with learning difficulties.
fields.body:
Detectives are investigating allegations that dozens of children might have been sexually abused at a home for young people with learning difficulties.

The abuse was claimed to have taken place "several years ago" at Betts Way children's home in Bromley, Kent, Scotland Yard said last night.

It is understood that child protection officers have interviewed about 40 people so far, but not all are alleged victims.

One woman claimed that her daughter, who has Down's syndrome, was raped at the home, but said the abuser was unlikely to be prosecuted due to lack of evidence. She claimed that he was now working at another children's home.

The mother, named as Sarah, told Radio 4's Today programme she was one of 11 parents told by police last year that their children had made allegations of sexual abuse. Since then at least 28 other families have been given similar news. The allegations are thought to go back 12 years.

"I had two police officers sit in my living room and interview my daughter," the woman said. "They said they totally believed she was sexually abused, but there was no proof to back up that belief. The person who abused my child is about to walk free. I will have to live with this fact for the rest of my life, and I don't want police coming back in 10 years' time saying the case has been reopened because they have abused some other child."

Betts Way, which closed temporarily last spring, is owned by Bromley council and run by the Ravensbourne NHS trust. It offered respite care for children with learning disabilities.

A council spokeswoman said the interviews were being conducted "sensitively, skilfully and thoroughly. Every effort is being taken to safeguard confidentiality and to protect the children.

"Matters cannot be made public until the investigation is concluded and the crown prosecution service has considered whether there is evidence to warrant further action."

A Metropolitan police spokeswoman said she could not give details of the investigation for fear of prejudicing the outcome. The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children said it was involved in the inquiry but could make no comment until it was completed.

A University of Kent study suggested that up to 1,500 adults and children with learning difficulties were sexually abused each year, yet only 3% of cases were prosecuted.

Alan Corbett, of the charity Respond, which helps children with learning difficulties who have been sexually abused, said that often "they are simply not believed or not considered reliable enough witnesses.

"It is often assumed that they won't be able to give evidence well enough because their story is not consistent and they have problems of time and memory. Of course they can give evidence well - it just needs more working at it."

However, a CPS spokesman said he did not believe that such cases were prevented from going to court. Judges often allowed video evidence to be used if they feared that the atmosphere in the court would cause the witness to "clam up".

This year a report by Sir Ronald Waterhouse found that hundreds of children in Welsh care homes were systematically exploited sexually and brutalised over 20 years.

The report called for an independent children's commissioner to make sure that children who made allegations of abuse were listened to.

webTitle: Docment restoration experts after the deluge in York

fields.headline: Paper chase to save money after the deluge
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Document restoration experts are on standby for a fresh deluge of soaked bank statements and inundated files, after days of painstaking rescue work following the October floods.
fields.body:
Document restoration experts are on standby for a fresh deluge of soaked bank statements and inundated files, after days of painstaking rescue work following the October floods.

Nearly 30,000 business documents have been returned to relieved business executives by conservators at York University, who usually work on recovering fragments of mediaeval texts.

More than 900 files from one company were glued together in a mess of ink and soggy paper after the river Ouse swamped storage rooms in York.

"We've had everyone in the building working on the job," said Chris Webb, director of the Borthwick Institute, whose regular weapons to recover texts include enzymes which eat 19th century glue.

Washing lines hung with drying sheets of invoices and receipts have been strung across the institute's rooms, with dehumidifiers and fan-heaters helping to separate sheets.

"It's a much more delicate job in many ways than medieval conservation," said Mr Webb, "because modern paper is much less robust and modern ink runs easily. We've had some sheets of paper which have just gone a nice shade of watery blue - the ink's run and the writing's disappeared."

Other documents, printed on paper made from woodpulp rather than the much stronger rag-fibre used before Victorian times, have split under their own weight, or turned into an irrecoverable mush.

"The hardest ones to restore were those kept in transparent plastic folders," said Mr Webb. "The paper sticks to the plastic when soaked, there's a reaction and they're very difficult to prise apart."

The institute is standing by for fresh consignments as rivers, including the Ouse, approach danger levels again after this week's rainfall. But the long history of flooding in York, where the conservators' base has been prudently sited well above the river, is part of the team's life.

One of its last pre-flood jobs was the restoration of York city council minutes dating back to the 15th century, when "an accumulation of from the depths of the rivers blocked their course and flooded lowlying lands, destroying all the crops to such an extent that they had to be sown again. On another occasion, scribes recorded how servants at St Mary's Abbey in York had to go to work in boats, with the Ouse up to the level of the high altar."

A member of York University's staff affected by the October floods, Tessa Hilton, is still looking for goldfish from her garden pond. She caught two on a nearby roundabout but 22 are still missing.

We've had some sheets of paper which have just gone a nice shade of watery blue - the ink's run and the writing's disappeared." Other documents, printed on paper made from woodpulp rather than the much stronger rag-fibre used before Victorian times, have split under their own weight, or turned into an irrecoverable mush. "The hardest ones to restore were those kept in transparent plastic folders," said Mr Webb. "The paper sticks to the plastic when soaked, there's a reaction and they're very difficult to prise apart." The institute is standing by for fresh consignments as rivers, including the Ouse, approach danger levels again after this week's rainfall. But the long history of flooding in York, where the conservators' base has been prudently sited well above the river, is part of the team's life. One of its last pre-flood jobs was the restoration of York city council minutes dating back to the 15th century, when "an accumulation of from the depths of the rivers blocked their course and flooded lowlying lands, destroying all the crops to such an extent that they had to be sown again. On another occasion, scribes recorded how servants at St Mary's Abbey in York had to go to work in boats, with the Ouse up to the level of the high altar." A member of York University's staff affected by the October floods, Tessa Hilton, is still looking for goldfish from her garden pond. She caught two on a nearby roundabout but 22 are still missing.

fields.headline: Living with the inEquitable
fields.trailText: My husband was advised to take a with-profits annuity with Equitable Life two years ago (Leader, December 20). He is suffering from a terminal disease which may need full nursing care, so the pension is particularly important to us.
fields.body:
My husband was advised to take a with-profits annuity with Equitable Life two years ago (Leader, December 20). He is suffering from a terminal disease which may need full nursing care, so the pension is particularly important to us.

The aspect of the present situation which we feel very bitter about is that former chief executive, Alan Nash, wrote to us in February 2000, stating that: "Contrary to many of the reports in the press, there would be no significant costs imposed on the society if the court of appeal's decision were upheld in the House of Lords ... Your society remains and will continue to remain, financially secure." This statement was clearly a lie. Surely the Financial Services Association could have given us more protection?
Name and address supplied

 The day Equitable commenced issuing policies with guaranteed annuity returns (GAR), they changed the basis of all the existing with-profits policies. Further, all the with-profits policies issued after GAR policies were discontinued were issued without the purchasers being advised of any abnormal commitment with respect to GAR policies.

In other words Equitable has mis-sold in excess of 1m policies - all the with-profits policies, including AVCs, together with the GAR policies with a guarantee that is likely to be impossible to fulfil. Mis-selling on this scale requires an inquiry and arbitration to adjudicate between the obligations to all policy holders.

The 10% penalty for policy holders who decide to transfer to another company should also be challenged.
JE Atherton
Leicester

 Here's a proposition to the 90,000 who have wrecked Equitable Life: if you withdraw your claim, the insurer can be rescued and you can share in its success with the other 1m; if you persist in enforcing your guarantee, I'll help set up a campaign to ensure all 1m remove their funds and your guarantee, and investments, will be worthless. I'm serious.
Sean Kelly
Leighton Buzzard, Beds
skelly@argonet.co.uk

 The management of our society may have been misguided but, in reporting that Mr Hyman and well-heeled associates brought the action against the society, you failed to give credit to the society for funding that action to clarify its responsibilities. To those accustomed to societies operated by members for the benefit of members, it comes as a great shock to find the Lords rule that a minority can take generous benefits at the expense of the majority of members. Lawyers yet again have helped the litigious at the expense of the trusting and charitably minded. I suspect that many, policyholders feel angry and cheated yet again by the establishment in the City and at Westminster.
MJ Cahalan
Dunblane, Perthshire
bmmj.cahalan@lineone.net

 Discussion about Equitable Life is mainly about the best course of action for investors who have not yet retired and have the option to move their funds. I am one of the 65,000 retired people who are already drawing an Equitable with-profits annuity and have no choices.

We signed up because the investment policy meant that our income would increase every year. Now we are contractually committed for life even though that investment policy is to change, inevitably reducing the income that we can expect to receive.

Equitable Life should offer some other option to people in our situation.
Judith Stone
London
judith.stone@virgin.net

fields.headline: Power walkers
fields.standfirst: Penguin waddle disguises energy super-store
fields.trailText: Penguin waddle disguises energy super-store
fields.body:
Californian scientists have worked out why penguins waddle. It is because they have such short legs and such big feet.

This insight into what scientists call gait mechanics - and the rest of the world calls walking - answers some burning questions about penguins, obesity and how pregnant women get along.

The blubber-lined, waterproof birds of the southern ocean can swim like fish. But on dry land or ice, they seem like fish out of water. And yet emperor penguins fast for four months during the winter while hatching their young - and then walk 100 miles to the open sea before they can eat.

The answer, according to Timothy Griffin at the University of California, Berkeley, is that the clumsy walk is a way of conserving energy. He and Rodger Kram report in Nature today that they worked this out by prodding emperor penguins to make them walk across a "force platform" at San Diego Sea World.

Emperor penguins weigh 40lb and stand more than 3ft 6in tall. They normally walk at 1.5ft a second. And they burn energy at twice the rate of a mammal of the same weight, such as a dog.

The next step was to test the birds on a trackway that measured the force of each movement they made. "We found they are inefficient because of their short legs and big feet, and waddling is a means to cut their losses."

One was required to think of the waddling penguin as an inverted pendulum, the scientists said. At the end of each swing, when the penguin was for an instant still, the energy of the side to side motion was stored as potential energy. On the return swing, this was converted to energy of motion that peaked as the penguin rocked through the vertical.

All animals recovered some energy with each step. But waddling penguins turned out to be the big winners. They got up to 80% of their energy of motion back with each swing. This was the highest of any terrestrial animal. Humans got about 65% back with each step.

The knowledge from the study may help treatment of people with gait disabilities.

webTitle: Letters: Satan, Santa? Hard to tell

fields.headline: Satan, Santa? Hard to tell
fields.trailText: Parents who are buying computers for children this Christmas (Switched on, Guardian Education, December 19) need to be aware of the dangers.
fields.body:
Parents who are buying computers for children this Christmas (Switched on, Guardian Education, December 19) need to be aware of the dangers. Seven leading children's charities - NCH, Barnardos, Childline, NSPCC, NCVCCO, NCB and the Children's Society are launching a campaign calling on the internet and computer industries to make children's safety on the net their priority. We are proposing measures which include the promotion of child-friendly search engines; more effective monitoring of chat rooms; and the blocking of newsgroups containing child pornography. In the meantime parents can get advice from www.nch.org.uk
John Carr
London

 Maybe one reason for the rise and rise of Father Christmas (Parents, December 20) is his promotion by business. We might like to see him as the spirit of giving, but he is really the spirit of selling - of making money; of exploitation, especially of children and their parents. If there's money to be made, of course Jesus can't compete. Father Christmas has been turned into a grubby, capitalist child abuser. Ho, ho, ho!
Michael Peet
London
michael@mpeet.fsnet.co.uk

 I should like to tell Nathan Graham (Letters, December 20) that in this large and varied family (18 for dinner on Christmas day) a goodly proportion of the presents under the Christmas tree come directly from "F Christmas".
Gerald White
Leeds
gerald@janetwhite.com

 Santa doesn't put gift tags on his presents because, duh, they're all from him.
John Dean
Oxford
john-dean@msn.com

fields.headline: Going to the dogs
fields.trailText: Harry Pearson eulogises Pickles' achievements in the 1966 World Cup (Sport, December 19) campaign but omits his less sparkling performances.
fields.body:
Harry Pearson eulogises Pickles' achievements in the 1966 World Cup (Sport, December 19) campaign but omits his less sparkling performances. If every dog has his day, finding the Jules Rimet trophy was certainly his. If memory serves, he subsequently starred in the dire film, The Spy with the Cold Nose, and met his end under a car while chasing a cat.
Alan Gravett
Gilbraltar

 Presumably men with one eye and one arm count as disabled (Defence chief lays into culture of 'risk aversion', December 20). It's a good thing Nelson was not forbidden to serve in the Napoleonic wars or the Navy might not have won the battles of the Nile, Copenhagen or Trafalgar.
Dr Toby Lipman
Newcastle upon Tyne

 I would suggest a more likely source for Fay Weldon's "edoarchy" (Leader, December 20) is Edo, an old name for Tokyo. The Edo (or Tokugawa) period of Japanese culture was marked at its height by its extravagance and frivolity; a world of courtesans, rich merchants and epicures.
Bob Rait
Hartlepool

 Steve Bell's customary self-censorship has broken down (December 19) - neither carers, sufferers (were they able to) nor their relatives would consider the appalling disease of Alzheimers a candidate for a cartoon.
Christopher Mezzetti
Bromley, Kent

 Would you be so kind as to print something along the lines of "Warning - dangerously funny Steve Bell cartoon inside" the next time that your resident genius comes up with something like this (December 20)? We had to spend several valuable minutes this morning wiping cornflakes off the wall, and very nearly missed the train as a result.
Tom Locke
Burntisland, Fife

fields.headline: Holy water
fields.trailText: The confusion about Quakers and alcohol is not confined to them (Letters, December 19). Other religious sects held the same view - that the real problem was drinking to excess.
fields.body:
The confusion about Quakers and alcohol is not confined to them (Letters, December 19). Other religious sects held the same view - that the real problem was drinking to excess. The brewing of light ale (small or table beer) was essential for health reasons at a time when there was no substantial source of pure water; even a Quaker school had its own brewery until early in the 19th century, when a healthy water source was found.

As a persecuted sect that was denied access to the professions of the day, Quakers turned to trade: malting, brewing, mining, banking, importing (tea and cocoa), biscuits, chocolate, soap, medicinal drugs, chemicals and financing railways as their main sources of honest employment. The result was the rapid development of commerce in England.
John Youatt Dunning
Wakefield

 In addition to inventing pub lunches, Quakers could claim to have invented the wine bar. Many years ago I was a blowsy barmaid in the employ of the Yates, a Quaker family, in one of their Wine Lodges, when they were "spit and sawdust" working-men's boozers.

In addition to Aussie white, Red Biddy and Cape red wines, customers could purchase flour, tea, sugar and tinned sardines. These latter items were taken home to placate the missus. Now re-branded to attract trendy youngsters, Yates' appear to have dropped the motto which adorned our flunkey jackets: "Moderation is True Temperance."
Jinty Batkins
Liverpool

fields.headline: Students sold short
fields.trailText: The abolition of grants and the related issue of access is of central concern to the NUS (Living on credit, December 20). We have anticipated and noted the disastrous consequences of the withdrawal of grants and this is reflected in our research and campaign focus. The problem is with politicians, not the NUS.
fields.body:
The abolition of grants and the related issue of access is of central concern to the NUS (Living on credit, December 20). We have anticipated and noted the disastrous consequences of the withdrawal of grants and this is reflected in our research and campaign focus. The problem is with politicians, not the NUS. Perhaps Angela Phillips failed to notice 17,000 students marching through London on November 15?

Our research has highlighted the worrying effect that the new system is having on participation, especially among low-income students and those traditionally under-represented in higher education. We are calling for the introduction of targeted grants to ensure that higher education is accessible for all and that those on a low income do not incur unacceptable levels of debt.

Unfortunately, whilst Angela Phillips recognises the shortfall between assessed parental contribution and actual contribution highlighted in Professor Callender's report, she perpetuates the myth that tuition fees are only paid by those who can afford to do so. It is clear that whilst "middle-class" parents are assessed to be able to afford tuition fees on the basis of their income and assets, in the majority of cases it is students, who on average have the same level of expenditure as the poorest 20% of young people in the population, who bear the cost of tuition fees.

Only a system such as that recommended by the Cubie report, where graduates contribute once they are earning £25,000, can truly ensure that only those in a position to pay do pay.
Owain James
President, National Union of Students

fields.headline: So, the award of the lottery turns out to be ... a lottery
fields.trailText: Having had 20 years to come to terms with the delights of privatisation and competition as propounded by both main political parties, I find the debate over who should run the lottery bizarre (Sorry, but it's not you ... December 20).
fields.body:
Having had 20 years to come to terms with the delights of privatisation and competition as propounded by both main political parties, I find the debate over who should run the lottery bizarre (Sorry, but it's not you ... December 20). Why not let them both run a lottery and then we'll see just who runs it efficiently and whether "the people" really do want a profit-free lottery - or what really matters is the payout? Surely the country's best known capitalist would welcome the challenge? After all, his railway company has done so well.
P Robinson
Waterlooville, Hants

 You report that "the [lottery] commission returned repeatedly to the suggestion that it was more risky to appoint a new operator". Oddly enough, there was no such risk aversion when Govia was recently given the Connex South Central rail franchise, given: a) Connex's performance figures were better than those of the Govia-owned Thameslink; b) the Connex bid was the more adventurous; and c) Connex's safety record is considerably better than Govia's.
AK Daniell
Brighton

 The decision to renew Camelot's licence is incomprehensible - especially as earlier this year the commission admitted that the People's Lottery would generate far more money for good causes. The public have a right to know exactly on what grounds the commission based its decision. One of the biggest problems in Britain is that too many decisions are made by small cliques of well-connected individuals behind closed doors. And most of the time we meekly accept their decisions. It is to be hoped that not only Mr Branson, but the people of this country will not allow this farcical decision to go unchallenged
Robert Readman
Boscombe, Dorset

 The lottery commissioners were unanimously in favour of a continuing bid by the People's Lottery and the government had pledged a non-profit lottery. The chair was replaced by a Thatcherite civil servant and the decision is suddenly reversed, even though nothing in the bids had altered.

Sounds suspicious to me.
Mike Homfray
Liverpool

 Thankfully one person does emerge with credit from this sorry affair. I am a friend of resigning commissioner Hilary Blume and may be biased. But it is worth pointing out that she has founded and runs a successful trust which earns millions of pounds for voluntary bodies. At least those of us at the hard end can thank Hilary Blume for acting with integrity and courage.
Bob Holman
Glasgow
bob@holman24.fsnet.co.uk

 So awarding the lottery contract has turned out to be a bit of a, well, lottery. Isn't postmodernism great?
Andy Clark
Whitley Bay, Tyne and Wear

 Perhaps Lord Burns has spent the last four months on Virgin Trains?
Ann Black
Oxford

webTitle: Leader: The mentally ill have rights; so do others

fields.headline: Correcting the balance
fields.standfirst: The mentally ill have rights; so do others
fields.trailText: The mentally ill have rights; so do others.
fields.body:
It was billed as the biggest mental health shake up for 40 years. True, there was a Mental Health Act in 1983, but based on a 50s review. Yesterday's reforms emerged from an intensive eight-year debate, sparked by Ben Silcock, suffering from schizophrenia, who climbed into the lion cage at London zoo and was seriously mauled.

Ben Silcock was not refusing medication but had turned to hospitals for treatment and been refused. Ministers have conceded that too many vulnerable people have been left to cope on their own, too many confused people have been left wandering the street and sleeping rough, and a small but significant minority have become a danger to the public as well as themselves.

This last minority has been the focus of fevered media attention, not least because of the tragic murders these mentally ill people have committed. They include Christopher Clunis, who killed Jonathan Zito, and Michael Stone who attacked Josie Russell and killed her mother and sister. But the tabloid press has lost all perspective. Fewer than 10 homicides a year - less than 2% of all killings - involve people with schizophrenia.

Another 30 have had some contact with mental health services, but the home office has recorded no increase in killings by psychiatric patients in recent years. Statistically, you are 20 times more likely to be killed by a sane than by an insane person. The biggest threat which mental patients pose is to themselves. Over 1,000 kill themselves every year.

Two controversial proposals with far-reaching civil rights implications have emerged from this debate: that for community treatment orders (CTOs), under which patients in the community could be subjected to compulsory treatment; and that for an indeterminate reviewable hospital order, under which dangerous people with a severe personality disorder, formerly known as psychopaths, could be detained not for what they have done, but for what they might do.

We have supported CTOs in principle because of the changing pattern of mental health services and the need to protect patients and public. In the new ethos of "hospitals without walls", requiring compulsory treatment to be confined to patients in hospitals seemed inappropriate. We suggested two conditions, both of which have been met. First, that they should not be a substitute for investing in mental services. An extra 3,000 staff have been recruited.

The NHS plan in July included another £330m over the next three years. By next April, ministers are promising 500 extra secure beds, 320 other beds with 24-hour cover, and 170 outreach teams. Second, a proper procedure protecting patients' rights. Yesterday's package sets out a three-stage assessment procedure, with a new independent mental health tribunal to decide any compulsory order.

The indeterminate hospital order for people with a severe personality disorder is more troubling. Ben Silcock was not refusing medication but had turned to hospitals for treatment and been refused. They include Christopher Clunis, who killed Jonathan Zito, and Michael Stone who attacked Josie Russell and killed her mother and sister. But the tabloid press has lost all perspective.
