fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
19 dead as Turkish police move in on jails
Jospin wins battle to switch poll
Troops kill 2 in Gaza as talks go on
Policeman shot dead in Eta attack
New Year blues for Eiffel Tower
fields.body:
19 dead as police move in on jails

Turkish police stormed two prisons yesterday in a second day of raids as the justice minister urged protesting prisoners to end armed resistance which has so far cost at least 19 lives.

Paramilitary police raided Istanbul's Umraniye prison before dawn, accompanied by fire engines, a bulldozer and armoured cars. Hours later, they moved on Canakkale prison, western Turkey.

"There is strong resistance at both prisons," an interior ministry official said.

Justice minister Hikmet Sami Turk called on the inmates to end what have become the bloodiest clashes in years in Turkey's prisons, where inmates often have more control than jailers.

Mr Turk said that two paramilitary gendarmes had died along with at least 17 prisoners, most of whom burned themselves to death when security forces stormed 20 prisons on Tuesday to halt hunger strikes aimed at blocking the transfer of inmates to small cells from larger dormitories. Overall, 78 inmates were injured in the riots.

Human rights groups dispute claims that most of the dead committed suicide.

Prison officials say that the transfer of inmates is necessary to break the grip of gangsters, leftists, Kurdish separatists and militant Islamic groups inside the jails.

The protesters, mostly from far-left groups, say the small cells will make them more vulnerable to abuse by jailers.

Paramilitary police armed with gas grenades and backed by helicopters struck early on Tuesday after weeks of attempts to bring a peaceful end to the protests. By Tuesday night, the security forces were in charge except at Umraniye and Canakkale.
Reuters, Istanbul

Jospin wins battle to switch poll

Prime Minister Lionel Jospin scored an important tactical victory in his push for the French presidency yesterday when the National Assembly voted to reverse the 2002 election calendar.

Opposition Union for French Democracy (UDF) deputies joined Mr Jospin's Socialists to approve a plan to hold the 2002 presidential poll before voters pick a new parliament, not afterwards. The switch could boost his chances while sowing discord among President Jacques Chirac's supporters.

Mr Chirac's Rally for the Republic slammed the switch as a partisan move while Mr Jospin's Communist and Green allies denounced it as a bid to strengthen the presidency over the assembly.

Presidential polls precede legislative elections, but Mr Chirac's decision to dissolve the assembly in 1997 - a move which backfired and brought Mr Jospin to power - upset the rhythm.

Conservatives opposing the switch expect to win a majority in the 2002 polls because the far-right National Front vote has since collapsed. A conservative win in March, they say, would harm Mr Jospin's presidential challenge and help Mr Chirac.

Switching the calendar would negate that risk for Mr Jospin making the first election of the year a head-on battle with Mr Chirac - both men are about equal in the opinion polls. It would also level the field for other rightwing challengers. Francois Bayrou, head of the UDF, has already announced his candidacy and could be a compromise candidate for the right.

The pro-Chirac Paris daily Le Figaro warned that the president still had some trump cards. "Chirac the fighter is never as good as when he is in trouble," the paper wrote.
Paris, Reuters

Troops kill 2 in Gaza as talks go on

Israeli troops in the Gaza Strip opened fire on a Palestinian fire engine yesterday, killing a Palestinian civil defence officer and critically injuring a second. Elsewhere in Gaza, a young boy was killed and at least 33 other Palestinians hurt, they said.

Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat condemned the bloodshed just as both sides tried to restart the peace process.

As the US and Israeli mediators held preliminary talks for a second day in Washington, the Israelis expressed cautious optimism. Cabinet minister Amnon Lipkin-Shahak said that the talks would be able to bridge some gaps.

The Israeli army yesterday confirmed the shooting in Rafah, southern Gaza, where the young boy was killed, but said it knew of no shooting at Netzarim crossing, where the fire engine was hit.

Witnesses say the red truck with Palestinian Authority insignia and the red licence plates of an official vehicle came under fire as it passed an Israeli troop position at the junction. There were no clashes in the area at the time, eyewitnesses said.
AP, Gaza City

Policeman shot dead in Eta attack

A policeman who approached two men pushing a car in central Barcelona yesterday was shot dead in an apparent attack by the Basque separatist group Eta, the authorities said.

The shooting occurred yesterday morning on Avenida Diagonal, a major thoroughfare in Spain's second largest city. The officer was identified as Miguel Angel Gervilla Valladolid, 38.

The officer saw two men pushing a red Fiat car, walked up to them to ask for their identity papers and was shot in the head and chest, officials said. The killers fled on foot.

Fearing the car might contain a bomb, police cordoned off the area and urged people living in flats on the avenue to stay away from their balconies.

The car had fake licence plates, a technique often employed by Eta when it uses a stolen vehicle.

Police examining the car from the outside spotted a cooking pot on one of the seats, the interior ministry office in Barcelona said. Such pots are sometimes used by Eta to pack explosives.

"It seems this car belonged to Eta," the office's director, Julia Garcia Valdecasas, said.

The last two attacks attributed to Eta this year also occurred either in or near Barcelona. Before yesterday's shooting, the group had claimed or been blamed for 22 killings in a wave of bombings and shootings.

On Monday, police defused a suspected Eta bomb at a university outside the Basque city of Bilbao. Eta's 32-year terrorist campaign has left around 800 people dead.
AP, Barcelona

New Year blues for Eiffel Tower

The Eiffel Tower will turn blue from midnight until dawn to welcome in the new year, organisers of celebrations in Paris said yesterday.

They said a team of 40 mountain climbers would begin the arduous, three-day task of placing blue Lycra covers on each of the 20,000 light bulbs strung across the 324-metre (1,036ft) tower for last New Year's eve.

The white bulbs have burst into life every night this year, twinkling for 10 minutes each hour from dusk until 1am, making the tower look like a giant sparkler.

The firm which rents the tower from the city of Paris had planned to end the light spectacle at the end of this year but city authorities say the show must go on.

The Eiffel Tower, with about 6m visitors a year, says it is the world's most-visited paying monument. Most other Paris monuments will also be bathed in light on December 31 and 1,000 drummers will drum in the 12 strokes of midnight at the Pompidou centre.
Reuters, Paris

fields.trailText: Yesterday's G2 cover piece was Allison Perkin's story of finding out that a well known 1970s London robber, Bobby King, was her father. The accompanying picture, page 3, purported to show her with him. In fact, the woman in the photo is actress Julie Christie. The panel with the article says King described himself as a "liberal" robber because his shotgun cartridges "were loaded with sand not gunpowder". Rather, the sand would have replaced the metal shot, with cordite being the explosive element.

webTitle: Eruptive activity from Mexico's Popocatepetl volcano

fields.headline: Villages deserted as Popo spits red
fields.trailText: With red hot rocks spewing from the crater of Mexico's Popocatepetl volcano for the second night running, tens of thousands of people face a prolonged exile from villages dotted around the danger zone.
fields.body:
With red hot rocks spewing from the crater of Mexico's Popocatepetl volcano for the second night running, and no end in sight to the mountain's most dramatic eruptive phase in more than 500 years, tens of thousands of people face a prolonged exile from villages dotted around the danger zone.

"When the volcano started spitting fire we realised we couldn't wait any longer and had to leave," explained Adolfo Flores, 16, from the safe distance of a school-turned-shelter in the colonial town of Cholula, famed for its stunning views of Popocatepetl.

Like many from the poor villages at the volcano's feet which are most at risk if the eruptions prompt a major lava flow or avalanche of acidic sludge, Adolfo's family had ignored evacuation calls over the weekend.

"When there were just the white and grey plumes coming out of the crater we thought we didn't need to worry," he said, displaying generations of collective memory in which periodic phases of intensified exhalations were dismissed as unthreatening heavy breathing. "But then the volcano showed that this was something different this time, something serious."

Popo, as the mountain is commonly known, had been pouring out water vapour and ash for days, but a dome of lava inside the crater had blocked the release of the energy, triggering the first eruptive episode on Monday night.

The evacuees in the Cholula shelter described how the waves of incandescence spraying across the night sky just a few miles away sent them scurrying for the evacuation buses which had been on standby since Friday.

"We have nothing with us. Documents, a few clothes, but that's all," said Irma Sanchez, waiting in a lunch queue with her standard-issue plate and mug. "When you have to make a choice between your material possessions and protecting your life, you don't have to think very hard."

This shelter holds about 700 of the approximately 35,000 people evacuated, mostly on Monday night or during the second eruptive episode, before dawn on Tuesday. While the majority went willingly, some refused to abandon all their possessions, although most of those who remained were persuaded to go when Popo erupted for several hours during Tuesday night.

"I can't go. Who will feed my piglets?" Juana de la Cruz, 71, said as she trudged through the village of Santiago Xalitzintla. She believed that the volcano would never harm those who lived by its side, but promised to bail out if it started spitting red again, as it did three hours later.

During the relative daytime calm on Tuesday, a twisted mass of vapour and ash stretched for miles into a bright blue sky, providing a dramatic backdrop to the now ghostlike villages below.

With shutters down, the only signs of life were provided by the odd evacuee picking up essentials or feeding animals, dogs roaming in packs, and troops on standby to evacuate even the most reticent if a major eruption were forecast.

The alert has captured Mexico's imagination, with millions glued to the live transmissions of eruptions on television. It has also provided President Vicente Fox with his first test of disaster-management in a country that, as well as being home to 14 active volcanoes, is plagued by floods, hurricanes and earthquakes.

On a tour of the danger area, Mr Fox called for caution but promised everything was under control because "the volcanologists have all the information about what is going on in the intestines, the stomach, and the mind of the volcano. We just have to be prepared to react to what it tells us." No injuries have yet been reported.

But if the correct prediction of the first eruption has forced locals to rethink their view of the experts as scaremongers playing with expensive useless toys, many still believe there is much more to the eruption than pressure build-ups.

"Me and my mates have been talking, and although we aren't sure why he [the volcano] is acting this way, we think it might be that he's angry that we're cutting down the trees on his side," explained Adolfo, who recalls seeing the personification of the volcano, an old man called Don Goyo, in a forest on the mountain's flank six years ago.

In an updated version of the traditional offerings taken to Popo's mystical shrines, Adolfo and his friends plan to rent a sound system and hold a dance to honour and placate Don Goyo as soon as it is safe to go home.

fields.headline: Liverpool's ghost of Christmas past
fields.standfirst:
A Christmas Carol
Playhouse
Liverpool
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
A Christmas Carol
Playhouse
Liverpool
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Scrooge liked darkness - "darkness was cheap". He would have approved of the condition of the Playhouse which has remained dark these past three years, shuttered and barred like the greatest hulk of humbug in the city.

Now the chains are off and the ghosts have come flying out of the closet. Dickens's seasonal warning of an excessively parsimonious past is the perfect reawakening for Liverpool's dormant repertory tradition, founded in 1911 and the oldest in the country.

Rep has had a rough ride here in recent years. In the 1980s Alan Bleasdale and Willie Russell had their hands on the Playhouse tiller, but in the 1990s local-born impresario Bill Kenwright had to bail it out. The new Liverpool and Merseyside Theatres Trust has fused the operation with the equally erratic Everyman, and will be hoping that the return of home-grown theatre adds impetus to the Liverpool renaissance.

Productions of this quality are a promising start. Richard Williams, a former artistic director of the Playhouse, has staged his own adaptation of the tale with a rhetorical fizz to match the pugnacity of the original. Dickens's dramatic enthusiasms are written into the pulse of his prose - we are reminded that the author's one-man rendition of his text was a tour de force of rhetorical theatre. This staging astutely disperses the authorial voice throughout the acting ensemble, rather than simply gutting the book for dialogue. It captures the simmering sense of a social tract dressed in the trappings of Yuletide celebration.

It is a suitably murky pea-souper of a production. David Collis's grim, portcullis-like design suggests the prisons and workhouses so approved of by Scrooge. And Stephen McNeff's fine, eclectic music keeps a large ensemble of muffler-clad actor-musicians milling around evocatively.

Through the middle of it all scuttles the spidery presence of Bob Goody's superlative Scrooge. Goody resists the temptation to ham up the part; indeed there is scarcely an ounce of flesh on his skeletal shanks. With his high-rise forehead and lank stringy hair, Goody never plays Scrooge explicitly for laughs but with the realisation that he must chart a clear moral course between misanthropy and munificence in what is a curiously godless unchristian tale.

Dickens taught us how to celebrate the modern Christmas, yet in doing so distanced it from its religious foundation. Do more people now believe in Marley's ghost than the virgin birth? As any good Dickensian agnostic would note: bah humbug.

 Until January 13. Box office: 0151-709 4776.

fields.trailText:
The Nutcracker
Coliseum
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Two years ago, the Royal Ballet's demon virtuoso, Tetsuya Kumakawa, deserted London in search of dizzier levels of superstardom in his native Japan. He formed a touring company, K Ballet, with a group of other disaffected Royal dancers, and is now apparently trailed everywhere by a besotted fan club. This Christmas, "Teddy" is back in London for the first time, dancing in The Nutcracker with another ex-Royal principal, Viviana Durante.

There may, perhaps, be a mischievous subtext to this visit, since they are guesting with English National Ballet, down the road from the Opera House, rather than with their alma mater. But fans of both dancers might have preferred to see them coming home in a more substantial piece.

In any Nutcracker production, the Sugar Plum Fairy and her prince are not on stage for long, but they are usually the emotional heart of the story - the magical role models of little Clara's dawning adult consciousness. In Derek Deane's staging, however, their dramatic focus is usurped by an especially vain and bossy Drosselmeyer (danced by Deane) who takes ostentatious control of the whole ballet, except for the fairy couple's final, grand pas de deux.

We thus get only a superficial viewing of the two stars, although, since Kumakawa has an even bigger stage ego than Dean, he is almost comically assiduous in his attempts to rout the latter from the limelight whenever possible. From the moment he appears, he makes every step as big, glossy and fast as possible, embroidering his jumps with a dazzle of aerial display and sending sparks from his careening pirouettes.

It's always fun to see dancing like this, but I missed the cocky devil that used to rattle around Kumakawa's performances. In the past he often seemed like a crazy kid pushing himself to the limits, even if it meant vandalising the show around him. Now there's something automatic, even detached, about his virtuosity. He looks as if he has become bored with himself and his audience, since his move to Japan.

Certainly his absence from the Royal has done nothing for his partnering skills, which are even sloppier than they used to be. This proved a liability for Durante, who appeared brittle with nerves. She can be an intensely dramatic dancer with a fine-spun lyricism but as the Sugar Plum Fairy she was barely able to sustain a smile and her jumpy, awkward phrasing seemed deaf to the music.

By far the most satisfying performance came from ENB's own Alice Crawford as Clara. Crawford may not be a star but her musically responsive, rounded dancing amplified the choreography to a scale surprisingly grander than her own tiny frame.

The ENB Orchestra, conducted by Anthony Twiner, also played better than I have heard in ages. Tchaikovsky, at least, came off well.

 Until January 6. Box office: 020-7632 8300.

fields.headline: The Hobbit
fields.standfirst:
Queen's Theatre
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Queen's Theatre
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
"Where are we?" cries one of the dwarves about an hour into this adaptation of JRR Tolkien's book. The urge to call out "Going round in circles" is almost irresistible.

Glyn Robbins's version of the tale of Bilbo Baggins, respectable hobbit burglar who gets mixed up with scruffy dwarfish types and helps them to steal back their treasure from a particularly stinky dragon, plods on to its conclusion like a faithful old dog. But unless you are Théâtre de Complicité and can conjure up rivers and bridges, misty mountains and murky woods without resorting to tons of hardware, this kind of epic quest is probably best left either to celluloid or to the imagination. The Queen's stage isn't big enough for it.

The cast spend a lot of time exiting the stage from one place and entering from another as if we might actually be fooled into believing that they have just marched for days from one dangerous place to another. I found it exhausting to watch, particularly when everybody forgot that they were supposed to keep quiet in case something nasty came out of the woods, and starting singing and dancing as if they were at a 1970s folk convention.

If you don't want to use your imagination, then this production certainly looks spooky enough, providing lots of dry ice and frondy things hanging all over the solid set. The array of goblins, trolls, wolves and other nasties - each with a more distressing skin condition than the last - is also pretty effective.

But the charm of Mr Baggins himself is never made evident, and when your dwarves are leather-clad and seem six-foot tall, and the elves are also strapping great fellows, you begin to realise what a testosterone-fuelled story this is. It is not even a sympathetic one: except for the odd skirmish with a troll and the ghoulish Gollum (Clive Kneller, very good my precious), this is by no means a conflict between good and evil. In the front stalls we all felt quite sorry for Smaug the dragon, whose only crime seems to be a penchant for theft and exceptionally bad breath. Thorin Oakenshield behaves just as despicably in refusing to share his sweets... sorry, I mean treasure.

Of course, that's why the story needs Gandalf as a God substitute, wandering around like a patient kindergarten teacher restoring order and calming down all the little boys - sorry dwarves - who are rushing around trying to bash each other. At the end everyone gets slapped on the wrists by Gandalf and has another little dance.

By trying to turn Tolkien's little story into a big theatre spectacular, this production just makes it - and itself - look silly.

 Until January 13. Box office: 020-7494 5040. Then tours until summer.

fields.headline: LSO/Hickox/Vogt
fields.standfirst:
Barbican Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Barbican Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
With A Stirring in the Heavenlies, Andrew March has written for the huge forces of the full-strength LSO with confidence. Seeking to evoke planetary movement and the music of the spheres, he has deployed bold musical gestures, thickly scored.

Unison melodies for the string section showed a Romantic expansiveness, while the movement of all five horns raising their bells to play fortissimo seemed almost choreographed. Resting on a soft bed of string sound, the opening flute solo dissolved into a flurry of overblown notes that anticipated the scurrying string lines tapering away at the close, 15 minutes or so later.

In between, March's priority seemed to be to create beautiful swathes of sound - it is no surprise to find that he lists Debussy among his influences. With A Stirring in the Heavenlies he is travelling towards a more individual, mature style, but he still needs to find more of an edge; the title suggests something momentous or threatening, but the former didn't quite happen and the latter seemed a light-year away.

This was a rather disjointed programme, though Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto, which followed March's work, still stands up well alongside contemporary scores. An awkward style of bowing dictated to the violins smudged the impact of some of the punchier passages, however, and we had to wait until the final movement for some really crisp string playing. Soloist Lars Vogt played a little clinically at times, but made much of the work's more dramatic corners, throwing out phrases to the orchestra as if in challenge.

The LSO seemed more comfortable playing Vaughan Williams's London Symphony. This is a bright, colourful score, and while the second movement breathed nostalgia, the fourth evoked a monstrous grandeur, conductor Richard Hickox building up the climaxes for all they were worth.

fields.headline: Bonus brothers win multimillion payout
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Two Moroccan-born brothers at rival City banks have emerged among the winners in this year's round of multimillion-pound bonus payments after oiling the wheels of some of Europe's biggest deals in an unprecedented year for corporate transactions.
fields.body:
Two Moroccan-born brothers at rival City banks have emerged among the winners in this year's round of multimillion-pound bonus payments after oiling the wheels of some of Europe's biggest deals in an unprecedented year for corporate transactions.

Yoel Zaoui is head of European mergers and acquisitions at Goldman Sachs while his brother Michael holds the equivalent position at Morgan Stanley.

Reports yesterday suggested both were in line for performance payouts of more than £20m. Insiders insisted these figures were "greatly exaggerated" - although there was little doubt that the two were among the banking industry's top earners.

Yoel is the younger by four years. He is described by colleagues as "a very charming guy - very professional, very good at what he does".

Like his brother, he was born in Morocco and lived in Rome before going to school in Paris. Both are French nationals and they often holiday together, with their families, on the Côte d'Azur.

The two have reaped the rewards of a series of mega-mergers - both headed teams which advised on Glaxo Wellcome's £120bn tie-up with SmithKline Beecham.

Yoel's department worked on Unilever's purchase of Bestfoods and Royal Bank of Scotland's takeover of NatWest, while Michael Zaoui's dealmakers helped put Orange together with France Telecom.

webTitle: MPC's two dissenters lower odds for early rate cut in new year

fields.headline: MPC's two dissenters lower odds for early rate cut in new year
fields.trailText: The City reduced the odds yesterday on a cut in UK interest rates in the new year after the Bank of England revealed that two members of its monetary policy committee are urging cheaper borrowing.
fields.body:
The City reduced the odds yesterday on a cut in UK interest rates in the new year after the Bank of England revealed that two members of its monetary policy committee are urging cheaper borrowing.

Minutes of the meeting of the nine-strong committee this month show that DeAnne Julius and Sushil Wadhwani called for a quarter-point reduction in base rates to 5.75% to fend off the impact of a pronounced slowdown in the global economy.

Although the two were outvoted 7-2, signs that the Bank is becoming concerned at the prospects of weaker demand prompted hopes of the first cut in rates since summer 1999.

The cost of borrowing has been on hold at 6% since February but, with inflation below its 2.5% target and fears of recession growing in the US, any lingering pressure for higher rates has now disappeared.

According to the minutes, Ms Julius and Mr Wadhwani argued that the "sharper than expected slowing in world demand" would lower activity in the UK, pushing down inflation. Although sterling had fallen on the foreign exchanges, any increase in domestic prices caused by dearer imports would be offset by cheaper oil and the shake-out in global stock markets.

However, the majority of the committee preferred to wait and see, noting that consumption remained strong, household borrowing was rising strongly and there were indications of a rekindling of house-price inflation.

 Separate figures published yesterday showed Britain's public finances swung back into deficit in November after a hefty surplus the month before. National Statistics reported a public sector net cash requirement of £2.31bn in November, after a surplus of £7.32bn the month before.

fields.headline: Schumann in great voices
fields.standfirst:
Röschmann/Goerne/Johnson
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Röschmann/Goerne/Johnson
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
If any work gives the lie to the assumption - still voiced in certain quarters - that Schumann was primarily a Romantic drip who composed exquisite miniatures, then it is surely his colossal song cycle Myrthen, written in 1840.

In many respects, it's a starkly modern piece, confounding expectations and straying into territory that still seems avant garde. Most of its 25 songs, the settings of a phantasmagorical jumble of writers, are short but push towards aphoristic terseness rather than miniaturistic delicacy. There's no attempt at a linear narrative and the cycle depends for its effect on patterns of jolting emotional contrasts.

The subject matter is frequently violent, sometimes darkly sexual, culminating in a weird song about sibling incest. It takes in such themes as a mother encouraging her son to a life of pillage and plunder, a bloke fancying the waiter who brings him his wine, and various vignettes dealing with soul-shattering existential isolation.

Complete performances are rare, largely, one suspects, because few singers seem willing to tackle its repetitive swivelling between genders. The Wigmore got round this by splitting the songs between two performers, Dorothea Röschmann and Matthias Goerne, both great, if radically different artists. Goerne - his head brutally shaved and looking more than ever like Erich von Stroheim - emotes with expressionistic wildness, hurling himself round the platform and raking the air with talon-like hands. Röschmann is essentially non-interventionist, singing with meditative stillness and frequently letting the sheer beauty of her golden soprano speak for itself.

The contrast between them highlights the cycle's extreme range of feeling, while Graham Johnson's playing, alert to every shift in mood, is second to none. Just occasionally, however, the momentum slips during the pauses that allow the singers to reposition themselves on the platform.

Before the interval, each of them gets a shorter song cycle apiece, with Goerne tackling the Heine Liederkreis and Röschmann singing Frauenliebe und Leben. Neither work is deemed politically correct nowadays, and both are open to charges of sexism. In the case of the Heine Liederkreis, things are more ambivalent. Its theme is frequently described as "love and loss": in fact, it portrays a man's descent into misogyny after his beloved has scarpered. Goerne delivers it with such vitriolic force and explosive anger that you gradually become aware why the woman has absented herself.

The controversial Frauenliebe und Leben depicts a woman defining her life in constant reference to the man she adores. Röschmann wisely avoids trying to give it a feminist gloss, and plays it straight, filling the hall with a glorious stream of sensual tone, until she gets to the end, when grief-stricken, declamatory rage takes over as she contemplates her husband's death.

Few singers these days can hold an audience captive with the work. Röschmann manages it in spades.

webTitle: Eight to resign in Equitable fallout

fields.headline: Eight to resign in Equitable fallout
fields.standfirst:
MPs to question directors after debacle

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: MPs to question directors after debacle
fields.body:
The president and seven non-executive directors of insurer Equitable Life are to resign en masse following fierce criticism of the company's actions from policyholders and MPs.

The directors quitting include Jennie Page, the former chief executive of the Millennium Dome, who resigned from that position in February, and several senior City figures.

Yesterday's announcement came as it emerged that the company's directors, City regulators and others who have played a role in the crisis look set to go before a parliamentary committee of MPs.

In a statement the company said the directors had decided the board should be "restructured," and the eight current non-executive directors, including John Sclater, the president, would all step down once suitable replacements had been found.

Their departures follow the resignation on December 8 of Alan Nash, Equitable's chief executive, who was replaced by Chris Headdon, the former finance director. Mr Headdon is unaffected by yesterday's moves, as is the only other executive director, head of investment David Thomas.

An Equitable spokesman said the changes came as a result of "listening to what policyholders have said". Those directors leaving in addition to Mr Sclater and Ms Page include Peter Davis, former director general of the National Lottery, and vice-president Peter Sedgwick, deputy chairman of Schroders. None of the directors will receive pay-offs.

Equitable, the world's oldest mutual life insurer, closed its doors to new business two weeks ago and warned existing policyholders that they will face lower investment returns in future after it lost a £1.5bn legal battle in July involving so-called guaranteed annuities, sold as part of pension plans until 1988.

The company opened the way for applications for the vacant posts from policyholder representatives when it said it was "seeking new directors...who reflect the concerns of members".

The new appointments will need to be made by the spring to give time for the directors to be in place before the society's annual meeting in May.

Responding to the announcement, Equitable policyholder David Hyman, 70, said: "They probably should have resigned en masse after the [July] verdict."

Giles Radice, chairman of the Commons Treasury select committee, said he would be recommending that the committee holds hearings on the Equitable issue.

The move came 24 hours after the government said the financial services authority would be investigating its handling of the debacle since it took over responsibility for policing insurers in January 1999.

That announcement was criticised by policyholders and some MPs, who said a wider investigation was needed.

"It is right [the FSA] should look into it...but it probably needs to go wider than that," said Mr Radice. The committee would probably want to produce a report containing its findings, he added.

fields.headline: CBSO/Oramo
fields.standfirst:
Symphony Hall
Birmingham
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Symphony Hall
Birmingham
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Next month the 33-year-old Julian Anderson follows in the footsteps of Mark-Anthony Turnage and Judith Weir as the City of Birmingham Symphony's third composer-in-association. He will work with the orchestra for three years, writing pieces for them, for their sibling chorus and for the Birmingham Contemporary Music Group. The knowledgeable and faithful Symphony Hall audience had a taste of what to expect when Sakari Oramo began his CBSO programme by conducting one of Anderson's most attractive and successful orchestral works, The Stations of the Sun, which he wrote to a commission for the 1998 Proms.

Loosely based on the rotation of the seasons, the score shows off the full range of Anderson's gifts - as an expert orchestrator with a sharp ear for colour and texture, as an inventor of memorable melodic ideas, and as a lucid organiser of musical structure. All this makes the progress of this 17-minute piece easy to track. The sections flow seamlessly into one another, the emotional heart of the work is exactly sited in a long-limbed melody that wells up in the brass at its mid point, and the pulling together of all the harmonic threads in the coda is totally satisfying.

Oramo's performance was first-rate - vivid and carefully detailed, with a real dramatic sweep - but he remains a perplexing conductor. Though Tchaikovsky's Fourth Symphony, which took up the second half of the programme, has an extrovert grandeur that suits his propulsive approach, Mozart's C major Piano Concerto K467, which followed The Stations of the Sun, certainly does not.

Alexei Lubimov's account of the solo part may have been rather eccentric, full of self-conscious ornamentation and stiff-fingered emphases, but the accompaniment the CBSO provided was wretched, sloppy in both articulation and tuning. Oramo seems to know only two ways of tackling a Mozartian phrase, either in jagged sforzandos or slithery, shapeless legato. Neither is remotely convincing.

fields.headline: Nationwide will allow vote
fields.standfirst:
Building society squares up for mutuality debate

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Building society squares up for mutuality debate
fields.body:
The stage is set for a fresh demutualisation showdown next year after Nationwide, Britain's biggest building society, said yesterday it would allow members to vote on conversion at its annual meeting in July if it receives a valid resolution.

Nationwide is firmly committed to remaining member-owned but expects a conversion proposal to be put forward in the next few months and says it has "never shirked the mutuality debate".

Provided a resolution backed by sufficient eligible members is received, the society's 10m saver and borrower members will be able to vote on whether the society should stay a mutual or convert to a bank - and pay windfalls which some commentators have claimed could average £1,000.

Nationwide is immune from another conversion vote until next year after narrowly defeating a demutualisation campaign mounted by butler Michael Hardern in 1998.

Society member Andrew Muir - who stood unsuccessfully for election to the board on a windfall ticket two years ago - announced in the summer that he would be undertaking another conversion campaign for 2001. Stephen Major, a plumber who led the successful attack on Bradford & Bingley, said two weeks ago he had more than the 250 signatures he needs to stand for election to the board at the July annual meeting.

A Nationwide spokesman said that under its rules it need not accept another conversion resolution until after the annual meeting.

However, by accepting a conversion vote at the meeting, the board feels it can avoid the "uncertainty, cost and disruption" that would be caused by holding a special meeting later in the year.
